sense.s: The first letter of the alphabet [according to the order in which the letters are now commonly disposed; and also according to the original order, which see in art. Abjd]: called OalifN. [This name, like most of the other names of Arabic letters, is traceable to the Phœnician language, in which it signifies “an ox;” the ancient Phœnician form of the letter thus called being a rude representation of an ox's head.] It is, of all the letters, that which is most frequent in speech: and some say that, in MlLmL, in the Kur [ch. ii. &c.], it is a name of God. (TA.) Its name is properly fem., as is also that of every other letter; [and hence its pl. is OalifaAtN;] but it may be made masc.: so says Ks: Sb says that all the letters of the alphabet are masc. and fem., like as AlRisaAnN is masc. and fem. (M.) As a letter of the alphabet, it is abbreviated, [or short, and is written A, as it also is generally when occurring in a word, except at the end, when, in certain cases, it is written I,] and is pronounced with a pause after it: and it is also prolonged: (S, K, * TA:) [in the latter case, it is written MCN; and] this is the case when it is made a subst.: and when it is not called a letter, [i. e. when one does not prefix to it the word Harof,] it is [properly] fem. (S.) Its dim. is OuyayRapN, meaning an AC written small, or obscure, (S, IB,) according to those who make it fem. and who say, zayRayatu zaAyFA and cayRalotu caAlFA; but OuwayRapN according to those who say, zawRayotu zaAyFA. (IB.)

OalifN [properly so called] is one of the letters of prolongation and of softness and of augmentation; the letters of augmentation being ten, which are comprised in the saying, Alyawoma tanosaAhu [“to-day thou wilt forget it”]. (S.) There are two species of Alf; namely, layRinapN [or soft], and mutaHarRikapN [or movent]; the former of which is [properly] called OalifN; and the latter, hamozapN; (S, TA;) which is a faucial letter, pronounced in the furthest part of the fauces [by a sudden emission of the voice after a total suppression, so that it resembles in sound a feebly-uttered E whence the form of the character (C) whereby it is represented]: but this latter is sometimes tropically called Alf; and both [as shown above] are of the letters of augmentation. (S in art. Aw, and TA.) There are also two other species of Alf; namely, Oalifu waSolK [the alif of conjunction or connexion, or the conjunctive or connexive alif]; and Oalifu qaToEK [the alif of disjunction, or the disjunctive alif]; every one that is permanent in the connexion of words being of the latter species; and that which is not permanent, [i. e. which is not pronounced, unless it is an alif of prolongation,] of the former species; and this is without exception augmentative; [but it is sometimes a substitute for a suppressed radical letter, as in QbonN, originally banaIN or banawN;] whereas the alif of disjunction is sometimes augmentative, as in the case of the interrogative alif [to be mentioned below, and in other cases]; and sometimes radical, as in Oaxaca and Oamara: (S, TA:) or, according to Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà and Mohammad Ibn-Yezeed, (T, TA,) the primary OalifaAt are three; the rest being subordinate to these: namely, OalifN OaSoliyRapN [radical alif], (T, K, TA,) as in UilofN and Oakala (T) and Oaxaca; (K;) and OalifN qaToEiyapN [disjunctive alif], as in OaHomadu (T, K) and OaHomaru (T) and OaHosana; (T, K;) and OalifN waSoliyRapN [conjunctive or connexive alif], (T, K,) as in QsotaxoraAjN (T) and Qsotaxoraja. (T, K.)

The Oalif which is one of the letters of prolongation and of softness is called AlOalifu AlhaAdiYapu [the quiescent alif, and AlOalifu AlsRaAkinapu, which signifies the same]: (MF, TA:) it is an aerial letter, (Mughnee, MF, TA,) merely a sound of prolongation after a fet-hah; (T, TA;) and cannot have a vowel, (IB, Mughnee, MF,) wherefore it cannot commence a word: (Mughnee:) when they desire to make it movent, if it is converted from w or I, they restore it to its original, as in EaSawaAni and raHayaAni; and if it is not converted from w or I, they substitute for it hemzeh, as in rasaAYilu, in which the hemzeh is a substitute for the A in [the sing.] rasaAlapN. (IB.) IJ holds that the name of this letter is laA, [pronounced lá or lé, without, or with, imáleh, like the similar names of other letters, as baA and tA and vaA &c.,] and that it is the letter which is mentioned [next] before I in reckoning the letters; the l being prefixed to it because it cannot be pronounced at the beginning of its name, as other letters can, as, for instance, S and j; and he adds that the teachers [in schools] err in pronouncing its name laAma Qlifo. (Mughnee.)
The grammarians have other particular appellations for alifs, which will be here mentioned. (T, TA.)

AlOalifu Almajohuwlapu [The unknown alif] is such as that in faAEilN [or faAEala] and faAEuwlN; i. e., every A, (T, K,) of those having no original [from which they are converted, not being originally O nor w nor I, but being merely a formative letter, and hence, app., termed “unknown”], (T,) inserted for the purpose of giving fulness of sound to the fet-hah in a verb and in a noun; (T, K;) and this, when it becomes movent, becomes w, as in the case of xaAtamN and xawaAtimu, becoming w in this case because it is movent, and followed by a quiescent A, which A is the A of the pl., and is also mjhwlp. (T.)

OalifaAtu AlmadRaAti [The alifs of prolongations] are such as those [which are inserted for the same purpose of giving fulness of sound to the fet-hah] in kalokaAlN, for kalokalN, and xaAtaAmN, for xaAtamN, and daAnaAqN, for daAnaqN. (T, K.) In like manner, w is inserted after a dammeh, as in OanoZuwru; and I after a kesreh, as in XiymaAlN. (TA.) An alif of this species is also called Oalifu AlUiXobaAEi [The alif added to give fulness of sound to a fet-hah preceding it]: and so is the alif in manaA used in imitation [of a noun in the accus. case; as when one says, raOayotu rajulFA (pronounced rajulaA) “I saw a man,” and the person to whom these words are addressed says, manaA Whom?]. (Mughnee.)
Oalifu AlSRilapi [The alif of annexation, or the annexed alif,] is that which is an annex to the fet-hah of a rhyme, (T, K,) and to that of the fem. pronoun haA: in the former case as in

in which A is made an annex to the fet-hah of the E [of the rhyme]; and in the saying in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], wataZunRuwna biQllRehi AlZRunuwnaA, in which the A after the last n is an annex to the fet-hah of that n; and in other instances in the final words of verses of the Kur-án, as qawaAriyra and salosabiylaA [in lxxvi. 15 and 18]: in the other case as in DarabotuhaA and mararotu bihaA. (T.) The difference between it and Oalifu AlwaSoli is, that the latter is in the beginnings of nouns and verbs, and the former is in the endings of nouns [and verbs]. (T, K.) It is also called Oalifu AlUiTolaAqi [The alif of unbinding, because the vowel ending a rhyme prevents its being muqayRd, i. e. “bound” by the preceding consonant]: (Mughnee;) and Oalifu AlfaASilapi [the alif of the final word of a verse of poetry or of a verse of the Kur-án or of a clause of rhyming prose]. (TA.) [This last appellation must not be confounded with that which here next follows.]

AlOalifu AlfaASilapi [The separating alif] is the A which is written after the w of the pl. to make a separation between that w and what follows it, as in XakaruwA (T, K) and kafaruwA, and in the like of yagozuwA and yadoEuwA [and yaroDawoA]; but when a pronoun is affixed to the verb, this A, being needless, does not remain: (T:) also the A which makes a separation between the n which is a sign of the fem. gender and the heavy [or doubled] n [in the corroborated form of the aor. and imperative], (T, K,) because a triple combination of n is disliked, (T,) as in [yafoEalonaAnRi and tafoEalonaAnRi and] AifoEalonaAnRi (T, K) and laA tafoEalonaAnRi. (T.)

Oalifu AlnRuwni Alxafiyfapi [The alif of the light, or single, noon in the contracted corroborated form of the aor. and imperative], as in the phrase in the Kur [xcvi. 15], lanasofaEFA biAlnRaASiyapi [explained in art. sfE], (T, K,) and the phrase [in xii. 32], walayakuwnFA mina AlSRaAgiriyna [And he shall assuredly be of those in a state of vileness, or ignominy], in both of which instances the pause is made with A [only, without tenween, so that one says lanasofaEaA and layakuwnaA, and this seems to be indicated in Expositions of the Kur-án as the proper pronunciation of these two words in the phrases here cited, the former of which, and the first word of the latter,
I find thus written in an excellent copy of the Mughnee, with a fet-hah only instead of tenween, though I find them written in copies of the Kur-án and of the K with tenween, and for this reason only I have written them therewith in the first places above], this A being a substitute for the light n, which is originally the heavy n: and among examples of the same is the saying of El-Aashà,
[And praise not thou the opulent, but God do thou praise], the poet meaning faQHomadano, but pausing with an A: (T:) and accord. to 'Ikrimeh Ed-Dabbee, in the saying of Imra-el-Keys,

L.foreign: qafaA naboki mino cikary HabiybK wamanozili

sense.s: [what is meant is, Do thou pause that we may weep by reason of the remembrance of an object of love, and of a place of abode, for] the poet means qifano, but substitutes A for the light n; (TA;) or, accord. to some, qfA is in this case [a dual] addressed to the poet's two companions. (EM p. 4.)

Oalifu AlEiwaDi [The alif of exchange] is that which is substituted for the tenween (T, K) of the accus. case when one pauses upon it, (T,) as in raOayotu zayodaA (T, K [and so in the copy of the Mughnee mentioned above, but in the copies of the T I find zayodFA,]) and faEalotu xayoraA and the like. (T.)

Oalifu AltRaEaAyiI [The alif of inability to express what one desires to say], (T,) or Oalifa AltagaAbiI [the alif of feigning negligence or heedlessness], (K,) [but the former is evidently, in my opinion, the right appellation,] is that which is added when one says UinRa Eumara, and then, being unable to finish his saying, pauses, saying UinRa EumaraA, [in the CK EumaraM,] prolonging it, desiring to be helped to the speech that should reveal itself to him, (T, K,) and at length saying munoTaliqN, meaning to say, if he were not unable to express it, UinRa Eumara munoTilaqN [Verily 'Omar is going away]. (T.) The A in a case of this kind is [also] said to be liltRacakRuri [for the purpose of endeavouring to remember]; and in like manner, w, when one desires to say, yaquwmu zayodN, and, forgetting zyd, prolongs the sound in endeavouring to remember, and says yaquwmuw. (Mughnee in the sections on A and w.) It is also added to a curtailed proper name of a person called to, or hailed, as in yaA EumaA for yaA Eumaru [which is an ex. contrary to rule, as Eumaru is masc. and consists of only three letters]. (T.)

Oalifu AlnRudobapi [The alif of lamentation], as in waA zayodaAho [Alas, Zeyd!], (T, K,) i. e. the A after the d; (T;) and one may say waA zayodaA, without the h of pausation. (Alfeeyeh of Ibn-Málik, and I 'Ak p. 272.)

Oalifu AlQisotinokaAri [The alif of disapproval], (T,) or AlOalifu liloUinokaAri [which means the same], (Mughnee,) is similar to that next preceding, as in OaOabuw EumaraAhR [What! Aboo- 'Omar?] in reply to one who says, “Aboo-'Omar came;” the h being added in this case after the letter of prolongation like as it is in waA fulaAnaAho said in lamentation. (T.) [The ex. given in the Mughnee is M EamoraAho, as said in reply to one who says, “I met 'Amr;” and thus I find it written, with M; but this is a mistranscription of the interrogative Oa, which see below.] In this case it is only added to give fulness of sound to the vowel; for you say, OalrRajuluwho [What! the man? for OaQlrRajuluwho,] after one has said “The man stood;” and OalrRajulaAho in the accus. case; and OalrRajuliyho in the gen. case. (Mughnee in the section on w. [But in my copy of that work, in these instances, the incipient A, which is an A of interrogation, is written M.])

AlOalifu Almunoqalibapu Eano yaMCi AlUiDaAfapi [The alif that is converted from the affixed pronoun I], as in yaA gulaAmaA Oaqobilo [O my boy, advance thou,] for yaA gulaAmiI; (TA in art. Hrz;) [and yaAEajabaA lizayodK (I 'Ak p. 271) O my wonder at Zeyd! for yA EajabiI lzyd;] and in yaA OabataA for yaA OabatiI, and yaA wayolataA for yaA wayolatiI, and yaAbiOabaA and yaA biOabaAho for yaA biOabiI (T and TA in art. bO.) [This is sometimes written I, but preceded by a fet-hah.]

AlOalifu AlmuHawRalapu [The transmuted alif, in some copies of the K Oalifu AlmuHawRalapi, which, as MF observes, is put for the former,] is every A that is originally w or I (T, K) movent, (T,) as in qaAla [originally qawala], and baAEa [originally bayaEa], (T, K,) and gazaA [originally gazawa], and qaDaI [originally qaDaI], and the like of these. (T.)

Oalifu Altavoniyapi [The alif of the dual, or rather, of dualization], (T, K,) in verbs, (TA,) as in yajolisaAni and yacohabaAni, (T, K,) and in nouns, (T,) as in AlzRayodaAni (T, K) and AlEamoraAni; (T;) [i. e.] the A which in verbs is a dual pronoun, as in faEalaA and yafuEalaAni, and in nouns a sign of the dual and an indication of the nom. case, as in rajulaAni. (S.)
It is also indicative of the accus. case, as in raOayotu faAhu [I saw his mouth]. (S.)
Oalifu AljamoEi [The alif of the plural, or of pluralization], as in masaAjidu and jibaAlN (T, K) and furosaAnN and fawaAEilu. (T.)

Oalifu AltRaOoniyvi [The alif denoting the fem. gender], as in HubolaI (Mughnee, K) and sakoraI [in which it is termed maqoSuwrap shortened], and the meddeh in HamoraMCu (K) and bayoDaMCu and nufasaMCu [in which it is termed mamoduwdap lengthened]. (TA.)

Oalifu AlUiloHaAqi [The alif of adjunction, or quasi-coordination; that which renders a word an adjunct to a particular class, i. e. quasi-coordinate to another word, of which the radical letters are more in number than those of the former word, (see the sentence next following,)], (Mughnee, TA,) as in OaroTFA (Mughnee) [or OaroTFI; and the meddeh in EilobaMCN &c.].

Oalifu Altakoviyri [The alif of multiplication, i. e. that merely augments the number of the letters of a word without making it either fem. or quasi-coordinate to another, unaugmented, word], as in qabaEovaraI (Mughnee, TA) [correctly qabaEovarFI], in which the A [here written I] is not to denote the fem. gender, (S and K in art. qbEvr,) because its fem. is qabaEovaraApN, as Mbr. says; (S and TA in that art.;) nor to render it quasi-coordinate to another word, (K and TA in that art.,) as is said in the Lubáb, because there is no noun of six radical letters to which it can be made to be so; but accord. to Ibn-Málik, a word is sometimes made quasi-coordinate to one comprising augmentative letters, as AiqoEanosasa is to AiHoranojama. (TA in that art.)

OalifaAtu AlwaSoli [The alifs of conjunction or connexion, or the conjunctive or connexive alifs], (T, K,) which are in the beginnings of nouns, (T,) [as well as in certain well-known cases in verbs,] occur in QbonN (T, K) and QbonumN (K) and QbonapN and QvonaAni and QvonataAni and QmoruWN and QmoraOapN and QsomN and QsotN, (T, K,) which have a kesreh to the A when they commence a sentence, [or occur alone, i. e., when immediately preceded by a quiescence,] but it is elided when they are connected with a preceding word, (T,) [by which term “word” is included a particle consisting of a single letter with its vowel,] and QyomunN and Qyomu [and variations thereof, which have either a fet-hah or a kesreh to the A when they commence a sentence, or occur alone], (K,) and in the article Qlo, the A of which has a fet-hah when it commences a sentence. (T.)

Oalifu AlqaToEi [The alif of disjunction, or the disjunctive alif,] is in the beginnings of sing. nouns and of pl. nouns: it may be known by its permanence in the dim., and by its not being a radical letter: thus it occurs in OaHosanu, of which the dim. is OuHayosinu: (I Amb, T:) in pls. it occurs in OalowaAnN and OazowaAjN (I Amb, T, K) and OalosinapN [&c.]: (I Amb, T:) [it also occurs in verbs of the measure OafoEala, as Oakorama; in which cases it is sometimes lilsRalobi, i. e. privative, (like the Greek alpha,) as in OaqosaTa “he did away with injustice,” which is termed qusuwTN and qasoTN, inf. ns. of qasaTa:] it is distinguished from the radical A, as shown above: (I Amb, T:) or it is sometimes augmentative, as the interrogative Oa [to be mentioned below]; and sometimes radical, as in Oaxaca and Oamara; and is thus distinguished from the conjunctive A, which is never other than augmentative. (S.)

Oalifu AltRafoDiyli wa AltRaqoSiyri [The alif denoting excess and deficiency, i. e., denoting the comparative and superlative degrees], as in fulaAnN Oakoramu minoka [Such a one is more generous, or noble, than thou], (T, K, *) and OaloOamu minoka [more ungenerous, or ignoble, than thou], (T,) and Oajohalu AlnRaAsi [the most ignorant of men]. (T, K. *)

Oalifu AlEibaArapi [The alif of signification], (T, K,) as though, (T,) or because, (TA,) significant of the speaker, (T, TA,) also called AlEaAmilapi [the operative], as in OanaA Oasotagofiru QllReha [I beg forgiveness of God], (T, K,) and OanaA OafoEalu kacaA [I do thus]. (T.)

Oalifu AlQisotifohaAmi [The alif of interrogation, or the interrogative alif], (T, S, Msb in art. hmz, Mughnee,) as in OazayodN qaAYimN [Is Zeyd standing?], (Mughnee,) and OazayodN Einodaka Oamo EamorNw [Is Zeyd with thee, or at thine abode, or 'Amr?], (S,) and OaqaAma zayodN [Did Zeyd stand?], said when the asker is in ignorance, and to which the answer is laA or naEamo; (Msb;) and in a negative phrase, as Oalamo naXoraHo [Did we not dilate, or enlarge? in the Kur xciv. 1]. (Mughnee.)
When this is followed by another hemzeh, an A is interposed between the two hemzehs, [so that you say OaAOanota, also written MOanota,] as in the saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,

L.foreign: wabayona AlnRaqaA OaAOanoti Oamo OumRu saAlimi

sense.s: [O thou doe-gazelle of El-Waasà between Jelájil and the oblong gibbous hill of sand, is it thou, or Umm-Sálim?]; (T, S;) but some do not this. (T.) [It is often conjoined with UinRa, as in the Kur xii. 90, OaYinRaka laOanota yuwsufu Art thou indeed Joseph?] It is sometimes used to make a person acknowledge, or confess, a thing, (T, Msb in art. hmz, Mughnee,) and to establish it, (Msb,) as in the phrase in the Kur [v. 116], OaOanota qulota lilnRaAsi or MOanota [Didst thou say to men?], (T,) and Oalamo naXoraHo [explained above], (Msb in art. hmz,] and in OaDarabota zayodFA or OaOanota Darabota [Didst thou beat Zeyd?], and OazayodFA Darabota [Zeyd didst thou beat?]. (Mughnee.) And for reproving, (T, Mughnee,) as in the phrase in the Kur [xxxvii. 153], OSoTafaI QlobanaAti EalaI Qlobaniyna [Hath He chosen daughters in preference to sons?], (T,) [but see the next sentence,] and [in the same ch., verse 93,] OataEobuduwna maA tanoHituwna [Do ye worship what ye hew out?]. (Mughnee.) And to express a nullifying denial, as in [the words of the Kur xvii. 42,] OafaOaSofaAkumo rabRakumo biQlobaniyna waQtRaxaca mina QlomalaAYikapi UinaAvFA [Hath then your Lord preferred to give unto you sons, and gotten for himself, of the angels, daughters?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote irony, as in [the Kur xi. 89,] OaSalawaAtuka taOomuruka Oano natoruka maA yaEobudu MbaAWunaA [Do thy prayers enjoin thee that we should leave what our fathers worshipped?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote wonder, as in [the Kur xxv.47,] Oalamo tara UilaI rabRika kayofa madRa QlZRilRa [Hast thou not considered the work of thy Lord, how He hath extended the shade?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote the deeming a thing slow, or tardy, as in [the Kur lvii., 15,] Oalamo yaOoni lilRciyna MmanuwA [Hath not the time yet come for those who have believed?]. (Mughnee.) And to denote a command, as in [the Kur iii. 19,] OaOasolamotumo, meaning OasolimuwA [Enter ye into the religion of El-Islám]. (Mughnee, and so Jel.) And to denote equality, occurring after sawaMCN and maA OubaAliI and maA OadoriI and layota XiEoriI, and the like, as in [the Kur lxiii.6,] sawaMCN Ealayohimo Oasotagofarota lahumo Oamo lamo tasotagofiro lahumo [It will be equal to them whether thou beg forgiveness for them or do not beg forgiveness for them], and in ,aA OubaAliI Oaqumota Oamo qaEadota [I care not whether thou stand or sit]: and the general rule is this, that it is the hemzeh advening to a phrase, or proposition, of which the place may be supplied by the inf. n. of its verb; for one may say, sawaMCN Ealayohimu QlQisotigofaAru waEadamuhu [Equal to them will be the begging of forgiveness and the not doing so], and maA OabaAliI biqiyaAmika waEadamihi [I care not for thy standing and thy not doing so]: (Mughnee.)

Oalifu AlnRidaMCi [The alif of calling, or vocative alif], (T, S,* Mughnee,* K,) as in Oazayodu, meaning yaA zayodu [O Zeyd], (T, K,) and in Oazayodu Oaqobilo [O Zeyd, advance], (S,) used in calling him who is near, (S, Mughnee,) to the exclusion of him who is distant, because it is abbreviated. (S.) M with medd, is a particle used in calling to him who is distant, (Mughnee, K,) as in Mazayodu Oaqobilo [Ho there, or soho, or holla, Zeyd, advance]. (TA.) Az says, You say to a man, in calling him, MfulaAnu and OafulaAnu and MyaA fulaAnu (TA) or OayaA. (S and K in art. AyA.)
UiQllRehi, for UiIo waQllRehi: see UiI.

In a dial. of some of the Arabs, hemzeh is used in a case of pausing at the end of a verb, as in their saying to a woman, quwliYo [Say thou], and to two men, quwlaOo [Say ye two], and to a pl. number, quwluWo [Say ye]; but not when the verb is connected with a word following it: and they say also laOo, with a hemzeh, [for laA,] in a case of pausation. (T.) But Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà says, All men say that when a hemzeh occurs at the end of a word, [i. e. in a case of pausation,] and has a quiescent letter before it, it is elided in the nom. and gen. case, though retained in the accus. case [because followed by a quiescent A], except Ks alone, who retains it in all cases: when it occurs in the middle of a word, all agree that it should not be dropped. (T.) AZ [however] says that the people of El-Hijáz, and Hudheyl, and the people of Mekkeh and ElMedeeneh, do not pronounce hemzeh [at all]: and 'Eesà Ibn-’Omar says, Temeem pronounce hemzeh, and the people of El-Hijáz, in cases of necessity, [in poetry,] do so. (T.)
Ks cites, [as exhibiting two instances of a rare usage of OaA, or M, in a case of pausing, in the place of a suppressed word,]

L.foreign: Alxayoru xayoraAni wa Uino XarRN faOaA
walaA Ouriydu AlXRarRa UilRaA Oano taOaA

sense.s: [written without the syll. signs in the MS. from which I transcribe this citation, but the reading seems to be plain, and the meaning, Such a one supplicated his Lord, and made his words to be heard, saying, Good is double good; and if evil be my lot, then evil; but I desire not evil unless Thou will that it should befall me]: and he says, he means, UilRaA Oano taXaMCa; this being of the dial. of Benoo-Saad, except that it is [with them] taA, with a soft A [only]: also, in replying to a person who says, “Wilt thou not come?” one says, faOo, meaning faQcohabo [Then go thou with us]: and in like manner, by fOA, in the saying above, is meant faXRarRN. (TA.)
Hemzeh also sometimes occurs as a verb; Uih, i. e.! with the Ui of pausation added, being the imperative of waOaI as syn. with waEada. (Mughnee.)
[As a numeral, 1 denotes One.]

1. OabRa, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
Aabiba
, (M, K,) agreeably with analogy in the case of an intrans. verb of this class, (TA,) and
Aabuba
, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) contr. to analogy, (TA,) inf. n. OabRN (T, S, M, K) and OabiybN (M, K) and OabaAbN and OabaAbapN (S, M, K) and UibaAbapN; (M;) and QYotabRa↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytabRa]; (T, K;) He prepared himself, (AZ, S, M, A, K,) and equipped himself, (AZ, S, A,) for (li) departing, or going away, (AZ, S,) or for journeying: (M, A, K:) or he determined upon journeying, and prepared himself. (T.) El-Aashà says,

L.foreign: OaxN qado TawaI kaXoHFA waOabRa liyacohabaA

sense.s: (T, S, M, TA,) i. e. I cut [in effect, while I did not really cut] you: for like one who cuts is a brother who has determined and prepared to go away. (TA.) [Hence,] laA EabaAba wa laA OabaAba, [or lA EabaAbi wlA OabaAbi,] a prov. [which see explained in art. Eb]. (TA.) [And hence the saying,] huwa fiI OabaAbihi, (S, M, K,) and OabaAbatihi, and UibaAbatihi, (M,) He is in his [state of, or he is engaged in his,] preparation or equipment [for departing or journeying]. (S, M, K.) The hemzeh in OabRa is sometimes changed into w; and thus wabRa, inf. n. wabRN, signifies He prepared himself to assault, or charge, in battle. (T, TA.)
OabRato OabaAbatuhu, and UibaAbatuhu, His way, or course, of acting, or conduct, or the like, was, or became, rightly directed, or ordered. (M, K.)

OabRa OabRahu↓ i. q. qaSada qaSodahu, (K,) which signifies He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, towards him, or it: (S and Msb in art. qSd:) and also, he pursued his (another‘s) course, doing as he (the latter) did. (L in art. wkd.)

OabRadi UilaI waTanihi, (M, K,) aor.
Aabiba
(IDrd, M, K) and
Aabuba
, (K,) inf. n. OabRN (AA, S, M, K) and UibaAbapN and OabaAbapN (M, K,) and OabaAbN, (TA,) He yearned for, longed for, or longed to see, his home. (AA, S, M, K.)
8: see 1, first signification.

10. AisotaOabRahu He adopted him as a father; an extr. form; (IAar, M;) from OabRN, a dial. var. of OabN: (TA:) regularly, AisotaOobaAhu. (M.) And AstObR OabFA and AisotaOobaba OabFA He adopted a father. (TA in art. Abw.)
OabN: see art. Abw.

OabRN Herbage, (M, K,) whether fresh or dry: (M, * K, * TA:) or pasture, or herbage which beasts feed upon, (Fr, AHn, Zj, T, S, M, A, Msb, K,) of whatever kind, (AHn, Zj,) [or] not sown by men: (Msb:) it is, to cattle and other beasts, what fruit is to men: (Mujáhid, T, Msb:) or whatever grows upon the face of the earth; (Atà, Th, T, M;) whatever vegetable the earth produces: (K, * TA:) and also, green herbage, or plants: (K, * TA:) and, as some say, straw, (Jel in lxxx. 31, and TA,) because cattle eat it: (TA:) or herbage prepared for pasture and for cutting: (TA:) accord. to IF, (Msb,) dried fruits; because prepared for winter (Bd in lxxx. 31, and Msb) and for journeying: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OawubRN, originally OaOobubN. (I' Ak p. 367.) You say, fulaAnN raAEa lahu AlHabRu waTaAEa lahu AlOabRu, meaning Such a one's seed-produce
[or grain] increased, and his pasture became ample. (A.)
Also a dial. var. of OabN, A father. (T, and MF from the Tes-heel of Ibn-Málik.)
OabRa OabRahu: see 1.
OabaAbapN and UibaAbapN A way, or course, of acting, or conduct, or the like. (M, K.) [See 1.]

UibRaAnN The time, or season, of a thing: (Msb:) or the time of preparing, or making ready, of a thing: (Mgh:) as, for instance, of fruit: (Mgh, Msb:) it is of the measure fiEolaAnN, (Mgh, Msb,) from OabRa in the first of the senses assigned to it above, (Mgh,) the n being augmentative; (Msb;) or of the measure fiERaAlN, (Mgh, Msb,) from OabRana “he watched” or “observed” a thing, (Mgh,) the n being radical: (Msb:) but the former derivation is the more correct. (Mgh.) [See also art. Abn.]

Oabojado The first of a series of eight words comprising the letters of the Arabic alphabet [in the order in which they were originally disposed, agreeing with that of the Hebrew and Aramaic, but with six additional letters: they are variously written and pronounced; generally as follows: Oabojada hawRazo HuTRiI kalamano saEofaSo qaraXato vaxaco DaZago: but the Arabs of Western Africa write the latter four thus: SEfD qrst vxc ZgX]: (K and TA in art. bjd: [in both of which are related several fables concerning the origin of these words:]) accord. to the general opinion, the word Abjd is of foreign origin, [like each of the words following it,] and therefore its first letter [as well as each of the others] is a radical. (TA.) [Hence, AlOabojadu signifies The alphabet. You say Huruwfu AlOabojadi The letters of the alphabet.

It is probable (as De Sacy has observed in his Ar. Gram., 2nd ed., i. 8,) that the Arabic alphabet originally consisted of only twenty-two letters: for some of the ancient Arabs called Saturday Abjd, Sunday hwzR, and so on to qrXt inclusive; calling Friday Earuwbapu.

In the lexicon entitled “El-'Eyn,” the letters of the alphabet are arranged nearly according to their places of utterance; as follows: E, H, h, x, g, q, k, j, X, D, S, s, z, T, d, t, Z, c, v, r, l, n, f, b, m, w, A, I: and this order has been followed in the Tahdheeb and Mohkam and some other lexicons.]

1. Oabada, aor.
Aabida
, inf. n. OubuwdN, He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, (T, S, M, K,) constantly, continually, or permanently, without quitting, (T, L,) bimakaAnK in a place; (T, S, M, K;) and so Oabada having for its aor.
Aabuda
. (TA.)

Oabada, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
Aabida
and
Aabuda
, (T, S, M, L, Msb, K,) inf. n. OubuwdN; (M, L, Msb;) and tObRd↓; (T, M, A, Mgh, L;) He (a beast) became wild, or sky; syn. tawaHRaXa: (S, M, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K:) [because wild animals live long, unless killed by accident; accord. to what is said by As and others in explanation of OwaAbidN (sing. MbidapN) applied to animals, as meaning wild:] took fright, and fled, or ran away at random: (Mgh:) took fright at, and shunned, mankind. (T, Msb.) OubuwdN also signifies The shrinking from a thing, or shunning it; syn. nufuwrN. (Kull pp. 30 and 31.) And Oabida, (S, K,) aor.
Aabada
; (K;) and tObRd↓; (A, K;) He (a man, S, A,) became unsocial, unsociable, unfamiliar, or sky; like a wild animal; syn. twHRX. (S, A, K.)

[Hence,] Oabada, (K,) aor.
Aabida
, inf. n. OubuwdN, (TA,) (tropical:) He (a poet) made use, in his verses, of words, or phrases, strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or far from being intelligible, (K, * TA,) such as were not understood (K) at first sight, or on first consideration. (TA.)

[And perhaps from Oabida in the sense explained above, but more probably, I think, by the substitution of O for w,] Oabida, aor,
Aabada
, (T, S, &c.,) inf. n. OabadN, (L,) He (a man, S) was angry; (T, S, M, L, K;) as also Oamida and wabida and wamida and Eabida. (T, L.) You say, Oabida Ealayohi He was angry with him. (L.)

2. ObRd, inf. n. taOobiydN, He made, or rendered, perpetual. (S, K.) [See also the pass. part. n. below.] lamo OafoEalo taOobiydFA is a phrase used as though meaning lamo Mti biMbidapK↓ [I did not a deed ever to be remembered, or mentioned]. (Ham p. 191.)
He, or it, made [a beast] to take fright; to become wild, or sky. (KL.)
5. tObRd: see 1, in two places.
It (a place of abode or sojourning) became deserted [by mankind]: (T, M, K:) and became inhabited by wild animals. (T, M, A.)
UibodN: see UibidN

OabadN Time, syn. dahorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) in an absolute sense: (TA:) or a long time, syn. dahorN TawiylN: (A, and Mgh: [and this may be meant in the S &c. by the syn. dahorN alone, q. v.:]) or, properly, a long time (dhr Twyl) that is unlimited: (Msb, TA:) or an extended space of time that is indivisible; for you say zamaAnu kacaA: “ the time of such a thing,” but not Oabadu kacaA: (Er-Rághib:) [and generally, time, or duration, or continuance, or existence, without end; endless time, &c.; prospective eternity; opposed to OazalN, which signifies “ time, or duration, &c., without beginning: ” (see the latter word for further explanations, &c.:) each of these significations may be meant by the explanation in the S and M and K, which is also given in the Msb: each correctly applies in particular instances:] pl. [of pauc.] MbaAdN (S, M, Msb, K) and [of mult.] OubuwdN (S, M, K) [and Oabaduwna, of which an ex. will be found below]: but the use of these pls. is restricted to particular cases, to signify portions of time, or to serve as corroboratives to the sing.: (MF:) as signifying an extended indivisible space of time, [or the like,] OabadN should have neither dual nor pl.; but MbaAdN is sometimes said, when the sing. is restricted to denote a particular part, or portion, of the whole of that to which it applies, in like manner as a generic noun is restricted to a special and partial signification: some, however, have mentioned MbaAdN as being post-classical; not of the language of the Arabs called AlEarabu AlEarobaMCu. (Er-Rághib.) TaAla AlOabado EalaI lubado [The time became long to Lubad, the last, and the longest of life, of Luk- mán's seven vultures, to the term of the life of which his own term of life was decreed to extend,] is a proverb applied to any thing that has been of long duration. (M.) And you say, razaqaka QllRehu EumurFA Tawiyla AlMbaAdi baEiyda AlMmaAdi [May God grant thee a life long in duration (lit. durations, the pl. form being used not in its proper sense, but to give intensiveness of signification), and remote in limit (lit. limits)]. (A.) And kaAna hecaA fiI MbaAdi AldRahori This was a long time ago. (Mgh.) And OabadN MbidN↓ (TA) and OabadN OabiydN↓, (S, M, TA,) meaning daAYimN [in an intensive sense]; (TA;) [A long, or an endless, period of time;] like as you say, dahorN daAhirN (S) or dahorN dahiyrN. (M.) [In each of these phrases, the latter word is added as a corroborative, or to give intensiveness to the signification.] liloOabida and liOabidK and [in an intensive sense, as will be seen below,] liOabida OabadK and liOabadi AlOabadi, accord. to different recitals of a trad., signify To the end of time; for ever; and for ever and ever. (TA.) OabadFA is an adv. n., of which the signification includes all future time; [meaning Ever; like qaTRu in relation to past time;] (El-Khafájee, El-Bedr Ed-Demámeenee, MF;) and EalaI AlOabadi signifies the same. (TA.) [So, too, does AlOabada, unless used in a limited sense known to the hearer.] When you say, laA OukalRimuhu OabadFA, you mean, [I will not speak to him as long as I live, or henceforth, or ever; or I will never speak to him; i. e.,] from the time of your speaking to the end of your life. (Msb.) [In this case, OabadFA may also be considered as a mere corroborative. It is used in both these ways (lltRaOosiysi and liltRawokiydi) in affirmative as well as negative sentences. For exs. of its use in affirmative sentences, see the Kur xviii. 2 and iv. 60, &c.] One also says, laA OafoEaluhu, (S, M, A,) and laA Mtiyhi, (T, K,) Oabada AlMbaAdi, (T, M, A, K,) which, though of classical authority, is said to be no evidence of the use of MbAd as a pl. of OabadN in a general way by the Arabs of the classical ages, as it is here added merely as a corroborative, as MzAl is in the phrase Oazala AlMzaAli; (MF;) and Oabada AlOabadiyna, (M, A, K,) in which the latter word is not a rel. n., for if so it would be AlOabadiyRiyna, but app. a pl., (M,) like OaraDuwna; (M, K;) and Oabada AlMbidiyna↓, (S, K,) like as you say, dahora AlMbidiyna; (S;) and Oabada AlOabadiyRapi↓; (M, K;) and Oabada AlOabiydi↓; (T, S, M, A, K;) and Oabiyda AlOabiydi↓; (M, K;) and Oabada AlOabadi; (K;) and Oabada
AldRahori; (M, K; [in the T yada AldRahori;]) all of which phrases are the same in meaning; (K;) [i. e. I will not do it, and I will not come to him, (or lA Mtyh may here mean the same as lA AfElh,) during the endless space of all future times, or time; or the like; or for ever and ever; εἰς αἰῶνα τῶν αἰώνων???; in seculum seculorum; in omne ævum;] the last word in every case being a corroborative. (MF.)

Also, [for cuw OabadK, and (applied to a fem. n.) caAtu OabadK,] Lasting: or everlasting. (S, A, K.) So in the saying, AldRunyaAC OamadN waAlMxirapu OabadN [The present state of existence is limited in duration, but the final state of existence is everlasting]. ('Obeyd Ibn-'Omeyr and L.) And AlOabadu signifies [The Everlasting; i. e. God; because He alone is AlbaAqiI AlOabadiyR↓ The Enduring without end or cessation; for the Muslims hold that all living creatures (even the angels) must die, and be raised again to life: or] The Ancient without beginning. (K.)
Also Offspring that is a year old. (K.)

OabidN Unsocial, unsociable, unfamiliar, or shy; like a wild animal; applied to a man, and to a young camel: (S, L:) and UibidN↓, applied to a female slave, and to a she-ass, signifies shunning mankind, shy, or wild. (K.) [See also MbidN.]
See also UibidN, in four places.
UibidN: see OabidN.

This word, (Lth, ISh, S, K,) said by Lth and ISh to be the only word of its measure heard from the Arabs except UibilN and nikiHN and xiTibN, but Az says that he had not heard the last two from any person worthy of reliance, and that they are pronounced nikoHN and xiTobN, (L,) [see UibilN,] and OabidN↓ and UibodN↓, (K,) which are thought by Az to be dial. vars. of the first, (L,) applied to a female slave, and to a she-ass, signify Prolific; that breeds, or brings forth, plentifully; (S, K;) and OabidN↓ and OabidapN↓ (Aboo-Málik, TA) and UibidapN↓, (Aboo-Málik, K,) applied to a she-camel, signify the same: (Aboo-Málik, K, TA:) and UibidN (Lth, ISh, L) and OabidN↓, (M, L,) applied to a female slave, (M, L,) and to a she-ass, (Lth, ISh, M, L,) and to a mare, (M, L,) that brings forth every year; (Lth, ISh, L;) or applied as a pl. to the female slave and the mare and the she-ass, that breed, or bring forth: (M, L:) and AlUibidaAni the female slave and the mare. (K, TA.) In the following saying,

[Hard fortune will not depart save with the fortune which is the necessary attendant of the possessor of the female slave, as long as he possesses her, (or, if we take cI in the sense of hecihi, save with the fortune of this female slave,) who every year (mA being redundant) brings forth,] AlAbd means the female slave because her being prolific is an obstacle to prosperity, and is not good fortune; i. e., she only increases evil [and brings reproach upon her master by bearing him children; for the Arab in ancient times was considered as dishonoured by his having a child by a slave]. (S.) The Arabs also said, lano yaboluga AljadRa AlnRakido AlARa AlOabido↓, meaning Nothing will attain to the object of removing hard fortune save female slaves and beasts or cattle which breed, or bring forth. (M, L: [in the latter of which is added, fiI kulRi EaAmK talido in every year bringing forth.])
OabidapN: see UibidN.
UibidapN: see UibidN.
OabadiIRN: see OabadN, last sentence but one.
OabadiyRapN [The quality, or attribute, of unlimited, indivisible, or endless, duration; everlastingness]. (M, K.) See OabadN.
OabadiyRaAtN a term applied to Sayings of which the following is an ex.: laA Mtiyka maA balRa baHorN SuwfapF. (M in art. Swf [q. v.]; &c.)
OabuwdN: see MbidN.
OabiydN: see OabadN, in three places.

MbidN Remaining, staying, abiding, or dwelling, constantly, continually, or permanently, in a place; applied to a man [and to a bird]. (L.) And OawaAbidu [pl. of MbidapN] Birds that remain in a country constantly, winter and summer; (T, L;) contr. of qawaATiEu. (A, L.)
For the phrases OabadN MbidN and Oabada AlMbidiyna, see OabadN.

A wild animal; (M, L, Msb;) that shuns, and takes fright at, mankind, amp;c.: (L, Msb:) fem. with p: pl. [properly fem.] OawaAbidu, (M, Mgh, L,) and [masc. and fem.] OubRadN: (M, L:) and OabuwdN↓ is syn. with MbidN; (M;) as also mutaOabRidN↓. (A.) Wild animals are called OawaAbidu (S, M, L, K) and OubRadN (M, L, K) because they endure for a long, or [naturally] unlimited, time; (M, L;) because they do not die a natural death, (As, M, L, K,) but from some evil accident; and the same is asserted of the serpent. (As, M, L.) [See also OabidN.] [Hence,] qayodu AlOawaAbidi (assumed tropical:) The light, or active, horse, which overtakes the wild animals, and which they can hardly, or never, escape: so called because he prevents their escaping the pursuer like a shackle. (Msb.) [See also art. qyd.] [Hence also the saying,] AlnRiEamu OawaAbidu faqayRiduwhaA biAlXRukori (tropical:) [Benefits are fugitive, or fleeting; therefore detain ye them by gratitude]. (A trad.)
MbidapN fem. of MbidN, q. v.

Also, [as a subst.,] (assumed tropical:) A deed, (Har p. 364,) or a calamity, (S, M, K,) ever to be remembered, or mentioned, (S, M, K, Har,) by reason of its extraordinary nature, and its grievousness: (Har:) or a great, or formidable, event, at which people take fright, or are alarmed: (TA:) or a strange, abominable, or evil, thing: (Ham p. 627:) pl. OawaAbidu. (K.) You say, jaACa fulaAnN biMbidapK Such a one did, or brought to pass, [a deed or] calamity ever to be remembered, or mentioned. (S.) See also 2.

(tropical:) A strange, an unusual, or an unfamiliar, word or saying; one far from being intelligible; (M;) pl. OawaAbidu, signifying expressions of subtile meanings; so called because remote from perspicuity. (Msb.)
The pl. also signifies (tropical:) Strange, unusual, unfamiliar, or extraordinary, rhymes, or verses, or poems; syn. XawaAridu mina AlqawaAfiI, (S,) or qawaAfK XurRadN. (K.) El-Farezdak says,
[Ye will not attain to my nobility with the ignobleness of your father, nor to my extraordinary verses by arrogating to yourselves the verses of other men]. (S.) [See Oabada.]
muWabRadN [Made, or rendered, perpetual]. You say, waqafa OaroDahu waqofFA muWabadFA He made his land an unalienable bequest for pious uses in perpetuity, not to be sold nor to be inherited. (T.)
Also, with p, A she-camel that is wild, and intractable, or unmanageable; syn. waHoXiyRapN muEotaASapN. (K.)
mutaOabRidN: see MbidN.

1. Oabara Alkalobi, (S, K,) aor.
Aabira
and
Aabura
, (K,) inf. n. OaborN, (TA,) He gave the dog, to eat, a needle in bread: (S, K:) and [app., in like manner, Oabara AlXRaApa he gave the sheep, or goat, to eat, a needle in its fodder: for you say,] Oubirati AlXRaAp the sheep, or goat, ate a needle in the fodder. (A.)
Oabaratohu AlEaqorabu (tropical:) The scorpion stung him with the extremity of its tail. (S, M, A, K.)

Oabarahu (tropical:) He spoke evil of him behind his back, or in his absence, or otherwise, with truth, or though it might be with truth; or defamed him; (IAar, T, A, K;) and annoyed him, or hurt him. (IAar, T, A.)

Oabara, (T, S, A, Msb, K,) aor.
Aabira
and
Aabura
, inf. n. OaborN (M, Msb, K) and UibaArN and UibaArapN, (M, K,) He fecundated a palm-tree [by means of the spadix of the male tree, which is bruised, or brayed, and sprinkled upon the spadix of the female; or by inserting a stalk of a raceme of the male tree into the spathe of the female, after shaking off the pollen of the former upon the spadix of the female (see OaloqaHa)]; (T, S, A, Msb;) as also ObRr↓, (S, A,) inf. n. taOobiyrN: (S:) or the latter has an intensive and frequentative signification [meaning the doing so much, or frequently, or to many palmtrees]: (Msb:) and the former (S, M, A, K) and ↓latter, (M, A, K,) he dressed, or put into a good or right or proper state, a palm-tree, (S, M, A, K,) and seed-produce, (M, K,) or any thing, as, for instance, a snare for catching game. (A Hn, M.) You say also, Oubirati AlnRaxolapu, and OubRirat↓, and wubirat, The palm-tree was fecundated. (Aboo- 'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà, L.)

Oabira, aor.
Aabara
, He, (a man, TA,) or it, was, or became, in a good or right or proper state. (T, K.)
2: see 1, in three places.
5. tObRr It (a palm-tree, A and Msb, or a young palm-tree, S) admitted, or received, fecundation: (S, A, Msb:) it became fecundated of itself. (S.)

8. QYotabarahu [written with the disjunctive alif Aiyotabarahu] He asked him to fecundate, or to dress, or put into a good or right or proper state, his palmtrees, or his seed-produce. (T, S, M, * K.)
See also baOara.

UiborapN A needle; (T, Msb;) an iron misalRap: (M,
K:) pl. UibarN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and UibaArN. (M, K.)
(tropical:) The sting, or extremity of the tail, of a scorpion; (S, * M, A, K;) as also miYobarN↓; of which latter the pl. is maMbiru: (A:) and of a bee. (A.)
(tropical:) The extremity of a horn. (A.)
(tropical:) The [privy] member of a man. (TA.)

UiborapN AlcRiraAEi (tropical:) The extremity of the elbow; (Zj in his Khalk el-Insán; and A;) the extremity of the ciraAE [here meaning the ulna] of the arm, (K,) from which the measurer by the cubit measures; (TA;) [this being always done from the extremity of the elbow;] the extremity of the bone from which the measurer by the cubit measures: the extremity of the os humeri which is next to the elbow is called the qabiyH; and the zujR of the elbow is between the qbyH and the Abrp AlcrAE: (T:) or a small bone, the head of which is large, and the rest slender, compactly joined to the qbyH: (TA voce qbyH:) or the slender part of the crAE: (S, M: or a bone, (as in some copies of the K,) or small bone, (as in other copies of the K and in the M,) which latter is the right reading, (TA,) even with the extremity of the zanod [which is applied to the ulna and to the radius] of, or from, (mn,) the crAE [or fore arm] to the extremity of the finger. (M, K.)

AlUborapu also signifies (tropical:) The bone of what is termed watarapu [i. e. of the heel-tendon of a man, or of the hock of a beast], (M, K,) which is a small bone adhering to the kaEob [i. e. to the ankle or to the hock]: (M, TA:) and [app. more correctly “or”] the slender part of the Erqwb [or hock] of the horse: (M, * K, * TA:) in the ErqwbAn [or two hocks] are [what are termed] UiborataAni, which are the external extremity of each hock. (S.)
See also miYobarapN.
UiboriyRN: see OabRaArN.
UibaArN a subst. [signifying The fecundation of a palm-tree]: (S:) or it is an inf. n.: [see 1:] or it signifies a palm-tree whereof the spadix is used for the purpose of fecundation. (Msb.)
OabuwrN: see miYobarN.
OabRaArN A maker of needles: (T, M, K:) and a seller thereof: or the latter is called UiboriIRN↓ of which UibariIRN is a corruption. (K.)
(assumed tropical:) The flea. (K.)
See also baORrN, in art. bOr

Mbiru One who fecundates a palm-tree, or palmtrees: who dresses, or puts into a good or right or proper state, a palm-tree, or palm-trees, or seedproduce; (T, TA;) or any work of art; and hence applied to the fecundater of the palm-tree. (Aboo-'Abd-Er-Rahmán, TA.)
maA bihaA MbirN (assumed tropical:) There is not in it [namely the house (AldAr)] any one. (TA from the Expositions of the Fs.)
maOobirN: see miYobarN
miYobarN The place [or case] of the needle. (K.)
(assumed tropical:) The tongue. (L.)
See also UiborapN
and miYobarapN

Also, (T, L, K,) and maOobirN↓, (T, L,) and OabuwrN↓, (Msb,) That. (Msb, K,) [namely] what is called juXr, (T, TT,) or juXR, (so in a copy of the T,) [in the L and TA it is said to be “ like (what is termed) AlHX, ” thus written with the unpointed H, and without any syll. signs, perhaps a mistranscription for HuXor, and doubtless meaning the anthers, or the pollen,] with which palm-trees are fecundated. (T, L, Msb, K.)

miYobarapN (Lh, S, M, K) and miYobarN↓ and UiborapN↓ (M, K) (tropical:) Malicious and mischievous misrepresentation; calumny; or slander; (Lh, S, M, K;) and the (assumed tropical:) marring, or disturbance, of the state of union or concord or friendship or love between a people or between two parties: (Lh, S, K, TA:) pl. maMbirN. (S, M.) You say, xabuvato minohumu AlmaxaAbiro famaXato bayonahumu AlmaMbiro (tropical:) [Their internal states, or qualities, became bad, or evil, or corrupt, and in consequence calumnies became current among them]. (A.)
muWabRarN: see what follows.

maOobuwrN A dog that has had a needle given him, to eat, in bread: (S:) and, with p, applied to a sheep or goat (XAp) that has eaten a needle in its fodder, and in whose inside it has stuck fast; in consequence of which the animal eats nothing, or, if it eat, the eating does it no good. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlmuWominu kaQlokalobi AlmaOobuwri The believer is like the dog that has had a needle given to him, to eat, in bread. (S.) [Accord. to Ibr D, the meaning is, that he is generous and incautious, so that he is easily deceived.]

Also, (T, S, A,) and muWabRarN↓, (S,) A palm-tree fecundated: (T, S, A:) and the same, and seed-produce, dressed, or put into a good or right or proper state. (T, TA.) The former is the meaning in the phrase sikRapN maOobuwrapN, (T, S,) occurring in a trad., [q. v. voce maOomuwrN,] i. e. A row of palm-trees [or perhaps a tall palm-tree] fecundated: or, as some say, this phrase means a ploughshare properly prepared for ploughing. (TA.)

1. OabaDahu, aor.
AabiDa
(S, A, K) and
AabuDa
(L,) inf. n. OaboDN (S) and OubuwDN (L,) He tied, or bound, the pastern of his (a camel's) fore leg to his (the camel's) EaDud [or arm], so that his fore leg became raised from the ground; (S, A, K;) as also tObRDhu↓: (S, K:) and accord. to IAar, OaboDN signifies [simply] the act of tying, or binding. (TA.)
[Also, inf. n. OaboDN, He loosed him, or it: for] OaboDN also signifies the act of loosing; syn. taxoliyapN; i. e. contr. of XadRN: (IAar, K:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (TA.)
Also, (K,) inf. n. OaboDN, (TA,) He hit, or hurt, his vein called the UibaAD. (K, TA.)

OabaDa (S, L, K,) inf. n. OaboDNe; (TA;) and OabiDa; (S, L, K;) It (the vein called AlnRasaA) became contracted, (S, L, K,) and strengthened the hind legs; (L;) as also tObRD↓: (S, L:) and taOabRuDN↓ in the hind legs signifies their being contracted (A, TA) and tense: (TA:) taOabRuD of the hind legs of a horse, and taXanRuj [or contraction] of the vein above mentioned, are qualities approved; and the latter is known by means of the former. (AO, TA.)
OaboDN also signifies The being in a state of rest, or motionless. (IAar, K.)
And The being in a state of motion: (I Aar, K:) thus, again, having two contr. significations. (TA.)

5. tObRD He (a camel) had his pastern of his fore leg tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg became raised from the ground. (S, K.) You say, taqabRaDa kaOanRamaA taOabRaDa [He contracted himself as though he had his leg thus bound]. (A, TA.)
tObRDt She (a woman) sat in the posture of the mutaOabRiD↓ [app. meaning having her shanks pressed back against her thighs]. (TA.)
See also OabaDa, in two places.
tObDhu: see OabaDahu.
OaboDN, or OubuDN, or UibiDN, or OubRaDN: see maOobiDN.
Also, the first, i. q. dahorN [Time; or a long period of time; or a period of time whether long or short; &c.]: pl. MbaADN. (S, K.)

UibaADN The cord, or rope, with which the pastern of a camel's fore leg is tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg is raised from the ground: (As, S, A, K:) pl. OubuDN. (K.) The dim. is OubayRiDN↓. (S.)
A certain vein (Eiroq) in the hind leg (AO, K) of a horse. (AO.)
OabuwDN, (K,) or OabuwDu AlnRasaA, (ISh,) A very swift horse: (ISh, K:) as though he bound up his hind legs by the quickness with which he raised them when he put them down. (ISh.)
OubayRiDN: see UibaADN.

maOobiDN The inner side of the knee (S, A, K) of any thing: (S:) or the inner sides of the two knees are called maOobiDaA AlsRaAqayoni: (T, TA:) or any part upon which a man bends, or folds, his thigh: or what is beneath each thigh, in the prominent places of the lower parts thereof: or the inner side of each thigh, as far as the belly: and also the wrist; the joint of the hand in the fore arm: (TA:) and in the camel, (K,) [i. e.] in each of the fore legs of the camel, (T, TA,) the inner side of the elbow: (T, K, TA:) as also ONboDN↓; (IDrd, K;) or, as in [some of] the copies of the S in art. byD, OubuDN↓; [in one copy of the S OubRaDN↓; and in another, imperfectly written;] but some write it UibiDN↓: and one says, Oaxaca biUibiDihi, meaning He put his hands, or arms, beneath his knees, from behind, and then carried him. (TA.) The pl. of maOobiDN is maMbiDu. (S.)

maOobuwDN A camel having the pastern of his fore leg tied, or bound, to his arm, so that his fore leg is raised from the ground; (A, * TA;) as also mutaOabRiDN↓: (S:) or the latter, having his fore shank bound to his arm with the UibaAD (K.)
Hit, or hurt, in the vein called the UibaAD. (TA.)
muWotabiDu AlnRasaA The crow: because it hops as though it were maOobuwD (K.)
mutaOabRiDN: see maOobuwDN: and see 5.
Also Having the vein called UibaAD in a tense state. (TA.)
1. OabaTahu i. q. habaTahu, q. v.: (IAar, Az, Sgh, K:) said of God. (K.)

5. tObRThu He put it (a thing, S Mgh, Msb) beneath his UiboT [or arm-pit]; (S, Msb, K;) or in
his UiboT. (Mgh.)

Hence, (K,) taOabRaTa XarRaA, the surname of Thábit the son of Jábir (S, K) ElFahmee: (S:) because they assert that the sword never quitted him: (S:) or because he put beneath his arm—pit a quiver of arrows, and took a bow, or put beneath his arm—pit a knife, and came to an assembly of Arabs, and smote some of them. (K.) It is invariable: but if you desire to express the dual or pl., you say, cawaA taOabRaTa XarRFA and cawuw taOabRaTa XarRKA, or you say kilaAhumaA and kulRuhumo. (S.) It does not admit of the formation of a dim., nor is it abridged: (S, K:) but some of the Arabs used to say taOabRaTu [so written with refa], using a single word, accord. to Sb, as is said in the L. (TA.) Its rel. n. is taOabRaTiIRN↓. (S, K.)
[Hence also] tObRT fulaAnN fulaAnFA (assumed tropical:) Such a one placed such a one under his protection. (TA.)

tObRT also signifies He put his ridaMC, (S,) or garment, (Mgh, K,) under his right arm, and then threw [a portion of] it over his left shoulder, (S, Mgh, K,) in prayer, or in UiHoraAm; (Mgh;) as also AiDoTabaEa. (S.) [See also tawaXRaHa.]

UiboTN [The armpit;] the inner side of the shoulderjoint: (ISd, K:) or the part beneath the janaAH [which signifies the arm, upper arm, armpit, and wing, &c.]: (S, Msb:) also written UibiTN↓; (Msb, K;) which is said to be a dial. var. by some of the moderns; but this is strange, on account of what is said respecting UibilN; (Msb;) for Sb says that there are only two substs. of the measure fiEilN, which are UibilN and HibirN; and one epithet, namely bilizN: other instances have been mentioned, but their transmission from Sb is not established: (Msb. in art. Abl:) it is also said that there is no other word like UibilN; but this means, in its original form, and does not deny that there are words like it by the insertion of a second vowel like the first, such as this and many other words: (TA:) [see also UibidN:] it is fem.; (Mgh;) or masc. and fem.; (S, Msb;) sometimes the latter; (Lh, K;) but the making it mase. is more approved: (TA:) Fr cites, from certain of the Arabs, the phrase, (S,) farafaEa AlsRawoTa HatRaI baraqato UiboTuhu [And he raised the whip so that his armpit shone]: (S, Msb:) the pl. is MbaATN. (S, Msb, K.)

[Hence,] Daraba MbaATa AlOumuwri wamagaAbinahaA (tropical:) [He hit the secret and occult particulars of the affairs]. (A, TA [followed by the words wa QXotaqRa DamaAYirahaA wabawaATinahaA, a pleonastic addition, merely explaining what goes before.])
And Daraba MbaATa AlmafaAzapi (tropical:) [He traversed the recesses of the desert]. (TA.)
And UiboTu jabalK (assumed tropical:) The foot, or bottom, or lowest part, (safaHo,) of a mountain. (TA.)

And UiboTu ramolK (assumed tropical:) The place where the main body of sand ends: (S:) or what is thin, of sand: (K:) or the lowest part of an oblong tract of sand collected together and elevated, where the main body thereof ends, and it becomes thin. (TA.)
And UibETu AlXRimaAli (assumed tropical:) Evil fortune; ill luck. (TA.)
UibiTN: see UiboTN.
UiboTiyRN [Of, or relating to, the armpit].
AlUiboTiIRu The axillary vein. (Golius, on the authority of Meyd.)

AlsRayofu UibaATN liI The sword is beneath my OiboT [or armpit]: and AlsRayofu EiTaA fiI wa UibaATiI I put, or place, the sword upon my side, and beneath my UiboT. (TA.) And jaEalotuhu I put it (namely the sword, TA) next my UiboT (K, TA.) The Hudhalee, (S, TA,) El-Mutanakhkhil, describing water to which he came to drink, (TA,) says, (S, TA,) accord. to the Deewán, but some ascribe the words to Taäbbata—Sharrà, (TA,)

meaning [I drank of the main body thereof, and returned from it, and a sharp steel—edged sword was] beneath my UiboT: (S, TA:) or, accord. to one relation, the poet said, biOaboyaDa SaArimK cakarK: and accord. to another, wa EaDobN SaArimN: Skr says that the last word of the verse is a contraction of MbaATiI: and Ibn-Es-Seeráfee, that it is originally UibaATiIRN↓; and if so, it is an epithet. (TA.)
UibaATiIRN: see what next precedes.
taOabRaTiIRN: see 5.

1. Oabaqa, aor.
Aabiqa
, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) which is the most common form, (Msb,) and
Aabuqa
, (S, TS, Mgh, Msb,) and
Aabaqa
, (K,) so in the copies of the K in the place of
Aabuqa
; (TA;) and Oabiqa, aor.
Aabaqa
; (IDrd, Msb, K;) inf. n. UibaAqN (S, Mgh, Msb) and OaboqN and OabaqN, (K,) or the first of these is a simple subst., and the second and third are the inf. ns.; (Msb;) He (a slave) ran away, or fled, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) or went away, (K,) from his master, (T, Msb,) without [being induced to do so by] fear, or severity of work: (Msb, K:) thus the signification is restricted in the 'Eyn: (Msb:) and in this case, the law ordains that the slave shall be restored; but if the act arise from severity of work or from fear, he is not to be restored: (Lth, TA:) in the Kur xxxvii. 140, it is said of Jonas, (T, Bd,) because he fled from his people without the permission of his Lord: (Bd:) and it is also, tropically, said of a fish: (Mgh:) or he (a slave) hid himself, and then went away: (M, K:) as also tObRq↓: (M:) or this signifies, simply, he hid, or concealed, himself: or he confined, restricted, limited, restrained, or withheld, himself: (S, K:) or it has both of the last two significations: (Sgh:) and he abstained from a thing, as from a sin, or crime. (IAar, K *.) A poet says, (S,) namely, 'Ámir Ibn—Kaab, (AZ,) or 'Ámán Ibn-Kaab, or, as some say, Ghámán, (AA,)

anchor.foreign: OalaA qaAlato bahaAni wa lamo taOabRaqo↓

sense.s: [Now surely Baháni said, and she did not hide herself, or did not restrain herself, Thou hast grown old, and enjoyment doth not befit thee]: (S:) or she did not hide herself [or her mind], but said openly: (TA:) or she did not go far [from the person whom she addressed, or from the truth]; so says AZ, taking it from UibaAqN as relating to a slave: (TA:) or she did not abstain from her speech, as from a sin, or crime: (IAar:) or she did not disdain, or scorn. (TA.) AHát says that he asked As respecting tObRq↓, and he answered that he knew it not. (TA.)
5: see 1, in three places.
taOabRaqato She (a camel) withheld her milk. (TA.)

tObRq AlXRaIoCa [or mina AlXRaIoCi] He denied, or disacknowledged, the thing. (K.) One says to a man, “ Verily in thee is such a quality; “ and he replies, maA OataOabRaqu I do not deny, or disacknowledge: and one says, “ O son of such a woman; ” and the man replies, maA OataOabRaqu minohaA I do not deny, or disacknowledge, her. (IF.)
OabuwqN: see MbiqN.
OabRaAqN: see MbiqN.

MbiqN A slave running away, or fleeing, &c.; a runaway, or fugitive, slave; part. n. of Oabaqa; (Mgh, Msb, K;) as also OabuwqN↓ [but in an intensive, or frequentative, sense, i. e. who runs away, or flees, &c., much, or often; and so OabRaAqN↓, occurring in the K, in art. mlx]: (IF, K:) pl.OubRaAqN (Mgh, Msb, K) and ONbRaqN. (K.)

1. Oabila, aor.
Aabala
; (S, M, K;) and Oabala, aor.
Aabula
; (K;) inf. n. OabaAlapN, (S, M, K,) of the former verb, (S, M, TA,) or, accord. to Sb, UibaAlapN, because it denotes an office, and, if so, of the latter verb, (TA,) and OabalN, (M, K,) which is of the former verb, (M, TA,) and OabalapN [like galabapN]; (T;) He (a man, S) was, or became, skilled in the good management of camels (S, M, K) and of sheep or goats. (M, K.) UibaAlapN, like kitaAbapN [in measure], signifies The management, or tending, (A, K, TA,) of maAl [meaning camels or other beasts]. (A, TA.) You say, huwa Hasanu AlUibaAlapi He is good in the management, or tending, of his mAl [or camels, &c.]. (A, TA.)

Oabala, aor.
Aabila
: see 2, second signification.
Oubilati AlUibilu The camels were gotten, or acquired, as permanent property. (S, TA.)

Oabilati AlUibilu, aor.
Aabala
; and Oabalat, aor.
Aabula
; (K;) inf. n. [of the former] OabalN and [of the latter] OubuwlN; (TA;) The camels became many, or numerous. (K.)

Also Oubalati AlUibilu, (S, M, K,) and the like is said of wild animals, (S, M,) or others, (K,) aor.
Aabula
and
Aabila
, inf. n. OubuwlN (S, M, K) and OabolN; (M, K;) and Oabilat; and tOblRt↓; (M, K;) The camels were content, or satisfied, with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water: (S, M, K:) the last verb is mentioned by Z, and he says that it is tropical, and hence OabiylN applied to “a monk.“ (TA.)

[Hence,] Oabala AlrRajulu Eani QmoraOatihi, and tObRl↓, (S, M, K,) The man was content to abstain from conjugal intercourse with his wife; syn. AijotazaOaEanohaA; (M;) the man abstained from conjugal, or carnal, intercourse with his wife. (S, K, TA.)

[Hence also] Oabala, (K,)
inf. n. OabolN, (TA,) (tropical:) He devoted himself to religious exercises; or became a devotee; (K, TA;) as also Oabula, like faquha, inf. n. OabaAlapN: or this signifies he became a monk. (TA.)

And Oabala, aor.
Aabila
, (Kr, M, K,) inf. n. OabolN, (Kr, M,) (assumed tropical:) He overcame, and resisted, or withstood; (Kr, M, K;) as also ObRl↓, (K,) inf. n. taOobiylN; (TA;) but the word commonly known is OabalRa. (M, TA.)
Also (K, TA, but in the CK “ or ”) Oabalati AlUibilu signifies The camels were left to pasture at liberty, and went away, having with them no pastor: (K:) or they became wild, or shy. (K, * TA.)
And The camels sought by degrees, or step by step, or bit by bit, after the Oubul [q. v.], i. e. the xilofap of the herbage or pasture. (TA.)
And, inf. n. OubuwlN, The camels remained, or abode, in the place: (M, K:) or remained, or abode, long in the pasturage, and in the place. (El-Moheet, TA.)
Oabala AlEuXobN, inf. n. OubuwlN, The herbage became tall, so that the camels were able to feed upon it. (K.)
Oabala AlXRajaru, inf. n. OubuwlN, The trees had green [such, app., as is termed OubulN] growing in its dried parts, mixing therewith, upon which camels, or the like, fatten. (Ibn- 'Abbád.)
Oabalahu, inf. n. OabolN, He assigned to him, or gave him, (jaEala lahu) pasturing camels, or camels pasturing by themselves. (K.)
2. ObRl, (S, K,) inf. n. taOobiylN, (K,) He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, camels; he acquired them as permanent property. (S, K.) [See also 5.]

He was one whose camels had become numerous; (T, M, K;) as also Mbl↓, (M, K,) inf. n. UiybaAlN; (TA;) and Oabala↓, aor.
Aabila
, (K,) inf. n. OabolN. (TK.)
taOobiylN AlUibili The managing, or taking good care, of camels; (M;) and the fattening of them: (M, K:) mentioned by AHn, on the authority of Aboo—Ziyád ElKilábee. (M.)
See also 1.
4: see 2.
5: see 1, in two places:
and see 8
tObRl UibilFA He took for himself, got, gained, or acquired, camels; (AZ, T, M, K;) like tgnRm ganamFA. (AZ, T.) [See also 2.]

8. laA yaOotabilu, (S, M, K,) in the O lA yataOabRilu↓, (TA,) He does not, or will not, keep firmly, or steadily, to the pasturing of camels, nor tend them well; (M, K;) he does not, or will not, manage them, or take care of them, in such manner as to put them in good condition: (As, A 'Obeyd, T, S:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (S,) he does not, or will not, keep firmly, or steadily, upon them when riding them; (T, S, M, K, TA;) used in this sense by a man excusing himself for not putting on a camel his aged father who was walking. (T.)
UibolN: see UibilN:
and OabilN.
OabalN: see OabalapN.

OabilN Skilled in the good management of camels (S, M, K) and of sheep or goats; (M, K;) as also MbilN↓: (S, M, K:) and OabilN biAlUibili, and in poetry UibolN↓, skilled in the management, or care, of camels. (T.)

A man possessing camels; (Fr, M, K;) as also MbilN↓, (M, K,) similar to taAmirN and laAbinN, (Ham p. 714,) but this is disapproved by Fr; (TA;) and UibaliIRN↓, (S, M, O,) with fet-h to the b (S, O,) because several kesrehs together are deemed uncouth; (O;) in the K, erroneously, OabaliIRN↓, with two fet-hahs; (TA;) and UibiliIRN↓ also, (M, K,) with two kesrehs. (K.)
baEiyrN OabilN A fleshy he-camel. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)
naAqapN ObilapN A she-camel blessed, prospered, or made to have increase, in respect of offspring. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) In one place in the K, mina Alwaladi is put for fiI Alwaladi. (TA.)

OubulN [mentioned in two places in the latter part of the first paragraph,] The xilofap of herbage, (K,) i. e., of dry herbage; [app. meaning what grows in the season called AlSRayof, or summer, among herbage that has dried up;] growing after a year; upon which camels, or the like, fatten. (TA.)

UibilN (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) said by Sb to be the only subst. of this form except HibirN, and to have none like it among epithets except bilizN; for though other instances are mentioned, they are not of established authority; (Msb;) but IJ mentions, with these, HibikN and UiTilN [which may be of established authority]; (TA;) [and to these may be added UibiTN and UibidN, and perhaps nikiHN and xiTibN; respecting which see UibidN;] and for UibilN one says also UiblN↓, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) sometimes, by way of contraction; (S, Msb;) or this may be a dial. var. of the former; (Kr, MF;) [Camels: and a herd of camels: or] at the least, applied to a Siromap; i. e. a number [of camels] more than a cawod [which is at least nine,] up to thirty; after which is the hajomap, i. e. forty and upwards; and then, hunayodapu, which is a hundred of Uibil: (T:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, a hundred of Uibil: (TA:) it is a quasi-pl. n.; (Az, S, ISd, Z, O, Msb, &c.;) a word having no proper sing.; (S, M, O, Msb;) and is of the fem. gender, because the quasi-pl. n. that has no proper sing. is necessarily fem. (S, O, Msb) when not applied to human beings, (S, O,) or when applied to irrational beings, (Msb,) and has p added in the dim.; (S, Msb;) the dim. of UibilN being OubayolapN↓: (S, Msb, K:) it is said in the K that it is a sing. applied to a pl. number, and is not a pl., nor a quasi-pl. n.; but in this assertion together with the saying that the dim. is as above is a kind of contradiction; for if it be a sing., and not a quasi-pl. n., what is the reason of its being fem.? (TA:) the pl. is MbaAlN (S, M, Msb, K) and OabiylN [like EabiydN pl. of EabodN, q. v.]; (Msb, TA;) the pl. meaning herds [of camels]; and in like manner OagonaAmN and OaboqaArN mean flocks of sheep or goats and herds of bulls or cows: (Msb, TA:) and the dual, UiblaAni, means two herds [of camels], (Sb, T, S, M, Msb,) each with its pastor; (T;) like as ganamaAni means two flocks of sheep or goats: (S:) or, accord. to Ibn-'Abbád, the dual means two hundreds of Uibil. (TA.)
AlUibilu AlSRugoraI [The smaller camels] is an appellation applied to sheep; because they eat more than goats. (IAar in TA art. DbT.)

It is said in the Kur [lxxxviii. 17], OafalaA yanoZuruwna UilaI QloUibili kayofa xuliqato, meaning, accord. to 'Aboo-Amr Ibn-El- 'Alà, (T, TA,) (tropical:) [Will they not then consider] the clouds that bear the water for rain, [how they are created?] (T, K, TA:) but accord. to him who reads AlUiboli, the meaning is, the camels. (T, TA.)

OubolapN A blight, blast, taint, or the like: (T, K:) thus written by IAth, agreeably with the authority of Aboo-Moosà; (TA;) occurring in a trad., in which it is said that one should not sell dates until he is secure from AlAubolapN; (T, TA;) but accord. to a commentary on the Nh, it is correctly written OabalapN↓ [q. v.] (TA.)
UibolapN Enmity; hostility. (Kr, M, K.)

OabalapN Unwholesomeness and heaviness of food; (S, M, K;) originally wabalapN, like as OaHadN is originally waHadN; (S;) as also OabalN↓. (K.) It is said in a trad. that this departs from every property for which the poor-rate has been paid. (S, M.)
See also OubolapN.
An evil quality of herbage or pasture. (AHn, TA in art. nXr.)
A cause of harm or injury; evil; mischief. (TA.)

A consequence of an action, or a claim which one seeks to obtain for an injury; and a cause of blame or dispraise: having these meanings in the saying, Uino faEalota caAka faqado xarajota mino Oabalatihi [If thou do that, thou wilt escape from its consequence, &c.]. (T.)
A fault, vice, or the like. (Aboo-Málik, T.) So in the saying, maA Ealayoka fiI hecaA AlOamori OabalapN [There is not to be charged against thee, in this affair, any fault, &c.]. (T.)
A crime; a sin; an unlawful action. (K.)
Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite. (IB.)
OabaliIRN: see OabilN
OabuliIRN: see OabiylN
UibaliIRN, with fet-h to the b because several kesrehs together are deemed uncouth, Of, or relating to, camels. (S.)
See also OabilN.
UibiliIRN: see OabilN

OabiylN (assumed tropical:) A Christian monk; (S M, Msb, K;) so called because of his abstaining (litaOabulihi) from women: (TA:) or the chief monk: (T:) or a derotee: (TA:) or an old man, or elder: (M:) or the chief, or head-man, of the Christians: (M, K:) or the man who calls them to prayer by means of the naAquws; (A Heyth, M, * K;) the beater of the nAqws: (IDrd:) as also OayobaliIRN↓, (M and K, but according to the M as meaning “ a monk, ”) which is either a foreign word, or changed by the relative I, or of the same class as UinoqaHolN [in which the first letter as well as th second is augmentative], for Sb says that there is not in the language an instance of the measure fayoEalN; (M;) and OayobuliIRN↓, and hayobaliIRN, and OabuliIRN↓ and OayobalN↓, (K,) which last is disallowed by Sb for the reason stated above; (TA;) and OayobulN↓ like OayonuqN; and OayobiliIRN↓; (K;) the last with fet-h to the hemzeh, and kesr to the b, and with the
[first] I quiescent; or OayobaliIRN [app. a mistranscription for OayobiliIRN] is used by poetic licence for OabiyliIRN↓, like OayonuqN for OanowuqN: (TA:) pl. MbaAlN (M, K) and OubolN, or OubulN, [accord. to different copies of the K,] with damm [which indicates that the former is meant, though it is irregular]. (K.) By OabiylN AlOabiyliyna is meant 'Eesà [or Jesus], (S, K,) the Messiah. (S.)
In the Syriac language it signifies Mourning, or sorrowing. (K.)
Also A staff, or stick. (M, K.)
See also UibaAlapN.
OubaAlap: see the next paragraph.
UibaAlapN: see UibRawolN.

Also A bundle of firewood; (T, S, Msb;) and so UibRaAlapN↓: (T, S:) or a great bundle of firewood; and so OubaAlapN↓ and bulapN (K) and UibRaAlapN↓: (Bd in cv. 3; but there explained only as signifying a great bundle:) or a bundle of dry herbage; (M, TA;) and so UibRaAlapN↓ (K) and OabiylN↓ and OabiylapN↓ (M, K) and UiybaAlapN↓, (K, [in the CK AayobaAlap,]) with one of the two b s changed into I, and mentioned by Az, but it is said in the S and O that this is not allowable, because this change may not be made in a word of the measure fiERaAlapN, with p, but only in one without p, as in the cases of diynaArN and qiyraATN; (TA;) and wabiylapN signifies the same, (K,) belonging to art. wbl. (TA.) Hence the prov., (S, TA,) SigovN EalaI UibaAlapK and UibRaAlapK↓, (S, K, &c.,) but the former is the more common, and UiybaAlapK↓, which is allowed by Az but disallowed by J; (TA;) [lit. A handful of herbage, or the like, upon a bundle, or great bundle, of firewood, or a bundle of dry herbage;] meaning (assumed tropical:) a trial, or trying event, upon another (S, O, K) that had happened before: (S, O:) or plenty (xiSobN) upon plenty; as though bearing two contr. significations. (K.)
OabiylapN: see UibaAlapN.
OubaylapN dim of UibilN, q. v. (S, Msb, K.)
OabiyliIRN: see OabiylN.
OabaAbiylN: see UibRawolN.
OabRaAlN A pastor of camels, (M, K, TA,) who manages them, or takes care of them, well. (TA.)
UibRaAlN: see the next paragraph.

UibRawolN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) like EijRawolN, (S, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Eajuwl,]) A separate, or distinct, portion of a number of birds, and of horses, and of camels, (M, K,) and of such following one another; (K;) as also UibiylN↓ and UibRaAlapN↓, (M, K,) and UibaAlapN↓, and UiyobaAlN↓: (K:) or it signifies a bird separating itself from the row of other birds; (T, TA;) accord. to IAar. (TA.) It is said to be the sing. of OabaAbiylN↓: (T, S, M, and Jel in cv. 3:) Ks says, I used to hear the grammarians say that this latter has for its sing. UibRawolN, like EijRawolN, of which the pl. is EajaAjiylN: (Msb:) or its sing. is UibaylN↓; (S, Msb;) but he who says this adds, I have not found the Arabs to know a sing. to it: (S:) or each of these is its sing.; (M, Jel;) and so is UibRaAlN↓: (Jel:) or its sing. is UibRaAlapN↓, (Bd in cv. 3, and Msb,) originally signifying “a great bundle:” (Bd:) it is said that this seems to be its sing.; and so OabRaAlapN↓: or the sing. may be UiybaAlapN↓, like as diynaArN is sing of danaAniyrN: (T:) or it has no sing., (T, S, M, Bd, Msb, K,) accord. to Fr (T, Msb) and Akh (S) and AO, (T, M,) like XamaATiyTu (Fr, T, Bd) and EabaAdiydN. (AO, M, Bd.) OabaAbiylN signifies, accord. to some, A company in a state of dispersion: (M:) or dispersed companies, one following another: (Msb:) or distinct, or separate, companies, (Akh, S, Msb, K,) like leaning camels: (Msb:) or companies in a state of dispersion. (AO, Msb.) One says, jaMCato Uibiluka OabaAbiyla Thy camels came in distinct, or separate, companies. (Akh, S.) And TayorN OabaAbiylu [in the Kur cv. 3 means Birds in distinct, or separate, flocks or bevies]: (Akh, S:) [or] birds in companies from this and that quarter: or following one another, flock after flock: (Zj, T:) or (assumed tropical:) birds in companies; (Bd, Jel;) likened to great bundles, in respect of their compactness. (Bd.) [Respecting these birds, Fei, in the Msb, quotes many fanciful descriptions, which I omit, as absurd.]
UibRiylN: see UibRawolN, in two places.
OabRaAlapN: see UibRawolN.
UibRaAlapN: see UibaAlapN, in three places:
and UibRawolN, in two places.

MbalN More, and most, skilled in the good management of camels. (S, M, K, TA.) Hence the prov., Mbalu mino Hunayofi AlHanaAtimi [More skilled &c. than Honeyf-el-Hanátim]. (TA.) And the phrase, huwa mino Mbila AlnRaAsi [He is of the most skilled &c. of men]. (S, M, K.) Mentioned by Sb, who says that there is no verb corresponding to it. (M.) [But see 1, first signification.]
MbilN: see OabilN, in two places.

UibilN OawaAbilN, (S, M, K,) and OubRalN, and OubRaAlN, (M,) [all pls. of MbilN or MbilapN,] and muWabRalapN↓, (M,) Many, or numerous, camels: (S, M, K:) or this, [app. meaning the last,] as some say, put in distinct herds; (M;) and so OubRaAlN: (TA:) or gotten, gained, or acquired, for permanent possession: (M:) this last is the meaning of the last of the epithets above. (S, K.)

MbilN, applied to a camel, also signifies Content, or satisfied, with green pasture, so as to be in no need of water: pl. OubRaAlN: (S, K:) and so OawaAbilu, applied to she-camels, (T, * TA,) and to wild animals. (S in art. bl.)
And UibilN MbilapN Camels seeking by degrees, or step by step, or bit by bit, after the Oubul [q. v.], i. e. the xilofap of the herbage or pasture. (TA.)
And UibRilN OubRalN Camels left to themselves, (S, M, K, TA,) without a pastor. (TA.)
OayobalN and OayobulN: see OabiylN.
OayobaliIRN and OayobuliIRN and OayobiliIRN: see OabiylN.
UiyobaAlN: see UibRawolN.
UiyobaAlapN: see UibaAlapN, in two places:
and see UibRawolN.
OaroDN maOobalapN A land having camels. (S, K.)
UibilN muWabRalapN: see MbilN.

1. Oabanahu, aor.
Aabuna
and
Aabina
, inf. n. OabonN, He made him an object of imputation, or suspected him: and he found fault with him, or blamed him: (M:) or he cast a foul, or an evil, imputation upon him. (IAar, T.) You say, Oabanahu biXaIoCK, (S, K,) or biXRarK (as in one copy of the S,) or bixayorKwaXRarK, (Lh, M,) aor. as above, (Lh, S, M, K,) and so the inf. n., (Lh, M,) He made him an object of imputation, or suspected him, (Lh, S, M, K,) of a thing, (S, K,) or of evil, (S, accord. to one copy,) or of good, and evil: (Lh, M:) and ObRnhu↓ signifies the same. (M.) And bixayorK fulaAnN yuWabRanu↓, or biXRarK, Such a one is made an object of imputation, or suspected, of good, or of evil: (AA, * Lh, T [as in the TT; but perhaps yuWabRanu is a mistranscription for yuWobanu; for it is immediately added, fahuwa maOobuwnN:]) when, however, you say yWbn [i. e. yuWobanu or yuWabRanN↓] alone, it relates to evil only. (AA, T. [But see 2.]) And fulaAnN yaWabanu bikacaA, or yuWabRanu↓, Such a one is evil spoken of by the imputation of such a thing. (S, accord. to different copies.) And it is said respecting the assembly of the Prophet, fiyhi AlHuramu, laA tuWabRanu↓, (T, and so in a copy of the S,) or lA tuWobanu, (so in some copies of the S,) i. e. Women (T) shall not be mentioned in an evil manner therein: (T, S:) or shall not have evil imputations cast upon them, nor be found fault with, nor shall that which is foul be said of them, nor that which ought not, of things whereof one should be ashamed. (IAar, T.)
Also, and ObRnhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taOobiynN, (K,) He found fault with him, or blamed him, to his face; (M, K;) and he upbraided him, or reproached him. (M.)
2. ObRn AlXRaIoCa, (AZ, S,) inf. n. taOobiynN, (K,) He watched, or observed, the thing; or he expected it, or waited for it. (AZ, S, K.)

ObRn AlOavara, (M,) inf. n. as above, (As, T, S, K,) He followed the traces, or footprints, or footsteps, (As, T, S, M, K,) of a thing; (As, S, K;) as also tObRn↓. (K.) And hence the next signification. (As, T.)

ObRn AlrRajula, (S, M,) inf. n. as above, (Sh, T, S, K,) He praised the man, or spoke well of him, (Sh, Th, T, S, M, K,) after his death, (Th, S, M, K,) or in death and in life, (Sh, T,) used in poetry to signify praise of the living; (M;) and wept for him: (S:) he praised him; and enumerated, or recounted, his good qualities or actions: you say, lamo yazala yuqarRiZu OaHoyaAkumo wayuWabRinu mawotaAkumo [He ceased not to eulogize your living and to praise your dead]: (Z, TA:) for he who praises the dead traces his [good] deeds. (As, T.)
See also 1, in six places.
5: see 2.
AibonN: see art. bny.

OubonapN A knot in wood, or in a branch; (S, M, K;) or in a staff, or stick; (T;) and in a bow, (TA,) [i. e.] the place of the shooting forth of a branch in a bow, (M,) which is a fault therein; (TA;) and in a rope, or cord: (M in art. Avl:)
pl. OubanN. (T, S.)
Hence, (M,) (tropical:) A fault, defect, or blemish, (T, M, K, TA,) in one's grounds of pretension to respect, (T, TA,) and in speech, or language. (M, TA.)
(assumed tropical:) Particularly The enormity that is committed with one who is termed maOobuwn. (TA.)
And (tropical:) Rancour, malevolence, malice, or spite: (K, TA:) and enmity: pl. as above. (TA.) You say, bayonahumo OubanN (tropical:) (S, TA) Between them are enmities. (S.)
Also The [part called] galoSamap [meaning the epiglottis] of a camel. (M, K.)
AibonapN: see art. bnI

UibRaAnN The time of a thing; (T, S, M, K, and Msb in art. Ab;) the season of a thing; (Msb in that art.;) the time of the preparing, or making ready, of a thing; (Mgh in that art.;) as, for instance, of fruit, (S, Mgh, Msb,) of the fresh ripe dates, and of the gathering of fruits, and of heat or cold: (T.:) or the first of a thing. (M, K.) You say, Oaxaca AlXRaIoCa biUibRaAnihi He took the thing in its time: or in, or with, the first thereof. (M.) The n is radical, so that it is of the measure fiERaAlN; or, as some say, augmentative, so that it is of the measure fiEolaAnN. (TA.) [See art. Ab.]
muWabRanN occurs as meaning Dead, or dying; i. e., [properly,] wept for. (S.) [See 2.]
muWabRinN A praiser of the dead; because he traces his [good] deeds. (As, T.)
maOobuwnN Made an object of imputation, or suspected, of evil: thus when used alone: otherwise you add bixayorK [of good], and biXRarK [of evil]. (M, K.)
Hence, [A catamite;] one with whom enormous wickedness is committed; (TA;) i. q. muxanRavN. (Idem, voce duEobuwvN.)
Also One who is imprisoned; because suspected of a foul fault, or crime. (T.)
Abns, accord. to the Msb; or bns, accord. to the TA.
