MbinuwsN, with medd to the A and kesr to the b, (TA,) or with damm to the b, [i. e. MbunuwsN, and by some written MbanuwsN,] or with the bquiescent, [i. e. OabonuwsN,] and without w, [app. OabonusN,] (Msb,) [Ebony;] a thing well known, which is brought from India: an arabicized word: (Msb [in which is added the proper Arabic appellation; but the word in my copy of that work is imperfectly written; app. jEfr; which, however, does not seem to be the word intended:]) some say that it is the same as saAsam: others, that it is different therefrom: and respecting the measure of the word, authors differ. (TA.)

1. Oabaha lahu, (JK, K,) and bihi; (K;) and Oabiha; aor. [of both] yaOobahu; inf. n. OabohN, (JK, K,) of the former, (TA,) and OubuwhN, [also of the former,] (JK,) and OabahN, (JK, K,) which is of the latter; (TA;) He knew it; or understood it; or knew it, or understood it, instinctively: or he recognised it readily; knew it, or understood it, readily, after he had forgotten it. (K.) You say, maA Oabahotu lahu, (AZ, JK, S, Mgh,) aor. Mbahu, inf. n. OabohN; (AZ, S) and maA Oabihotu lahu, (JK, S,) aor. as above, inf. n. OabahN; (S;) I did not know it, or understand it; or did not know of it; was not cognizant of it: (JK, Mgh:) or I did not have my attention roused to it after I had forgotten it: (AZ, S:) the former is like wabahotu; (Mgh;) and the latter, like [wabihotu and] nabihotu. (S.)
laA yuWobahu lahu (Mgh, K, TA) He will not be cared for, minded, or regarded, because of his lowness of condition, or abjectness. (Mgh, TA.)
Oabahotuhu bikacaA I imputed to him, or suspected him of, such a thing. (JK, K, TA.)

2. OabRahotuhu, inf. n. taOobiyhi, I roused his attention: and I made him to know, or understand. (Kr, K.) The two meanings are nearly alike. (TA.) And Mbahotuhu↓ I made him to know; informed, apprized, advertised, or advised, him; gave him information, intelligence, notice, or advice. (IB.)
4: see 2.

5. tObRh He magnified himself; behaved proudly, or haughtily. (JK, S, K.) You say, taOabRaha AlrRajulu EalaI fulaAnK The man magnified himself against such a one, and held himself above him. (JK, * TA.) And taOabRahu Eano kacaA He shunned, avoided, or kept himself far from, such a thing; (JK, Z, K;) he was disdainful of it, he disdained it, or held himself above it. (Z, K.)

OubRahapN Greatness, or majesty; (JK, S, K;) a quality inspiring reverence or veneration; (TA;) goodliness and splendour; (K;) and goodliness of aspect: (TA:) and pride, self-magnification, or haughtiness. (JK, * S, * K.)

1. Oabawotu, [third pers. OabaA,] (T, S, M, K,) and Oabayotu, [third pers. OabaI,] (T, M, K,) the latter accord. to Yz, (T,) aor. Mbuw, (TK,) inf. n. OubuwRapN, (Yz, T, S, Msb,) or this is a simple subst., (M,) I became a father. (T, * S, * M, K.)
Oabawotuhu, (ISk, T, M, K,) aor. Mbuwhu, (IAar, ISk, T,) inf. n. UibaAwapN, (M, K,) I was, (IAar, ISk, T,) or became, (M, K,) a father to him. (IAar, ISk, T, M, K.)

[Hence, I fed him, or nourished him; and reared him, or brought him up.] You say, fulaAnN yaOobuw hecaA Alyatiyma, inf. n. UibaAwapN, Such a one feeds, or nourishes, this orphan, like as the father does his children. (Lth, T.) And maAlahu OabN yaOobuwhu (ISk, T, S) He has not a father to feed him, or nourish him, and to rear him, or bring him up. (S.)
2. OabRayotuhu, inf. n. taOobiyapN, I said to him biOabiI [meaning fudiyati biOabiI Mayest thou be ransomed with my father! or the like: see OabN, below]. (K, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, yA AabiI.])

5. tObRAhu He adopted him as a father; (M, K, TA;) as also AstObAhu↓; (M in art. Ab;) and so tObRAhu OabFA, accord. to A'Obeyd: (TA:) [or,] accord. to A'Obeyd, you say, taOabRayotu OabFA I adopted a father: (T:) and you say also, AisotaOabRa OabFA and AisotaOobaba OabFA he adopted a father. (TA.)

OabN is originally OabawN, (S, Msb, K,) as is shown by the first of its dual forms and of its pl. forms mentioned below; (S, Msb;) and signifies A father [in the ordinary sense: and also as meaning (assumed tropical:) an ancestor]: (M:) as also OabFA↓, a dial. var., (M, K,) the same in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases, like qafFA: (M:) and OabRN is a dial. var. of the same, [the second letter being doubled to compensate for the w suppressed, as is the case in OaxRN, (TA voce OaxN)] but is rare. (Msb.) Accord. to the dial. commonly obtaining, when you use it as a prefixed noun, you decline it with the letters w and A and I, saying, hecaAOabuwhu [This is his father], (Msb,) and Oabuwka [thy father]; (M;) and raOayotu OabaAhu [I saw his father]; and mararotu biOabiyhi [I passed by his father]: (Msb:) but accord. to one dial., you say, hecaA OabaAhu, (Msb:) and OabaAka; (M;) and raOayotu OabaAhu; and mararotu biOabaAhu: (Msb:) and accord. to one dial., which is the rarest of all, it is defective in every case, like yadN and damN; (Msb;) and [thus] you say, hecaA Oabuwka [&c.]. (M.) The dual is OabawaAni, (S, M, Msb,) meaning [two fathers, and] father and mother; and some say OabaAni: (S, M:) you say, humaAOabawaAhu, meaning They two are his father and mother; and in poetry you may say, humaA OabaAhu; and in like manner, raOayotu Oabayohi [I saw his father and mother], (T,) and Oabayoka [thy father and mother]; (S;) but the usual, or chaste, form is raOayotu Oabawayohi. (T.) The pl. is MbaMCN, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the best form, (T,) and Oabuwna, (T, S, M, K,) and OubuwRN (M, K, [in the CK AlAabowN is erroneously put for AlOubuwRN,]) and OubuwRapN, (Lh, T, S, M, K, *) like EumuwmapN and xuWuwlapN: (T, S:) you say, heWulaMCi Oabuwkumo, meaning MbaAWukumo [These are your fathers]; (T;) and hence, in the Kur [ii. 127], accord. to one reading, waUileha Oabiyka Uibrehiyma waUisomeEiyla waUisoHeqa [And the God of thy fathers, Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac], meaning the pl. of ObN, i. e. Oabiynaka, of which the n is suppressed because the noun is prefixed [to the pronoun]; (S;) and some of the Arabs say, OabuwRatunaA Oakoramu AlMbaMCi [Our fathers are the most generous of fathers]. (T.) The dim. is OubRaIRN↓; originally OubayowN, with the final radical letter restored. (Msb.)
maA yadoriI lahu mino OabK, and maA OabN, mean- ing He knows not who is his father, and what is his father, are sayings mentioned by Lh on the authority of Ks. (M.)

laA OabaA lika, (T, S, M, K, &c.,) [accord. to the dial. of him who says OabFA instead of OabN,] as also laA Oaba laka, and laA OabaAka, (S, K,) [the last, accord. to J, because the l (meaning the l in lk in the preceding phrases) is as though it were redundant, but he seems not to have known the dial. var. OabFA, and I rather think that laA OabaAka, is for laA OaboqaI QllRehu OabaAka, or the like,] and laA Oabaka, (Mbr, Sgh, K,) and laAba laka, (K,) which is for laA Oaba laka, (M,) means Thou art, in my estimation, one deserving of its being said to him, Mayest thou have no father! it is used in the manner of a proverb, is of frequent occurrence in poetry, (M,) is said to him who has a father and to him who has not a father, and is an imprecation as to the meaning, of necessity, though enunciative as to the letter; (M, K;) and hence the saying of Jereer,

L.foreign: yaA tayomu tayoma EadiIRK laA OabaA lakumo

sense.s:
[O Teym, Teym of 'Ades, may ye have no
father!]; which is the strongest evidence of its being a proverb, and not having a literal meaning; for all of [the tribe of] Teym could not have one father, but all of them were fit objects of imprecation and rough speech: (M:) it is an expression of praise: (S:) [i. e.] it is an imprecation against him to whom it is addressed, not, however, said with the desire of its having effect, but on an occasion of intense love, like laA OumRa laka, &c.: (Har p. 165:) and sometimes in dispraise, like laA OumRa laka: and in wonder, like lilRhi darRuka: (TA:) or, as A Heyth says, on the authority of Aboo-Sa'eed Ed- Dareer, it expresses the utmost degree of reviling; [meaning Thou hast no known father;] and laA OumRa laka expresses reviling also, but means Thou hast no free, or ingenuous, mother: (Meyd in Har p. 165: [see OumRa:]) sometimes it means Strive, or exert thyself, in thine affair; for he who has a father relies upon him in some circumstances of his case: (TA:) accord. to Kh, it means Thou hast none to stand thee in stead of thyself: (ISh, TA:) Fr says that it is a phrase used by the Arabs [parenthetically, i.e.,] to divide their speech: (TA:) [thus, for instance,] Zufar Ibn-El-Hárith says,

L.foreign: OariyniI silaAHiI laA OabaA laka UinRaniI
OaraI AlHaroba laA tazodaAdu UilRaA tamaAdiyaA

sense.s: [Show thou me my weapons: (mayest thou have no father! or thou hast no father: &c.:) verily I see the war, or battle, increases not save in perseverance]. (TA.) [Aboo-'Alee, as cited in the M, observes that the A (meaning the final A) in OabaA, in the phrase laA OabaA laka, indicates that it is a prefixed noun, and determinate; whereas the l in lk together with the government exercised upon the noun by lA indicates that it is, on the contrary, indeterminate, and separate from what follows it: but it seems that he was unacquainted with the dial. var. OabRaA; for laA OabaA laka in the dial. of him who uses the form OabRaA instead of OabN is the same grammatically as laA Oaba laka in the dial. of him who uses the form OabN.] Suleymán Ibn-'Abd-El-Melik heard an Arab of the desert, in a year of drought, say, Oanozilo EalayonaA Algayova laA OabaA laka, and Suleymán put the best construction upon it, [as though it meant, Send down upon us rain: Thou hast no father], and said, I testify that He hath no father nor female companion nor offspring. (TA.) They say also, in paying honour [to a person], laA Oaba liXaAniYika, and laA Oaba liXaAniYika, (TA,) i. e. May thy hater have no father! or, accord. to ISk, each is a metonymical expression for laA OabaA laka. (S in art. XnO, q. v.)

One also says, on the occasion of an occurrence that is approved and commended, by way of expressing wonder and praise, lalRihi Oabuwka, meaning To God, purely, is attributable [the excellence of] thy father, seeing that he begat thee a generous son, and produced the like of thee! (TA;) [or to God be attributed (the excellence of) thy father!] it means that to God [alone] belongs the power to create the like of this man [to whom it relates], from whom has proceeded this wonderful action. (Har p. 44.)

And hiIa binotu OabiyhaA, meaning She resembles her father in strength of mind, or spirit, and sharpness of disposition, and in hastening, or striving to be first, to do things: said of Hafsah, by 'Áïsheh. (TA.)

biOabiI, (TA,) or biOabiI Oanota, (T in art. bO,) [said to a person,] means [fudiyta biOabiI Mayest thou be ransomed with my father! (see the next sentence but one;) or] Oafodiyka biOabiI [I will ransom thee with my father]; (T ubi suprà;) or Oanota mafodiIRN biOabiI Thou art, or shalt be, ransomed with my father]; or fadayutuka biOabiI [I have in my heart ransomed thee, or I would ransom thee, with my father]; the b being dependent upon a word suppressed, which, accord. to some, is a [pass. participial] noun, and accord. to others, a verb; and this word is suppressed because of the frequent usage of the phrase. (TA.) You say also, biOabiI Oanota wa OumRiI [With my father mayest thou be ransomed, and with my mother!]. (TA.) And biOabiI mano wadadtRuhu, i. e. fudiIa biOabiI mano wadadtRuhu [May he whom I love be ransomed with my father!], meaning may he [my father] be made a ransom for him [whom I love]! (El-Wáhidee on the Deewán of El-Mutanebbee, in De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed. vol. iii. p. 35 of the Arabic text.) Sometimes they change the I into A: a poet says,

L.foreign: wahalo jazaEN Oano qulotu waA biOabaA humaA

sense.s: [And they have asserted that I have become impatient on account of them two: but is it an evidence of impatience that I said, Alas, with my father may they two be ransomed?]; meaning waA biOabiI humaA. (S.) And some of the Arabs used to say, waA biOabaA Oanota [Alas, with my father mayest thou be ransomed!]: this, says AM, being like yaA wayolataA for yaA wayolatiI; as also yaA bayobaA, with the hemzeh changed into I, originally yaA biOabaA, meaning yaAbiOabiI: and hence what is related, in a trad., of Umm- 'Ateeyeh; that she used not to mention the Prophet without saying, biyabaA [for biOabi huwa]. (TA in art. bO.) A woman said,

L.foreign: yaA biOabiI Oanota wa yaA fawoqa Albiyabo

sense.s: [O thou to whom I would say, With my father mayest thou be ransomed! and O thou who art above him to whom I would address the saying, With my father mayest thou be ransomed!]; respecting which Fr observes that the two words [bi and Oab] are made as one [by prefixing the article] because of their frequent occurrence; (S;) and Aboo-'Alee says that the I in biyab is substituted for C, not necessarily; but ISk quotes the words as commencing with yaA biyabaA, which is the right reading, in order that this expression may agree with AlbiYabo, which is derived from it: EtTebreezee, however, relates Abu-l-'Alà's reciting the words as ending with AlbiYabo; saying that this is compounded from the phrase biOabiy, and that therefore the C is preserved. (TA.) [See also the first paragraph in art. bO.]

You say also, yaA Oabati [meaning O my father], (S, M, K,) as in yaA Oabati AfoEalo [O my father, do thou such a thing]; (S;) and yaA Oabata; (S, M, K;) and yaAOabatu; (Z in the Ksh xii. 4;) and yaA Oabaho (S, M, K) when you pause after it. (S, M.) The p, [here written t,] (Kh, M,) the sign of the fem. gender, (S, Z,) is substituted for the [pronominal] affix I, (Kh, S, M, Z,) as in yaAOumRati; (S;) and is like the p in EamapN and xaAlapN, as is shown by your saying, in pausing, yaA OabahN, like as you say, yaA xaAlapN: (Kh, M:) the annexing of the fem. t to a masc. noun in this case is allowable, like as it is in HamaAmapN cakarN and XaApN cakarN and rajulN raboEapN and galaAmN yafaEapN: its being made a substitute for the affix I is allowable because each of these is an augmentative added at the end of a noun: and the kesreh is the same that is in the phrase yaA OabiI: (Z ubi suprà:) the t does not fall from Ab in the phrase yaA Oabati when there is no pause after it, though it [sometimes] does from OumR in the like phrase in that case, because the former word, being of [only] two letters, is as though it were defective. (S.) yaA Oabata is for yaA OabataA, (Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee, S, * M, [the latter expression mentioned also in the K, but not as being the original of the former,]) the A [and h] being suppressed; (the same Aboo- 'Othmán and M;) or for yaA OabataA, the A being suppressed, like as the I is in yaA gulaAmi; or it may be after the manner of yaAOabiIa. (Z ubi suprà.) yaA Oabatu is thus pronounced after the usual manner of a noun ending with the fem. p, without regard to the fact that the t is in the former a substitute for the suffix I. (Z ubi suprà.) yaA Oabaho is said in a case of pause, except in the Kur-án, in which, in this case, you say, yaA Oabaho, following the written text; and some of the Arabs pronounce the fem. p, in a case of pause, t [in other instances], thus saying, yaA TaloHatu. (S.) yaA OabaAhu is also said; (M, K;) though scarcely ever. (M.) A poet uses the expression yaA OabaAta, for yaA OabataAho: (S, M:) IB says that this is used only by poetic license, in a case of necessity in verse. (TA.)
OabN is tropically applied to signify (tropical:) A grandfather, or any ancestor. (Msb.)
It is also applied to signify (assumed tropical:) A paternal uncle; as in the Kur ii. 127, quoted before. (M.)

[It is also (like OumR and Aibon and binot) prefixed to nouns of various significations. Most of the compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, as exs. of different kinds.]

Oabuw AlmaroOapi (assumed tropical:) The woman's husband: (Ibn-Habeeb, M:) it is said in the TS that AlOabu, in certain of the dials., signifies the husband: MF deems this meaning strange. (TA.) Oabuw AlmavowaI (assumed tropical:) The master of the dwelling, or of the place of abode: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) the guest. (K in art. vwI.) Oabuw AlOaDoyaAfi (assumed tropical:) The very hospitable man. (TA.)
Oabuw AlHaArivi (assumed tropical:) The lion. (TA.) Oabuw jaEodapa (assumed tropical:) The wolf. (TA.) Oabuw AlHuSayoni (assumed tropical:) The fox. (TA.)
Oabuw jaAbir (assumed tropical:) Bread. (S and K in art. jbr.)
Oabuw maAlikK (assumed tropical:) Extreme old age: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) hunger. (MF in art. jbr.)
OabRaA: seeOabN.
UibowaMCN or OabowaMCN: see OubuwapN.
OabawiIRN Of, or relating or belonging to, a father; paternal. (S, TA.)
OabaIRN dim, of OabN, q. v. (Msb.)

OubuwapN [in copies of the K UibowaMC↓, and in the CK AabowAC↓, both app. mistranscriptions for OubuwRap, which is well known,] Fathership; paternity; the relation of a father. [S, * M.) You say, bayoniy w bayona falaAnK OubuwapN [Between me and such a one is a tie of fathership]. (S.)

1. OabaI, aor. yaOobaI, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is anomalous, (S, M, Msb,) because it has no faucial letter (S, Msb) for its second or third radical, (Msb,) and yaOobiI, (M, Msb, K,) mentioned by IJ as sometimes said, (M,) agreeably with analogy, (TA,) and yiYobaI, which is doubly anomalous, first because the pret. is of the measure faEala, and this pronunciation of the I of the aor. is [regularly allowable only] in the case of a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu, and secondly because it is only in an aor. like yiyojalu, (Sb, M,) i. e., of a verb of which the first radical letter is w or I, (TA in art. wjl,) and yiYobiI, (IB, [who cites as an ex. a verse ending with the phrase HatRaI tiYobiyaho,]) inf. n. UibaMCN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and UibaMCa pN, (K,) or UibaApN, (so in a copy of the M,) or UibaAyapN, (so in the Msb,) He refused; or refrained, forbore, abstained, or held back; syn. AimotanaEa; (S, Msb, MF, Bd in ii. 32, Kull p. 8,) voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice: (Bd ubi suprà, Kull:) [thus when used intransitively: and it is also used transitively:] you say, OabaI AlOamora he refused assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair; disagreed to it; and did not desire [to do] it: (Mtr in Har p. 483:) he did not assent to, consent to, approve, or choose, it; he disallowed it; rejected it: (Mgh:) and Oabay AlXRaIo Ca he disliked, was displeased with, disapproved of, or hated, the thing. (M, K.) Fr says that there is no verb with fet-h to its medial radical letter in the pret. and fut. [or aor.] unless its second or third radical is a faucial letter, except OabaI: that AA adds rakana: but that one says rakana with yarokunu for its fut., and rakina with yarokanu for its fut.: (T:) so that the instance mentioned by AA is one of an intermixture of two dial. vars.: (TA:) Th adds qalaI and gasaA and XajaA; and Mbr adds jabaA: but most of the Arabs say yaqoliI and yagosuw and yaXojuw and yajobiI. (T.) [Some other instances are mentioned by other authors; but these are verbs of which the aors. are rarely with fet-h, or are instances of the intermixture of two dial. vars.] Oabayota AllRaEona is a greeting which was addressed to kings in the time of ignorance; meaning Mayest thou refuse, or dislike, (ISk, * S, * M, * Har p. 491,) to do a thing that would occasion thy being cursed! (ISk, S, M;) or, to do that for which thou wouldst deserve the being cursed! for it implies the meaning of a prayer; i. e., may God make thee to be of those who dislike the being cursed! and hence it occurs parenthetically. (Har ubi suprà.) You say also, OabaI Oano yuDaAma [He refused, or did not submit, to be harmed, or injured]. (T.) [And sometimes laA is inserted after Oano, and is either redundant, or corroborative of the meaning of the verb, as in the case of Oana laA or OalRaA after manaEa.] It is said in the Kur ix. 32, wayaOobaI AllRhu UilRaA Oano yutimRa nawrahu, meaning But God will not consent or choose [save to complete, or perfect, his light]. (Bd.) And in the same xvii. 91, faOabay Oakovaru AlnaAsa UilRaA kufuwrFA, i. e. [But the greater number of men have not consented to, or chosen, aught] save denying [its truth, or disbelieving it]; this phrase with UilRaA being allowable because it is rendered by means of a negative. (Bd.) You also say, kaAna yaOobaI AllRaHoma [He used to refuse, or dislike, flesh-meat], (K,) or Oakola AllRaHomi [the eating of flesh-meat]. (Mgh.) And OabaI falaAnN AlmaMCi [Such a one refused, or disliked, water, or the water]: (S:) or OabaI mino Xurobi AlmaMCi [he refused, or voluntarily refrained from, the drinking of water, or the water]. (AAF, M.) And OabaI Ealayohi AlOamara, (Mgh, and Mtr. [author of the Mgh] in Har p. 483,) and Ealayohi taOabRaAhu↓, both signify He refused him his assent, or consent, to the thing, or affair. (Mtr ubi suprà, in Har.) Hence, (Mtr ubi suprà,) OabaI Ealayohi, (Mgh, and Mtr ubi suprà,) and Ealayohi taOabRaI↓, (T, S, and Mtr ubi suprà,) He was incompliant, or unyielding, to him; he resisted him, withstood him, or repugned him; syn. AimotanaEa (T, S, Mgh, and Mtr ubi suprà) Ealayohi: (T:) thus explained because the objective complement (AlOamora) is suppressed. (Mtr ubi suprà.)

Oabiyotu AlTRaEaAma, (K,) or mina AlTRaEaAmi, and AllRabani, (M, TA, [in a copy of the former of which the verb is written Abayotu, but this I suppose to be a mistranscription, on account of what here follows,]) like raDiyotu, (K,) inf. n. OabRaI, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) or UibRaI, (so in some copies of the K,) with kesr, and with the short final alif, (TA, [i.e. like riDRaI, but perhaps this may have been supposed to be the right reading only because the verb is likened to raDiytu, of which riDRaI is the most common inf. n.,]) I left, or relinquished, the food, (M, K,) and the milk, (M, TA,) without being satiated, or satisfied. (M, K.)
OabiIa AlfaSiylu, and OubiIa, inf. n. OabRaI, The young camel, or young weaned camel, suffered indigestion from the milk, and became affected with a dislike of food. (M, K.)
Oabayotu as syn. with Oabawotu: see the latter.

4. Mbayotuhu UiyRaAhu [in the CK, erroneously, Oabayotuhu] I made him to refuse it; or to refrain, forbear, abstain, or hold back, from it, voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice: (S: [this meaning being there implied, though not expressed:]) or I made him to dislike it, to be displeased with it, to disapprove of it, or to hate it: (M, K:) namely, water [&c.]. (S, M.) One says, fulaAnN baHorN laA buWobiI, (ISk, S, K, * [in the CK, erroneously, lA yuWobI,]) i. e., laA yajoEaluka taOobaAhu [Such a one is like a sea, or great river, that will not make thee to refuse it, or dislike it, &c.]; (K;) i. e., that will not fail, or come to an end, (ISk, S, K,) by reason of its abundance. (ISk, S.) In like manner one says, of any water, maMCN laA yuWobiI [Water that will not fail, or come to an end]. (TA.) And EinodanaA maMCN maA yuWobiI With us, or at our abode, is water that does not become scanty, or little in quantity. (Lh, T, M.) And MbaI AlmaMCu The water decreased, or became deficient. (AA, from El-Mufaddal.) And qaliybN laA yuWobiI A well that will not become exhausted: (IAar, M:) one should not say, yuWobaI. (M, TA.) In like manner, also, one says, kalaOa laA yuWobaI Herbage, or pasture, that will not fail, or come to an end. (S.) And Einodahu daraAhimu laA tuWobiI He has dirhems, or money, that will not fail, or come to an end. (TA.) And MbaI AlmaMCu signifies also The water [in a well] was, or became, difficult of access (AimotanaEa), so that no one was able to descend to it but by exposing himself to peril or destruction: (M:) if a drawer of water descend into the well, (T, TA,) and the water be altered for the worse in odour, (TA,) he expose himself to peril, or destruction. (T, TA.)
5. taOabRaI Ealayohi AlOamora: and tObRI Ealayohi alone: see 1, latter half of the paragraph.

UiboyapN A paucity, or deficiency, and revulsion, of the milk in the breast: (Fr, TS:) or a revulsion of the milk in the udder; (K;) but the saying “in the udder” requires consideration. (TA:) You say to a woman, when she has a fever on the occasion of childbirth, UinRamaA hcihi AlHumRaI UiboyapN vadoyika [This fever is only occasioned by the paucity, or deficiency, and revulsion, of the milk in thy breast.] (TA.)
OaboyaAnN and OaboyaAnu and OabayaAnN: see MbK, in four places.

OubaMCN, (T, S, M,) or OubaMCN mina AlTRaEaAmi, (K,) A dislike, or loathing, of food: (T, S, M, K:) of the measure fuEaAlN, (S, M,) with damm, (S, K,) because it is like a disease, and nouns significant of diseases are generally of that measure. (M.) You say, Oaxacahu OubaMCN (T, S, M, K) mina AlTRaEaAmi (K) He was, or became, taken, or affected, with a dislike, or loathing, of food. (T, S, M, K.)
UibaMCN inf. n. of OabaI, q. v. (S, M, &c.)
See also OubRiyRapN.
OabiIRN and OabiyapN: see MbK, in three places.

Also, the former (OabiIRN), She [app. a camel, or any beast,] that refuses, or refrains from, fodder, by reason of her suffering from indigestion: and she that refuses, or refrains from, the stallion, by reason of her having little appetency. (AA.) [See also OawaAbK, voce MbK.]
OabRaMCN A man who refuses, or does not submit, to be harmed, or injured. (T.)

OubiyapN, with damm, (K,) and kesr to the b, and with teshdeed of this letter and of the I, (TA,) [in the CK Auboyap,] Pride; self-magnification, or greatness, or majesty: (K:) and UibaMCN↓ [also] signifies pride, self-magnification, or haughtiness. (Ham p. 118.)

MbK, and OabiIRN↓, (S, M, Msb, K, TA,) and OabayaAnN↓,
(S, TA,) part. ns. of OabaI, signifying Refusing; or refraining, forbearing, abstaining, or holding back [voluntarily, or of his own free will or choice]: (S, Msb, TA: *) [refusing assent or consent; &c.:] disliking, being displeased with a thing, disapproving of it, or hating it: (M, * K, * TA:) or the first and second, a man disliking, or loathing, food: (M, K, TA:) and the third, (K,) and OaboyaAnN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) or ObayaAnN, (K,) a man who refuses, or refrains from, or dislikes, or hates, (yaOobaI,) food; or, things that are base, or mean, (M, K, TA,) and causes of dispraise or blame: (TA:) or the second (OabiIRN), a man who refuses, or refrains, &c., vehemently, or much; incompliant, unyielding, resisting, withstanding, or repugning: (T:) and OaboyaAnu↓ and OaboyaAnN, a man having vehement AbMC [app. OubaMC, i. e. dislike, or loathing, of food; agreeably with a common quality of words of the measure faEolaAn]: (T, TA: [but in copy of the T, accord. to the TT, AbMC in this last explanation is written AibMC: in the TA it is without any vowel-sign:]) the pl. of MbK is Mbuwna and OubaApN (M, K) and OubiIRN, (K,) with damm, then kesr, and then teshdeed, (TA, [in the CK AubaIR, and in a copy of the M Aubiyn,]) and OubRaMCN, (M, TA,) or UibMCN, (K, TA,) like rijaAlN: (TA: [in the CK AubAC:]) the pl. of OabiIRN↓ is OabiyRuwna; (M, K;) of which an instance occurs wherein the pl. n is likened to a radical n; the gen. case being written, at the end of a verse, Oabyiyni: (M:) the pl. of OaboyaAnN↓, (M,) or OabayaAnN, (K,) is UiboyaAnN. (Kr, M, K.)
[Hence,] AlMbiI The lion. (K.)

And MbiyapN, (M,) so in some copies of the K, but in others OabiyRapN↓, (TA,) She [app. a camel] that dislikes, or loathes, and will not drink, water: and she that desires not the evening-food: and she (a camel) that is covered and does not conceive, or become pregnant: (M, K:) and OawaAbK, [its pl.,] she-camels that refuse, or refrain from, the stallion. (TA. [See also OabiIRN.]) It is said in a prov., AlEaAXiyapN tahiyju AlMbiyapa [She that is eating her eveningfood, or pasturing in the evening, excites her that has no desire for that food]; i. e., when the camels that desire not the evening-food see the camels eating that food, they follow them, and pasture with them. (M, and so in the S in art. EXw.)
muWobK [act. part. n. of 4, q. v.] Water failing, or coming to an end: (TA:) or water that is scanty, or little in quantity.] (Lh, M, TA.)
maMCK maOobaApN, (M,) or maMCa pN maOobaApN, (K,) Water which the camels refuse, or dislike. (M, K.)

2. OatRabahaA UitobFA, (M, K, [but in the latter the pronoun is masc.,]) and biUtobK, (M,) or simply OtRbhA, (S,) inf. n. taOotiybN, (S, K,) He put on her, or clad her with, an Uitob: (S, M, K:) or OtRbhA signifies he put on her, or clad her with, a shift. (AZ, T.)
OutRiba, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) was made into an Atob. (M, K.)

5. tOtRb biOtobK, (M, K,) and AYttb↓, [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytataba], (M,) or AYtbR↓, (K, [but this I think a mistranscription,]) He put on himself, or clad himself with, an Uitob: (M, K:) or AYttbt↓, alone, she put on herself, or clad herself with, an Uitob. (AZ, T, S, M.)

tOtRb AldRiroEa wa AlsRilaAHa (assumed tropical:) He put on (i. e. on himself) the coat of mail, and the arms, or weapons. (A.) And tOtRb Alqawosa (assumed tropical:) He put forth his shoulderjoints from the belt of the bow, [the belt being across his breast,] so that the bow was on his shoulder-blades: (A:) accord. to AHn, (M,) taOatRubN signifies (assumed tropical:) a man's putting the suspensory of the bow across the breast, and putting forth the shoulder-joints from it, (M, K,) so that the bow is on the shoulder-joints: (M:) and you say also, tOtRb qawosahu EalaI Zahorih (assumed tropical:) [he put his bow in the manner above described upon his back]. (S.)
[And hence,] tOtRb signifies also (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself, or made himself ready, (K,) lilOamori [for the affair]. (TK.)
And (assumed tropical:) He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, hardiness, courage, or vehemence. (K.)
8: see 5, in two places.
9: see 5.

UitobN (T, S, M, A, K) and miYotabapN↓ (M, K) A baqiyr, (S,) or baqiyrap, (M, K,) i. e., (S, M, [but in the K what here follows is given as a meaning distinct from that of bqyrp,]) a burod [q. v.], (S, M, K,) or piece of cloth, (S, A,) which is slit (S, M, A, K) in the middle, (S,) and worn by a woman, (A, K,) who throws it upon her neck, (S, M,) [putting her head through the slit;] having neither an opening at the bosom (a jayob), nor sleeves: (S, M, A, K:) and a woman's shift: (T, M, K:) and, (K,) or accord. to some, (M,) a garment that is short, reaching half-way down the shank: (M, K:) or [a garment like] drawers, or trousers, without legs; (M, K;) i. q. nuqobahN: (M:) or a shirt without sleeves, (S voce baqiyrN, M, K,) worn by women: (S ubi suprà:) the first explanation alone is given in most lexicons: (TA:) some say that it is different from the UizaAr; that it has no band like that of drawers or trousers, and is not sewed together after the manner of drawers or trousers, but is a shirt of which the two sides are not sewed together: (M:) or i. q. EiloqapN and SidaArN and XawocarN; all signifying one and the same thing: (T:) pl. [of pauc.] MtaAbN (M, K [in the CK and a MS. copy of the K written AatAbN]) [originally OaOotaAbN which is mentioned as one of the pls. by MF] and MtubN [originally OaOotubN which is also mentioned as one of the pls. by MF] and by transposition OatoWubN, (MF,) and [of mult.] OutuwbN, (S,) or UitaAbN, (M,) or both. (K.)
[Hence,] UtobN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The husk of barley. (M, K.)
miYotabN A [wrapper, or wrapping garment, such as is called] miXomalN. (T.)
miYotabapN: see UitobN.
muWatRabu AlZRufuri (assumed tropical:) A man whose nail is crooked. (K.)

1. OatomN, (M, K,) in, or in relation to, a siqaMC [or skin for water or milk], (TA,) signifies The having two punctures of a seam (xuzorataAni) rent so as to become one. (M, K.) You say, Oatamati AlqirobapN, aor.
Aatima
, inf. n. OatomN, The water-skin had its two punctures (xzrtAhA [or rather two of its punctures, agreeably with the explanation of the inf. n. in the M and K, as given above,]) rent so that they became one. (TK.)
[And hence,] The meeting together of the masolakaAni [or vagina and rectum]: whence OatuwmN [q. v.] as an epithet applied to a woman. (Ham p. 373.)

[It seems to be indicated in the T, that one says, Oatima AlnisaMCu, aor.
Aatama
, and Oatama, aor.
Aatima
; as meaning, or perhaps the former only, The women assembled, or came together: for I there find, immediately after maOotamN as signifying “a place in which women assemble,” “one says, Oatima, aor.
Aatama
, and Oatama, aor.
Aatima
: ” but it is then added that, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Yezeed, mOtm is from Oatima, aor.
Aatama
.]
I. q. fatoqN [The act of rending, rending asunder, ripping, or the like; or undoing the sewing of a thing]. (TA.)
The act of cutting. (Sgh, K.) You say, Oatamahu He cut it. (TK.)

Oatama, aor.
Aatima
, also signifies He brought together, or united, two things. (T.) [See OatuwmN, and maOotamN.]

Oatama biAlmakaAni, (Sgh, Msb,) with two forms of aor., [app.
Aatima
and
Aatuma
,] (Msb,) inf. n. OatomN, (Sgh, K,) or OutuwmN; (Msb;) and Oatima, aor.
Aatama
; (Msb;) He stayed, remained, dwelt, or abode, in the place. (Sgh, Msb, K.)
2: see 4.
4. MtamahaA, inf. n. UiytaMmN; and OatRamahaA↓, inf. n. taOotiymN; He rendered her such as is termed Oatuwm, q. v. (O, K.)
OatuwmN is primarily used in relation to the siqMC [or skin for water or milk; as meaning] Having two punctures of a seam (xurozataAni) rent so that they become one. (S.)

And hence, (S,) or from Oatama as meaning “he brought together, or united,” two things, (T,) A woman whose masolakaAni [or vagina and rectum] meet together in one, [by the rupture of the part between them,] (T, M,) becoming conjoined, so that the faroj is enlarged thereby, (TA,) on the occasion of devirgination; (M;) i. q. mufoDaApN, (T, S, M,) as some say; (T;) or mufaADapN; (K; [said in the TA to be a mistake: but mufoDaApN and mufaADapN are said in the M, in art. fyD, to have the same signification;]) a woman whose masolakaAni have become one: (Ham p. 271:) or, as some say, small in the faroja [or vagina]: (M:) or it has these two contr. significations. (K.)

maOotamN is a quasi-inf. n. of Oatama in the last of the senses explained above. (Msb.) [Thus it signifies A staying, remaining, dwelling, or abiding, in a place. But it more commonly signifies] The assembling of women [and of men also] in a case of rejoicing and of mourning. (Har p. 234.)
It is also a noun of time from the same. (Msb.) [Thus it signifies A time of staying or remaining, &c.]

And it is also a noun of place from the same. (Msb.) [And thus it signifies A place of staying or remaining, &c. But it more commonly signifies] A place of assembling of women [and of men also] in a case of rejoicing and of mourning: from Oatima, aor.
Aatama
, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Yezeed. (T.)

And hence, tropically, (Msb,) (tropical:) Women assembling together (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) in a case of rejoicing and of mourning, (T, M, Mgh, K,) or in a case of good and of evil: (S, Msb:) or any assembly, (M, K,) of men and of women, (M,) in a case of mourning or of rejoicing: (M, K:) or particularly of young women; (M, K,) accord. to some; but it is not so: and some assert that the word is derived from OatomN, in the first of the senses explained in this art.; and from OatuwmN, as an epithet applied to a woman; because it signifies women coming together, and meeting face to face, in a case of good and of evil: (M:) the pl. is maMtimu. (S, Mgh.) Abu-l-'Atà Es-Sindee says,

[In the evening when arose the wailing women to wail, and openings at the necks and bosoms of garments were rent with the hands of assembled mourning women, and cheeks also were lacerated]: (S, M, Mgh:) i. e., biOayodiI nisaMCK. (S.) And another says,

[So that thou seest them (referring to women) standing in his presence, or at, or by, it, like as thou seest the assembly of men around the prince, or commander]: AlmOtm here necessarily denoting men. (M.)

IKt says, (Msb,) it is used by the vulgar to denote An affliction, or evil accident; (S, Mgh, Msb;) [and Mtr adds,] and a wailing: (Mgh:) they say, kunRaA fiI maUotami falaAnK [meaning We were present at the affliction of such a one]: (S, Msb:) or kunRaA fiI maOotami baniy fulalnK [meaning, We were present at the affliction, and wailing, of the sons of such a one]: (Mgh:) but the correct word in this case, (S, Mgh,) or the better, (Msb,) is manaAHap: (S, Mgh, Msb:) so says IAmb. (Mgh.) But accord. to IB, nothing forbids that it may occur in the sense of A place of wailing; and in the sense of mourning, and wailing, and weeping; for therefore do women assemble: and thus it may be in the saying of Et-Teymee, respecting Mansoor Ibn-Ziyád,

L.foreign: fiI klRi daArK ranRapN wa zafiyru

sense.s: [The people's mourning, &c., for him was one: in every house was a moaning, and a sighting]: and in the saying of another,
i. e. [The daughters of the captives, when they were slain, became, in the early part of the day,] in a state mourning; and the beasts of prey, in a state of rejoicing. (TA.)

1. Oatana biAlmakaAni, (S, M, Msb, K, *) aor.
Aatuna
, (Msb,) or
Aatina
, (K,) inf. n. OutuwnN (M, Msb, K) and OatunN, (K,) He remained, continued, stayed, or abode, in the place; (S, M, Msb, K; *) or became fixed, or settled, therein. (M.)

10. AstOtn [lit.] He (an ass) became a she-ass. (M.) The saying, kaAna HimaArRaA faAsotaOotana, said of a man, [lit.] signifies [He was a he ass,] and he became a she ass; meaning (assumed tropical:) he was mighty, or of high condition, [like the wild he-ass,] and he became base, abject, or vile. (S, TA.)
Also, (S, TA,) or AstOtn OataAnRaA, (M,) He (a man) purchased a she-ass; (S;) he took for himself a she-ass. (S, M.)

OataAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and UitaAnN↓, (K,) but one should not say OataAnapN, (ISk, S, Msb,) or this is of rare occurrence, (K,) occurring in certain of the trads., (IAth,) A she-ass [domestic or wild]: (S, M, Msb, K:) pl. (of pauc., T, S, Msb) MtunN and (of mult., T, S, Msb) OutunN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OutonN and (quasi-pl. n., M) maOotuwnaMCu↓. (S, M, K.)
Hence, OataAnN signifies (tropical:) A foolish and soft or weak woman; as being likened to a she-ass. (TA.)

Also The station of the drawer of water at the mouth of the well; (S, M, K;) and so UitaAnN↓. (M, K.) And A rock, or great mass of stone, (AA, T, S, M,) in water; (AA, T, M;) or, as some say, at the bottom of the casing of a well, so that it is next the water. (AA, T.) And A large, round mass of rock, which, when it is in shallow water, is called OataAnu AlDRaHli; and a she camel is likened thereto, in respect of her hardness: (S:) or OataAnu AlDRaHli signifies a large mass of rock projecting from the water. (T:) or a mass of rock, (M, K, TA,) large and round, in the water, (TA,) at the mouth of the well, overspread with [the green substance called] TuHolub, so that it is smooth, (M, K, TA,) more smooth than other parts: (M, TA:) or a mass of rock, part of which is immerged (gaAmirN, M, K) in the water, (K,) and part apparent. (M, K.) And OataAnu AlvRamiyli signifies A large mass of rock in the interior of the water-course, which nothing raises or moves, of the measure of the stature of a man in length and likewise in breadth. (ISh.)
Also The [piece of wood called] qaAEidap [which is one of four forming the support] of the fawodaj [more commonly called hawodaj, q. v.]: pl. MtunN, (K, TA,) with medd. (TA: [but in the CK AutunN.])
UitaAnN: see OataAnN, in two places.

OatuwnN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and OatRuwnN, (K,) or, accord. to J, (Msb,) it is thus, with teshdeed, but pronounced without teshdeed by the vulgar, (S, Msb,) A certain place in which fire is kindled, (S, Mgh,) called in Persian kulaxon [or kuloxano], pertaining to a bath: and metaphorically applied to (tropical:) that in which bricks are baked, and called in Persian tuwnaqo and daAXuwzano [or simply tuwno and daAXo]: (Mgh:) accord. to Az, (Msb,) it is that of the bath, and of the place in which gypsum is made: (T, Msb:) or the trench, hollow, or pit, of the jayRaAra [or lime-burner, (in the CK, erroneously, the xabRAz,]) and of the preparer of gypsum; (M, K, TA;) and the like: (K:) the pl. [said in the TA to be of the latter, but it is implied in the T and M and Mgh that it is of the former,] is OataAtiynu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K, [in the CK, erroneously, AatAniyonu,]) by common consent of the Arabs, (Mgh,) with two ts, (T,) accord. to Fr, who says that they sometimes double a letter in the pl. when they do not double it in the sing., (T,) and accord. to IJ, who says that it seems as though they changed OatuwnN to OatRuwnN; (M;) and [of OatuwnN, as is said in the TA and implied in the M,] OutunN. (M, K.) [J says that] it is said to be post-classical; (S;) [and ISd says,] I do not think it to be Arabic. (M.)
maOotuwnaMCu: see OataAnN.

1. OataA, aor. yaOotuw; (Msb;) and Oatawotuhu, (T, S, M, K,) aor. Mtuwhu; (S;) inf. n. OatowN, (M, Msb,) or OatowapN, (S,) or the latter is an inf. n. of un.; (T, TA;) He came; (Msb;) and I came to him, or it; (S;) the former a dial. var. of OataI, aor. yaOotiI; (Msb;) and the latter, of Oatayotuhu. (T, S, M, K.) [See art. AtI, to which, as well as to the present art., belong several words mentioned in this.]
OataA, aor. as above, (TK,) inf. n. OatowN, (M, K, TK,) also signifies He pursued a right, direct, straight, or even, course, in going, or pace. (M, K, TK.)
And He (a man, TK) hastened, made haste, or sped; or he was quick, hasty, speedy, rapid, swift, or fleet. (M, K, TK.)

And Oatati AlnaAqapu, inf. n. as above, The she-camel returned her fore legs, [drawing the feet back towards the body, and lifting them high,] in her going. (M.) You say, maA OaHosana Oatowa yadaIo hcihi AlnRaAqapi, and OatoIa yadayohaA, How good, or beautiful, is this she-camel's returning of her fore legs in her going! i. e. rajoEa yadayohaA fiI sayorihaA. (T, * S, M.)
And OatowN signifies also The act of impelling, or propelling; particularly, of an arrow from a bow. (TA.) See also this word below.

Oatawotuhu, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. Mtuwhu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. UitaAwapN, (S, M, Msb, K,) so accord. to A'Obeyd, (M,) and mentioned by Sgh on the authority of AZ, (TA,) and OatowN, (S, TA,) [I gave him what is termed UitaAwap, as meaning the tax called xaraAj: this is the signification which seems to be indicated in the S: or] I bribed him; gave him a bribe. (M, Msb, K.) [See also UitaAwapN below.]

Oatati AlnRaxolapu, (T, S, M, K,) and AlXRajarapu, (M, K,) aor. taOotuw, (S,) inf. n. UitaMCN, with kesr, (Kr, M, K,) [in a copy of the T, and in two copies of the S, OataMCN, but this is said in the M to be a subst.,] and OatowN; (M, K;) and Alnxlp Mtati↓, inf. n. UiytaMCN; (T;) The palm-tree [and the tree]
bore: (S:) or put forth its fruit: or showed its being in a good state: (M, K:) or bore much: (T, M, K:) and AtMC signifies also the increasing, or thriving, of seed-produce. (T.)

And Oatati AlmaAXiyapN, inf. n. UitaMCN, [in a copy of the M OataMCN,] The cattle, or camels &c., increased, or yielded increase. (M, K. [In the CK, immediately before this phrase, wAlvRimAri is erroneously put for waAlnRamaMCu.])
taOotaI for tOotawiI: see 1 in art. AwI.
4: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.
OatowN an inf. n. of 1, q. v.

A way, course, mode, or manner. (M, K.) You say, of speech, or language, (M,) and of a speaker, or reciter of a xuTobap, (IAar, M,) maA zaAla EalaI Oatow waAHd It, and he, ceased not to follow one [uniform] way, &c. (M.)

An impulsion; a propulsion; particularly an act of shooting an arrow from a bow: so in a trad., where it is said, kunRaA naromiI AlOatowayoni We used to shoot one shooting and two shootings; meaning, of arrows from bows, after the prayer of sunset. (TA.)

Death: or [so in the T, but in the K “and,”] a trial; or an affliction. (T, K.) You say, OataI EalaI fulaAnK OatowN Death came upon such a one: or a trial; or an affliction. (ISh, T.) And Uino OataI EalRaI OatowN fagulAmiI HurRN If I die, [or if death befall me,] my slave shall be free. (T.)
A vehement sickness or disease: (T, K:) or the fracture of an arm, or of a leg. (T.)
A gift. (S, K.)

Butter; (S;) as also OataMCN↓, (A,) or UitaMCN↓. (TA: [in which it is said to be like kitaAbN; but this I think a mistake: see OataMCN below.]) You say, when a skin of milk is agitated, and its butter comes, qado jaMCa Oatowuhu [Its butter has come]. (S, TA.) And you say, labanN cuw AtMCK↓ Milk having butter. (A, TA.)
A great body or corporeal form or person (XaxoSN EaZiymN). (AZ, Sgh, K.)
OatowapN A single coming; as also OatoyapN. (T.)

OatowaAnu a corroborative [or imitative sequent] of OasowaAnu, which signifies grieving mourning, or sorrowful: (TA:) or i. q. HariySN [vehemently desirous; eager; &c.]. (Mirkát el-Loghah, cited by Golius.)

OataMCN, (T, S, M,) or UitaMCN, like kitaAbN, (K, [but it is said in the M that the former is a subst. and the latter an inf. n.,] Increase; syn. namaMCN, (S, M, K, [in the CK wAlvRimaAri is erroneously put for waAlnRamaMCu,]) and barakapN: (S:) increase, and produce, or net produce, of land; as though from AlUitaAwapN signifying AlxaraAju: (TA:) gain, or revenue, arising from the increase of land, or from the rent thereof, or the like: (TA, and so in a copy of the S:) the produce of land, and fruits, &c.: (As, T:) what is produced of the fruits (MkaAl [in the CK AukAl]) of trees: (M, K:) the fruit of palm-trees. (S.)
See also OatowN, in three places.

OatiIRN (S, M, Sgh, K) and OutiIRN [respecting which see what follows] and UitiIRN, (Sgh, K,) of all which, the first is said by A'Obeyd to be the form used by the Arabs, (TA,) [and all belong to art. AtI, as well as to the present art.,] and OataAwiIRN↓ (M, Sgh, K) and OutaAwiIRN and UitaAwiIRN, (Sgh, K,) all these, and the three preceding them, mentioned by Sgh on the authority of AA, but the last of all said by him to be strange, (TA,) A rivulet for which a man makes a way or channel, or an easy course or passage, to his land: (S, M, K:) or a torrent, or flow of water, from another region or quarter: (M, K: [both these meanings mentioned in the M in art. Atw, and the former in art. Aty also, of that work:]) or OatiIRN signifies a conduit of water; and any channel in which water is made to have an easy course; as also OutiIRN, mentioned by Sb; or, as some say, this is a pl.: (M:) or any rivulet: (As, T:) or a rivulet less than the [trench called] nuWoI: (IB:) and sayolN OatIRN (Lh, T, S, M) and OataAwiIRN, (Lh, S, M,) a torrent, or flow of water, that comes one knows not whence: (M:) or that comes when the rain that has produced it has not fallen upon the people to whom it comes: (Lh, S, M:) or that comes from a land upon which rain has fallen to a land upon which rain has not fallen. (T, Msb.)

Hence, (T, M,) or the reverse is the case, (T, M, Msb,) all the words above, (AA, T, K,) or OatiIa and OataAwiIRu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, [the last said in the T to be the most approved,]) A stranger; or a man not of one's own people, or not of one's own kindred: (AA, T, S, M, Mgh:) or a man who asserts his relation to a people of whom he is not: (Msb:) or OatiIRN signifies one who is among a people of whom he is not: (As, T:) and OataAwiIRN, a stranger, who is not in his own country; or, accord. to Ks, a stranger, who is not in his own home: (T:) the pl. of this last is OataAwiyRuwna: (S:) [the fem. sing. is OataAwyRapN:] and the pl. fem. OataAwyRaAtN. (T, S, M.)

UitaAwapN i. q. xaraAjN [i. e. A tax, a tribute, or an impost], (T, S, M, K,) such, for instance, as is levied on land, (TA in the present art.,) and such as is imposed on a slave; (TA in art. Drb;) and any tax or other exaction that is taken by compulsion, or against the will, or that is apportioned to a people: (M: [in the TA “to a place” instead of “to a people:”]) and also, a bribe: or, (accord. to some, M,) particularly, a bribe for water: (M, K:) the pl. is OataAwaI, (T, M, K, TA, [but in some copies of the K OataAwiIRu, and accord. to copies of the S it is OataAwK, being written, with the article, AlOataAwiI; both of which appear to be wrong; for it is said to be] like EalaAwaI and haraAwaI, pls. of EilaAwapN and hiraAwapN, (M, TA,) and like sakaAraI; (TA;) changed, [in the accus. case, with the article prefixed,] at the end of a verse, into AlOataAwiyaA, for the sake of the rhyme: (M, TA:) this occurs in a verse of El-Jaadee: (S:) it has also for a pl. UitaAwaAtN, (T,) and OutRay, [in the CK, erroneously, AatiIRN,] which is extr., (M, K,) as though its sing. were OutowapN, being like ruXRaI, pl. of ruXowapN, (M,) and like EurRaI, pl. of EurowapN. (TA.) You say, OadRaI UitaAwapa OaroDihi [He payed the tax of his land]; i. e. xaraAjahaA: and Duribato Ealayohimu AlUitaAwapu [The tax, or tribute, or impost, was imposed upon them]; i. e. AljibaAyapu: and some assert it to be tropical. (TA.) You say also, Xakama faAhu biAloUitaAwapi [He stopped (lit. bitted) his mouth with the bribe]; i. e. baAlRriXowapi. (TA.)
OataAwiIRN and its vars.: see OatIRN, above.

1. OataI, aor. yaOotiI, (Msb,) and, in the dial. of Hudheyl, yaOot, without I; (S;) and Oatayotuhu, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) [aor. Mtiyhi;] and in the imperative, some of the Arabs say, ti, suppressing the A, like as is done in xuco and kulo and muro; (IJ, M;) inf. n. UitoyaAnN, (T, S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb.) and UitoyaAnapN, (M, K,) which should not be used as an inf. n. of un., unless by a bad poetic licence, (Lth, T,) and OatoIN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OutiIN and UitiIN and maOotaApN; (M, K;) He [or it] came; (Msb;) and I came to him, or it; (S, M, Mgh, * Msb, K;) or was, or became, present at it, namely, a place: (Mgh:) as also OataA, aor. yaOotuw; (Msb;) and Oatawotuhu, (T, S, M, K), aor. Mtuwhu: (S:) for which reason, we assign the generality of the words mentioned in art. Atw to the present art. also. (M.) [Accord. to the authorities here indicated for the signification of OataI, this verb and jaMCa are syn.: some attempt to distinguish them; but contradict one another in so doing: the slight distinctions that exist between them will be best seen by a comparison of the exs. in this art. with those in art. jyO:] accord. to Er-Rághib, the proper [or primary] signification of AlUitoyaAnu is The coming with ease. (TA.)

OataAhaA, (Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. UitoyaAnN, (Msb,) [lit. He came to her,] means (assumed tropical:) he lay with her; syn. jaAmaEahaA; (Mgh, Msb;) namely, a woman, (Mgh,) or his wife. (Msb.) Hence an expression in the Kur xxvi. 165. (TA.)
OataI Alqawoma [He came to the people: and hence,] he asserted his relationship to the people, not being of them. (Msb.) [See OatiIRu in art. Atw.]

Oatay bihi [He came with, or brought, him, and it; or] he made him (a man), and it (a thing, such, for instance, as property), to come. (Kull.) [See also 4: and see, in what follows, other significations of OataI trans. by means of bi. Hence, OataI biwaladK He begot a child, or children. And Oatato bihi She brought him forth; gave birth to him.] Accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, the meaning of the words in the Kur [ii. 143] OayonamaA takuwnuwA yaOoti bikumu AllRehu jamiyEFA is, Wherever ye be, God will bring you all back unto Himself. (M.) [You say also, OataI bibayRinapK He adduced a proof.] See also 3.

OataI AlOamora [He entered into, engaged in, or occupied himself with, the thing, or affair: and, as also OataI bihi,] he did, executed, or performed, the thing, or affair; (M. K;) and in like manner, AlcRanoba, [and baAlcRanobi,] the crime, sin, or offence. (M.) It is said in the Kur [ix. 54], walaA yaOotuwna AlSRalaApa UilRaA wahumo kusaAlaI, meaning And they do not enter into, or engage in, prayer, unless when they are heavy, or sluggish. (TA.) And you say, OataI AlfaAHiXaha, [and biAlfaAHiXapi,
(see Kur iv. 23 and lxv. 1,)] He entered into, engaged in, or occupied himself with, [or he did, or committed,] that which was excessively foul or evil. (TA.) And OataI biAljayRidi mino qawolK Oawo fiEolK [He said, gave utterance to, uttered, or expressed, or he brought to pass, did, or effected, what was good, or excellent; he said, or did, well, or excel-lently]. (Msb in art. jwd.) And OataI bijaroIi baEoda jaroIK[He (a horse) performed, or fetched, run after run]. (S in art. tOm, &c.)

walaA yufoliHu AlsRaAHiru Hayovu OataI[in the Kur xx. 72] means Hayovu kaAna [And the enchanter shall not prosper where he is, or wherever he may be]; (M, Bd, K;) and where he cometh: (Bd:) or Hayovu OataI bisiHorihi[where he cometh with his enchantment; or where he performeth his enchantment]: (Jel:) and it is said to mean that where the enchanter is, he must be slain: such is the doctrine of the lawyers. (M.)

Z mentions that OataIoccurs in the sense of SaAra [He, or it, became; like as we sometimes say, he, or it, came, or came to be]; like jaMCain the saying, jaMCa AlbinaMCu muHokamFA. (Kull.) [So you say, AlbinaMCu muHokamFA The building became, or came to be, firm, strong, or compact.]

The saying, in the Kur [xvi. 1], OataI Oamoru MllRehi falaA tasotaEojiluwhumeans [The threatened punishment ordained of God hath approached: therefore desire not ye to hasten it:] its coming hath approached. (TA.) [And in like manner,] OutiIa fulaAnN, like EuniIa, means Such a one was approached by the enemy come in sight of him. (K.) Outiyta yaA fulaAnN[Thou art approached &c., O such a one,] is said when one is warned of an enemy that has come in sight of him. (Sgh, TA.) And OataI Ealayohimu AlEaduwRumeans The enemy came to them, [or came down upon them, for, as MF observes, OataIwhen trans. by means of EalaIseems to imply the meaning of nazala,] overcoming, or overpowering, them. (Bd in xviii. 40.)

Hence, OataI Ealayohi[and OataAhu, as will be seen by what follows,] (assumed tropical:) He destroyed him, or it. (Bd ubi suprà.) And hence, from UitoyaAnu AlEaduwRi, (Mgh,) OataI Ealayohi AldRahoru(tropical:) Time, or fortune, destroyed him. (M, Mgh, Msb, K.) Destruction is meant in the Kur [lix. 2], where it is said, fOatAhumu AllRehu mino Hyovu lamo yaHotasibuwA(assumed tropical:) [But God brought destruction upon them whence they did not reckon, or expect]. (EsSemeen, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [xvi. 28], faOataI AllRehu bunoyaAnahumo mina AlqawaAEidi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) But God removed their building from the foundations, and demolished it upon them, so that He destroyed them. (TA.) OataI Ealayohialso signifies (assumed tropical:) He caused it to come to an end; made an end of it; consumed it; [devoured it;] exhausted it; came to, or reached, the end of it; namely, a thing; (Kull;) as, for instance, what was in a bowl; (K in art. jrdm;) and what was in a vessel; (K in art. jrjb;) like faraga minohu: (ISd cited in the TA in art. nkX:) or i. q. marRa bihi[which may be rendered he went away with it; but this, as an explanation of OataI Ealayohi, has another meaning, which see in what follows]. (Kull.) And one says, OutiIa fulaAnN mino maOomanihi(assumed tropical:) Destruction came to such a one from the quarter whence he felt secure. (TA.) And OutiIa Ealay yadi fulaAnK(assumed tropical:) Property belonging to such a one perished. (T.) And yuWotaI duwnahu(assumed tropical:) He is taken away, or carried off, and overcome. (TA.) A poet says,

meaning (assumed tropical:) [Misfortunes, in the footsteps of which were misfortunes,] took away [what was sweet, of life, and rendered it bitter]. (TA.) One says also, mino hehunaA Outiyato, [so I find it written, but I think that the last word should be Outiyta, agreeably with a preceding phrase from the T,] (assumed tropical:) Hence the trial, or affliction, came in upon thee. (Mgh.) And OutiIa mino jihapi kacaA, with the verb in the passive form, (assumed tropical:) He missed [his object in respect of such a thing] by laying hold upon it when it was not fit to be laid hold upon. (Msb.) And OutiIa AlrRajulu, [also] like EuniIa, (assumed tropical:) The man was deceived, or deluded, and his faculty of sense became altered to him, so that he imagined that to be true which was not true. (TA.)

OataI Ealayohi is also syn. with marRa bihi[meaning He, or it, (as, for instance, a period of time,) passed by him, or over him]. (Msb.) You say, Oata Ealayohi HawolN[A year passed over him; or he became a year old]. (S, K, Msb, in art. Hwl; &c.)
Oatati AlnRaAqahu, and maA OaHosana OatoIa yadaI hcihi AlnRAqapi: see art. Atw.

2. OtRI lilmaMCi, (T, S, M,) or AlmaMCa, (K,) or both, (TA,) inf. n. taOotiyapNand taOotiIRN, He smoothed, made easy, or prepared, (sahRala, S, K, or hayRaOa, T,) the way, course, passage, or channel, of the water, (T, S, K,) in order that it might pass forth to a place; (S;) he directed a channel for it (M, TA) so that it ran to the places wherein it rested or remained. (TA.) And OtRI liOaroDihi OatiyRaA He made a rivulet, or a channel for water, to run to his land. (M.)

OtRI AllRehu lifulaAnK Oamorahu, inf. n. taOotiyapN, (T, M, * TA,) God prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a good or right state, [and thus rendered feasible or practicable or easy,] for such a one, his affair. (M, * TA.)

3. MtaAhu, [inf. n. as below,] He requited, compensated, or recompensed, him. (M, K.) The saying, in the Kur [xxi. 48], waUino kaAna mivoqaAla bihaA HabRapK mino xarodalK OatayonaA↓, some read thus, (M, * TA,) meaning [Though it be the weight of a grain of mustard,] we will bring it [forward for requital]: others read bhA MtayonaA↓, meaning we will give [a recompense] for it; in which case the verb is of the measure OafoEala: or we will requite for it; in which case the verb is of the measure faAEala. (M, TA.)

Mtayotuhu EalaI AlOamori, (T, S, M, Msb,) inf. n. muWaAtaApN, (T, S,) I agreed with him, or was of one mind or opinion with him, upon, or respecting, the thing, or affair; I complied with him respecting it; (T, S, M, Msb;) in a good manner: (T:) the vulgar say, waAtayotuhu: (S:) this is of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, inf. n. muwaAtaApN; and is the form commonly current: (Msb:) but it should not be used, except in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen. (T.)
[Hence, app., MtaIas meaning He aided; a signification mentioned by Golius, on the authority of Z and Ibn-Maaroof.]

4. MtaAhu, (S, M, &c.,) inf. n. UiytaMCN, (TA,) i. q. OataI[He came with, or brought, him, or it]; (S;) he made it (a thing) to come, Uilayohi to him; (TA;) he made, or caused, him, or it, to be present; (Ksh, TA;) he made, or caused, it (a thing) to go, pass, or be conveyed or transmitted, (syn. saAqahu,) Uilayohi to him. (M, K.) It is said in the Kur [xviii. 61], MtinaA gadMCa naA, i. e. AiytinaA[Come thou to us with, or bring thou to us, our morningmeal]. (S.)

Hence, (Ksh, TA,) inf. n. as above, (T, S,) He gave him (T, S, M, Msb, K) a thing, (M, K,) or property: (Msb:) and you say, haAtiin the sense of the [imperative] Mti[give thou]. (T.) We read in the Kur. [v. 60, &c.] wayuWotuwna AlzRakaApa[And they give the portion of property which is the due of the poor]. (TA.) And in [xxvii. 23 of] the same, waOuwtiyato mino kulRi XaIoCK, meaning And she hath been given somewhat of everything. (M, TA.) [You say also, OuwtiIa kacaA as meaning He was gifted, or endowed, with such a thing; as, for instance, a faculty.] See also 3.

Mtayotu AlmukaAtaba I made a gift to the slave between whom and me was a contract that he should become free on payment of a certain sum: or I abated, or took off, somewhat of his appointed part-payments, or instalments. (Msb.)

maA MtaAkumu AlrRasuwlu, in the Kur lix. 7, means What the Apostle giveth you, of the [spoil termed] faIoC, (Bd, Jel,) &c.: (Jel:) or what command he giveth you: (Bd:) or what he commandeth you [to receive]. (Kull.)

OuwtiIa fiI XaIoCK A dispute, or an altercation, was held before him, respecting the meaning of a thing: [perhaps more properly signifying he was given authority to decide respecting a thing:] occurring in a trad. (Mgh.)

5. tOtRI lahu It (an affair, T, Mgh, Msb, K, or a thing, S, M) was, or became, prepared, disposed, arranged, or put into a good or right state, for him; (T, * S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) and hence, it (a thing) was, or became, feasible or practicable, and easy, to him; (Mgh;) it (an affair) was, or became, facilitated, or easy, to him; (Msb;) the way thereof (i. e. of an affair) was, or became, facilitated, or easy, to him. (TA.) The following is an ex.:

[Fortune became well, or rightly, disposed for him, so that he became restored to wealth, or competence]: (T:) or taOatRaI lahu Alxayoru Alx[good fortune, or prosperity, became prepared, &c., for him, &c.]. (So in the TA.) And hence the saying, hecaA mimRaA yataOatRaI liIa AlmaDogu This is of the things which it is feasible or practicable, and easy, to me to chew. (Mgh).

He applied himself to it with gentleness, (As, S, K,) and so tOtRI lahaA, meaning liHaAjatihi, to his needful affair or business, (T,) and entered into it, engaged in it, occupied himself with it, did it, executed it, or performed it, by the
way, or manner, proper, or suitable, to it. (As, T, S, K. [In the CK, for OataAhu mino wajohihi, we find AtAhu En wajohih.]) And tOtRI fiI Oamrihi He used gentleness, or acted gently, in his affair. (Msb.)
tOtRI lahu bisahomK HatRaI OaSaAbahu He sought him leisurely or repeatedly [with an arrow, app. taking aim in one direction and then in another, until he hit him]. (Z, TA.)

jaMCa fulaAnN yataOatRaIis explained by Fr as meaning yataEarRaDu limaEoruwfika[Such a one came, or has come, addressing, or applying, or directing, himself, or his regard, or attention, or mind, to obtain thy favour, or bounty]. (S.) And you say, tOtRI limaEruwfihi, meaning taEarRaDa lahu[He addressed, applied, or directed, himself, &c., to obtain his favour, or bounty]. (TA.)
Some say that tOtRIsignifies He prepared himself to rise, or stand. (TA.)
10. AstMtI flaAnAF He asked such a one to come, deeming him slow, or tardy. (K.)
AstOtt AlnRaAqapu The she-camel desired to be covered; (A, TA;)IE desired the stallion; (S, M, K;) being excited by lust. (S, A.)
UitRaI: see OatiIRN.
OatoyapN A single coming; as also OatowapN; but not UitoyaAnapN↓, unless by a bad poetic licence. (T.)
See also OutiyRapu AljurHi.
UitoyaAnN is either an inf. n. of OataI, or a simple subst. [signifying A coming]. (Msb.)
UitoyaAnapN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: (M, K:) see also OatoyapN.
OataMCN or UitaMCN: see OtiIRN.
OatiIRN as syn. with OtaAwiIRN: see art. Atw.

Also, (M, and so in some copies of the K, where it is said to be like raDiIRN,) or UitFI↓, like riDFI, (so in other copies of the K,) and OataMCN↓, (M, K,) written by some UitaMCN, (TA,) What falls, of wood or leaves, into a river: (M, K:) from AlUitoyaAnu: (M:) pl. MtaMCN[in the CK AitAC] and OutiIRN. (M, K.)

rajulN OatiIRN A man who is sharp, energetic, vigorous, and effective, in affairs; who applies himself to them with gentleness, and enters into them, or performs them, by the way, or manner, proper, or suitable, to them. (M.)
farasN OatiIRN: see musotaOotK.

OutiyRapu AljuroHi, (so in a copy of the M,) or OutRiyRatuhu↓, (so in some copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) or Oatoyatuhu↓, (so in other copies of the K,) and Mtiyatuhu↓, (so in the M, and in some copies of the K,) or UitRiyatuhu↓, (so in some copies of the K, and accord. to the TA,) or OatiyRatuhu, (so in a copy of the K,) The matter which comes from the wound: (M, K:) from Aboo-'Alee. (TA.)
OatRaI i. q. HatRaI; (K;) a dial. var. of the latter. (TA.)
Uitiyatuhu AljurHi and OutRyRatuhu: see OutiyRapu AlMjuroHi.
MtK [Coming; (see also maOotiIRN;) applied to a man, &c.; and to time, meaning future: also a comer:
and hence,] An angel. (Mgh, Msb.)
Mtiyapu AljurHi: see OutiyRapu AljuroHi.
maOotFI A place of coming. (Msb.) [And maOotaApF↓ signifies the same: or A road, or way, by which one comes; a way of access; an approach; as also maOotFI: or, more properly, a means of coming.]
maOotaI AlmaroOapi[The place of access of the woman; i. e. the meatus of her vagina; or her vagina itself;] the maHiyD, or place of menstruation, of the woman. (Zj in the TA in art. HyD.)

maOotaIi AlOamriand maOotaAtuhu↓ The way, or manner, (wajoh, S, or jihap, M, K,) of the affair, (S, M, K,) by which it is, or is to be, entered into, engaged in, done, executed, or performed; like as you say maEonay AlkalaAmiand maEonaAtuhu, meaning the same by both. (S.) You say, Oatayotu AlOamora mino maOotAhuand maOotaAtihi↓, (S, M,) i. e., mino wajohihi AlRaciy yuWutaI minohu[I entered into, engaged in, did, executed, or performed, the affair by the way, or manner, whereby it should be entered into, &c.], (S,) or mino jihatihi [which means the same]. (M.)
muWotFI: see musotaOotK.
maOotaApF: see maOotFI, in three places.

maOotiIRN [pass. part. n. of 1; Come: come to:] is of the measure mafoEuwlN; the wbeing changed into Iand incorporated into the Iwhich is the final radical letter. (S.) In the saying, in the Kur [xix. 62], UinRahu kaAna waEoduhu maOotiyRFA, the meaning is MtiyFA↓ [Verily that which He hath promised, or the fulfilment of his promise, is coming]; like as, in the phrase HijaAbFA masotuwrFA, in the Kur [xvii. 47], saAtirFA is meant: or it may be a pass. part. n. [in signification as well as form]; for what cometh to thee, of that which God commandeth, thou comest thereto. (S.) It is said in a prov., maOotiIRN Oanota OayRuhaA AlsRawaAdu[lit. Thou art come to, O thou person], meaning there is no escape for thee from this event. (TA.)
Applied to a man, it also signifies OutiIa fiyhi[in a sense indicated in the Kur xxvi. 165]. (TA.)

TariyqN miYotMCN A road to which people come (Th, M, Mgh, Msb) much, or often; (Mgh, Msb;) the latter word being of the measure mifoEaAl, (Th, M, Mgh, Msb,) originally miYotaAINor miYotaAwN; (Msb;) from Oatayotu, (Th, M,) or AlUitoyaAnu; [or from Oatawotu;] like daArN miHolAalN, i. e. a house where people alight or abide much, or often: (Mgh, Msb:) a road that is frequented (S, M, K) and conspicuous: (M, K:) in [some of] the copies of the K, incorrectly, miYotaMCapN: (TA:) A' Obeyd has inadvertently written it without [the radical] C, and in the category of fiEolaMCN. (M.) Death is thus termed in a trad., as being a way which every one travels: (TA:) and as that trad. is related, it is without [the radical] C. (M.)

mYotaMCN AlTRariyqi The main part, or middle, of the road; or the part of the road along which one travels: (Sh, TA:) or the space within which the road is comprised; (S, Msb, K;) as also miydaMCu AlTryqi: (TA:) or this last, as also miytaMCu AlTryqi, signifies the measure of the two sides, and the distance, of the road. (L in art. myt.)
miYotaMCNalso signifies The extreme limit of the distance to which horses run; (S, Msb;) and so miydaMCN. (S, TA.)

And i. q. tiloqaMCN(K.) You say, daAriI bimYotaMCi daAri fulaAnK My house is opposite to the house of such a one; facing it, or fronting it; and so bimiydaMCi diArihi; (S;) and bimiytaMCi daArihi. (L in art. myt.)

And banaI Alqawomu buyuwtahumo EalaI miYotaMCK waAHidK(S) and miydaMCK waAHidK(S, and L in art. myd,) The people built their houses, or constructed their tents, after one mode, manner, fashion, or form. (L in art. myd.)
rajulN miYtaMCN A man who requites, compensates, or recompenses; who gives much, or largely. (M, K.)

farasN musotaOotK, and OatiIRN↓, and muWotFI↓, and mstwtI, [so I find it written, perhaps for musotawotK, which may be a dial. van. of musotOotK, like as waAtayotuhuis of Mtayotuhu,] A mare desiring the stallion. (TA.)

1. OavRa, aor.
Aaviva
(T, S, M, L, K) and
Aavuva
and a, (M, L, K,) inf. n. OavaAvapN(T, S, M, L, K) and OavaAvN(M, L, K) and OuvuwvapN, (M,) or OuvuwuvN, (L, K,) It (anything) was, or became, much in quantity, abundant, or numerous: and great, or large: (M, L:) it (herbage, or a herb,) was, or became, abundant, or plenteous, and tangled, or luxuriant; (T, S, K;) or abundant and tall: (M:) it (hair) was, or became, abundant and long. (M, TA.)

OavRato, (M, K,) aor.
Aavuva
, inf. n. OavRN, (M,) said of a woman, She was, or became, large in the hinder parts. (M, K.)
2. OvRvhu He made it plain, level, smooth, soft, or easy to lie or ride or walk upon. (M, K.)

5. tOvRv He obtained, or acquired, goods, household-goods, or furniture and utensils and the like; or abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life; (S;) or property; (S, M;) or wealth; or what was good. (M.)
OavRN, fem. with p: see OaviyvN, in two places.

OavaAvN Goods; or utensils and furniture of a house or tent; household-goods; syn. mataAEN; (T, M;) or mataAEu bayot; (S, Msb, K;) of whatever kind; consisting of clothes, and stuffing for mattresses or the like, or outer garments [&c.]: (M, TA:) or (so accord. to the M and K, but in the T “also,”) all property, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) [consisting of] camels, and sheep or goats, and slaves, and utensils and furniture or householdgoods: (AZ, T, S:) or abundant property: or abundance of property: (M, TA:) [in which last sense it is an inf. n. used as simple subst.:] or what is made, or taken, for use, and i. q. mataAEN; not what is for merchandise: or what is new, of the utensils and furniture of a house or tent; not what is old and worn out: (TA:) [it is a coll.
gen. n., and] the n. un. is with Avr: (AZ, T, S, M, Msb, K:) or it has no n. un.: (Fr, T, S, Msb, K:) if you form a pl. from AvAv, you say, valaAvapu MvRapK, [originally OaOovivap, like OaToEimap, pl. of TaEaAm,] and OuvuvN kaviyrapN. (Fr, T.)

OaviyvN Much in quantity, abundant, or numerous: and great, or large: as also OavRN↓; (M, K;) which is, in my opinion, [says ISd, originally OavivN,] of the measure faEilN: (M:) the fem. is OaviyvapN: and the pl. is UivaAvNand OavaAYivu; (M, K; *) both being pls. of the masc. and of the fem.; (K;) or the latter is pl. of the fem. only; (M, * MF;) but the former is [pl. of the masc.,] like kiraAmNas pl. of kariymN, (TA,) and is pl. of the fem. also. (M.) You say, nabaAtN OaviyvN Herbage, or a herb, that is abundant, or plenteous, and tangled, or luxuriant: (T, S:) or abundant and tall. (M.) And XaEarN OaviyvN Hair that is abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant: (S:) or abundant (T, M) and long. (M.) And liHoyapN OaviyvapN, and OavRapN↓, A thick beard. (M, TA.) And AimoraOapN OaviyvapN A fleshy woman: (M, TA:) pl. OavaAYivu, (M,) signifying fleshy women; (S, M, K;) as also UivaAvN: (M:) or the former of these pls. signifies tall, full-grown, women. (K.)

OavaAviIRu i. q. OavaAfiIRu, (K,) i. e. The [three] stones which are set up and upon which the cooking-pot is placed: the [second] vis said to be a substitute for f, and some hold the hemzeh to be augmentative. (TA.)

1. Oavara xufRa AlbaEiyri, aor.
Aavura
, inf. n. OavorN, He made an incision in the foot of the camel [in order to know and trace the footprints]; as also OvRrhu↓. (M.) And Oavara AlbaEiyri He made a mark upon the bottom of the camel's foot with the iron instrument called miYovarap in order that the footprints upon the ground might be known: (T, TT:) or he scraped the inner [i. e. under] part of the camel's foot with that instrument in order that the footprints might be traced. (S.)

Oavara AlHadiyva, (T, S, M, A, &c.,) Eani Alqawomi, (M,) aor.
Aavura
(S, M, Msb, K) and
Aavira
, (M, K,) inf. n. OavorN(T, S, M, Msb, K) and OavaArahNand OuvorahN, (M, K,) the last from Lh, but in my opinion, [says ISd,] it is correctly speaking a subst., and syn. with maOovurahNand maOovarahN, (M,) He related, or recited, the tradition, narrative, or story, as received, or heard, from the people; transmitted the narrative, or story, by tradition, from the people: (T, S, * M, A, L, Msb, * K: *) or he related that wherein they had preceded [as narrators: so I render OanobaOahumo bimaA sabaquwA fiyhi, believing hmto have been inserted by a mistake of a copyist in the M, and hence in the L also:] from AlOavaru. (M, L.) [See OavarN.] You say also, Ovara Eanohu Alkaciba, meaning He related, as heard from him, what was false. (L, from a trad.)

OavorN, aor.
Aavura
, (M,) inf. n. OavorN, (M, K.) also signifies Multum inivit camelus camelam. (M, K.)

Oavira liloOamori, aor.
Aavara
, He applied, or gave, his whole attention to the thing, or affair, having his mind unoccupied by other things. (K.)
Oavira Ealay AloOamori He determined, resolved, or decided, upon the thing, or affair. (T, K.)
laqado Oavirotu Oano OafoEala kacaA w kacaA, (Lth, T, L,) inf. n. OavorNand OavarN, (L,) I have assuredly purposed to do such and such things. (Lth, T, L.)
See also 4.
And see 10.

2. OvRr fiyhi, inf. n. taOoviyrN, He, or it, made, (Msb,) or left, (M, K,) or caused to remain, (S,) an impression, or a mark, or trace, upon him, or it. (S, * M, Msb, K. *) It is said of a sword, [meaning It made, or left, a mark, or scar, upon him, or it,] and in like manner of a blow. (T, TA.) [Whence,] OavRara fiI EiroDihicross; [He scarred his honour]. (K in art. wxX.) You say also, OavRara biwajohihi wabijabiynihi AlsRujuwdu[Prostration in prayer made, or left, a mark, or marks, upon his face and upon his forehead]. (T, * TA.) See also 1, first sentence.
He, or it, made an impression, or produced an effect, upon him, or it; impressed, affected, or influenced, him, or it. (The Lexicons passim.)
OavRara kacaA bikacaA, (T, TT,) or Mvara↓, (K,) He, or it, made such a thing to be followed by such a thing. (T, TT, K. *)
4: see 2, last sentence.

[Hence, app.,] Mvrhu, (As, T, M, Msb,) inf. n. UiyvaArN, (As, T,) He preferred him, or it. (As, T, M, Msb, TA.) You say, Mvrhu Ealayohi He preferred him before him: so in the Kur xii. 91. (As, M.) And Mvarotu fulAanFA EalaI nafosiI[I preferred such a one before myself], from AlUiyvaAr. (S.) And qado Mvarotuka I have preferred for thee it; I have preferred to give thee it, rather than any other thing. (T.) And Mvara Oano yafoEala kacaA He preferred doing such a thing; as also Oavira↓, inf. n. OavarN; and Oavara. (M.)
Mvralso signifies He chose, or elected, or selected. (K.)
And Mvirhu He honoured him; paid him honour. (M, K.)
5. tOvRr It received an impression, or a mark, or trace; became impressed, or marked. (Msb.)
He, or it, had an impression made, or an effect produced, upon him, or it; became impressed, affected, or influenced. (The Lexicons passim.)
See also 8.
8. AYotavarahu, [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytavarahu,] and tOvRrhu↓, He followed his footsteps: (M, K:) or did so diligently, or perseveringly. (TA.)

10. AstOvr EalaI OaSoHaAbihi; (ISk, S, K;) and Ealayohimo Oavira↓, aor.
Aavara
; (K;) He chose for himself [in preference to his companions] (ISk, S, K) good things, (K,) in partition, (TA,) or good actions, and qualities of the mind. (ISk, S.) And AstOvr bAlXRaIoCi, (S, K,) or AlXRaIoCa, (Msb,) He had the thing to himself, with none to share with him in it: (S, Msb, K:) and the former signifies he appropriated the thing to himself exclusively, (M, K,) EalaI gayorihi in preference to another or others. (M.) It is said in a trad., UicaA AsotaOovara AllRehu biXaIoCK faAloha Eanuhu When God appropriateth a thing to Himself exclusively, then be thou diverted from it so as to forget it. (M.) And one says, AisotOovara AllRehu bifulaAnK, (and fulaAnFA, TA,) [God took such a one to Himself,] when a person has died and it is hoped that he is forgiven. (S, M, A, K.)

OavorN, (AZ, T, S, A, L, K, &c.,) said by Yaakoob to be the only form known to As, (S,) and OavarN↓, which is a form used by poetic licence, (M, L,) and OvorapN↓, (M, L, K,) and OuvurN↓, (M,) and OuvurN↓, which is in like manner a sing., not a pl., (T, L,) and OvorapN↓, (El-Leblee,) and Oaviyro↓, (K,) The diversified wavy marks, streaks, or grain, of a sword; syn. firinodN; (As, T, S, M, A, L, K;) and tasalosulN; and diybaAjapu; (AZ, T;) and its lustre, or glitter: (M, L:) pl. [of the first] Ouvuro: (T, M, L, K:) the pl. of OuvorapNis OuvarN. (El-Leblee.) Khufáf Ibn-Nudbeh Es-Sulamee says, [describing swords,]

[The furbishers polished them, and freed them from impurities, making them light: each of them preserving itself from the evil eye by means of its lustre]: i. e., each of them opposes to thee its firinod: (S, L:) yatoqiIis a contraction of yatRaqiI; and the meaning is, when a person looks at them, their bright rays meet his eye, so that he cannot continue to look at them. (L.)

OuvorN The scar of a wound, remaining when the latter has healed; (As, Sh, T, S, M, K;) as also OuvurN↓(S, K) and OavarN↓: (Sh, T:) pl. MvaArN, though properly UivaArN, with kesr to the A [but why this is said, I do not see; for MvaArNis a regular pl. of all the three forms of the sing.;] and UuvuwrNmay be correctly used as a pl. (Sh, T, L.)
A mark made with a hot iron upon the inner [i. e. under] part of a camel's foot, by which to trace his footprints: (M, K:) pl. OuvuwrN. (M.) [See also OuvorapN.]
Lustre, or brightness, of the face; as also OuvurN↓. (M, K.)
See OavorN.
See also UivorN.
UivorN: see OavarN, in three places:
and OavorN:
and see MvirN, in two places.

Also, (S, M, K,) and OuvorN↓, (M, K,) but the latter is disallowed by more than one authority, (TA,) What is termed the xulaASap[q. v.] of clarified butter: (S, M, K:) or, as some say, the milk when the clarified butter has become separated from it. (M.) [See also qiXodapN.]

OavarN A remain, or relic, of a thing; (M, Msb, K;) as of a house; as also OavaArapN↓: (Msb:) a trace remaining of a thing; and of the stroke, or blow, of a sword: (S:) see also OuvorN: a sign, mark, or trace; opposed to the Eayon, or thing itself: (TA:) a footstep, vestige, or track; a footprint; the impression, or mark, made by the foot of a man [&c.] upon the ground; as also UivorN↓: and an impress, or impression, of anything: (El-Wá'ee:) pl. MvaArNH(M, Msb, K) and UuvuwrN. (M, K.) [The sing. is also frequently used in a pl. sense: and the former of these pls. is often used to signify Remains, or monuments, or memorials, of anti-
quity, or of any past time.] It is said in a prov., laA OaTolubu OavarFA baEoda EayonK I will not seek a trace, or vestige, [or, as we rather say in English, a shadow,] after suffering a reality, or substance, to escape me: or, as some relate it, laA taTolubo seek not thou. (Har pp. 120 and 174.) And one says, qaTaEa AllRehu Oavarahu [May God cut short his footsteps]: meaning may God render him crippled: for when one is crippled, his footsteps cease. (TA.) And fulaAnN layaSoduqu Oavaruhu, and Oavarahu, Such a one, if asked, will not tell thee truly whence he comes: (M in art. Sdq:) a prov. said of a liar. (TA.) And xarajotu, (S, M, * K,) and jaYotu, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) fyi Oavarihi, and ↓, fy Uivorihi, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) the former of which is said by more than one to be the more chaste, (TA,) [but the latter seems to be the more common,] and EalaI Oavarihi, and ElI Uivorihi↓, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) I went out, (S, &c.,) and I came, (El-Wá'ee, Msb,) after him: (M, A, K:) or at his heel: (Expos. of the Fs:) or following near upon him, or hard upon him, or near after him, or following him nearly: (Msb:) as though treading in his footsteps. (El-Wá'ee.) And Oavara ciI Oaviyrayoni: see MvirN. (K.)

An impress or impression, a mark, stamp, character, or trace, in a fig. sense; an effect. (The Lexicons passim.) You say, EalaI maAXiyatihi OavarN HasanN Upon his camels, or sheep, or goats, is an impress of a good state, or condition; of fatness, and of good tending; like UiSobaEN. (TA in art. SbE.) And UinRahu laHasanu AlOavarifiI maAlihi Verily he has the impress of a good state, or condition, in his camels, or sheep, or goats; like Hasanu AlUiSobaEi, and Almasi. (TA ubi suprà.) And Ealayohi Oavaru kacaA He, or it, bears the mark, stamp, character, or trace, of such a thing. (The Lexicons passim.)
[The pl.] MvaArNalso signifies Signs, or marks, set up to show the way. (K.)
Also the sing., i. q. OavorN, q. v. (M, L.)
