He took his hand, or arm; meaning (assumed tropical:) he aided, or assisted, him: a phrase of frequent occurrence.] And Oaxaca EalaIyadi fulaAnK (assumed tropical:) He prevented, restrained, or withheld, such a one from doing that which he desired; as though he laid hold upon his hand, or arm: (L:) and Oaxaca EalaI yadihi duwna maA yuriyudhu [signifies the same]. (K in art. lgd.)
Also, inf. n. OaxocN, He took, or received; contr. of OaEoTay. (L.) [Hence,] Oaxaca Eanohu, (assumed tropical:) He received from him traditions, and the like. (TA passim.)
(assumed tropical:) [He took, or derived, or deduced, a word, a phrase, and a meaning.]

(tropical:) He took, received, or admitted, willingly, or with approbation; he accepted. (B, MF.) So in the Kur [vii. 198], xuci AlEafowa (tropical:) [Take thou willingly, or accept thou, superfluous property, or such as is easily spared by others]. (MF.) So too in the same [iii. 75], wa OaxactRumo Ealay celikumo UiSoriI (tropical:) [And do ye accept my covenant to that effect?]. (B.) [And in the phrases, OaxaconaA miyvaAqakumo biAlEamali bimaA fiy AltRawoAraApi, (Jel ii. 60,) and Ealay AlEamRli bmA fy AltwArp, (Idem ii. 87,) (assumed tropical:) We accepted your covenant to do according to what is in the Book of the Law revealed to Moses.] xuco Eanoka [is elliptical, and] means xuco maA Oaquwlu wadaE Eanoka AlXRaka wAlmirMCa (assumed tropical:) [Accept thou what I say, and dismiss from thee doubt and obstinate disputation]. (S, L.)

He took a thing to, or for, himself; took possession of it; got, or acquired, it; syn. HaAza; (Z, Er-Rághib, B;) which, accord. to Z and Er-Rághib and others, is the primary signification; (MF;) and HaSRala. (B.) [See also 8.]
[He took and kept;] he retained; he detained: as in the Kur [xii. 78], faxuco OaHadanaA makaAnahu [Therefore retain thou one of us in his stead]. (B.)

[He took, as meaning he took away. Hence,] Oaxaca minohu AlsRayoru Journeying, or travel, took from him strength; (AlquwRapa being understood;) weakened him. (Har p. 529.) And Oaxaca mina AlXRaAribi, (Mgh,) and mina AlXRaEari, (Msb,) He clipped, or cut off from, (Mgh, Msb,) the mustache, (Mgh,) and the hair. (Msb.)

He, or it, took by force; or seized: (B:) (assumed tropical:) he, or it, overcame, overpowered, or subdued: said by some to be the primary signification. (MF.) [See also Oaxacahu EalowRaA, &c., in art. Elw: and Oaxacahu mino fawoqu, &c., in art. fwq.] It is said in the Kur [ii. 256], laA taOoxucuhu sinapi wa laA nawomN (assumed tropical:) Neither drowsiness nor sleep shall seize [or overcome] Him. (B.) [And you say, Oaxacatohu riEodapN (assumed tropical:) A tremour seized, took, affected, or influenced, him. And Oaxacahu baTonuhu (assumed tropical:) His belly affected him with a desire to evacuate it.] You say also, Oaxaca fiyhi AlXRaraAbu (assumed tropical:) The wine affected him, or influenced him, so that he became intoxicated. (TA in art. vml.) And Oaxaca AlrRaOosa (Msb in art. swr, &c.) and Oaxaca biAlrRaOosi (K in art. HmI, &c.) (assumed tropical:) [It had an overpowering influence upon the head]; meaning wine. (Msb, K.) And Oaxaca biAlHaloqi [It (food, &c.) choked]. (IAar in art. nXb in the TA, and S in art. bXE, &c.) And laA yaOoxucu fiyhi qawolu qaAYilK (assumed tropical:) [Nothing that any one may say will have any power, or effect, or influence, upon him]; meaning that he obeyeth no one. (L in art. lyt.)

He took captive. (L, Msb, B.) So in the Kur [ix. 5], faQqotuluwA QlmuXorikiyna Hayovu wajadtRumuwhumo waxucuwhumo [Then slay ye the believers in a plurality of gods wherever, or whenever, ye find them, and take them captives]. (Bd, L, B.)
See also 2, in three places.

He gained the mastery over a person, and killed, or slew, him; (Zj, L;) as also Mxaca↓: (L:) or simply, (assumed tropical:) he killed, or slew. (B.) It is said in the Kur [xl. 5], wahamRato kRulu OumRapK birasuwlihimo liyaOoxucuwhu, meaning [And every nation hath purposed against their apostle] that they might gain the mastery over him, and slay him; (Zj, L;) or (assumed tropical:) that they might slay him. (B.)

(assumed tropical:) He (God, Msb) destroyed a person: (Msb, MF:) and (assumed tropical:) extirpated, or exterminated. (MF.) faOaxacahumu QllRehu bicunuwbihimo [in the Kur iii. 9 and xl. 22] means But God destroyed them for their sins. (Jel.)

(tropical:) He punished, or chastised; (L, Msb, B, K, MF;) as also Mxaca↓: (L, Msb, MF:) as in the phrases, Oaxacahu bicanobihi
(Msb, K *) and bihi Mxacahu↓, inf. n. of the latter muWaAxacapN, (S, L, Msb, K,) (tropical:) he punished, or chastised, him for his sin, or offence: (Msb:) and Ouxica bicanobihi means (assumed tropical:) he was restrained and requited and punished for his sin, or offence: (L:) or, accord. to some, Oaxaca signifies he extirpated, or exterminated; and Mxc↓ he punished, or chastised, without extirpating, or exterminating. (MF.) [For Mxc↓,] some say waAxaca, (S, L,) which is not allowable, (K,) accord. to some; but accord. to others, it is a chaste form; (MF;) of the dial. of El-Yemen, and used by certain of the seven readers [of the Kur-án] in the instance of laA yuwaAxicukumu QllRehu [ii. 225 and v. 91]; and the inf. N. in that dial. Is muwaAxacapN, and the imperative is waAxico. (Msb.)

(tropical:) He made a violent assault upon a person, and wounded him much. (K, TA.) [You say also, Oaxacahu bilisaAnihi, meaning (assumed tropical:) He assailed him with his tongue; vituperated him; spoke against him.]

[He took, took to, or adopted.] You say, Oaxaca Oaxacahumo and Uixocahumo &c.: see OaxocN, below. And Oaxaca fiI Tariyqi kacaA [He took such a road]: and Oaxaca Eano yamiynihi Oawo yasaArihi [he took the way by, or on, the right of him, or it, or the left of him, or it]. (S in art. nZr.) [And Oaxaca biAlHazomi, and fiy AlHazomi, (the former the more common, the latter occurring in art. HwT in the K,) (assumed tropical:) He took the course prescribed by prudence, discretion, precaution, or good judgment; he used precaution: and, like Oaxaca biAlvRiqahi, (assumed tropical:) he took the sure course in his affair.] And Oaxaca Hicorahu (assumed tropical:) He took care; became cautious, or vigilant. (Bd in iv. 73 and 103.) [And Oaxaca bimaA qaAla fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) He took to, or adopted and followed, or adhered to, what such a one said: see Har p. 367; where it is said that Axc when thus used is made trans. by means of b because it implies the meaning of taXabRava.]

He took to, set about, began, or commenced; as in the saying, Oaxaca yafoEalu kacaA He took to, set about, began, or commenced, doing such a thing; in which case, accord. to Sb, Axc is one of those verbs which do not admit of one's putting the act. part. n. in the place of the verb which is its enunciative: [i. e., one may not say faAEilFA in the place of yfEl in the phrase above:] and as in Oaxaca fiI kacaA He began, commenced, or entered upon, such a thing. (L.)

[It is used in a variety of other phrases, in which the primary meaning is more or less apparent; and several of these will be found explained with other words occurring therein. The following instances may be here added.]

TariyqN yaOoxucu fiI ramolapK [A road leading into, or through, a tract of sand]. (K in art. frz.) And Oaxaca bihimu AlTRariyqu fiI gayori AlmaHajRapi [The road lead them otherwise than in the beaten track]. (T * and A in art. bhrj.)

maA Oaxacatoka EayoniI munocu HiynK (assumed tropical:) My eye hath not seen thee for some time; like maAZafiratoka. (T in art. Zfr.) And maA fiy AlHaIRi OaHadN taOoxucuhu Eayoniy [explained to me by Ibr D as meaning (assumed tropical:) There is not in the tribe any one whom my eye regards as worthy of notice or respect by reason of his greatness therein]. (TA in art. jhr.)
Oaxacotu Einodahu yadaI, and maEorwfAF: see 8.

Oaxica, aor.
Aaxaca
, inf. n. OaxacN, (S, L, K,) He (a young camel) suffered heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from the milk: (S:) or became disordered in his belly, and affected with heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from taking much milk. (L.)
He (a camel, L, K, or a sheep or goat, L) became affected by madness, or demoniacal possession; (K;) or by what resembled that. (L.)

Oaxicato Eayonuhu, aor.
Aaxaca
, inf. n. OaxacN, His eye became affected by inflammation, pain, and swelling, or ophthalmia. (Ibn-Es-Seed, L, K. *)

Oaxuca, aor.
Aaxuca
, inf. n. OuxuwcapN, It (milk) was, or became, sour. (K.) [See MxicN.]

2. OaxRacatohu, (S, L, K, *) inf. n. taOoxiycN, (S, L,) She captivated, or fascinated, him, (namely, her husband,) and restrained him, by a kind of enchantment, or charm, and especially so as to withhold him from carnal conversation with other women; (S, * L, K, * TA;) as also Oaxacatohu↓; and Mxacatohu↓ [of which the inf. n. is app. UiyxaAcN]. (L, TA.) A woman says, OuWaxRicu jamaliI I captivate, or fascinate, my husband, by a kind of enchantment, or charm, and withhold him from other women. (L, from a trad.) And one says, of a man, yuWaxRicu Eani QmoraOatihi He withholds others [by a kind of enchantment, or charm,] from carnal conversation with his wife. (Msb.) The sister of Subh El-'Ádee said, in bewailing him, when he had been killed by a man pushed towards him upon a couch-frame, or raised couch, OaxactRu↓ Eanoka AlrRaAkiba waAlsRaAEiIa waAlmaAXiIa wAlqaAEida waAlqaAYima walamo Mxuco Eanoka AlnRaAYima [I withheld from thee by enchantment the rider and the runner and the walker and the sitter and the stander, and did not so withhold from thee the prostrate]. (L.) And one says of a beautiful garment, Alquluwba maOoxacahu Oaxaca↓ [It captivated hearts in a manner peculiar to it]: (K in art. HSr: [in the CK, incorrectly, Aaxacat and Alquluwbu:]) and Axc biqalobihi [He, or it, captivated his heart; or] he [or it] pleased him, or excited his admiration. (TA in art. Alh.)
OxRc AllRabana, inf. n. as above, He made the milk sour. (K.) [See MxicN.]
3. Mxc, inf. n. muWaAxacapN: see 1, in the middle portion of the paragraph, in five places.
4. Mxc, inf. n., app., UiyxaAcN: see 2.

8. AYtxc [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaxaca] occurs in its original form; and is changed into QtRaxaca [with the disjunctive alif AitRaxaca]; this being of the measure AftEl from Oaxocu, the [radical] C being softened, and changed into t, and incorporated [into the augmentative t]: hence, when it had come to be much used in the form of AftEl [thus changed], they imagined the [former] t to be a radical letter [unchanged], and formed from it a verb of the measure faEila, aor. yafoEalu; saying, taxica, aor. yatoxacu, (S, L, Msb, *) inf. n. taxacN and taxocN: (Msb:) and Qsotaxaca↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aisotaxaca], of which exs. will be found below, is also used for AtRxc; one of the two ts being changed into s, like as s is changed into t in sitRN [for sidosN]: or Astxc may be of the measure AstfEl from taxica; one of the two ts being suppressed; after the manner of those who say Zalotu for Zalilotu: (S, L:) and IAth says that AtRxc, in like manner, is of the measure AftEl from taxica; not from Oaxaca: (L and K in art. txc:) but IAth is not one who should contradict J, whose opinion on this point is corroborated by the fact that they say QtRazara from UizaArN, and QtRamana from OamonN, and QtRahala from OaholN; and there are other instances of the same kind: or, accord. to some, AtRxc is from waxaca, a dial. var. of Oaxaca, and is originally Aiwotaxaca. (MF.) [The various significations of AtRxc and taxica and Astxc will be here given under one head.]

You say, UiYotaxacuwA fiI AlqitaAli, (S, L, K, *) and fI AlHarobi, (Msb,) with two hemzehs, (S, L, K,) or, correctly, UiytaxacuwA, with one hemzeh, [or AiytaxacuwA,] as two hemzehs cannot occur together in one word, (marginal note in a copy of the S,) [but in a case of wasl, the first hemzeh being suppressed, the second remains unchanged,] They took, or seized, (OaxacuwA,) one another (S, L, Msb, K) in fight, (S, L,) and in war; (Msb;) and so AitRaxacuwA. (Msb.) And Aiytaxaca Alqawomu The people, of company of men, wrestled together, each taking hold in some manner upon him who wrestled with him, to throw him down. (L, TA.)

[AtRxc, as also Astxc↓, and] taxica, aor.
Aaxaca
, (K in art. txc,) inf. n. taxaca and taxocN, (TA in art. txc,) likewise signifies i. q. Oaxaca, (K in art. txc, and B and TA in the present art.,) as meaning He took a thing to, or for, himself; took possession of it; got, or acquired, it; syn. HaAza and HaSRala. (B, TA.) Some read, [in the Kur, xviii. 76,] lataxicota Ealayohi OajorAF [Thou mightest assuredly have taken for thyself a recompense for it]: (S, L, K in art. txc, and TA in the present art.:) this is the reading of Mujáhid, (Fr, TA,) and is authorized by I'Ab, and is that of Aboo-'Amr Ibn-El-'Alà and AZ, and so it is written in the model-copy of the Kur, and so the readers [in general] read: (AM, L, TA:) so read Ibn-Ketheer and the Basrees; he and Yaakoob and Hafs pronouncing the c; the others incorporating it [into the t]: (Bd:) some read lAQtRaxactRa; (L and K in art. txc;) but these read at variance with the scripture. (AM, L, TA.) OaroDAF Astxc↓ is a phrase mentioned by Mbr as used by some of the Arabs, (S, L,) and signifies i. q. AitRaxacahaA [He took for himself a piece of land]. (S, L, K.) And AtRxc waladRaA [in the Kur, ii. 110, &c.,] signifies He got a son, or offspring. (Bd &c. See also below.) And taxica, aor.
Aaxaca
, inf. n. taxacN and taxocN, also signifies He gained, acquired, or earned, wealth, (L, and Msb in arts. Axc and txc,) or a thing. (Msb.)

Ealayohimo yadFA Astxc↓ and Einodahumo signify alike, i. q. AtRxc [He did to them a benefit, or favour; as though he earned one for himself in prospect, making it to be incumbent on them as a debt to him]: (ISh:) and AitRaxacotu Einodahu maEorwfFA means [in like manner, as also Endh mErwfA Oaxacotu↓, and yadRaA, (and AitRaxaca fiyhi HusonAF has a similar meaning; see Kur xviii.
85;)] I did to him a benefit, or favour; syn. Oasodayotuhu Uilayohi. (Msb in art. sdy.)

AtRxc also signifies He made a thing; syn. Eamila; like taxica, [aor.
Aaxaca
,] inf. n. taxacN and taxocN: (L:) he made, or manufactured, a bow, a water-skin, &c., mino kacaA of such a thing: he made, or prepared, a dish of food, a medicine, &c.: either absolutely or for himself. (The Lexicons passim.)

Also He made, or constituted, or appointed; syn. jaEala; doubly trans.; (B, Msb;) and so taxica. (Msb in art. txc.) You say, AtRxchu SadiyqFA He made him [or took him as] a friend; (Msb in the present art.;) and so taxicahu. (Idem in art. txc.) And AtRxchu huzuWFA [in the Kur ii. 63 and 231, &c.,] means He made him, or it, a subject of derision. (Bd, Jel.) And AtRxchu waladFA [in the same, xii. 21 and xxviii. 8,] He made him, or took or adopted him as, a son. (Bd. See also above.)
10. Qsotaxaca, written with the disjunctive alif Aisotaxaca: see 8, in four places. [Other meanings may be inferred from explanations of musotaOoxicN, q. v. infrà.]
OaxocN inf. n. of Oaxaca, q. v.

(assumed tropical:) A way, or manner, of life; as also UixocN↓. (S, L, K.) You say, cahaba banuw fulaAnK wamano Oaxaca Oaxocahumo, (S, L, K, *) and Uixocahumo↓, (L, K,) the former of the dial. of Temeem, and the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (TA,) meaning (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one went away, or passed away, and those who took to their way of life, (S, L, K,) and adopted their manners, or dispositions: (K:) and mano Oaxaca Oaxocuhumo and Uixocuhumo↓, and mano Oaxaca Oaxocuhumo [in the CK Aaxocuhumo] and Uixocuhumo↓, signify [virtually] the same: (K:) or mano Oaxacahu Oaxocuhumo and Uixocuhumo↓ signify [properly] mano Oaxacahu Oaxocuhumo wasiyratuhumo [those whom their way of life took, or influenced]. (ISk, S L.) One says also, QsotuEomila fulaAnN Eala AlXRaAmi wamaA Oaxaca Uixocahu↓, with kesr, meaning (assumed tropical:) [Such a one was appointed prefect over Syria,] and he did not take to that good way of life which it was incumbent on him to adopt: you should not say Oaxocahu: (AA, S, L:) or it means and what was adjacent to it: (Fr, L:) or, accord. to the Wá'ee, one says, in this case, wamaA Oaxaca Uixocahu↓ and Oaxocuhu and Ouxocuhu↓, with kesr and fet-h and damm [to the hemzeh, and with the c marfooah, as in instances before]. (Et-Tedmuree, MF.) One also says, lawo kunota minRaA laOaxactRa biUxocinaA↓, (S, L,) with kesr to the A, (L,) [in a copy of the S biOaxocinaA, which seems to be also allowable, accord. to the dial. of Temeem,] meaning Wert thou of us, then thou hadst taken to, or wouldst take to, our manners, or dispositions, and fashion, (S, L,) and garb, and way of life. (L.) The words of the poet,
IAar explains as meaning And were ye of us, we had caught and restored to you your camels: but no other says so. (L.)

nujuwmu AlOaxoci The Mansions of the Moon; (S, L, K;) also called nujuwmu AlOanowaMCN; (L; [see art. nwC;]) called by the former appellation because the moon every night enters (yaOoxucu fiI) one of those mansions: (S, L:) or the stars which are cast at those [devils] who listen by stealth [to the conversations of the angels]: (L, K:) but the former explanation is the more correct. (L.)
See also UixaAco.
OuxocN, whence maA Oaxaca Ouxocuhu: see OaxocN.
It is also a pl. of UixaAcN; (S, L;) and of UixocN or UixocapN, explained below with UixaAcN. (L.)
UixocN [The act of taking, taking with the hand, &c.], a subst. from Oaxaca. (S, L, Msb.)
See also OaxocN, in nine places.
And see UixaAcN.
Also A mark made with a hot iron upon a camel's side when a disease therein is feared. (K.)
OaxacN Heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, of a young camel, from the milk. (K.) [See Oaxica.]
See also OuxucN.
OaxicN A young camel disordered in his belly, and affected with heaviness of the stomach, and indigestion, from taking much milk. (AZ, Fr, L.) [See also SaboHaAnu.]
A camel, or a young camel, or a sheep or goat, affected by what resembles madness, or demoniacal possession. (L.)
A man affected with inflammation of the eye; with pain and swelling of the eye; with ophthalmia; (S, L;) as also musotaOoxicN↓. (L.) See also this latter.
See also MxicN.
OuxucN (S, L, K) and OaxacN↓, (Ibn-Es-Seed, L, K,) which latter is the regular form, (L,) Inflammation of the eye; pain and swelling of the eye; ophthalmia. (S, L, K.)
OaxocapN [inf. n. un. of Oaxaca, An act of taking, &c.: an act of punishment, or chastisement, or the like; as in the Kur lxix. 10: pl. OaxacaAtN].
OaxacuwA OaxacaAtihimo They took their places of abode. (IAth and L, from a trad.)
OuxocapN A manner of taking, or seizing, of a man with whom one is wrestling: pl. OuxacN. (L.)

A kind of enchantment, or fascination, like siHor, (S, L, Msb, * K,) which captivates the eye and the like, (L,) and by which enchantresses withhold their husbands from other women; called by the vulgar ribaATN and EaqodN; and practised by the women in the time of ignorance: (TA:) or a kind of bead (xazarapN, S, L, K) with which one captivates, or fascinates, or restrains; (K;) with which women captivate, or fascinate, or restrain, men, (S, L,) and withhold them from other women: (L:) or i. q. ruqoyapN. (A.)
A pitfall dug for catching a lion. (A, TA.)

baAdiro bizanodika Ouxocapa AlnRaAri [Strive thou to be before the time called (that of) Axcp AlnAr with thy wooden instrument for producing fire; i. e. haste thou to use it before that time;] means the time a little after the prayer of sunset; asserted to be the worst time in which to strike fire. (K.)
UixocapN: see UixaAcN.

UixaAcN and UixaAcapN↓ A pool of water left by a torrent: pl. OuxucN: (AO, K:) both signify the same: (L:) or UixaAcapN↓ signifies a thing like a pool of water left by a torrent; and UixaAcN is its pl. [or a coll. gen. n.]; and the pl. of this latter is OuxucN, like as kutubN is pl. of kitaAbN, and sometimes it is contracted into OuxocN: (S, L:) the like of this is said by Aboo-'Adnán: (L:) and UixaAcaAtN is also a pl. of UixAcapN, occurring in a trad., and signifying pools which receive the rain-water, and retain it for drinkers: (IAth, L:) or the correct word is UixaAcN, without p, and it signifies a place where beasts assemble at a pool of water left by a torrent; and its pl. is OuxucN (AA, A'Obeyd, L) and MxaAcN, which latter is extr.: (L:) but as to UixaAcapN↓, it has a different signification, which will be found below; i. e. land of which a man takes possession for himself, &c.: (AA, L:) or UixaAcN is a coll. gen. n., and UixaAcapN↓ is its n. un., and signifies a receptacle made for water to collect therein: and OaxocN↓ signifies a thing that one digs for himself, in the form of a watering-trough, which retains water for some days; and its pl. is OuxocaAnN: (L:) and UixocN↓ and UixocapN↓ also signify a thing that one digs in the form of a wateringtrough; and the pl. is OuxocN and UixaAcN. (L.) In a trad. of Mesrook Ibn-El-Ajda', UixaAc are likened to the Companions of Mohammad; and it is added, that one UixaAcap↓ suffices for a rider; and one, for two riders; and one, for a company of men: (S, L:) meaning that among them were the young and the old, and the possessor of knowledge and the possessor of more knowledge. (L.)
See also UixaAcapN.
OaxiycN i. q. maOoxuwcN↓ [Taken; taken with the hand; &c.]. (Msb.)

A captive: (S, L, Msb, K:) fem. with p. (S, L.) Hence the saying, Oakocabu mino Oaxiyci AljayXi More lying than the captive of the army: meaning him whom his enemies have taken captive, and whom they desire to conduct them to his people, and who lies to them to his utmost. (Fr, L.) [See another ex. voce SaboHaAnu.]
A strange, or foreign, old man. (K.)

UixaAcapN Land which a man, (S, L, K,) or a Sul- tán, (S, L,) takes for himself; as also UixaAcN↓: (S, L, K:) or land which a man takes for himself, and brings into a state of cultivation after its having been waste: (AA, Mgh, L:) or waste land which the owner gives to him who shall cultivate it: (Mgh:) and land which the Imám gives to one, not being property, (K,) or not being the property of another. (TA, as from the K.)
See also UixaAcN, in five places.
Also The handle of a [shield of the kind called] Hajafap; (K; [in the L written jHofp, with the j before the H;]) also called its vqAf. (L.)
OaxiycapN A thing that is taken by force. (L.) [See also OaxiycN.]

OaxRaAcN One who takes eagerly, or greedily: whence the saying, maA Oanota UilRaA OaxRaAcN nabRaAcN Thou art none other than one who taketh a thing eagerly, or greedily, and then throweth it away quickly. (A.)

MxicN, (as in some copies of the K, in both of
the senses here explained,) or Oaxico↓ (as in other copies of the K, and in the L and TA, [but the former is the more agreeable with the form of the pl.,]) A camel beginning to become fat; (L, K;) or to become aged: (K:) pl. OawaAxicu (L.)
Milk that bites the tongue; syn. qaAriSN. (K.) [See Oaxuca.]
maOoxaco [A place where, or whence, a thing is taken: pl. maMxicu.] [Hence,] maMxicu AlTRayori The places whence birds are taken. (K, TA.)
[The source of derivation of a word or phrase or meaning.]
A way [which one takes]; as in the phrase, AlmaOoxaca AlOaqoraba salaka He went the nearest way. (Msb. in art. xSr.)
[See also 2, last sentence but one.]
maOoxuwcN: see OaxiycN.
rajulN muWaxRacN Eani AlnRisaMCi A man withheld [by a kind of enchantment or charm (see 2)] from women. (L.)
muWotaxicN: see what follows.
musotaOoxicN [Requiring to be clipped; i. e.] long; applied to hair. (K.)

Lowering his head, or stooping, (As, S, L, K,) by reason of inflammation of the eyes, or ophthalmia, (As, S, L,) or by reason of pain, (As, S, L, K,) or from some other cause; (L;) as also OaxicN↓, q. v. (TA.) Lowly, or submissive, (AA, L, K,) by reason of disease; as also muWotaxicN↓. (AA, L.)

2. OxRr, (S, K, &c.,) inf. n. taOoxiyrN, (K,) is trans. (S, K, &c.) and intrans.: (K:) as a trans. verb it signifies He made to go back or backwards, to recede, retreat, retire, or retrograde: he put, or drove, back: he put, or placed, behind, or after; back, or backward: he made to be behind, or posterior, or last: he made to remain behind, hold back, hang back, or lag behind: he kept, or held, back: he postponed, put off, procrastinated, deferred, delayed, or retarded: he made backward, or late: contr. of qadRama. (Msb, TA.)
OaxRaraniI UilaI mudRapK He granted me a delay, or postponement, to a certain term, or period. (TA in art. Ajl.)
For its significations as an intrans. verb, see 5, in two places.

5. tOxRr is quasi-pass. of the trans. verb OxRr; (S, A, Msb;) i. e. He, or it, went back or backwards, drew back, receded, retreated, retired, or retrograded: became put, or driven, back: became put, or placed, behind, or after: became behind, posterior, or last: he remained behind, or in the rear; held back, hung back, lagged behind, or delayed; was, or became, backward, or late: it was, or became, kept back, postponed, put off, procrastinated, deferred, delayed, or retarded: contr. of taqadRama: (TA:) and AstOxar↓ is syn. therewith; (S, K:) and OxRr↓, inf. n. taOoxiyrN, signifies the same, being intrans. as well as trans. (K.) An ex. of the latter occurs in a saying of Mohammad to 'Omar: EanRIi OaxRiro↓ Retire thou from me: or the meaning is, OaxRiroEanRiI raOoyaka [hold thou back from me thine opinion; or reserve thou thine opinion until after mine shall have been given]. (TA.) You say, taOaxRira Eanohu taOaxRurapF waAHidapF [He went back, &c., from him, or it, once]. (Lh.) And tOxRr Eani AlXRaIoCi, or AlOamori, He went back, &c., from the thing, or the affair: he was, or became, behind, behindhand, or backward, with respect to it: he held back, hung back, refrained, or abstained, from it; and Eanohu AstOxr↓ signifies the same. (The Lexicons in many places.) faUicaA jaMCa saAEapF Oajaluhumo laA yasotaOoxiruwna↓, in the Kur vii. 32 and other places, means And when their time is come, for punishment, they will not remain behind, or be respited, [any while, or] the shortest time: or they shall not seek to remain behind, by reason of intense terror. (Bd.)
10: see 5, in three places.

OaxirN [an epithet variously explained]. One says, in reviling, (S, TA,) but not when the object is a female, (TA,) OaboEada AallRehu AlOaxira, (Th, S, A, &c.,) and AlMxira↓ (M, &c.,) or this latter is wrong, (Meshárik of 'Iyád, Mgh, Msb,) as is also AlMxara↓, (Meshárik of 'Iyád,) meaning (tropical:) May God alienate, or estrange, from good, or prosperity, or may God curse, him who is absent from us, (A, Msb, TA,) distant, or remote: (A, Msb:) or the outcast; the alienated: (Msb:) or him who is put back, and cast away: so says Sh: or, accord. to ISh, him who is put back, and remote from good: and he adds, I think that AlOaxiyr↓ is meant: (L:) or the base fellow: or the most ignoble: or the miserable wretch: (Et-Tedmuree and others:) or the last speaker: (Nawádir of Th:) or AlAxr is here a metonymy for the devil: (Lb:) it is a word used [for the reason explained voce OaboEadu] in relating what has been said by one of two persons cursing each other, to the other; (Expositions of the Fs;) and the phrase above mentioned is meant to imply a prayer for those who are present [by its contrasting them with the person to whom it directly applies]. (A.) One also says, laA maroHabFA biAloOaxiri, [alluding to a particular person,] meaning [May the place, or land, not be ample, or spacious, or roomy,] to the remote from good. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Mázin, UinRa AlOaxiraqado zanaI Verily the outcast, (Mgh, Msb,) or he who is remote, and held back, from good,, (Mgh, * TA,) hath committed adultery, or fornication: the speaker meaning himself; (Mgh, Msb;) as though he were an outcast. (Msb.) And in another trad. it is said, AlmasoOalapu Oaxiru kasobi AlmaroCi Begging is the most ignoble [mode of] gain of man: but El-Khattábee relates it with medd, [i. e. Mxiru↓,] explaining it as meaning begging is the last thing whereby man seeks sustenance when unable to gain [by other means]. (TA.)

OuxurN The back, hinder, or latter, part: the hindermost, or last, part: contr. of qudumN. (K.) [See also muWaxRarN; from which it appears to be distinguished by its being used only adverbially, or with a preposition: and see MxirN.] You say, XuqRa vawobuhu OuxurFA, and mino OuxurK, (S, K, *) His garment was rent, or slit, in its back, or hinder, part, (S,) or behind. (K.) And taOaxRara OuxurFA [He retired backwards]. (A.) And jaMCi OuxurFA: see MxirN, in two places.
OuxorapF and biOuxorapK: see MxirF.
OaxarapF and biOaxarapK: see MxirN, in five places.

biEotuhu biOaxirapK I sold it (namely the article of merchandise, TA) with postponement of the payment; upon credit; for payment to be made at a future period; syn. binaZirpK; (S, A, K;) i. e. binasiYapK. (S.)
OuxarapF and biOuxarapK: see MxirN.
OuxoraApN: see Mxaru, of which it is the fem.: and see also MxirN.
OuxoraApN another fem. of Mxaru. (K.)
OuxoriyRaA and UixoriyRaA and UixiriyRaA: see MxirN.
[OuxorawiIRN and OuxoraAwiIRu Relating to the other state of existence, or the world to come.]
OaxiyrN and OaxiyrFA: see MxirN, in five places. See also OaxirN.
OuxayoraI dim. of OuxoraI, fem. of Mxaru, q. v. (S.)

Mxaru a subst., of the measure OafoEalu, but implying the meaning of an epithet, (S,) from OaxRara in the sense of taOaxRara, (TA,) Another; the other; a thing [or person] other than the former or first; (L;) i. q. gayorN; (K;) as in the phrases, rajulN Mxaru another man, and vawobN Mxaru another garment or piece of cloth: (TA:) or one of two things [or persons]; (S, Sgh, Msb;) as when you say, jaMCa Alqawomu fawaAHidN yafoEalu kacaA waMxaru kacaA The people came, and one was doing thus, and one [i. e. another] thus: (Sgh, Msb:) originally meaning more backward: (TA:) fem. OuxoraI↓ (S, Msb, K) and OuxoraApN↓; (K) which latter is not well known: (MF:) pl. masc. Mxaruwna and Ouxaru; (S, K;) [the latter irreg. as such;] and, applied to irrational things, OawaAxiru, like as OafaADilu is pl. of OafoDalu: (Msb:) and pl. fem. UuxorayaAtN and Uuxaru; (S, Msb, K;) which latter is imperfectly decl.; for an epithet of the measure OafoEalu which is accompanied by mino has no [dual nor] pl. nor fem. as long as it is indeterminate; but when it has the article Al prefixed to it, or is itself prefixed to another noun which it governs in the gen. case, it has a dual and a pl. and a fem.; but it is not so with Mxaru; for it has a fem. [and dual] and pl. without mino and without the article Al and without its being prefixed to another noun: you say, mararotu biraxulK Mxara, and birijaAlK Ouxara and Mxariyna, and biANmoraOapK, and binisowapK [I passed by another man, and by other men, and by another woman, and by other women;] therefore, as it [namely Uuxaru] is thus made to deviate from its original form, [i. e. Mxaru, (I' Ak p. 287,) which is of a class of words used, when indeterminate, alike as sing. and dual and pl.,] and is [essentially and originally] an epithet, it is imperfectly decl.,
though a pl.: but when you name thereby a man, it is perfectly decl., when inderminate, accord. to Akh, or imperfectly decl. accord. to Sb. (S, L.) The dim. of Mxaru is Ouwayoxiru↓; the A with the C suppressed following the same rule as the A in DaAribN: (TA:) and the dim. of UuxoraI is OuxayoraI↓. (S.) See also AlOuxoraI voce MxirN.

laA OafoEaluhu OuxoraI AllRayaAliI, (S, K,) or AxrI Almanuwni, (K,) means I will not do it ever: (S, K:) or the latter, I will not do it to the end of time. (S.) And OuxoraI Alqawomi, The last of the people. (S, K.) One says, jaMCa fiI OuxoraI Alqawomi He came among the last of the people. (TA.) And jaMCi fiI OuxorayaAti AlnRaAsi He came among those who were the last of the people. (S, A, K.) [See also MxirN.]
In OaboEada AllRehu AlMxara, the last word is a mistake for AlOaxira q. v. (Meshárik of 'Iyád.)

MxirN, (S, Msb, K,) an epithet, of the measure faAEilN, (S,) and OaxiyrN↓, (S, Msb,) The last; aftermost; hindmost: and the latter; after; hinder: and [as a subst.] the end: contr. of OawRalu: [or of OawRalN when used as a subst.:] (A, Msb, K:) or of mutaqadRimN: (Lth, Msb:) or what is after the first or former: (S:) fem. of the former MxirapN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. [masc.] Mxiruwna (Kur xxvi. 84, &c.,) and (masc. and fem., Msb) OawaAxiru (S, Msb) and fem. MxiraAtN also: (Th:) and maMxiyru↓ is syn. with OawaAxiru; as in maMxiyruAllRayoli [occurring in the S and K in art. jhm, meaning The last, or latter, parts, or portions, of the night]. (TK in art. jhm.) You say, jaMCi MxirFA and OaxiyrFA↓ and OuxurFA↓ and biOaxarapK↓, all meaning the same [He came lastly, or latterly]: and in like manner, maA Earafotuhu UilRaA OaxiyrFA↓ and AlRA biOaxarapK↓ [I did not know it save at the last, or lastly, or latterly]: (S:) or jaMCi OaxiyrFA↓ and OuxurFA↓ and OaxorapN↓ and biOuxorapK↓ and OuxarapK↓ and biOuxarapK↓ (K,) or OuxorapN↓ and biOuxorapK↓ (Lh, L,) and biMxirapK (TA) and UixoriyRaA↓ and OuxoriyRaA↓ and UixiriyRaA↓ and MxiriyRaA↓ (K) mean he came lastly of everything. (K.) It is said in a trad., respecting Mohammad, UicaA OaraAda Oano yaquwma mina Almajolisi kaAna yaquwlu biOaxarapK↓ kacaA wakacaA He used to say, at the end of his sitting, when he desired to rise from the place of assembly, thus and thus: or, accord. to IAth, it may mean, in the last, or latter, part of his life. (TA.) And you say, Oatayotuka Mxira marRatayoni and Mxira marRatayoni (IAar, M, K. *) And laA OukalRimuhu Mxira AldRahori I will not speak to him [to the end of time, or] ever. (A.) [See a similar phrase above, voce Mxaru.] And jaAWuwA Eano Mxirihimo [They came with the last of them; En being here syn. with bi; meaning they came all, without exception]. (A.) [And kaAna clika fiI Mxiri AlXRahori, and AlsRanapi; and fI OawaAxiri himaA, That was in the end of the month, and of the year; and in the last days thereof.] And AlnRahaAru yajurN Eano MxirK faMxirK [The day lengthens] hour by hour. (A.) See also OaxirN, last sentence.
AlMxiru is a name of God, signifying [The last; or] He who remaineth after all his creatures, both vocal and mute, have perished. (Nh.)
AlMxiraAni The two hinder dugs of the she-camel; opposed to the qaAdimaAni; (TA;) the two dugs that are next the thighs. (K.)

AlMxirapN, (K,) for AldRAru AlMxirapu, (Bd in ii. 3,) [and AlHayaApu AlMxirapu,] and AlOuxoraI↓, (K,) [The latter, ultimate, or last, and the other, dwelling, or abode, and life; i. e. the latter, ultimate, or last, and the other, world; the world, or life, to come; and the ultimate state of existence, in the world to come;] the dwelling, or abode, [and life,] of everlasting duration: (K:) [each] an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (Z, and Bd ubi suprà.) [Opposed to AldRunoyaA. And MxirapN also signifies The enjoyments, blessings, or good, of the ultimate state; of the other world; or of the world, or life, to come: in which sense likewise it is opposed to dunoyaA: (see an ex. of both voce baAEa, in art. byE: so too OuxoraI↓.)]

Mxirapu AlrRaHoli, (S, Msb, K,) and AlsRaroji, (Msb,) and Mxiruhu, (S in art. qdm, and K,) and muWoxiratuhu↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) which is a rare form, or, accord. to Yaakoob, not allowable, (S,) and muWxiruhu↓, and muWaxRaratuhu, and muWaxRaruhu↓, (S in art. qdm, and K,) and muWaxRiratuhu↓, (Msb, K,) or this is a mistake, (Mgh, Msb,) and muWaxRiruhu↓, (K,) but the first of all is the most chaste, (Msb,) The thing, (S,) or piece of wood, (Msb,) of the camel's saddle, (S, Msb,) and of the horse's, (Msb,) against which the rider leans [his back]; (S, Msb;) the contr. of its qaAdimap [by which term qAdmp is meant the waAsiT]: (K:) the wAsT of the camel's saddle is the tall fore part which is next to the breast of the rider; and its Mxrp is its hinder part; (Az, L;) i. e. its broad piece of wood, (Mgh,) or its tall and broad piece of wood, (Az, L,) which is against, or opposite to, (tuHaAciI,) the head [and back] of the rider: (Az, Mgh, L:) [for] the Mxrp and the wAsT are the XaroxaAni, between which the rider sits: this is the description given by En-Nadr [ISh]; and all of it is correct: there is no doubt respecting it: (Az, L:) the pl. of Mxrp is is OawaAxiru. (Msb.) Mxirapu AlEayoni↓: see muWoxiruAlEayoni. MxirN↓ and OaxiyrN↓ [accord. to some] also signify Absent. (K.) But see OaxirN, second sentence.
MxiriyRaA: see MxirN.
Ouwayoxiru dim. of Mxaru, q. v. (TA.)

muWoxiru AlEayoni, (T, S, A, Mgh, Msb, K, [in the CK muWaxRarhA,]) said by AO, (Msb,) or A 'Obeyd, (TA,) to be better without teshdeed, from which observation it is to be understood that teshdeed in this case is allowable, though rare, but Az disallows it, (Msb, TA,) and muWoxiratuhaA, and MxiratuhaA↓, (K,) [The outer angle of the eye;] the part of the eye next the temple; (S, A, Mgh, Msb;) the part next the laHaAZ: (K:) opposed to its muqodim, which is the extremity thereof next the nose: (S, Mgh, Msb:) pl. maMxiru. (Mgh.) You say, UalayRa bimuWoxiri [He looked at, or towards, me from (lit. with) the outer angle of his eye]. (S.)
muWoxiru AlrRaHoli, and muWoxiratuhu: see MxirN.

muWaxRarN The back, hinder, or latter, part of anything: its hindermost, or last, part: contr. of muqadRamN: as in the phrase, Daraba muWaxRara raOosihi [He struck the back, or hinder part, of his head]. (S, Msb.) [See also OuxurN and MxirN.]
muWaxRaruAlrRaHoli, and muWaxRaratuhu: see MxirN.

AlmuWaxRiru a name of God, [The Postponer, or Delayer;] He who postpones, or delays, things, and puts them in their places: [or He who puts, or keeps, back, or backward: or He who degrades:] contr. of AlmuqadRimu. (TA.)
muWaxRiru AlRarHoli, and muWaxRiratuhu: see MxirN.

naxolapN miYoxaArN A palm-tree of which the fruit remains until the end of winter: (AHn, K:) and until the end of the time of cutting off the fruit of palm-trees: (S, M, K:) contr. of mibokaArN and bakuwrN: pl. maMxiyru. (A.)
maMxiyru [reg. pl. of miYoxaArN]: see Mxiru, first sentence.
mutaOaxRirN: see its verb. ↓ [An author, or other person, of the later, or more modern, times.]

AlmusoOoxiriyna in the Kur xv. 24 is said by Th to mean Those who come to the mosque after others, or late: (TA:) or it means those who are later in birth and death: or those who have not yet come forth from the loins of men: or those who are late, or backward, in adopting the Muslim religion and in fighting against unbelievers and in obedience. (Bd.)

1. Oaxawota, [third pers. OaxaA,] (S, K,) aor. taOoxuw, (S,) inf. n. OuxuwRapN; (S, K, &c.;) and Mxayota↓, (K, TA,) [in the CK Aaxayotu, which is wrong in respect of the pers., and otherwise, for it is correctly] with medd, (TA,) inf. n. UixaMCN and muWaAxaApN; (Lth;) and taOaxRayota↓; (K;) Thou becamest a brother [in the proper sense of this word, and also as meaning a friend, or companion, or the like]. (S,* K,* TA.) OuxuwRapN↓ is also [used as] a simple subst., (TA,) signifying Brotherhood; fraternity; the relation of brother; as also UixaMCN↓ and muWaAxApN; and taOaxK↓: (Lth, TA:) and the relation of sister. (S.) You say, bayoniI wabayonahu OuxuwRapN and UixaMCN↓ [&c., meaning] Between me and him is brotherhood. (JK, TA.) And bayona AlsRamaAHapi waAlHamaAsapi taOaxK↓ (assumed tropical:) [Between liberality and courage is a relation like that of brothers]. (TA.) And xuwRapN is a dial. var. of OuxuwRapN, occurring in a trad. (IAth, TA.)
[It is also trans.] You say, Oaxawotu EaXarapF I was, or became, a brother to ten. (TA.)

2. OaxRayotu lildRaAbRapi, (S, K,) or AldRaAbRapa, (Msb, [so accord. to a copy of that work, but probably this is a mistranscription,]) inf. n. taOoxiyapN, (S, Msb, K,) I made an MxiyRap [q. v.] for the beast, (Msb, K,) and tied the beast therewith; (Msb;) [and
so, app., Mxayotu↓ (which, if correct, is probably of the measure OafoEalotu); for it is related that] an Arab of the desert said to another, liI MxiyRapF Mxi↓ OarobiTu UalayohaA muhoriI [Make thou for me an MxyRp to which I shall tie my colt]. (TA.) And you say, fulaAnN fiI fulaAnK MxiyRapF fakafarahaA MxiI↓ (assumed tropical:) Such a one did a benefit to such a one, and he was ungrateful for it. (TA.) [But perhaps Mxi and MxaI in these two exs. are mistranscriptions for OaxRi and OaxRaI.]

3. MxAhu, (S, K,) vulgarly waAxaAhu, (S,) or the latter is a dial. var. of weak authority, (K,* TA,) said by some to be of the dial. of Teiyi, (TA,) inf. n. muWaAxaApN and UixMCN (S, K) and wixaMCN, (K) and [quasi-inf. n.] UixaAwapN↓ (Fr, K) and wixaAwapN, (CK,) He fraternized with him; acted with him in a brotherly manner: (S,* K,* PS, TK:) A'Obeyd mentions, on the authority of Yz, Mxayotu and waAxayotu, and Msayotu and waAsayotu, and Mkalotu and waAkalotu: the pret. is said to be thus assimilated to [a form of] the fut.; for they used [sometimes] to say, yuwaAxiI, changing the hemzeh into w. (IB, TA.)

It is said in a trad., MxaI bayona AlmuhaAjiriyna waAlOanoSaAri, meaning He united the emigrants [to El-Medeeneh] with the assistants [previously dwel-ling there] by the brotherhood of El-Islám and of the faith. (TA.) You say also, Mxayotu bayona AlXRayoYanoni [I united the two things as fellows, or pairs]; and sometimes one says, waAxayotu, like as one says, waAsayotu, for Msayotu; mentioned by ISk. (Msb.)
See also 1, in three places.
4: see 2, in three places.
5. taOaxRayota, and the inf.n. taOaxK: see 1, in three places.
taOaxRayotu OaxFA I adopted a brother: (S, K:) or [taOaxRayotuhu signifies] I called him brother. (K.)

taOaxRayotu AlXRaIoCa, (S, K, TA,) or biAlXRaIo, (Msb,) I sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, the thing; (S, Msb, K, TA;) as the brother does the brother; and in the same manner the verb is used with a man for its object: but tawaxRayotu, in the same sense, is more common. (TA.) You say, taOaxRayotu maHabRataka I sought, &c., thy love, or affection. (TA in art. wxI.)
6. taMxayaA They became brothers, or friends or companions or the like, to each other. (S,* TA.)

OaxN, (S, Msb, K,) originally OaxawN, (Kh, S, Msb,) as is shown by the first of its dual forms mentioned below, and by its having a pl. like MbaMCK, (S,) and OaxRN, (K,) with the second letter doubled to compensate for the w suppressed, as is the case in OabRN, (TA,) and OaxFA↓, [like OabFA,] and Oaxuw↓, (IAar, K, TA, [the last, with the article prefixed to it, erroneously written in the CK AlAuxuwRN,]) and OaxowN↓, like dalowN, (Kr, K,) a well-known term of relationship, (K, TA,) i. e. A brother; the son of one's father and mother, or of either of them: and also applied to a foster-brother: (TA:) and (assumed tropical:) a friend; and a companion, an associate, or a fellow: (K:) derived from MxiyRapN [q. v.]; as though one Oax were tied and attached to another like as the horse is tied to the MxyRp: (Har p. 42:) or, accord. to some of the grammarians, it is from waxaI meaning qaSada; because the Oax has the same aim, endeavour, or desire, as his Oax: (TA:) when Oax is prefixed to another noun, its final vowel is prolonged: (Kh:) you say, hcaA Oaxuwka [This is thy brother, &c.], and mararotu biOaxiyka [I passed by thy brother, &c.], and raOayotu OaxaAka [I saw thy brother, &c.]: (S: [in which it is also asserted that one does not say Oaxuw without prefixing it to another noun; but this is inconsistent with the assertion of IAar and F, that AlOaxuw is a syn. of AlOaxu:]) the dual is OaxawaAni, (S, Msb, Kur xlix. 10, Ham p. 434,) or OaxowaAni, with the x quiescent, (TA, [but this I have found nowhere else,]) and some of the Arabs say OaxaAni, (S, Msb,) and Kr mentions OaxuwaAni, with damm to the x, said by IB to occur in poetry, and held by ISd to be dual of Oaxuw, with damm to the x: (TA:) the pl. is UixowapN and UixowaAnN, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) the former generally applied to brothers, and the latter to friends [or the like], (T, S,*) but not always, as in the Kur xlix. 10, where the former does not denote relationship, and in xxiv. 60 of the same, where the latter does denote relationship, (T, TA,) and sometimes the former is applied to a [single] man, as in the Kur iv. 12, (S,) and OuxowapN, (Fr, S, Msb, K, [in the CK AaxowapN,]) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, TA,) and OuxowaAnN, (Kr, Msb, K,) and MxaMCN, (S, K,) like MbaMCN, (S,) and OuxuwRN, and OuxuwRapN, (ISd, K,) the last mentioned by Lh, and thought by ISd to be formed from the next preceding by the addition of p characterizing the pl. as fem., (TA,) and Oaxuwna, (S, Msb, K,) and AxAwwn. (Msb: [there written without any syll. signs, and I have not found it elsewhere.]) The fem. of OaxN is OuxotN↓ [meaning A sister: and (assumed tropical:) a female friend, &c.]: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) written with damm to show that the letter which has gone from it is w; (S;) the t being a substitute for the w; (TA;) not to denote the fem. gender, (K, TA,) because the letter next before it is quiescent: this is the opinion of Sb, and [accord. to SM] it is the correct opinion: for Sb says that if you were to use it as a proper name of a man, you would make it perfectly decl.; and if the t were to denote the fem. gender, the name would not be perfectly decl.; though in one place he incidentally says that it is the sign of the fem. gender, through inadvertence: Kh, however, says that its t is [originally] h [meaning p]: and Lth, that OuxotN is originally OaxapN: and some say that it is originally OaxowapN: (TA:) the dual. is OuxotaAni: (Kh:) and the pl. is OaxawaAtN. (Kh, S, Msb, K.) The saying laA OaxaAlaka bifulaAnK [Thou hast no brother, or (assumed tropical:) friend, in such a one] means layosa laka biOaxK [such a one is not a brother, or friend, to thee]. (S, K.) It is said in a prov., mano laka biOaxiyka kulRihi [Who will be responsible to thee for thy brother, or (assumed tropical:) thy friend, altogether? i. e., for his always acting to thee as a brother, or friend]. (JK.) And in another, rubRa OaxK laka lamo talidohu OumRuka [(assumed tropical:) There is many a brother to thee whom thy mother has not brought forth]. (TA.) And in another, Oaxuwka Oami AlcRaYobu [Is it thy brother, or the wolf?]; said in suspecting a thing: as also Oaxuwka Oami AllRayolu [Is it thy brother, or is it the night that deceives thee?]. (Har p. 554.) And another saying is, AlrRumoHu Oaxuwka warubRamaA xaAnaka [(assumed tropical:) The spear is thy brother, but sometimes, or often, it is unfaithful to thee]. (TA.)

Ibn-'Arafeh says that when OuxuwRapN does not relate to birth, it means conformity, or similarity; and combination, agreement, or unison, in action: hence the saying, hcaA AlvRawobu Oaxuw hcaA [(assumed tropical:) This garment, or piece of cloth, is the like, or fellow, of this]: and hence the saying in the Kur [xvii. 29], kaAnuwA UixowaAna AlXRayaATiyni (assumed tropical:) They are the likes, or fellows, of the devils: and in the same [xliii. 47], UilRaA hiIa Oakobaru mino OuxotihaA↓ (assumed tropical:) But it was greater than its like, or fellow; i. e., than what was like to it in truth &c. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlnRawomu Oaxu Almawoti [Sleep is the like of death]. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer.) One says also, laqiIa fulaAnN OaxaA Almawoti (assumed tropical:) Such a one met with the like of death. (Msb, TA.) And they said, lahaA wamaAhu MllRehu bilayolaPK laA Ouxota↓ [(assumed tropical:) God afflicted him with a night having none like to it], i. e., a night in which he should die. (TA.) And laA OukalRimuhu UilRaA OaxaA AlsRirAri (assumed tropical:) I will not speak to him save the like of secret discourse. (As, TA.) [And hence,] suhayolK OuxotaA↓ [(assumed tropical:) The two sisters of Canopus;] the two stars called AlXREoraI AlEabuwru and AlXREoraI AlgumayoSaMCu. (S and K in art. XEr, q. v.)
yaAa OaxaA bakorK, or tamiymK, means (assumed tropical:) O thou of [the tribe of] Bekr, or Temeem. (Ham p. 284.)

Lh mentions, on the authority of Abu-d-Deenár and Ibn-Ziyád, the saying, Alqumomu biOaxiI AlXRarRa, as meaning (assumed tropical:) The people, or company of men, are in an evil state or condition. (TA.) [But accord. to others,] one says, tarakotuhu biOaxiI Alxayori, meaning (tropical:) I left him in an evil state or condition: (JK, * Msb, K, TA:) and biOaxiI AlXRarRi (tropical:) in a good state or condition. (TA.)
You say also, huwaOaxuw AlSRadoqi (assumed tropical:) He is one who cleaves, or keeps, to veracity. (Msb.)

[Oixuw, as a prefixed noun, is also used in the sense of Oaholu, meaning (assumed tropical:) Worthy, or deserving, of a thing: and meet, fit, or fitted, for it. So in the phrase Oaxuw viqapK (assumed tropical:) Worthy, or deserving, of trust, or confidence; expl. by W (p. 91) as meaning a person in whom one trusts, or confides. And so in the prov., layosa Oaxuw AlkiZaAZi mano yasoOamuhu (assumed tropical:) He who is fit, or fitted, for vehement striving for the mastery is not he who turns away from it with disgust: see art. kZ.]

It is also used in the sense of cuw: as in the phrase, huwaOaxuw AlginaI [(assumed tropical:) He is possessed, or a possessor, of wealth, or competence, or sufficiency]. (Msb.) [So too in the phrase, Oaxuw Alxayori (assumed tropical:) Possessed, or a possessor, of good, or of what is good. And in like manner,] Oaxuw AlxanaEi means [cuw AlxanaEi, i. e. cuw AlcRilRapi, i. e.] AlRcRaliylu [(assumed tropical:) The low, base, or abject]. (Ham p. 44.) [So too] sayorunaA Oaxuw Aljiyodi means [sayorunaA cuwAljayodi, i. e.] sayorunaA jaAhidN
[(assumed tropical:) Our journeying is laborious: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. gdr]. (TA.)

HumRaI AlOaxawayoni (assumed tropical:) A fever that affects the patient two days, and quits him two days; or that attacks on Saturday, and quits for three days, and comes [again] on Thursday; and so on. (Msb.)
damu AlOaxawayoni: see damN, in art. dmI.
OaxFA: see OaxN.
OaxowN: see OaxN.
Oaxuw: see OaxN.
OuxotN: see OaxN, in four places.
[OuxayRN and OuxayRapN dims. of OaxN and OuxotN.]

OaxawiyRN Brotherly; fraternal; of, or relating to, a brother, and a friend or companion: and also, sisterly; of, or relating to, a sister; because you say OaxawaAtN [meaning “sisters”]; but Yoo used to say OuxotiIRu↓, which is not agreeable with analogy. (S, TA.)
OuxotiIRu: see OaxawiIRu.
UixowaAnN, besides being a pl. of OaxN, q. v., is a dial. var. of xiwaAnN. (TA. [See art. xwn.])
UixaAwapN: see 3.
OuxuwRahN an inf. n. of 1: and also [used as] a simple subst. (TA.) See 1.
When it does not relate to birth, it means (assumed tropical:) Conformity, or similarity; and combination, agreement, or unison, in action. (Ibn-'Arafeh, TA.)

MxiyRapN, (Lth, S, Msb, K, &c.,) originally of the measure faAEuwlapN, [i. e. MxuwyapN,] (Msb,) and MxiyapN, (Lth, Msb, K,) and OaxiyRapN, (JK, K, TA, [but in the K the orthography of these three words is differently expressed in different copies, and somewhat obscurely in all that I have seen,]) A piece of rope of which the two ends are buried in the ground, (ISk, JK, S,) with a small staff or stick, or a small stone, attached thereto, (ISK, S,) a portion thereof, resembling a loop, being apparent, or exposed, to which the beast is tied; (ISk, JK, S;) it is made in soft ground, as being more commodious to horses than pegs, or stakes, protruding from the ground, and more firm in soft ground than the peg, or stake: (TA:) or a loop tied to a peg, or stake, driven [into the ground], to which the beast is attached: (Msb:) or a stick, or piece of wood, (K, TA,) placed crosswise (TA) in a wall, or in a rope of which the two ends are buried in the ground, the [other] end [or portion] protruding, like a ring, to which the beast is tied: (K, TA:) or a peg, or stake, to which horses are tied: (Har p. 42:) [see also MriIRu:] the pl. of the first is OawaAxiIRu; (JK, S, Msb, K;*) and of the second, OwaAxK; (Msb;) and of the third, OaxaAyaA, (JK, K,*) like as xaTaAyaA is pl. of xaTiyRapN. (TA.) In a trad., the believer and belief are likened to a horse attached to his MxyRp; because the horse wheels about, and then returns to his MxyRp; and the believer is heedless, and then returns to believe. (TA.) And in another, men are forbidden to make their backs like the OaxaAyaA of beasts; i. e., in prayer; meaning that they should not arch them therein, so as to make them like the loops thus called. (TA.)
Also i. q. TunubN; (K;) i. e. The kind of tent-rope thus called. (TA in art. Tnb, q. v.)

And (assumed tropical:) A sacred, or an inviolable, right or the like; syn. HuromapN and cimRapN. (S, K.) You say, lifulaAnK OawaAxiIRu waOasobaAbN turoEaI [(assumed tropical:) To such a one belong sacred, or inviolable, rights, and ties of relationship and love, to be regarded]. (S.) And lahu EinodiI MjiyRapN (assumed tropical:) He has, with me, or in my estimation, a strong, sacred, or inviolable, right; and a near tie or connexion, or means of access or intimacy or ingratiation. (TA.)

In a trad. of 'Omar, in which it is related that he said to El-'Abbás, Oanota MxiyRapu MbaMCi rasuwli AallRehi, it is used in the sense of baqiyRapa; [and the words may therefore be rendered Thou art the most excellent of the ancestors of the Apostle of God;] as though he meant, thou art he upon whom one stays himself, and to whom one clings, of the stock of the Apostle of God. (TA.)

1. OadRatRapu daAhiyapN, aor
Aaduda
(T, S; M, K) and
Aadida
, (M, K,) but this latter is strange, [anomalous,] and unknown, (TA,) and
Aadada
, (M, K,) mentioned by Lh, whence it seems that he made the pret. to be of the measure faEila, or that it is co-ordinate to OabaI, aor yaOobaI, (M,) inf. n. OadRu, (T, S, M,) A calamity befell him. (M, K.) And in like manner, OadRahu OamorN, aor. and inf. n. as above, An event befell him: (M:) or oppressed him, distressed him, or afflicted him. (Bd in xix. 91.)
See also 5.
5. tOdRd; (T, K;) and OadRa↓, inf. n. OadRu; (TA;) i. q. taXadRada [He acted, or behaved, with forced hardness, firmness, strength, vigour, &c.]. (T, K.)
OadRu (S, M, K) and UidRu↓ (T, K) and MdRu↓ (K) Strength; power; force: (S, M, K:) superior power or force or influence; mastery; conquest; predominance. (M, K, TA.)
See also UidRu, in two places.
Also, the first, The sound of treading. (T.)
UidRu: see OadRu.

Also, and UidRapN↓, A wonder, or wonderful thing: (M, L, K:) a very evil, abominable, severe, thing, or affair: (S, M, A, L, K:) a calamity; (S, A, L, K,) or thus the former word signifies; (M;) as also OadRu↓, (as in the copies of the K,) or MdRu↓, [originally MdidF] of the measure faAEilo: (so in the S and L:) pl. (of UidRu M, TA) UidAdu (K, TA,) or OadaAdu (T, CK, [but this, if correct, is a quasi-pl. n.,]) or MdaAdu (M,) and (of UidRapN, S, M) UidadN (T, S, M, K.) You say also OamoroUidRu [meaning as above], using UidRu as an epithet, accord. to Lh. (M.) And daAhiyapN UidRapN↓ [A very evil, abominable, or severe, calamity]. (A.) Hence the saying in the Kur [xix. 91], laqado jiYotumo XayoYFA UidRFA Verily ye have done a very evil, or abominable, thing: (S, M: *) or, accord. to one reading, OadRuA↓; both meaning great, or grievous: and some of the Arabs say, biXaIoCK MdRK↓, which means the same. (T, TA.)
UidRapN: see UidRu in two places.
MdRu: see OadRu:
and see UidRu in two places.

1. Oadaba, aor.
Aadiba
, inf. n. OidobN, He invited (people, S, or a man, K) to his repast, or banquet; (S, K;) as also Mdaba↓, (K,) or Mdaba UilaI TaEaAmihi aor yuwdibu [or yuWodibu], (AZ, S,) inf. n. UiydaAbN [originally UiYodaAbN]. (AZ, S, K.) You say, Oadaba Alqawoma, (S,) or Oadaba EalaI Alqawomi, aor. as above, (T,) He invited the people to his repast. (T, S.) And Oadabahumo EalaI AlOamri He collected them together for the affair. (A.) And jiyraAnaka lituXaAwirahumo Ouwdibu↓ [I will collect thy neighbours in order that thou mayest consult with them]. (A.) The primary signification of OadobN is The act of inviting. (T.)

[Hence,] OadabN, aor.
Aadiba
; (Msb, K;) or Oadiba, aor.
Aadaba
; (so in a copy of the M;) inf. n. OadobN, (M, Mgh, Msb,) or OadabN; (K;) He made a repast, or banquet, (M, Msb, K,) and invited people to it; (Msb;) as also Mdaba↓, (M,) aor. and inf. n. as above: (TA:) or he collected and invited people to his repast. (Mgh.)

[Hence also, as will be seen below, voce OadabN] Oadabahu, aor.
Aadiba
, inf. n. OadobN, He taught him the discipline of the mind, and the acquisition of good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul; (Msb;) and OdRbhu↓, [inf. n. taOodiybN, signifies the same;] he taught him what is termed Oadab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. he disciplined him, or educated him, well; rendered him well-bred, wellmannered, polite; instructed him in polite accomplishments; &c.]: (S, M, A, Mgh, K:) or the latter verb, inf. n. taOodiybu, signifies he taught him well, or much, the discipline of the mind, and the acquisition of good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul: and hence, this latter also signifies he disciplined him, chastised him, corrected him, or punished him, for his evil conduct; because discipline, or chastisement, is a means of inviting a person to what is properly termed AlOadabu. (Msb.)

Oaduba, aor.
Aaduba
, (AZ, T, S, M, K,) inf. n. OadabN, (M, K,) He was or became, characterized by what is termed Oadab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e., well disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, or well-mannered, polite, instructed in polite accomplishments, &c.]. (AZ, T, S, M, K.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1, in three places.
Mdaba AlbilaAda, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He filled the provinces, or country, with justice, or equity. (K * TA.)

5. tOdRb He learned, or was taught, what is termed Oadab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. he became, or was rendered, well-disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, wellmannered, polite, instructed in polite accomplishments, &c.]; as also AstOdb↓. (S, Mgh, K.)

OadobN, (S, M, K,) or, accord. to some, UidobN↓, (TA,) Wonderful; or a wonderful thing; syn. EajabN; (S, M, K;) as also OudobapN↓ [used in the latter sense]. (K.) You say, jaMCa fulaAnN biOamorK UidobK↓ Such a one did a wonderful thing. (As, T. *)
See also OadabN, last sentence.
UidobN: see OadabN, in two places.

OadabN, so termed because it invites men to the acquisition of praiseworthy qualities and dispositions, and forbids them from acquiring such as are evil, (T, Mgh,) signifies Discipline of the mind; and good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul: (Msb:) or every praiseworthy discipline by which a man is trained in any excellence: (AZ, Mgh, Msb:) [good discipline of the mind and manners; good education; good breeding; good manners; politeness; polite accomplishments:] i. q. ZarofN [as meaning excellence, or elegance, of mind, manners, address, and speech]: and a good manner of taking or receiving [what is given or offered or imparted, or what is to be acquired]: (M, A, K:) or good qualities and attributes of the mind or soul, and the doing of generous or honourable actions: (El-Jawáleekee:) or the practice of what is praiseworthy both in words and actions: or the holding, or keeping, to those things which are approved, or deemed good: or the honouring of those who are above one, and being gentle, courteous, or civil, to those who are below one: (Towsheeh:) or a faculty which preserves him in whom it exists from what would disgrace him: (MF:) it is of two kinds, Oadabu AlnRafosi [which embraces all the significations explained above], and Oadabu AldRarosi [which signifies the discipline to be observed in the prosecution of study, by the disciple with respect to the preceptor, and by the preceptor with respect to the disciple: see ‘Haji Khalfæ Lexicon,’ Vol. I. p. 212]: (S, Btl, Mgh:) [also deportment, or a mode of conduct or behaviour, absolutely; for one speaks of good Oadab and bad Oadab:] the pl. is MdaAbN [which is often employed, and so is the sing. also, as signifying the rules of discipline to be observed in the exercise of a function, such as that of a judge, and of a governor; and in the exercise of an art, such as that of the disputer, and the orator, and the poet, and the scribe; &c.]. (Msb.)

Eilomu AlOadabi signifies [The science of philology; or] the science by which one guards against error in the language of the Arabs, with respect to words and with respect to writing; (‘Haji Khalfæ Lexicon,’ Vol. I. p. 215;) [and so, simply, AlOadabu: which is also used to signify polite literature: but in this sense, and like wise] as applied to the sciences relating to the Arabic language, [or the philological sciences, which are also termed AlEuluwmu AlOadabiyRaAtu↓,] AlOadabu is a post-classical term, innovated in the time of El-Islám. (El-Jawá- leekee.)
Oadabu AlbaHori, (A, K,) or AlbaHori Oadobu↓, (T, L,) (tropical:) The abundance of the water of the sea. (T, A, L, K.)
OudobapN: see maOodubapN:
and see also OadobN.
OadabiyRN Of, or relating to, what is termed Oadab, or AlOadab. Hence, AlEuluwmu AlOadabiyRaAtu: see UadabN, last sentence but one.]

OadiybN Characterized by what is termed Oadab [or good discipline of the mind and manners, &c.; i. e. well-disciplined, well-educated, well-bred, or well-mannered; polite; instructed in polite accomplishments, or an elegant scholar; &c.]: (T, S, M, Mgh, K:) pl. OudabaMCK. (M, K.)
See also maWadRabN.

Mdabu [originally OaOodabu, More, or most, characterized by what is termed Oadab; i. e. better, or best, disciplined, educated, bred, or mannered; more, or most, polite; &c.]. You say, huwamino Mdabi AlnRaAsi [He is of the best disciplined, &c., of men]. (A.)
MdibN One who invites people to a repast, or banquet: (T, S, Msb:) pl. OadabapN. (TA.)
maOodabapN: see what next follows, in two places.

maOodubapN A repast, or banquet, to which guests are invited; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) or made on account of a wedding: (M, K:) as also maOodubapN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, this latter has a different signification, as will be seen below, (TA,) and maOodubapu↓, (IJ,) and OudobapN↓: (M, K:) pl. maMdibu. (S.) In a trad., the Kur-án is called maOodubapu AllRehi fiI AlOaroDi, or maOodabap↓; and A 'Obeyd says that, if we read mOdubp, the meaning is, God's repast which He has made in the earth, and to which He has invited mankind; but if we read mOdabp, this word is of the measure mafoEalapN from AlOadabu, [and the meaning is, a means which God has prepared in the earth for men's learning good discipline of the mind, &c.; it being a noun similar to mavoraApN and makovarapN &c.:] El-Ahmar, however, makes both words synonymous. (T, M, * TA.)
maOodibapN: see what next precedes.
muWadRabN OadiybN↓ A camel well-trained and broken. (T, L.)
maOoduwbapN, occurring in a verse of 'Adee, [which I do not anywhere find quoted,] She [app. a bride] for whom a repast, or banquet, has been made. (TA.)

1. Oadira, aor.
Aadaba
, (T, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. OadarN (Lth, T, S, Mgh) and OadarapN, (Lth, TA,) or OudorapN, (as in the TT,) or OudorapN is a simple subst., (M, K,) and so is OudorapN, (K,) He (a man, S) had the disorder termed OudorapN. (T, S, M, &c.)

OudorapN a subst. from Oadira; [see Mdaru, below;] (K;) as also OadarapN↓: (M, K:) the former signifies [A scrotal hernia;] an inflation in the xuSoyap [or the testicle, or the scrotum]: (T, * S:) or an inflation of the xuSoyap: (Msb:) or a disorder consisting in an inflation, or a swelling, of the xuSoyataAni, and their becoming greatly enlarged with matter or wind therein: (Esh-Shiháb, on the Soorat el-Ahzáb:) or a largeness of the xuSa: (Mgh:) and OadarapN↓ also signifies what is vulgarly termed qayolapN [meaning in the present day a scrotal hernia]: or, accord. to some, i. q. xuSoyapN. (TA.) [See also 1.]
OadarapN: see OudorapN, in two places. [See also 1.]

Mdaru (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and maOoduwrN↓ (M, K) A man (S) [having a scrotal hernia; or] having an inflation in the xuSoyap [or the testicle, or the scrotum]: (T, * S:) or having an inflation of the xuSoyap: (Msb:) or having his SifaAq [or inner skin] ruptured, so that [some of] his intestines fall into his scrotum; the rupture being in every instance only in the left side: or afflicted by a rupture in one of his xuSoyaAni [or in either half of the scrotum]: (M, K:) or having a largeness of the xuSaI (Mgh:) pl. of the former, OudurN; (Msb, K;) and of the latter, maMdiyru. (K.) Accord. to some, (M,) OadoraMCu xuSoyapN signifies [A testicle, or scrotum,] large, without rupture. (M, K.)
maOoduwrN: see Mdaru.

1. Oadama Alxuboza, aor.
Aadima
, (M, Msb, K,) inf. n. OadomN; (M, Msb;) and Mdmhu↓, (Msb, K,) inf. n. UiydaAmN; (TK;) He mixed the bread with Oudom [or seasoning; i. e. he seasoned it]; (M, K;) he made the swallowing of the bread to be good, or agreeable, by means of UidaAm [or seasoning]. (Msb.) You say also, Oadama Alxuboza biAllRaHomi, aor.
Aadima
, [he seasoned the bread, or rendered it savoury, with flesh-meat,] from OudomN and UidaAmN, signifying maA yuWotadmu bihi. (S.)

Oadama Alqawoma, aor.
Aadima
, (K,) inf. n. OadomN; (TA;) or Mdamahumo↓; (M;) or both; (TA;) He seasoned for the people, or company of men, (Oadama lahumo, [in the CK, erroneously, AadAma lhm,]) their bread; (M, K, TA;) i. e., mixed it [for them] with UidaAm (TA.)

[From Oadama in the first of the senses explained above, is app. derived the phrase,] Oadamahu biOaholihi He mixed him, associated him, or united him in company, with his family. (M.) [And in like manner,] Oadama bayonahumaA, (T, S,) or bayonahumo, (M, Msb, * K,) aor.
Aadima
, (T, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. OadomN; (T, M, Msb;) and Mdm↓, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiyadAmN; (T, TA;) He (God, T, S, M, or a man, Msb) effected a reconciliation between them; brought them together; (S, M, Msb, K; [expl. in the M and K by laACa ma, for which we find in the CK laAuma;]) made them sociable, or familiar, one with another; (S, Msb, TA;) and made them to agree: (TA:) or induced love and agreement between them: held by A "Obeyd to be from OudomN, because thereby food is made good and pleasant. (T.) It is said in a trad., faUinRahu OaHoraI Oano yuWodama bayonakumaA, meaning For it is most fit, or meet, that there should be, between you two, love and agreement: (T, S:) or, that peace, or reconciliation, and friendship, should continue between you two. (Msb.) And a poet says,

i. e. [And the pure, or free from faults, among
women,] do not love any save one who is made an object of love [by his good qualities], (T, S,) a proper object of love. (T.)

Oadamahumo, (T, M, K,) aor.
Aadima
, (T,) or
Aaduma
, (M, K,) inf. n. OadomN, (M,) (tropical:) He was, or became, to them, what is termed Oadamap; (T, M, K;) i. e., one who made people to know them; (T;) or a pattern, an exemplar, an example, or one who was imitated, or to be imitated; and one by means of whom they were known: (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.)

Oadama AlOadiyma He pared, or removed the superficial part of, the hide: (T, * TA:) and AlOadiyma Mdama↓, with medd, he pared off the Oadamap [q. v.] of the hide: (TA:) or the latter signifies he exposed to view the Oadamap [in the CK, erroneously, the Audomap] of the hide. (M, K.)

Oadima, aor.
Aadama
, (M, K,) inf. n. OadamN; (TK;) and Oaduma, aor.
Aaduma
, (M, K,) inf. n. OuduwmapN (T, K) [or, more probably, OudomapN, like sumorapN &c.]; He (a camel, and a gazelle, and a man,) was, or became, of the colour termed Oudomap, q. v. infrà. (M, K.)
2. OdRmhu, inf. n. taOodiymN, He put much UidaAm [or seasoning] into it. (TA.)
4: see 1, in five places.

8. AYtdm bihi [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytadama] He made use of it [to render his bread pleasant, or savoury]; namely Oudom, (M, * TA,) or UidaAm. (M.) [UidaAmN is explained in the T and S &c. by the words maA yuWotadamu bihi, meaning That which is used for seasoning bread.]
AYtdm AlEuwdu (tropical:) The wood, or branch, had the sap (AlmaMC) flowing in it. (Z, K.)
10. AstOdmhu He sought, or demanded, of him UidaAm [or seasoning]. (Z, TA.)
OadomN: see OudomapN
huwa Oadomu Oaholihi: see OadamapN.
OudomN: see UidaAmN.
huwa Oudomu Oaholihi: and Oudomu baniI Oabiyhi: see OadamapN.
OadamN: see OadiymN, in two places:
and OadamapN.
Oadamu: see Mdamu.
huwa Oadomapu Oaholihi: see OadamapN.
OudomapN A state of mixing, or mingling, together [in familiar, or social, intercourse]. (Lth, T, M, K.) You say, bayonahumaA OudomapN Between them two is a mixing, &c. (Lth, T.)

Also, (M, K,) or OadomN↓, (S,) Agreement: (S, M, K, TA:) and familiarity, sociableness, companionship, or friendship. (S, TA. [The meanings in this sentence are assigned in the S only to the latter word: in the TA, only to the former.])
And the former, Relationship. (M, K.)

And A means of access (wasiylapN, Fr, T, S, M, K) to a thing, (Fr, T, S,) and to a person; (Fr, T;) as also OadamapN↓. (K.) You say, fulaAnN OudomatiI Uilayoka Such a one is my means of access to thee. (Fr, T.)
And [hence,] A present which one takes with him in visiting a friend or a great man; in Peraian dasot Mwiyz. (K, L.)
huwa Oudomapu Oaholihi: and huwa OudomapN lifulaAnK: see OadamapN.

In camels, A colour intermixed, or tinged, with blackness, or with whiteness; or clear whiteness; (M, K;) or, as some say, (TA,) intense whiteness; (S, TA;) or whiteness, with blackness of the eyeballs: (Nh, TA:) and in gazelles, a colour intermixed, or tinged, with whiteness: (M, K:) or in gazelles and in camels, whiteness: (T:) and in human beings, (M, K,) a tawny colour; or darkness of complexion; syn. sumorapN [q. v.]; (S, M, K;) or an intermixture, or a tinge, of blackness; (Lth, T;) or intense sumorap [or tawniness]; and it is said to be from Oudomapu AlOaroDi, meaning the colour of the earth: (Nh, TA:) or [in men,] i. q. HumorapN [which, in this case, signifies whiteness of complexion]: (TA:) accord. to AHn, it signifies whiteness; syn. bayaADN. (M.) [See also Mdamu.]
OadamapN: see OudomapN.

huwa Oadamapu Oaholihi, (M, K,) and Oudomatuhumo↓, (M,) or Oadomatuhumo↓, (K,) and Oudomuhumo↓, (M,) or Oadomuhumo↓, and UidaAmuhumo↓, (K,) (tropical:) He is the pattern, exemplar, example, or object of imitation, of his people, or family, by means of whom they are known: (M, K:) so says IAar. (M.) And jaEalotu fulaAnFA Oadamapa OaholiI (tropical:) I made such a one to be the pattern, exemplar, example, or object of imitation, of my people, or family. (T, S.) And huwa OadamapN lifulaAnK, and OudomapN↓, (tropical:) He is a pattern, &c., to such a one. (Fr, TA.) And fulaAnN Oadamapu baniI fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one is he who makes people to know the sons of such a one. (T.) And huwa Oadamapu qawomihi (tropical:) He is the chief, and provost, of his people. (A, TA.) And qawomihi fulaAnN UidaAmu↓, and banI Oabiyhi Oudomu↓, (tropical:) Such a one is the aider, and manager of the affairs, and the support, and right orderer of the affairs, of his people, and of the sons of his father. (A, TA.)

[The inner skin; the cutis, or derma;] the interior of the skin, which is next to the flesh; (S, M, K;) the exterior thereof being called the baXarap: (S:) or (as some say, M) the exterior thereof, upon which is the hair; the interior thereof being called the baXarap: (M, K:) and OadamN↓ may be its pl.; [or rather, a coll. gen. n.;] or, accord. to Sb, it is a quasi-pl. n. (M.)
Accord. to some, (M,) What appears of the skin of the head. (M, K. [See baXarapN.])
And (assumed tropical:) The interior of the earth or ground; (M, K;) the surface thereof being called its Oadiym: (M, TA:) or, as some say, its surface. (TA.)
OadamiIRN A seller of [Oadam, or] skins, or hides: (TA:) and OadRaAmN↓ signifies the same; and particularly a seller of goats' skins. (Golius, from the larger work entitled Mirkát el-Loghah.)
OudomAanN and OudomaAnapN: see Mdamu.

UidaAmN (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and OudomN↓ (the same except the K) [Seasoning, or condiment, for bread; and any savoury food;] what is used for seasoniny (maA yuWotadamu bihi, T, S, M, * Mgh, Msb, K) with bread; (T, TA;) that which renders bread pleasant and good and savoury; (IAmb, Mgh;) whether fluid or not fluid; (Mgh, Msb;) SibogN and SibaAgN being peculiarly applied to that which is fluid: (Mgh:) or OudomN is anything that is eaten with bread: (TA:) the pl. [of mult.] of UidaAmN is OudumN, (Mgh, Msb,) and, by contraction, OudomN, which is also used as the sing., (Msb,) and [pl. of pauc.] MdimapN (M, K) and MdaAmN; (K;) or this last is pl. of OudomN. (M, Mgh, Msb, TA.) It is said in a trad., niEoma AlUidaAmu AlxalRu [Excellent, or most excel-lent, is the seasoning, vinegar!]. (T, TA.) And in another, sayRidu MdaAmi AldRunoyaA waAlMxirapi AllRaHomu [The prince of the seasonings of the present world and of the world to come is flesh-meat]. (TA.)
huwa UidaAmu Oaholihi, and UidaAmu qawomihi: see OadamapN.
Anything conforming, or conformable; agreeing, or agreeable; suiting, or suitable. (M, K.) [Used also as a pl.: thus,] 'Ádiyeh Ed-Dubeyreeyeh says,
[They were, to those who mixed with them in social intercourse, conformable, or agreeable.] (M.)

OadiymN i. q. maOoduwmN↓ [Seasoned]: (T:) or TaEaAmN maOoduwmN↓ [seasoned food]; (M, K;) food in which is UidaAm. (TA.) Hence the prov., samonukumo huriyqa fiI Oadiymikumo [Your clarified butter is poured into your seasoned food]; (T, TA;) applied to a niggardly man; (Har p. 462;) meaning, your good, or wealth, returns unto you: (TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, into your siqaMC [or skin]: (T, Har * ubi suprà:) and the vulgar say, fiI daqiyqikumo [into your flour]. (TA.) And the saying, samonuhumo fiI Oadiymihimo [Their clarified butter is in their seasoned food]; meaning, their good, or wealth, returns unto them. (M.) And the saying of Khadeejeh to the Prophet, UinRaka latakosibu wa tuToEimu AlmaOoduwma AlmaEoduwma↓ (M, TA) Verily thou gainest what is denied to others, or makest others to gain what they have not, of the things they want, or makest the poor to gain, (TA in art. Edm,) and givest to eat food in which is UidaAm. (TA in the present art.) [Hence also,] OaToEamotuka maOoduwmiI↓ (M, K) meaning Oatayotuka biEucoriI [I gave thee my excuse; or, perhaps, my virginity; see EucorapN]: (K:) [or,] as some say, the meaning is, my good manners: said by the wife of Dureyd Ibn-Es-Simmeh, on the occasion of his divorcing her. (M, TA.)

And hence, (Ham p. 205, Mgh,) Tanned skin or hide; leather: (M, Ham, Mgh, Msb:) or skin, or hide, (M, K,) in whatever state it be: (M:) or red skin or hide: (M, K:) or skin, or hide, in the state after that in which it is termed OafiyqN; that is, when it is complete [in its tanning] and has become red: (M:) or the exterior of the skin of anything: (T:) pl. [of pauc.] MdimapN (S, M, K) and MdaAmN and [of mult.] OudumN, (M, K,) the last from Lh, and [says ISd] I hold that he who says rusolN says OudomN, (M,) and OadamN↓, (T, S, Msb, K,) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (Sb, M, Mgh,) [often used as a gen. n.,] of which MdaAmN may be pl. (M.)

Aiboni OadiymK and Aibonu Oadiymayoni and Aibonu valaAvapi MdimapK: see AibonN in art. bnI. One says, UinRamaA yuEaAtabu AlOadiymu cuw AlbaXarapi [lit.] Only the hide that has the exterior part, upon which the hair grows, is put again into the tan: (T:) a prov.; (TA;) meaning, only he is disciplined, or
reproved, who is an object of hope, and in whom is full intelligence, and strength; (T, TA, and AHn in TA, art. bXr [where, however, in the TA, duwna is erroneously put for cw];) and only he is disputed with in whom is place for dispute. (TA.)
Oadiymu AlHarobi is used metaphorically for Oadiymu Oaholi AlHarobi (tropical:) [The skin of the warriors, or of the people engaged in war or fight]. (M.)

fulaAnN SaHiyHu AlOadiymi [lit. Such a one is sound of skin] means (tropical:) such a one is sound in respect of origin, and of honour, or reputation. (Har p. 135.) You say also, fulaAnN bariIoCu AlOadiymi mimRaA luTixa bihi [meaning (tropical:) Such a one is clear in honour, or reputation, of that with which he has been aspersed]. (M, * TA.) And mazRaqa OadamiI↓ (tropical:) He rent my honour, or reputation. (Har ubi suprà.)
OadiymN also signifies (tropical:) The surface of the earth or ground: (S, M:) [see also OadamapN, last sentence:] or what appears thereof, (K,) and of the sky. (M, K.)

And (tropical:) The first part of the period called AlDRuHaI. (M, K, TA.) You say, jiYotuka Oadiyma AlDRuHaI (tropical:) I came to thee in the first part of the DHI; (Lh, M;) app. meaning, Einoda QrotifaAEi AlDRuHaI [when the morning was becoming advanced; when the sun was becoming high]. (M.)

And (tropical:) The whiteness of day: (IAar, M, K, TA:) and (tropical:) the darkness of night: (IAar, M, TA:) or (tropical:) the whole of the day, (M, A, K, TA,) and of the night. (A, TA.) You say, ZalRa Oadiyma AlnRahaAri SaAYimFA waOadiyma AllRayoli qaAYimFA (tropical:) He continued the whole of the day fasting, and the whole of the night standing [in prayer, &c.]. (A, TA.)
OadRaAmN: see OadamiIRN.

Mdamu Of the colour termed OudomapN: pl. OudomN and OudomaAnN↓; (S, M, K;) the latter like HumoraAnN as a pl. of OaHomaru: (M:) the fem. sing. is OadomaMCu and OudomaAnapN↓; (S M, K;) the latter anomalous; (K;) occurring in poetry, but disapproved (S, M) by As; (S;) said by Aboo-'Alee to be like xumoSaAnapN; (M;) and the fem. pl. is OudomN: (S, M, K:) applied to a camel, of a colour intermixed, or tinged, with blackness, or with whiteness; or of a clear white; (M, K;) or, as some say, intensely white; (TA;) or white, and black in the eyeballs; (S;) or white; (As, T;) and so applied to a gazelle: (T:) or, applied to a gazelle, of a colour intermixed, or tinged, with whiteness; (M, K;) Lth, however, says that OadomaMCu is applied to a female gazelle, but he had not heard Mdamu applied to the male gazelle; (TA;) and As says, (S,) OudomN applied to gazelles signifies white, having upon them streaks in which is a dust-colour, (S, M,) inhabiting the mountains, and of the colour of the mountains; (S;) if of a pure white colour, they are termed MraAmN: (T, TA:) or, accord. to ISk, white in the bellies, tawny in the backs, and having the colour of the bellies and of the backs divided by two streaks of the colour of musk; and in like manner explained by IAar: (T:) applied to a human being, Mdamu signifies tawny; or dark-complexioned; syn. Oasomaru; (S, M, K;) or, thus applied, it signifies OHomaru AllRawoni [which, in this case, means white of complexion]; (TA;) and the pl. is OudomiAnN. (S.) The Arabs say, qurayoXu AlUibili OudomuhaA waSuhobuhaA, meaning The best of camels are those of them which are Oudom and those of them which are Suhob; [see OaSohabu;] like as Kureysh are the best of men. (M.)

Also [Adam,] the father of mankind; (S, M, K;) and likewise Oadamu↓; but this is extr.: (K:) there are various opinions respecting its derivation; but [these it is unnecessary to mention, for] the truth is that it is a foreign word, [i. e. Hebrew,] of the measure faAEalu, like Mzaru: (MF:) and [therefore] its pl. is OawaAdimu. (S, M, K.)
MdamiIRN [Of, or relating to, Adam: and hence, human: and a human being:] a rel. n. from Mdamu. (TA.)

UiydaAmapN (assumed tropical:) Level, hard, but not rugged, ground: (As:) or hard ground without stones; (K;) from OadiymN signifying the “surface” of the earth or ground: (TA:) or ground somewhat elevated; not much so; only found in plains, and producing vegetation, which, however, is disapproved, because its situation is rugged, and little water remains in it: (ISh:) pl. OayaAdiymu, (As, Esh-Sheybánee, IB, K,) which J erroneously says has no sing.: (K:) for he says, [in the S,] OayaAdiymu signifies hard and elevated tracts (mutuwn) of ground; and has no sing. (TA.)
muWodamN, as in an ex. cited above, (see 1,) Made an object of love; (T, S;) a proper object of love. (T.)
