OarojN; (K, TA;) (assumed tropical:) He excited discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, (S, K, TA,) bayona Alqawomi between, or among, the people, or company of men, like OarRaXa, (S, TA,) and fiy AlHarobi in war. (TA.) And OrRj AlHaroba, (S, K, TA, and Ham ubi suprà,) and OarajahaA↓, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He kindled war, or the war; (S, TA, and Ham ubi suprà;) and in like manner, AlnRaAra the fire. (IAar, Ham.)
5: see 1.
OarajN (L) and OariyjN↓ and OariyjapN↓ (ISd, TA) A sweet odour: (ISd, L, TA:) pl. of the last, OaraAYiju. (ISd, TA.) [See also 1.]
OarijN Perfume diffusing, or exhaling, its odour: having a hot, or strong, odour. (TA.)
Applied also to a place: you say, makaAnN OarijN A strongly fragrant place: (Msb:) and bayotN OarijN biAlRiybi [a house, or chamber, fragrant, or strongly fragrant, with perfume]. (A.)
OariyjN: see OarajN.
OariyjapN: see OarajN.
OarRaAjN (K) and miYorajN↓ (TA) (assumed tropical:) A liar: and one who excites discord, dissension, disorder, strife, quarrelling, or animosity, among people. (K, * TA.)
miYorajN: see what next precedes.
AlmuWarRaju (assumed tropical:) The lion. (K.)
1. Oaraxa AlkitaAba: see 2.

2. OarRaxa AlkitaAba, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taOoriyxN; (S, Mgh;) and Oaraxahu↓, (IKtt, Msb, K,) inf. n. OaroxN; (TA;) but the former is the more common, (Msb,) and the latter is by some rejected, though correct accord. to IKtt and others; (MF;) and Mrxhu↓, (K,) inf. n. muWaAraxapN; (TA;) as also warRaxahu, inf. n. taworiyxN; (S, Mgh, * Msb;) in which the w is a substitute for the C; (Yaakoob, Msb;) a form seldom used; (Msb;) He dated the writing, or letter; inscribed it with a date, or note of the time when it was written. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) You say also, OarRaxa AlkitaAba biyawomi kacaA He inscribed the writing, or letter, with the date of such a day. (S, L.) And OarRaxa AlbayRinapa He dated, or mentioned the date of, the evidence, proof, or voucher: in the contr. case saying, OaTolaqa. (Msb.) Some say that tOryx is an arabicized word, (L, Msb,) borrowed by the Muslims from the people of the Bible: [i. e., from the Jews or Christians; app. from the Hebr. יָרֵחַ the “moon,” or יֶרַח “a month;“ or from the Chald. יְרַח “a month;” as observed by Golius:] (L:) others say that it is [pure] Arabic: (Msb, TA:) some, that it is formed by transposition from taOoxiyrN. (TA.)
3: see 2.
OuroxapN: see what next follows.
taOoriyxN inf. n. of 2.

Also, [as a subst., generally pronounced without C,] A date; an era; an epoch; (Msb;) and OuroxapN↓ is a subst. [signifying the same,] from Oaraxa. (K.) taOoriyxu Alhijorapi is The era, or epoch, of the Emigration [or Flight (for such it really was)] of Mohammad [from Mekkeh to El-Medeeneh], (L, Msb,) which his companions, in the time of 'Omar, agreed to make their era, commencing the year from the first appearance of the new moon of [the month] ElMoharram, [two months before the Flight itself,] and making the day to commence from sunset: (Msb:) it is also called taOoriyxa Almusolimiyna the era, or epoch, of the Muslims. (L.)

Also The utmost limit, term, or time, of anything: whence the saying, fulaAnN taOoriyxu quwomihi Such a one is the person from whom date the nobility, or eminence, and dominion, or authority, of his people. (Es- Soolee, Mgh, TA.)
[Also, A chronicle; a book of annals; a history: pl. tawaAriyxu, from taworiyxN.]
[muWarRixN A chronicler; a writer of annals; a historian..]

OarozN and OurozN↓ The pine-tree; syn. Xajaru AlSRanawobari: (K:) or this is called OarorapN↓, and OarozN is the pl.: (A 'Obeyd, S:) [or rather OarozN is a coll. gen. n., and OarozapN is the n. un.:] or the male of that kind of tree; (AHn, K;) as also OarozapN↓; (K;) and the author of the Minháj adds, it is that which does not produce fruit; but pitch (zifot) is extracted from its trunks and roots, and its wood is employed as a means of light, like as candles are employed; and it grows not in the land of the Arabs: A 'Obeyd says, OarozapN↓ is the name of a tree well known in Syria, called with us SanawobarN, because of its fruit: he says also, I have seen this kind of tree, called OarozapN, and it is called in El-'Irák SanawobarN, but this last is the name of the fruit of the Oaroz: (TA:) or i. q. EaroEarN [a name given to the cypress and to the juniper-tree]. (K.) It is said in a trad., Almujociyapi mavalu AlkaAfiri mavalu AlOarozapi↓ EalaI AlOaroDi HatRaI yakuwna MnojiEaAfuhaA bimarRapK waAHidapK [The similitude of the unbeliever is the similitude of the pine-tree standing firmly upon the ground until it is pulled up at once]: respecting which AA and AO say that it is AlOarazap↓, with fet-h to the r; meaning the tree called AlOarozan: but A 'Obeyd thinks this to be a mistake, and that it is AlOarozap↓, with the r quiescent. (L.)
OurozN: see OarozN:
and see also OaruzRN.
OaruzN: see OaruzRN.
OuruzN: see OaruzRN.
OarozapN: see OarozN, in five places.

OarazapN The tree called OarozanN [which is a hard kind, from which staves are made]: (AA, S, K:) some say that it is MrizapN↓, of the measure faAEilapN; but A 'Obeyd disapproves of this. (TA.) See also OrozN.

OaruzRN and OuruzRN↓ and OurozN↓ and OuruzN↓ (S, Msb, K) and OaruzN↓ and MruzN↓ (Kr, K) and ruzN (S, Msb, K) and runozN, (S, K,) the first of which is the form commonly obtaining among persons of distinction; the last but one, that commonly obtaining among the vulgar; (TA;) and the last, of the dial. of 'AbdEl-Keys; (S, TA;) [Rice;] a certain grain, (S, K,) well known: (K:) [said in the TA to be a species of burR; but this is an improper explanation:] there are several kinds; Egyptian and Persian and Indian; and the best kind is the jwhrI [perhaps a mistake for miSorIR, or Egyptian]: it is cold and dry in the second degree; or, as some say, moderate; or, as some say, hot in the first degree; and its husk is poisonous. (El-Minháj, TA.)
OuruzRN: see OaruzRN.
MruzRN: see OaruzRN.
MrizapN: see OarazapN.

1. OaraXahu, (TA,) aor.
AaruXa
, (TK,) inf. n. OaroXN, (K, TA,) He scratched with the nails, or lacerated, him, [a man,] or it, [the skin, or (as in the TK) the face,] little or much, so as to bring blood or not; syn. xadaXahu. (K, * TA.) [This signification is probably derived from OaroXN as syn. with taOoriyXN, in which sense it seems to be the inf. n. of an obsolete verb.]
OaraXahu, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K, TA,) He gave him (K, * TA) the fine, or mulct, for a wound. (TA.)
OaraXuwhu, inf. n. as above, They sold the milk of their camels for the water of his well. (Sgh.)
OuriXa, like EuniIa, (Sgh,) inf. n. as above, (Sgh, K,) He sought to obtain, or demanded, the fine, or mulct, for a wound. Sgh, K. *)

2. OrRX bayona Alqawomi, (S, L, Msb,) and bayona AlrRajulayoni, (TA,) inf. n. taOoriyXN, (S, Msb,) He made mischief; or excited disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling; (S, L, Msb, TA;) between, or among, the people, or company of men, (S, L, Msb,) and between the two men: (TA:) accord. to some, its original is HarRaXa. (Msb.)
And ArRX AlnRaAra, inf. n. as above, He kindled the fire; or made it to burn: (S, K:) and in like manner, AlHaroba (assumed tropical:) war, or the war. (S.)
8. MYotariXo [written with the disjunctive alif AiytariXo] Take thou from him the fine, or mulct, for thy xumaAXap, q. v. (K.)
MYotaraXa liloxumaAXapi [He surrendered himself to pay the fine, or mulct, for the injury termed xumaAXap,] is like Aisotasolama liloqiSaASi. (K.)

OaroDN The making mischief; or exciting disorder, disturbance, disagreement, discord, dissension, strife, or quarrelling; [like taOoriyXN; see 2, and see also 1;] syn. fasaAdN [in the sense of UifosaAdN]; (Msb;) and UigoraMCN. (K.)
Disagreement, discord, or dissension; and contention, or altercation: you say, bayonahumaA OaroXN Between them two is disagreement, &c. (K.)

A fine, or mulct, for a wound: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) from the first of the significations in this paragraph; (Msb;) or from its being one of the causes of contention, or altercation; or, accord. to AM, from the same word as inf. n. of OaruwXN in the first of the senses explained in this art.; accord. to IF, originally haroXN: (TA:) pl. OuruwXN. (Mgh, Msb.) Hence the saying mentioned by IAar, AinotaZironiI HatRaI taEoqila falayosa laka EinodanaA OaroXN UilRaA AlOasinRapu [Wait thou for me until thou accept a fine for a wound in lieu of retaliation; for thou hast no compensation for a wound to receive from us except the spearheads]: meaning, thou shalt not slay a man for whom we will ever give bloodwit. (L, TA.)
What is diminished [of the price] by reason of a defect in a garment or piece of cloth: as being a cause of contention, or altercation. (K, * TA.)

What is payed [by way of adjustment of the difference] between freedom from defect and defect in an article of merchandise: (Kt, K:) for when the purchaser of a garment or piece of cloth as being free from defect discovers in it a hole or other defect, contention ensues between him and the seller. (TA.)
A bribe. (Aboo-Nahshal, Sh, K.)
maOoruwXN Scratched with the nails, or lacerated, little or much, so as to bleed or not. Ru-beh says,

Then say thou to that man who is disquieted by envy, and as though he were stung, Act thou gently, for [there is no scarf-skin scratched; meaning,] my honour is uninjured, having in it no defect nor scratch. (L, * TA.)

1. OaruDati AlOaroDu, (S, K, [in two copies of the S OuriDat, but this is evidently a mistake,]) with damm, (S,) like karumat, (K,) inf. n. OaraADapN, (S, M, K,) The land became thriving, or productive; (S, K;) as also AstOrDt↓; (TA;) it became pleasing to the eye, and disposed by nature to yield good produce; (K, TA;) it became fruitful, and in good condition; (M;) it collected moisture, and became luxuriant with herbage; it became soft to tread upon, pleasant to sit upon, productive, and good in its herbage or vegetation: (AHn:) and OaraDati AlOaroDu, (K,) aor.
AaruDa
, (TA,) the land became abundant in herbage, or pasture. (K.)
OaruDa, inf. n. OaraADapN, is also said of a man, meaning (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, lowly, or submissive, and naturally disposed to good, or to do good. (L, TA,)
OaraDa AlOaroDa He found the land to be abundant in herbage, or pasture. (K.)

OuriDati AlxaXabapu, (S, A, Msb, TA,) in the pass. form, (Msb,) like EuniI, (TA,) aor. tuWoraDu, (S, TA,) inf. n. OaroDN, (S, A, TA,) with sukoon [to the r]; (S, TA;) and some add OariDat, aor. taOoraDu, inf. n. as above; (TA; [and so in a copy of the S in the place of what here precedes;]) The piece of wood was, or became, eaten by the OaraDap, q. v. (S, A, Msb, TA.)

OariDati AlqaroHapN, (S, M. K,) aor.
AaraDa
, (S, K,) inf. n. OaraDN, (S, M,) The ulcer, or sore, became blistered, (S, M, K,) and wide, (M,) and corrupt (S, M, K) by reason of thick purulent matter, (S,) and dissundered; (M;) so says As; (TA;) as also AstOrDt↓. (Sgh, K.)

OuriDa, like EuniIa, (K,) inf. n. OaroDN; (TA;) or OariDa, like samiEa, aor.
AaraDa
, inf. n. OaroDN; (L;) He was, or became, affected with zukaAm [or rheum]. (L, K.)

2. ArRD, (TK,) inf. n. taOoriyDN, (K,) He depastured the herbage of the earth, or land: and he sought after it: (K:) or, accord. to some, taOoriyDN denotes this latter signification with respect to a place of alighting, or abiding: (TA:) and you say [also], Almanozila tOrRD↓ he sought after, and chose, the place for alighting, or abiding: (M, TA:) and lilomanozili tarakotu AlHaIRa yataOarRaDuwna↓ I left the tribe seeking after a tract of country in which to alight, or abide. (TA.)
He, or it, rendered heavy; [app. meaning slow, or sluggish; see 5;] syn. vaqRala. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
He made to tarry; to tarry and wait, or expect; or to be patient, and tarry, and wait, or expect. (Ibn- 'Abbád, K.)
4. MrD, inf. n. UiyoraADN: see 5.
maA MraDu hcaA AlmakaAna How abundant is the herbage (EuXob) of this place! or, as some say, maA MraDa hcihi AlOaroDa How level, or soft, and productive, and good, is this land! (Lh, AHn.)
MraDahu, (S, K, [in the CK, incorrectly, AaraDahu,]) inf. n. as above, (S,) He (God) caused him to be affected with zukaAm [or rheum]. (S, K.)
5. tArRD It (herbage) became in such a state that it might be cut. (S, K.)

He clave, or kept, to the ground, not quitting it: (A:) and MrD↓, inf. n. UiyraADN, he remained upon the ground: and tOrRD biAlmakaAni he remained fixed in the place, not quitting it: or he waited, or expected, and stood upon the ground: and, as also bAlmkAn AstOrD↓, he remained, and tarried, or tarried in expectation, in the place: or he remained fixed therein: (TA:) and tOrRD alone, he tarried, loitered, stayed, waited, or paused in expectation: (S, TA:) and he was, or became, heavy, slow, or sluggish, inclining, or propending, to the ground; (S, K;) [as also AstOrD↓, accord. to IB's explanation of its act. part. n.] You say, fulaAnN Uino raOaI maToEamFA taOarRaDa waUino OaSaAba maToEamFA OaEoraDa [Such a one, if he see food, cleaves, or keeps, to the ground, not quitting it; and if he obtain food, turns away: or tOrRD may here be rendered agreeably with the explanation next following]. (A, TA.)

jaMCi fulaAnN yataOarRaDu liI (S, K, * TA) Such a one came asking, or petitioning, for a thing that he wanted, to me; syn. yataSadRaI, and yataEarRaDu; (S, K, TA;) and taDarRaEa is also a syn. of taOarRaDa, used in this manner. (TA.)
See also 2, in two places.
10: see 5, in two places.
AstOrD AlsRaHaAbu The clouds expanded, or spread: or, as some say, became fixed, or stationary. (M, TA.)
See also 1, first signification:
and see 1 again, last signification but one.

AlOaroDu [The earth;] that whereon are mankind: (TA:) [and earth, as opposed to heaven: and the ground, as meaning the surface of the earth, on which we tread and sit and lie; and the floor: without Al signifying a land, or country: and a piece of land or ground: and land, or soil, or ground, considered in relation to its quality:] it is fem.: (S, A, Msb, K:) and is a coll. gen. n.; (S, A, K;) of which the n. un. should be OaroDapN, but this they did not say: (S:) or a pl. having no sing.; (A, K;) for OaroDapN has not been heard: (K:) its pl. is OaraDaAtN, (S, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K OaroDaAtN, (TA,) for they sometimes form the pl. of a word which has not the fem. p with A and t, as in the instance of EurusaAtN; (S;) and OaraDuwna, [which is more common,] (AZ, AHn, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) with fet-h to the r, (AZ, AHn, Mgh, Msb,) and with w and n, though a fem. has not its pl. formed [regularly] with w and n unless it is of the defective kind, like vubapN and ZubapN, but they have made the w and n [in this instance] a substitute for the A and t which they have elided [from OaraDaAtN], and have left the fet-hah of the r as it was; (S;) but they also said OaroDuwna, (AZ, AHn, S,) sometimes, making the r quiescent; (S;) and OuruwDN (AZ, AHn, Msb, K) is sometimes used as a pl., as in the saying maA Oakovara OuruwDa baniI fulaAnK [How many are the lands of the sons of such a one!]; (TA;) and another [and very common] pl. is [OaraADK, with the article written] AlOaraADiI, contr. to rule, (S, Msb, K,) as though they had formed a pl. from MruDN; (S;) thus written in all the copies of the S; [accord. to SM; but in one copy of the S, I find kaOanRahumo jamaEuwA AArADFA; and in another, ArDFA;] and in one copy [is added], “ thus it is found in his [J's] handwriting; ” but IB says that correctly he should have said OaroDaI, like OaroTaI; for as to MruDN, its regular pl. would be OawaAriDu; and [SM says] I have found it observed in a marginal note to the S that the pl. of MruDN would be OaMriDu, like as OakaAlibu is pl. of OakolubN; and wherefore did he not say that AlArADI is a pl. of an unused sing., like layaAlK and OahaAlK, so that it is as though it were pl. of OaroDaApN, like as layaAlK is pl. of layolaApN? yet if any one should propose the plea that it may be formed by transposition from OaMriDu, he would not say what is improbable; its measure being in this case OaEaAlifu; the word being OaraADiYu, and the C being changed into I: (TA:) accord. to Abu-l-Khattáb, (S,) MraADN is also a pl. of OaroDN, (S, K,) like as MhaAlN is a pl. of OaholN; (S;) but IB says that, in the opinion of the critics, the truth with respect to what is related on the authority of Abu-l-Khattáb is, that from OaroDN and OaholN are formed OaraADK and OahaAlK, as though they were pls. of OaroDaApN and OaholaApN; like as they said layolapN and layaAl, as though this were pl. of layolaApN. (TA.) It is said in proverbs, OajomaEu mina AlOaroDi [More comprehensive than the earth]: (TA:) and Mmanu mina AlOaroDi [More trustworthy than the earth, in which treasures are securely buried]: and OaXadRu mina AlOaroDi [Harder than the earth, or ground]: (A, TA:) and OacalRu mina AlOaroDi [More vile, or more submissive, than the earth, or ground]. (TA.) And you say, mano OaTaAEaniI kunotu lahu OaroDaA (tropical:) [Whoso obeyeth me, I will be to him as ground whereon one treads]; denoting submissiveness. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN UinN Duriba faOaroDN (tropical:) [Such one, if he be beaten, is like ground]; i. e. he cares not for beating. (A, TA.) One says also, laA OaroDa laka [Mayest thou have no land, or country! or thou hast no land, or country]; like as one says, laA OumRa laka. (S, K,)
[And hence,] huwa Abonu OaroDK He is a stranger, (A, K, TA,) of whom neither father nor mother is known. (TA.)

Aibonu AlOaroDi [with the art. Al prefixed to the latter word] is A certain plant, (AHn, K,) which comes forth upon the summits of the [hills called] MkaAm, having a stem (OaSol), but not growing tall, (AHn,) which resembles hair, and is eaten, (AHn, K,) and quickly dries up; (AHn;) a species of baqol, as also binotu AlOaroDi: (S in art. bnI:) and banaAtu AlOaroDi plants: (M in art. bsr:) and the places which are concealed from the pastor. (S in that art.) Also The pool that is left by a torrent: (T in art. bnI:) and banaAtu AlOaroDi pools in which are remains of water: (IAar in TA art. bsr:) and rivulets. (T in art. bnI.)
OaroDN is also used to signify (assumed tropical:) A carpet; or anything that is spread: and in this sense, in poetry, it is sometimes made masc. (Msb.)

And (assumed tropical:) Anything that is low. (S, K.) And (tropical:) The lower, or lowest, part of the legs of a horse or the like: (S, K:) or the legs of a camel or of a horse or the like: and the part that is next to the ground thereof. (TA.) You say baEiyrN Xadiydu AlOaroDi (tropical:) A camel strong in the legs. (TA.) And farasN baEiydN maA bayoma OaroDihi wasamaAYihi (tropical:) A horse that is large and tall. (A, TA.)
Also, of a man, (tropical:) The knees and what is beneath, or below, (lit. after,) them. (TA.)
And of a sandal, (assumed tropical:) [The lower surface of the sole;] the part that touches the ground. (TA.)

A febrile shivering; a tremor: (S, K:) or vertigo: or it signifies also vertigo arising from a relaxed state, and occasioning a defluxion from the nose and eyes. (TA.) I'Ab is related to have said, on the occasion of an earthquake, Oazulozilati AlOaroDu Oamo biI OaroDN, (S,) i. e. [Hath the earth been made to quake, or is there in me] a tremor? or a vertigo? (TA.) [Oaholu AlOaroDi signifies A certain class of the jinn, or genii; by whom human beings are believed to be possessed, and affected by an involuntary tremor; whence it seems that this appellation may perhaps be from OaroDN as signifying “ a tremor. ” See maOoruwDN: and see xabalN, as explained in the S.]
Also Rheum; syn. zukaAmN: (S, K:) in this sense masc.; or, accord. to Kr, fem., on the authority of Ibn-Ahmar. (TA.)
See also maOoruwDN.
OaraDN: see OaraDapN.
OuroDapN: see what next follows.
UiroDapN of herbage, What suffices the camels, or other pasturing animals, for a year: (IAar, AHn, M:) or abundant herbage or pasture; as also OuroDapN↓ and UiraDapN↓. (K.)

OaraDapN [The wood-fretter;] a certain insect that eats wood, (S A, Msb, K,) well known; (A, K;) it is a white worm, resembling the ant, appearing in the days of the [season called] rabiyE: (TA:) there are two kinds: one kind is small, like the large of the carR [or grubs of ants]; and this is the bane of wood in particular: (AHn, TA:) or this kind is the bane of wood and of other things, and is a white worm with a black head, not having wings, and it penetrates into the earth, and builds for itself a habitation of clay, or soil; and this is said to be that which ate the staff of Solomon [as is related in the Kur xxxiv. 13, where it is called daAbRapu AlOaroDi, as is said in the A]: (TA:) the other kind [is the termite, or white ant; termes fatale of Linn.; called by Forskål (in his Descr. Animalium &c., p. 96,) termes arda, destructor; and this] is like a large common ant, having wings; it is the bane of everything that is of wood, and of plants; except that it does not attack what is moist, or succulent; and it has legs: (AHn, TA:)
the pl. is OaraDN↓ (AHn, Msb, TA) and OaraDaAtN; (Msb;) or, as some [more properly] say, OaraDN is a quasi-pl. [or coll. gen.] n. (AHn, TA.) It is said in a prov., Mkalu mina AlOaraDapi [More consuming than the wood-fretter, or the termite]. (TA.) And in another, Oafosadu mina AlOaraDapi [More marring, or injuring, or destructive, than the wood-fretter, or the termite.] (A, TA.)
OariDapN: see OariyDN.
UiraDapN: see UiroDapN.
OaruwDN: see OaryDN.
OariyDN part. n. of OaruDa.

You say OaroDN OariyDapN (S, A, K) and OariDapN↓ (TA) Land that is thriving, or productive; (S, A, K;) pleasing to the eye; (AA, S, A, K;) and disposed by nature to yield good produce: (A, K, TA:) or fruitful; increasing in plants or herbage: (IAar:) or level, or soft: (ISh:) or that collects moisture, and becomes luxuriant with herbage; that is soft to tread upon, pleasant to sit upon, productive, and good in its herbage or vegetation: (AHn:) it also signifies a wide land; syn. EariyDapN: (TA:) and UiraADNK [as pl. of OariyDN] is syn. with EiraADN and wisaAE; (AA, K, TA;) as though the C were a substitute for the E. (TA.)

OariyDN is also an imitative sequent to EariyDN; (S, K;) as in the phrase OariyDN XaIoCN EariyDN [A very wide thing]: (S:) or it signifies fat, as an epithet: (K:) some use it in this sense without EriyD, applied to a kid. (S.) And you say, AimoraOapN EariyDapN OariyDapN [A very wide, or wide and fat, woman; or, as seems to be indicated in the TA in art. EraD, prolific and perfect]; and in like manner, muWoriDapN↓. (TA.) You say also rajulN OariyDN, (S,) and liloxayori OaruwDN↓, (A,) A man lowly, or submissive; (S;) naturally disposed to good, or to do good. (S, A.) And nafosN waAsiEN OariyDN: see raAbiTN.

huwaMraDuhumo bihi He is the most adapted, meet, suited, fitted, or fit, of them, for it; or most worthy of them of it. (K.) And huwaMraDuhumo Oano yafoEala clika He is the most adapted, &c., or most worthy, of them to do that. (As, S.)
muWoriDapN: see OariyDN.
maOoruwDN Wood eaten by the OaraDap [or woodfretter, or termite, but generally meaning the former]; (S, A, Msb, K;) as also OaroDN↓. (TA.)

A person affected with xabal [q. v.] from the jinn, or genii, and [what are called] Oaholu AlOaroDi, (S, K,) i. e. (so accord. to the S and TA, but in the K “ and ”) he who moves about his head and body involuntarily. (S, K.)

A person affected with zukaAm [or rheum]: (S, K:) accord. to Sgh, [who seems, like J, not to have known OuriDa,] from MraDahu; (Sgh, TA;) whereas by rule, [if from MriDahu,] it should be muWoraDN. (TA.)

fasiylN musotaOoriDN, and wadiyRapN musotaOoriDapN, A young palm-tree, and a small young palm-tree, having a root in the ground: such as grows forth from the trunk of the mother-tree is called raAkibN. (S, K.)
musotaOoriDN also signifies Heavy, slow, or sluggish, inclining, or propending, to the ground. (IB.)

1: [The unaugmented verb from this root seems to be unknown, if it were ever in use, for it is not mentioned, though the pass. part. n., maOoruwTN, is mentioned as having three significations, which see below.]
2: see 4.

4. MraTati AlOaroDu, (AHeyth, K,) of the measure OafoEalat, [originally] with two alifs, (TA,) [aor. yuWoriTu, inf. n. UiyraATN,] The land produced the kind of trees called OaroTFI [or OaroTaI]; (AHeyth, K;) as also OaroTat, inf. n. UiroTaMCN; or this is a corruption, attributable to J: so says the author of the K, following AHeyth: but it is no corruption, for it is mentioned by the authors on verbs and by ISd and others; (MF, TA;) for instance, by AHn, in his book on plants, and by IF, in the Mj: (TA:) [and J mentions it in its proper place, in art. rTI, as well as in the present art.:] OarRaTat↓, with the r musheddedeh, has also been found in the handwriting of certain of the men of letters; but this is a corruption. (K.)
OariTN A colour like that of the OaroTFy [or OaroTay]. (Sgh, K.)

OaroTFy, (Mbr, S, K,) of the measure faEolFI, because you say OadiymN maOoruwTN, [explained below,] (Mbr, S,) the alif (Mbr, S, K) ending it (Mbr) [written I] being a letter of quasi-coordination, (S, K,) not to denote the fem. gender, (Mbr, S,) its n. un. being OaroTaApN, (Mbr, S, K,) wherefore it is with tenween when indeterminate, but not when determinate: (S, K:) or it is of the measure OafoEalN, (Mbr, * S,) the last letter being radical, (Mbr,) because you say OadiymN maroTiyRu, (Mbr, S,) and in this case it should be mentioned among words with an infirm letter [for the last radical], and is with tenween both when determinate and when indeterminate; (S;) [but this is a mistake, for when it is determinate, it can be with tenween only if used as a proper name; therefore,] IB observes, that if you make its last letter radical, its measure is OafoEal, and a word of this measure, if a subst., is imperfectly decl. when determinate, but perfectly decl. when indeterminate: (TA:) [the author of the K copies the error of the S, saying, “ or its alif is radical, ” (meaning its last letter,) “ and in this case it is always with tenween; ” and he adds, “ or, ” (for which he should have said “ and, ”) its measure is OafoEal: to all which it is necessary to add, that some of the grammarians hold it to be also of the measure faEolaI, ending with a fem. alif, and therefore assign to it no n. un.:] A kind of tree, (S, K,) of those growing in sands, (S, TA,) resembling the kind called EiDaAh, growing as a branch [in the TA EaSabFA, for which I read guDonFA,] from a single stem, to the height of the stature of a man, the leaves whereof are what are termed hadab [q. v., and are included among those termed xuwS], (AHn, TA,) and its flower is like that of the xilaAf [or salix ægyptia], (AHn, K,) save in being smaller, the colour being one; and the odour thereof is pleasant: it grows in sands, and therefore the poets make frequent mention of the wild bulls' and cows' taking refuge among this and other trees of the sands, burrowing at their roots to hide themselves there, and to protect themselves from the heat and cold and rain, but not among the trees in hard ground, for burrowing in the sand is easy: (AHn, TA:) its fruit is like the EunRaAb [or jujube], bitter, and is eaten by camels in its fresh moist state, and its roots are red, (AHn, K,) intensely red: (AHn, TA:) AHn adds, a man of the Benoo-Asad informed me, that the leaves (hadab) of the ArTy are red like the red pomegranate: its fruit also is red: (TA:) the dual is OaroTayaAni: (AHn, TA:) and the pl. OaroTayaAtN and OaraATayi and OaraATK, (AHn, K,) in the accus. case OraATiy. (TA.)
OaroTawiIRN: see what next follows.
OaroTaAwiIRu: see what next follows.
maOoruwTN A hide tanned with OaroTFy; (S, K;) i. e. with the leaves thereof; (S in art. rTy;) as also muWaroTFy↓; (TA;) and so maroTiyRN. (S.)
A camel having a complaint from eating OaroTFy: (L, K: *) and a camel that eats OaroTFy, (AZ, S, K,) and keeps to it; (K;) as also OaroTawiIRu↓ (AZ, S, K) and OaroTaAwiIRN↓. (Ibn-'Abbád, Sgh, L, K.)
muWaroTFy: see what next precedes.

2. OarRafahaA, (T, M, Mgh,) namely AldRaAra, and AlOaroDa, (T, M,) inf. n. taOoriyfN, (T,) He set, or put, limits, or boundaries, [Ouraf,] to it; (M, Mgh;) and marked it out: (Mgh:) or he divided it; and set, or put, limits, or boundaries, to it: (T:) namely the house, and the land. (T, M.) And OurRifa EalaI AlmaAli, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or ElI AlOaroDi, inf. n. as above, (K,) The property, (S, Mgh, Msb,) or the land, (K,) had limits, or boundaries, set, or put, to it, (S, Msb, K,) or around it; (Mgh;) and was divided. (K.) When this is done, it is said that there is no Xufogap [or right of preemption] with respect to the property. (S, Mgh, Msb.)
taOoriyfN also signifies The tying a rope, or cord, so as to form a knot or knots. (K.)
UanRahu lagiI Uirofi majodK i. q. Urovi majodK [Verily he is of a glorious origin, race, or stock]: mentioned by Yaakoob as an instance of a change of letters. (M.)

OurofapN A limit, or boundary, (As, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) making a separation (Msb) between two pieces of land; (Msb, K;) a sign, or mark, (As, T, S, Mgh,) of the limits, or boundaries, between two pieces of land: (S:) and a separation between houses and estates: (M:) and a dam between two pieces of land sown or for sowing: (Th, M:) Yaakoob asserts that its f is a substitute for the v of OurovapN [which is, however, less com-
mon]: (M:) the pl. is OurafN, (T, S, M, &c.,) signifying, accord. to Lh, like OuravN, limits, or boundaries, between two pieces of land [&c.]; (T;) and it is said in a trad., that these cut off AlXRufoEap [i. e. the right of preemption]; (T, S, Mgh;) meaning, in the language of the people of El- Hijáz, signs, or marks, and limits, or boundaries. (T.) Th relates that an Arab woman said, jaEala EalayRa zawojiI OurofapF laA OajuwzuhaA, i. e. My husband set me a sign, or mark, [or limit,] beyond which I should not pass. (M.) And Ourofapu OajalK signifies An extreme limit of a period of existence. (TA, from a trad.)
Also A knot. (Sgh, K.)
OurofiIRN A measurer of land, (K, * TA,) who marks it with limits, or boundaries. (TA.)
huwamuWaArifiI He has his limit, or boundary, next to mine, in dwelling, and in place: (K:) a phrase like huwamutaAximiI. (TA.)

1. Oariqa, aor.
Aaraqa
, inf. n. OaraqN, (T, S, K, &c.,) He was sleepless, or wakeful, or sleep departed from him, (JK, T,) by night; (T;) i. q. sahira (S, Mgh, Sgh, K) biAllRayoli; (Sgh, K;) or i. q. sahida: (S, and L and K in art. shd:) or sleep departed from him by reason of a malady, or a distracting accident or event: (M:) or he was sleepless or wakeful (sahira) in a case that was disliked, or evil; sahira having a general sense: (M, F:) or he shut his eyes one while and opened them another, [being unable to continue sleeping,] whereas sahira signifies he did not sleep at all: (Deewán of the Hudhalees, cited by Freytag in his Lex.:) or OaraqN signifies sleeplessness, or wakefulness, engendered by anxiety and grief: (Har p. 162:) and AYtrq↓ [with the disjunctive alif written Aiytaraqa] signifies the same as Oariqa. (S, K.)
Ouriqati AlnRaxolapu [and Ouriqa AlzRroEu] The palm-tree [and the seed-produce] was affected, or smitten, by what is termed OaraqaAn. (JK.)
2. OarRaqaniI kacaA, (JK, S, K, *) inf. n. taOoriyqN. (S, Mgh,) Such a thing rendered me, or caused me to be, sleepless or wakeful; (JK, S, Mgh, * K; *) as also MrqnI↓, (K,) inf. n. UiyraAqN. (TA.)
4: see 2.
8: see 1.
OaroqN: see OaraqaAnN.
OaruqN: see what next follows.

OariqN Sleepless or wakeful (S, K) by night (K) [by reason of a malady, or a distracting accident or event, &c. (see 1)]; as also MriqN↓ (IF, K) and OaruqN↓ and OuruqN↓; or the last signifies habitually so. (TA.)
OuruqN: see what next precedes.

OaraqaAnN (JK, S, K) and OaruqaAnN and OaroqaAnN and UiriqaAnN and UiroqaAnN and OaroqN↓ and OuraAqN↓ (K) i. q. yaraqaAnN; (JK, S, K;) OraqaAnN being a dial. var. of this last; (S;) or the hemzeh is a substitute for the I; (L;) and yrqAn is the word most commonly known; (K;) A blight, or disease, which affects, or smites, seed-produce: (JK, S, K:) and a disease [namely jaundice] which affects, or smites, man, (S, K,) causing the person to become yellow [or blackish]; (TA;) it is a disease which changes the colour of the person excessively to yellowness or blackness, by the flowing of the yellow or black humour to the skin and the part next thereto, without putridity. (Ibn-Seenà [Avicenna], K.)
OuraAqN: see OaraqaAnN.
MriqN: see OariqN.

ziroEN maOoruwqN Seed-produce affected, or smitten, with a blight, or disease, (JK, S, K,) such as is termed OaraqaAn; (JK, S;) as also mayoruwqN [from yaraqaAn]: (S, K:) and naxolapN maOoruwqapN a palm-tree affected, or smitten, therewith. (JK, TA.)

1. Oarakati AlUibilu, aor.
Aaruka
and
Aarika
, inf. n. OuruwkN, The camels fed upon the kind of tree called OaraAk: (S, Msb, K:) or remained, or continued, among trees of that kind, (ISk, S, K,) i. e., what are termed HamoD, (ISk, S,) eating them: (K:) or found, or lighted on, any trees whatever, and remained, or continued. among them: (K:) or, accord. to As, kept in a place (bimakaAnK), not removing therefrom: (ISk, S:) or remained, or continued, in a place for the purpose of feeding upon the ArAk: and hence the signification next following, which is tropical. (Er-Rághib.)

Oaraka biAlmakaAni, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Msb, TA,) (tropical:) He (a man, S) remained, continued, or abode, in the place, (S, Msb, K,) not quitting it; (TA;) as also Oarika, aor.
Aaraka
, (K,) inf. n. OarakN. (TA.)
And Oaraka, (K,) inf. n. OarokN and OuruwkN (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He persisted, or persevered, syn. lajRa, (K,) i. e. OaSarRa, (T, K,) in an affair. (T, K.)
And, (K,) inf. n. OuruwikN, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He held back, or drew back, (taOaxRara,) in an affair. (K.)

Oaraka AlUibila, (K,) aor.
Aaruka
, (TA,) inf. n. OarokN, (K,) He fed the camels, or made them to feed, upon the kind of the tree called OaraAk: or made them to remain, or continue, among trees of that kind: or brought them to any trees whatever, and made them to remain, or continue, among them. (K.)

Oaraka AlOamorafiI Eunuqihi, (L, K,) inf. n. OuruwkN, so in the L, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) He compelled him, or constrained him, to do the thing, or affair; or made him to keep, or cleave, to it. (L, K.)

Oarakat AlUibilu, aor.
Aaraka
, (S, K,) inf. n. OarakN; (S;) and Oarakat, aor.
Aaruka
; and Ourikat; (K;) The camels had a complaint, or suffered pain, (S, K,) of, or in, their bellies, (S,) from eating the OaraAk. (S, K.)
2. OarRakahaA, inf. n. taOoriykN, He concealed her (namely a woman, TA) by means of an Oariykap, q. v. (K.)

8. AYtrk [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytaraka] It (the kind of tree called OaraAk) became firm, strong, or compact, and big: (O, K:) or attained to maturity: (K:) or became tangled, or luxuriant, and abundant. (TA.)
UirokN: see OaraAkN.
EuXobN lahu UirokN Herbage in which the camels remain, or continue. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)
OaraAkN OarikN Abundant, and tangled, or luxuriant, trees of the kind called ArAk; (K, TA; [in the CK MrikN, but said in the TA to be like katifN;]) as also muWotarikN↓. (K.)
OaroDN OarikapN Land abounding with the kind of trees called ArAk. (K.)
UibilN OarikapN and OaraAkay, [the latter being the pl.,] Camels having a complaint, or suffering pain, (S, K,) of, or in, their bellies, (S,) from eating the ArAk. (S, K.)

OaraAkN The [kind of trees termed] HamoD; (AHn, K;) as also UirokN↓: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) and (K) certain trees of the kind termed HayoD, (T, S, Msb, K,) well known, bearing what resemble bunches of grapes, (T, TA,) and of which sticks for cleaning the teeth are made, (AHn, Aboo-Ziyád, Msb, K,) that is, of its branches, (AHn, Aboo-Ziyád, Msb,) and of its roots, which latter are more esteemed for this purpose: (Aboo-Ziyád:) it is the best of the trees of which the branches are used for this purpose, and the best of those upon which beasts feed with respect to the odour of the milk [yielded by those beasts]: (AHn:) or one of the large thorny trees, upon which camels feed: the milk of [the camels that feed upon] it is the best of milk: and it is not allowable to prohibit the public from feeding their beasts upon it: (Mgh:) or a kind of tall, smooth, or soft, tree, abounding with leaves and branches, the wood of which is weak, and which has a fruit in bunches, or racemes, called bariyr, one [bunch] of which will fill the hand: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb:) pl. (of the n. un., T) OurukN (T, K) and OaraAYiku, (IB, K,) which is a form sometimes used, and is also pl. of the n. un. (IB.)
A piece of land (K, TA) in which are trees of the kind thus called. (TA.)
OariykN: see the end of the next paragraph.

OariykapN A raised couch (sariyr) in a Hajalap, (K, and Jel in xviii. 30,) which is a tent, or pavilion, or chamber, (byt,) adorned with cloths and curtains, [or a kind of curtained canopy or alcove or the like,] for a bride; (Jel ubi suprà;) a raised couch (sryr) in a Hajalap, and having before it a curtain; when alone, not thus called: (TA:) or a bed, or thing spread upon the ground to sit or lie upon, in a Hajalap: (Zj, TA:) or a raised couch (sryr), absolutely, whether in a Hjlp or not: (TA:) or [in the CK “ and ”] anything upon which one reclines such as is termed sariyr or mnaSRap or firaAX: (K, TA:) or [in some copies of the K “ and ”] a raised couch (sryr) ornamentally furnished and decorated, in a [tent, or pavilion, or the like, such as is termed] qubRap, or in a chamber, or an apartment, bayot, [or by this may be meant here a tent of any kind, though I think that in this instance it more probably denotes an inner apartment, or an alcove,]) which, when there is not in it a sryr, is termed Hajalap: (S, Sgh, K:) accord. to Er-Rághib, so named because
originally made of [the wood of] the OaraAk; or because it is a place of abode; from Oarak biAlmakaAni “ be abode in the place: ” (TA:) pl OaraAYiku (S, K) and [coll. gen. n.] OariykN↓. (K.)
UibilN OaraAkiyRapN: see what next follows.

UibilN OarikapN Camels feeding upon the kind of tree called OaraAk; (S, Msb;) as also OaraAkiyRapN↓: (K:) or remaining, or continuing, among trees of that kind, i. e., what are termed HamoD: or keeping in a place, not removing therefrom: (S:) pl. OawaAriku. (S, Msb.) Their milk is said to be the best of milk. (TA.)
qawomN muWorikuwna A people, or company of men, alighting and abiding by trees of the kind called OaraAk, (K,) feeding their camels upon those trees. (AHn, K. *)
OaraAkN muWotarikN: see OarikN

1. Oaramahu, (S, Har p. 99,) aor.
Aarima
, inf. n. OaromN, (S,) He took away, or removed, its OaruwmapN, or OaSol: (Har ubi suprà:) [he extirpated it; eradicated it:] he ate it. (S.) You say, Oaramati AlsRaAYimapu AlmaroEay, aor. as above, The pasturing beasts consumed, or made an end of, the pasturage, not leaving of it anything. (AHn, M.) And Oarama maA EalaI AlxiwaAni, (T,) or AlmaAYidapi, (Th, M, K,) aor. as above, (M,) He ate what was on the table, (Th, T, M, K,) not leaving anything. (K.) And Oaramatohumu AlsRanapu, (AHeyth, T, M, K,) aor.
Aaruma
, (so in the T, as on the authority of AHeyth,) inf. n. as above, (M,) The year of dearth, or drought, or sterility, extirpated them; (T;) or devoured them; (AHeyth, T;) or cut them off. (M, K.) And Oaramati AlsRanapu biOamowaAlinaA The year of dearth, or drought, or sterility, devoured everything [of our property or cattle]. (S.) And Oaramati AlOaroDu AlmayRita The earth consumed the dead body. (T.)

Oarima AlmaAlu, aor.
Aarama
, The property, or cattle, perished, or came to nought. (TA.)
UiromN: see UiramN.

OarimN [part. n. of Oarima]. You say OaroDu OarimapN, meaning Land upon which rain has not fallen for a long time: (T:) or land which does not give growth to anything. (TA.) [Not to be confounded with MrimahN, q. v.]
See also what next follows.

UiramN (T, S, M, K) and OarimN↓, (M, K,) like katifN, (K,) or UiromN↓, (so in a copy of the M,) and UiramiIRN↓ and OaramiIRN↓, (M, K,) from Lh, (TA,) or OaromiIRN↓, from Lh, (so in a copy of the M,) and UiromiIRN↓, from Lh, (TA,) and yaramiIRN, (M, K,) from Lh, (TA,) and OayoramiIRN, (T, K,) A sign, or mark, set up to show the way; (M, K;) stones set up as a sign, or mark, to show the way in the desert: (S:) or particularly one belonging to [the tribe of]' Ád: (M, K:) accord. to ISh, the Uiram is [a thing] like a man in a standing posture upon the head of a hill, whereby one is directed to the right way, and whereby the land is marked, composed of stones set one upon another, and is only the work of the Muslims, and such is made by people in the present day, upon the road: (T:) or such as was made by the people in the time of ignorance, who were accustomed, when they found a thing in their way and could not take it with them, to leave upon it some stones, whereby to know it, until, when they returned, they took it: (TA:) the pl. [of pauc.] is MraAmN and [of mult.] OuruwmN (ISh, T, S, M, K:) or OuruwmN signifies the graves, or sepulchres, of [the tribe of]' Ád. (M, K.)

[UiramN in the phrase Uiramu caAtu AlEimaAdi (see art. Emd) is a proper name; but whether of a place, or a tribe, or an individual, is disputed: it is commonly believed to be the name of The terrestrial paradise of Sheddád the son of 'Ád: see Bd lxxxix. 6.]

OaroDN OaromaMCu Land in which there is not a root, or stock, of a tree; as though it were maOoruwmap↓ [or extirpated]: (O:) or land in which neither root nor branch is left; as also maOoruwmapN↓. (M, K.)
OaromiIRN and UiromiIRN and OaramiIRN and UiramiIRN: see UiramN.
OaruwmN: see what next follows.

OaruwmapN (T, M, K) and OuruwmapN, (M, K,) the latter of the dial. of Temeem, (TA,) or this is not allowable, (T,) or OaruwmN↓, (S,) or this is the pl., (M, K,) [or a coll. gen. n.,] The root, or base, or lowest part, syn. OaSol, (T, S, M, K,) of a tree (T, S) of any kind; (T;) and of a horn: (S:) or, of a tree, [or plant, the root-stock, or rhizoma, or] the part from which branch off the Euruwq [or roots properly so called]. (K in art. Erq. [See an instance of its use voce janobapN; another, voce jinovN; and another, voce jazarN.])
And [hence,] (assumed tropical:) The origin, or stock, of a man: (TA:) (tropical:) The origin of Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour, &c.]. (Har p. 99.)
sanapN MrimapN (S, K, TA [in the CK, erroneously, AarimapN]) An extirpating year of dearth or drought or sterility: (S:) or a year of dearth &c. cutting off people. (K.)
OaroDN maOoruwmapN: see OaromaMCu, in two places.
1. Oarati AldRaAbRapu marobaTahaA, (M, K,) and miEolafahaA, [aor. taOoriI,] inf. n. OaroIN, (M,) The beast kept to its place where it was tied, (M, K,) and to its manger. (M.)
Oarati AldRaAbRipu UilaI AldRaAbRapi, (K,) aor. as above, (S,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) The beast joined itself, or became joined, to the beast, and kept with it to one manger. (S, K.)

2. OarRayotu lildRaAbRapi, (S, M, K,) and AldRaAbRapa, (M, K,) inf. n. tOoriyapN, (S, M, K,) I made for the beast an MriIR [q. v.], (S, * M,) or an MriyRap. (K: [in the CK AariyRap; but this and MriyRap are probably mistakes of copyists.])

OarRaIa AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. as above, He rendered the thing permanent, or steadfast; confirmed it; established it. (M, K.) Hence, in a trad., AallehumRa OarRimaA bayonahumo, i. e. O God, make permanent, or confirm, or establish, what is between them, of love, or affection; said in praying for a man and his wife. (M, TA.) Mohammad is also related to have said, with this intention, AallehumRa OarRibayonahumaA, meaning O God, render permanent, or confirm, the union, or concord, or love, of them tow; (A'Obeyd, TA;) or cause union to subsist, and render permanent, or confirm, love, or affection, between them two: (IAth, TA:) or AallehumRa OarRi kulRa waAHidK minohumaA SaAHibahu, meaning O God, confine each of them two to the other, so that the heart of neither may become turned away to any but that other: the correct form of speech, however, is Ealay SaAHibihi, unless it be like taEalRaqotu fulaAnFA for tElRqt bifulaAnK. (IAmb, TA.)

4. Mrayotu AldRaAbRapa I joined the beast to another beast, and made it to keep with the other to one manger: (S, in the present art.; and K:) or Mrayotu AldRaAbRatayoni I joined the two beasts together, and made them both keep to one manger. (So accord. to the S in art. wOr.)

5. tOry biAlmakaAni He remained, stayed, or abode, in the place: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or he became confined, or he confined himself, therein; (T, M, K;) as also AYtry↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaraI]. (M, K.)
tOrRIEanohu He remained behind him, not going with him; held back, or hung back, from him. (M, K.)
8: see 5.
OariIRN: see what next follows.
OariyRapN: see what next follows.
MrK: see what next follows.

MriIRN, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with medd and teshdeed, (TA,) [originally MruwIN,] of the measure faAEuwlN, (T, S, Mgh, Msb,) from taOarRaI biAlmakaAni as explained above, (Mgh,) or hence this verb, (Msb,) and OariIRN↓, (M, K, * [but accord. to the latter, the second form may be either thus (as it is written in the M) or MrK↓, (agreeably with the latter of the two pls. mentioned below,) for the two forms are there expressed by AlMriIRu wa yuxafRafu, (in the CK, erroneously, AlAarIRu w yuxafRafu,) and in another place in the K we find it written MriyRap↓, or, as in the CK, AariyRap↓,]) The place of confinement of a beast: (ISk, T, S:) or i. q. MxiyRapN; (M, Mgh, Msb, K;) used in this sense by the Arabs; (Mgh, Msb,;) or sometimes having this application; meaning a rope to which a beast is tied in its place of confinement;; (S;) or a loop of a rope to which a beast is tied in that place: (Mgh:) so called because it withholds beasts from escaping: (TA:) sometimes, (Msb,) improperly, (ISK, T, S,) by the vulgar, and by the lawyers, (Mgh,) applied to a manger::(ISk, T, S, Mgh, Msb:) pl. OawaAriIRu (T, S, Mgh, Msb) and OawaArK (S.)

Hence, OawaAriIRu is metaphorically applied to (tropical:) The places (OaHoyaAz) that are made, in shops, for grain and other things: and to (tropical:) the water-tanks, or troughs,
in a bath. (Mgh.)
El-'Ajjáj says, describing a [wild] bull, and his covert,

meaning [And he frequented lodging-places] having a firm foundation for the quiet of the wild animals therein [as having been from the first occupied by such animals and unfrequented by men]. (S.)— MriIRu is also said to signify Land of a kind between even and rugged. (M.)
MriyRapN: see MriIRN.

1. OazRati Alqidoru, (S, K,) or Alburomapu, (A,) aor
Aazuza
(S, K) and
Aaziza
, (K,) inf. n. OaziyzN (S, A, K) and OazRN and OazaAzN, (K,) The cooking-pot made a sound in boiling: (S, accord. to an explanation there given of the inf. n.; and A:) or boiled: (S:) or boiled vehemently; (K;) as also AYtzRt↓ [written with the disjunctive alif AiytRazRat], (S, K,) inf. n. QYotizaAzN; (S;) and tOzRt↓, (K,) inf. N. taOazRuzN: (TA:) or all signify it boiled not vehemently. (K.) It is said in a trad., kaAna yuSalRiI wa lijawofihi Oaziyz kaOaziyzi Qlomirojali mina QlobukaMCi (tropical:) [He used to pray, his inside making a sound like the sound of the boiling of the cooking-pot, by reason of weeping]: (S, A, Mgh:) this is said of Mohammad: Azyz meaning boiling, or the sound thereof. (Mgh.)

OazRati AlsRaHaAbapu The cloud made a sound from afar. (K.) [In this instance, the TA assigns only one form to the aor., namely
Aaziza
, and gives only OazRN and OaziyzN as inf. ns.] OaziyzN signifies The sounding of thunder; (S, A;*) and of a millstone. (A.) You say, haAlaniI Oaziyzu AlrRaEodi [The sounding of the thunder terrified me]: and SadRaEaniI Oaziyzu AlrRaHaI [The sounding of the mill-stone made my head to ache]. (A, TA.)
Also, inf. n. OaziyzN, It flamed, or blazed, like fire in firewood, and was in motion, or in a state of commotion. (AO.)

OazRabiAlqidori, [aor.
Aazuza
,] inf. n. OazRN, He kindled a fire, or made it to burn or to burn fiercely, beneath the cooking-pot, in order that it might boil: or you say, OazRa Alqidora, inf. n. as above, meaning he collected firewood beneath the cooking-pot so that the fire flamed, or blazed: and he made the fire to flame, or blaze, beneath the cooking-pot. (TA.) And OazRa AlnRaAra, (K,) aor.
Aazuza
, inf. n. OazRN, (TA,) He kindled the fire, or made it to burn or to burn fiercely. (K, TA.)

OazRa AlXRaIoCa, (K,) aor.
Aazuza
, inf. n. OazRN and OaziyzN, (TA,) He put the thing into a state of violent motion or commotion: (ISd, K:) so accord. to IDrd: (ISd:) but Ibráheem El-Harbee explains OazRN only as signifying the act of moving. (TA.)

OazRahu, (A, TA,) aor.
Aazuza
, (TA,) inf. n. OazRN, (S, TA,) He put him in motion; disquieted him; (A,* TA;) stirred up, roused, or provoked, him; and incited, urged, or instigated, him; (S,* A,* TA;) EalaI kacaA to do such a thing. (A, TA.*) It is said in the Kur [xix. 86], Oalamo tara OanRA OarosalonaA AlXRayaATiyna EalaI AlkaAfiriyna taWuzRuhumo OazRaA Seest thou not that we have sent the devils against the unbelievers inciting them strongly to acts of disobedience? (S, TA.) Or OazRN signifies The inciting a man to do a thing by artifice, or cunning, and gentleness. (El-Harbee.)
5. tOzRt Alqidoru: see 1.
8. AYtzRt Alqidoru: see 1.
huwa yaOotazRu mino kacaA He becomes angry, and distressed, and disquieted or disturbed, by reason of such a thing. (A, TA.)
OazRapN A sound, or noise. (TA.)
OaziyzN inf. n. of 1.
Sharpness; syn. HidRapN. (TA.)

1. Oazaba, aor.
Aaziba
, (A, K,) inf. n. OazobN, (TK,) It (water) flowed or ran; (A, K;) like wazaba. (TA.)

miYozaAbN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and miyzaAbN, (S, Msb,) A water-spout; a pipe, or channel, that spouts forth water: (Mgh, TA:) or that by which water pours down from a high place: (Towsheeh:) or a water-spout of wood, or the like, to convey away the water from the roof of a house: (MF in art. zwb:) the former is from the verb above mentioned: (A, K:) or it is arabicized, (A, Mgh, K,) from the Persian, (Mgh, K,) signifying “make water:” (K:) its pl. is maMziybu: (ISk, S, Mgh, Msb:) and the pl. of myzAb is mayaAziybu and mawaAziybu, from wazaba, said of water, meaning “it flowed,” (Mgh, Msb,) accord. to IAar; (Mgh;) or this is arabicized; or postclassical: (Msb:) but myzAb, without C, is altogether disallowed by Yaakoob [i. e. ISk]: (Mgh:) it is also called mirozaAbN, (T, S, Msb,) accord. to IAar; (T, Msb;) but this is disallowed by ISk, Fr, and AHát, (Msb,) and by Az [the author of the T]; (Mgh;) and mizoraAbN also, accord. to IAar and Lth and others, as is mentioned in the T. (Msb.)
2. OzRj, inf. n. taOoziyjN, (Msb, K,) He built a structure of the kind called OazajN, and made it long: (K:) or he built a house, or chamber, in the form of what is so called. (Msb.)

OazajN A certain kind of structure; (S, K;) or a house, or chamber, built in a long, or an oblong, form; (Mgh, L, Msb;) called in Persian OuwisotaAnN, (Mgh, L,) and also, in the same language, sago, and kamaro: (Mgh:) [i. e. an oblong, arched, or vaulted, structure or edifice; (such as a bridge; see qanoTarapN;) a portico, gallery, or piazza; accord. to Golius and Freytag, ædificii genus oblongum et fornicatum, porticus instar; to which Freytag adds, portæ arcus superior:] or, accord. to some, a roof: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] MzaAjN (S, Msb, K) and MzujN (S, K) and [of mult.] UizajapN. (K.)

1. Oazarahu, aor.
Aazira
, (TK,) inf. n. OazorN. (IAar, K,) It surrounded, or encompassed, it, (IAar,* K,* TA,) namely, a thing. (TK.)
See also 2, in two places: and see 3.
2. OzRrhu, inf. n. taOoziyrN, He put on him, or clad him with, an UizaAr; (S;) as also Oazarahu↓. (TA.)
It covered it: (K,* TA:) as in the phrase, OzRr AlnRabotu AlOaroDa The herbage covered the ground, or land. (TA.)
(tropical:) He repaired the lower part of it, (namely, a wall,) and thus made that part like an UizaAr: (Mgh, Msb:*) he cased [the lower part of] it, (namely, a wall,) and thus strengthened it. (A.)
(tropical:) He strengthened him, or it; (K, TA;) as also Oazarahu↓, (Fr,) inf. n. OazorN (Fr, K.) [See also 3.]

3. Mzirihu, (Fr, S, A, Msb,) for which the vulgar say waAzarahu, (Fr, S,) the latter an extr. form, (K,) inf. n. muWaAzarapN; (Msb, K;) and Oazarahu↓; (TA;) He aided, assisted, or helped, him; (Fr, S, A, Msb, K;*) and strengthened him. (Msb.) [See also 2.] You say, Mzarotu AlrRaxula Eala fulaAnK I aided, assisted, or helped, and strengthened, the man against such a one. (Zj.) And Oaradotu kacaA faMzaraniI Ealayohi fulaAnN I desired to do such a thing, and such a one aided, assisted, or helped, me to do it. (A, TA.)

Mzara AlzRaroEu baEoDuhu baEoDFA, (A,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) The seed-produce became tangled, or luxuriant, (A, K,) one part reaching to another, (A,) and one part strengthening another; (K;) as also AlzRaroEu tOzRr↓: (TA:) or AlnRabotu tOzRr↓ signifies the herbage became tangled, or luxuriant, and strong. (S.)

Mzara AlXRaIoCu AlXRaIoCa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) The thing equalled, or was equal to, the thing: the thing matched, or corresponded to, the thing. (K,* TA.) In some copies of the K, in the place of AlmusaAwaApu, is found AlmuWaAsaApu: the former is the correct reading. (TA.)
5: see 8, in two places:
and see also 3, in two places.

8. Aiytazara, (S, Mgh, Msb,) originally QYotazara, (Mgh, Msb,) and tOzRr↓, (S,) or Aytzr biAlUizaAri, and bihi tOzar↓, (K,) He put on, or wore, the UizaAra: (S, Mgh, Msb, K:) AitRazara is wrong, (Nh,) or vulgar, (Mgh,) and should not be said: it occurs in certain of the trads., but is probably a corruption of the relaters: (K:) or it is a correct form, [like AtRaxaca &c., (see art. Axc,)] (Msb, MF,) accord. to ElKarmánee and Sgh and others. (MF.)
OazorN Strength. (IAar, S, A, K.)
And (or as some say, TA) Weakness: thus bearing two contr. significations. (IAar, K.)

And The back. (IAar, S, K.) AuXodudo bihi OazoriI, in the Kur [xx. 32], means Strengthen Thou by him my back: (IAar, S:) or confirm Thou by him my strength: or strengthen Thou by him my weakness. (IAar.)
Aid, assistance, or help. (Msb.)
Also, (S,) or OuzorN↓, (K,) The place, (K,) or part of [each of] the two flanks, (S,) where the UizaAr is tied in a knot. (S, K.)
OuzorN: see OazorN.
UizorN: see UizaArN.

UizorapN Any particular mode, or manner, of putting on, or wearing, the UizaAr. (S, K.) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlUizorapi [Verily he has a good manner of putting on, or wearing, the AzAr]. (A.) And Aiytazara UizorapF HasanapF He put on, or wore, the AzAr in
a good manner. (S.) And it is said in a trad., Uizorapu AlmuWomini UilaI niSofi AlsRaAqi walaA junaAHa Ealayohi fiymaA bayonahu wabayona AlkaEobayoni [The believer's mode of wearing the AzAr is to have it reaching to the middle of the shank; and there shall be no sin chargeable to him with respect to what is between that and the two ankles]. (TA.)

UizaArN, masc. and fem., and UizaArapN↓, and miYozarN↓, (S, Msb, K,) and miYozarapN↓, (Lh,) and UizorN↓, (K,) A thing well known; (S, Msb;) [a waist-wrapper;] a wrapper for covering, or which covers, the lower part of the body, [from the waist downwards, concealing the thighs, and generally the upper half, or more, of the shanks, (see OazorN, or OuzorN, and UizorapN,)] not sewed: or such as is beneath the shoulders, or on the lower half of the body: the ridaMCi is that which covers the upper half of the body; or that which is upon the shoulders and back; and this also is not sewed: each of these explanations is correct: (MF:) or i. q. miloHafapN: (K:) [in the present day, UizaAr, vulgarly pronounced UiyzaAr, is also applied to a woman's outer covering, or wrapper, of white calico; described in my “Modern Egyptians:” and miYozarN↓, to a pair of drawers: and app., in post-classical writings, to anything resembling a waist-wrapper, worn on any part of the person, and in any manner; sometimes as a turban:] and UizaArN also signifies anything with which one is veiled, concealed, or covered: (Th, K:) its pl. is MzirapN, (S, Msb, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S, Msb,) and (of mult., S, Msb) OuzurN (S, Msb, K) and OuzorN, (K,) which is of the dial. of Temeem, or, accord. to MF, a contraction of OuzurN: (TA:) and the pl. of mYzr is maMziru (Msb.) You say, XadRa lilOamori miYozarahu↓ (tropical:) He prepared himself for the thing, affair, or business. (A.) And XadRa AlmiYozara↓ (tropical:) He abstained from sexual intercourse: or he prepared himself for religious service. (TA, from a trad.) And AixoDarRa UizaAriI (tropical:) (The place of) my AzAr became black: or, rather, became of a [blackish] hue inclining to green: because the hair when it first grows is of that hue. (Har p. 494.) And daAriI UizaAriI [My house is my covering]: said by Es-Sarawee to IAar, on the latter's expressing his surprise at the former's walking in his house naked. (TA.)

(tropical:) Continence; chastity. (K, TA.) You say, fulaAnN Eafiyfu AlUi zaAri, and AlmiYozari↓ (tropical:) Such a one is continent, abstaining from women with whom it is unlawful to him to have commerce: (A 'Obeyd:) and in like manner, fulaAnN TayRbu AlUizaAri. (TA in art. Hjz.)

(tropical:) One's wife: (S, M, K:) or one's self: (IKt, Suh:) or one's wife and family: or one's family and self. (TA.) One says, fidFI laka UizaAriI(tropical:) May my wife be a ransom for thee: (Aboo-'Omar El-Jarmee, S:) or myself. (IKt, Suh.) And it is said in a trad. respecting the vow of allegiance made at the 'Akabeh, lanamonaEanRaka mimRaA namonaEu minohu OuzuranaA (tropical:) We will assuredly defend thee from that from which we defend our wives and our families: or ourselves. (TA.)
(tropical:) A ewe. (K, TA.) [But see XaApN muWazRarapN.] And UizaAro UizaAro is A cry by which a ewe is called to be milked. (K.)
UizaArapN: see UizaArN.

farasN Mzaru, and OazoraMCu, [which is the fem.,](tropical:) A horse, and a mare, white in the hinder part, (A, TA,) which is the place of the UizaAr of a man; (TA;) [i. e., it corresponds to the lower part of the body of a man:] when the whiteness descends to the thighs, the epithet masarowalN is employed: (A:) or the former signifies a horse white in the thighs, and having his fore parts black, or of any colour: (AO, K:) pl. OuzorN (A.)
miYozarN: see UizaArN, in five places.
miYozarapN: see UizaArN.

XaApN muWazRarapN (tropical:) A ewe, or she-goat, that is [black in the hinder part] as though attired with a black UizaAr. (A; [in which is added, wayuqaAlu lahaA UizaArN, which may mean, “and one says, She has an AzAr;” or “and one calls her AzAr;” but more probably the former is meant thereby;] and K; [in which naEojapN, “a ewe,” is put in the place of XaApN.])
naSorN muWazRarN (tropical:) Aid [made] effective and powerful: (K, TA:) occurring in a trad. (TA.)
maOozuwraAtK for mawozuwraAtK: see art. wzr.

1. Oazifa, aor.
Aazafa
, inf. n. OazafN (S, Msb, K) and OuzuwfN, (Msb, K,) It (departure) was, or became, or drew, near: (S, Msb, K:) and in like manner, a time. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [liii. 58], Oazifati AlMzifapu The resurrection draweth near. (S, (Msb.)
He (a man) hastened, or was quick: (S, K:) or he drew near, and hastened, or was quick. (A, TA.)
4. MzafanI He (a man, TA) incited me, or urged me, to hasten, or be quick: (K, TA:) it is of the measure OafoEalaniI. (TA.)
5. taOazRufN The stepping with contracted steps. (K.) But see xaTowN mutaMzifN, below. (TA.)
6. tMzfwA They drew near together, one to another. (IF, K.)
MzifN, applied to a man, Hastening, or quick: (S, TA:) and endeavouring to hasten, or be quick. (TA.)

AlMzifapu The resurrection: so in the Kur liii. 58, (S, Msb,) and xl. 18: (Bd:) or in the latter place it means the near event, or case, of being on the brink of the fire [of Hell]: or, as some say, death. (Bd.)

mutaMzifN, of the measure mutafaAEilN, applied to a man, (TA,) Short; (S, A, K;) as being contracted in make; (A, TA;) having his several parts near together. (S, K.) [In the CK it is written mutaOzRif, in this sense and others, following.]
A strait, or narrow, place. (O, L, K.)
A contracted stepping: you say, xaTowN mutaMzifN: so in the O and L. (TA.)
(tropical:) A man (Sgh, TA) evil in disposition; narrow-minded: (Sgh, K, TA:) weak; cowardly. (TA.)

1. Oazaqa, aor.
Aaziqa
; (K;) and Oaziqa, aor.
Aazaqa
; (IDrd, K;) inf. n. (of the former, TA) OazoqN, (S, O, K,) and (of the latter, TA) OazaqN, (IDrd, K,) or the latter is used by poetic licence for the former; (As, Sgh;) He, or it, (said of a man, MF, or of a man's bosom or mind, K,) became strait, or straitened; (IDrd, S,* O,* K, MF;) OazoqN being thus syn. with OazolN: (S, O:) or it (a man's bosom or mind) became straitened in war or fight; (K;) or he (a man) became straitened in his bosom or mind, in war or fight: (TA:) as also tOzRq↓, with respect to both these significations; (K;) or this signifies it (a man's bosom or mind) became strait, or straitened; like tOzRl; (Fr, S;) and tMzq↓ signifies the same as tOzRq. (Z, in Golius.) [See also 10.]
Oazaqahu, inf. n. OazoqN, He straitened him: the verb being trans. and intrans. (MF.)
5: and 6: see 1.
10. AusotuWoziqa EalaI fulaAnK The place became strait to such a one, (K, TA,) so that he was unable to go forth [into it, to war or fight]. (TA.)

maOoziqN A place of straitness, or a strait place, (S, K, TA,) in which people fight. (TA.) And hence, A place of war or fight. (S.) And maOoziqu AlEayoXi The place of straitness of life, or living. (Lh.) Pl. maMziqu. (TA.)

1. Oazala, (S, K,) aor.
Aazila
, inf. n. OazolN, (S,) He (a man) became in a state of straitness, or narrowness, and suffering from dearth or drought or sterility. (S, K.) [See also the pass. form of the verb here following; and see 5.]

Oazalahu, aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He confined, restricted, restrained, withheld, debarred, hindered, or prevented, him; (K,* TA;) and straitened him; in consequence of distress, or adversity, and fear. (TA.)
He shortened his (a horse's) rope, [or tether,] and then left him to pasture at pleasure (Lth, K, [in the CK, XayRabahu is put for sayRabahu,]) in the place of pasturage. (Lth.)

OazaluwA maAlahumo, (S,) or OamowaAlahumo, (K,) aor. as above, (S,) They confined, restricted, or debarred, their cattle from the place of pasturage, (S,) or did not take, or send, them forth thereto, (K,) in consequence of fear, (S, K,) or dearth or drought or sterility. (K.)

It is said in a trad. respecting Ed-Dejjál, and his besieging the Muslims in Beytel-Makdis, [or Jerusalem,] fayuWozaluwna OazolFA XadiydFA And they will be straitened with a vehement straitening. (TA.) And Ouzila AlnRaAsu signifies The people suffered, or were afflicted with, drought, or want of rain. (TA.)
4. Mzalati AlsRanapu The year became severe, distressful, calamitous, or adverse. (TA.)
Mzalahumu QllRehu God afflicted them with drought, or want of rain. (TA.)

5. tOzRl It (a man's bosom or mind) became
strait, or straitened; (Fr, S, K;) as also tOzRq. (Fr, S.)
OazolN Straitness; distress; difficulty; (S,* K;) and drought, or want of rain. (TA.)
Vehemence of might, or of strength, in war, or fight; of courage, valour, or prowess: or of war, or fight: or of fear: or of punishment: syn. XidRapu baOosK. (TA.)
It is also used as an epithet, meaning Strait; narrow; confined. (Ham p. 339.)
UizolN A calamity; (K;) because of its distressing character. (TA.)
Lying, or falsehood. (Yaa- koob, S, K.)

OazalN i. q. qidamN [i. e. Eternity, with respect to past time, or considered retrospectively; existence from eternity; or ancientness] (S, K, TA) that is without beginning; (TA;) or the continuance of existence in decreed times interminable in respect of the past; like as OabadN is the continuance of existence in decreed times interminable in respect of the future; (KT;) or that [existence, or time,] which has no extremity in its beginning; like qidamN; and OabadN is that which has no extremity in its latter part; like baqaMCN: the former is existence without any beginning: (Kull p. 31:) said to be from the phrase lamo yazalo [“he, or it, has not ceased” to be &c.; i. e. “has ever” been &c. (see OazaliIRN)]: or, accord. to some, from OazolN signifying “narrowness;” because the intellect is prevented by its narrowness from perceiving its beginning: (MF:) Azl is a name for that of which the mind is prevented by its narrowness from determining the limit of the beginning; from OazolN meaning “narrowness;”; and Abd is a name for that of which the mind shrinks from, or shuns, the determining the limit of the end; from OubuwdN meaning the act of “shrinking” from a thing, or “shunning” it. (Kull pp. 30 and 31.) Hence the saying, kaAna fiI AlOazali qaAdirFA EaAlimFA [He was, or has been, ever, powerful, knowing]. (A, TA.) The phrase Oazala AlMzaAli [During the space, without beginning, of all past times; or ever, in all past times;] is like the phrase Oabada AlMbaAdi; said to be no evidence of the use of MzaAlN as a pl. of OazalN in a general way by the Arabs of the classical ages, as it is here added merely as a corroborative. (MF in art. Abd.) [See also OazaliIRN.]
OazilN: see MzilN.

OazaliIRN [Eternal, with respect to past time; existing from eternity; or ancient without beginning; as is implied in the S and K &c.;] a thing, or being, which has not been preceded by non-existence: it is applied to God: and to [his] knowledge: that which exists must be one of three kinds only: OazaliIRN OabadiIRN [existing from eternity, and consequently existing to eternity]; and this is God [who is also called Alqadiymu AlOazaliIRu the Ancient without beginning]: and laA OazaliIRN wa laA OabadiIRN [not existing from eternity nor existing to eternity]; and such is the present world: and OabadiIRN gayoru OazaliIR [existing to eternity without existing from eternity]; and such is the world to come; the reverse of which [last] is impossible: (TA:) it is a rel. n. from OazalN: or, accord. to some, it is not [genuine] Arabic: (TA:) or it is originally yazaliIRN, a rel. n. from lamo yazalo, (S, K,) a phrase applied to that which is qadiym; and is formed by contraction; (S;) then, the I is changed into A, as being easier of pronunciation; as in OazaniIRN, applied to a spear, in relation to cuw yazan; (S, K,* Sgh, TA;) and as in OavorabiIRN, applied to a blade, (S, Sgh, TA,) in relation to yavorib: (TA:) so say some of the learned. (S.)
OazaliyRapN The quality, or attribute, of OazalN [eternity, with respect to past time, &c.]: but it is a forged term, not of the [genuine] language of the Arabs. (A, TA.)
sanapN OazuwlN A severe, distressful, calamitous, or adverse, year: pl. OuzolN. (K.)
MzilN A man in a state of straitness, distress, adversity, or difficulty. (TA.)
A man in a state of straitness in consequence of fever: or who is unable to go forth in consequence of pain: or confined, restricted, withheld, or prevented [from going forth]. (TA.)

labuwnN MzilapN [A milch camel] confined, or restricted, not pasturing at pleasure, having her shank tied up to her arm, on account of her owner's fear of a hostile incursion: occurring in a poem of El-Aashà. (TA.)
OazolN MzilN, in the K, erroneously, OazilN↓, Severe, or vehement, straitness, distress, or difficulty. (K, * TA.)

maOozilN A place of straitness, or a strait place; (S, K;) like maOoziqN: (S:) or a place of war or fight, when strait. (Lh.) And maOozilu AlEayoXi The place where the means of subsistence are strait, or narrow. (Lh.)
sunayRapN HamoraMCu muWozilapN [A severe year of dearth, or sterility,] afflicting with drought. (TA, from a trad.)
maOozuwlN A horse having his rope [or tether] shortened, and then left to feed at pleasure in the place of pasturage. (Lth.)

1. Oazama, aor.
Aazima
, inf. n. OazomN and OuzuwmN, He bit with the whole mouth, vehemently: (K:) or with the canine teeth: or you say, Oazamahu, and Oazama Ealayohi, meaning he bit it, and then repeated [the action] upon it, not letting it go: or he seized upon it with his mouth: (TA:) or Oazamahu signifies [simply] he bit it: (S:) and Oazama Ealayohi, aor.
Aazima
, inf. n. OazomN; and Oazima, aor.
Aazama
, inf. n. OazamN; the same; or he seized, or took hold, upon it with his teeth: (Msb:) and Oazamotu yada AlrRajuli I bit the arm, or hand, of the man most vehemently. (TA.) Oazama bihaA occurs in a trad. as meaning He bit it, (referring to a ring of a coat of mail,) and held it between two of his central teeth. (AO.) And in another trad., Oazama fiy yadihi, meaning He bit his arm, or hand. (TA.) And you say, Oazama Alfarasu EalaI faOosi AllRijaAmi The horse seized [with his teeth, or champed,] upon the fOs [q. v.] of the bit. (K.) And OazomN signifies also The cutting with the canine tooth, and with a knife, (K,) and with other things. (TA.)

[And hence,] Oazama EalayonaA, (S, Msb, * K, *) aor.
Aazima
, inf. n. OazomN (S) and OuzuwmN, (TA,) said of a time, (S, Msb,) or a year, (K,) It was, or became, distressful, or afflictive, to us, [as though it bit us,] by drought, dearth, or scarcity; (S, Msb, K;) and scant in its good things; (S;) as also Oazima, aor.
Aazama
, inf. n. OazamN. (Msb.) And OaSaAbatohumo sanapN Oazamatohumo, (S, K, *) inf. n. OazomN, (S,) A year, or year of dearth or drought or sterility, befell them, which extirpated them: (S, K: *) or, accord. to Sh, the verb in this sense is only with w. (TA. [See art. Arm.])

[Hence also,] Oazama bihi, (AZ, S, K,) inf. n. OazomN, (TA,) He clave to him, namely, his companion; (AZ, S, K;) and to it, namely, a place. (K.) And Oazama Ealayohi, (K,) aor.
Aazima
, inf. n. OazomN, (TA,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to it; (K;) he clave to it. (TA.) And Oazama biDayoEatihi, or lahaA, (accord. to different copies of the K, the former being the reading in the TA,) and EalayohA, (TA,) inf. n. OuzuwmN, (AZ, TA,) He kept, attended, or applied himself, constantly, perseveringly, or assiduously, to his DyEp [or land, &c.]. (AZ, K, TA.)

Oazama, (Nh, K,) inf. n. OazomN, (Nh, TA,) also signifies He held his teeth together, one upon another: (Nh:) [and he compressed, or put together, his lips: (see MzimN:)] and he closed, or locked, a door. (K, TA.) It is said in a trad., AlsRiwaAku tasotaEomiluhu Einoda tagayRuri Alfami mina AlOazomi The stick for cleaning the teeth, thou shalt use it on the occasion of the mouth's becoming altered in odour from the holding of the teeth together. (Nh.)

[And hence,] Oazama, (S, Nh, Msb,) inf. n. OazomN, (Msb, K,) He held, refrained, or abstained, (S, K, *) Eani AlXRaIoCi from the thing: (S, TA:) and he held, refrained, or abstained, from desiring much: (TA:) and from food (Msb, K *) and drink; (Msb;) as also Oazima, aor.
Aazama
, inf. n. OazamN: (Msb:) and from speech; (Nh, K; *) like as does the faster from food: and hence, (Nh,) or from the next preceding signification, (Msb,) HimoyapN [meaning as explained in what follows] is termed OazomN: (Nh, Msb:) but accord. to the relation commonly known, of a trad. in which Oazama is said to occur in the last of the senses explained above, the word is OaramRa, with r and with teshdeed in the case of the m. (Nh.) It is related in a trad., that 'Omar having asked El-Hárith Ibn-Keledeh, the Tabiyb of the Arabs, “What is the [best] remedy?” (S,) or having asked him respecting [the best] medical, or curative, treatment, (Msb,) the latter said, AlOazomu, meaning AlHimoyapu; (S, Msb;) both these words here meaning The practising abstinence; (PS;) or the abstaining, or desisting, from eating: (TA:) or, in this instance, (TA,) AlOazomu signifies the not putting in food upon food: and (some say, TA) the being silent: (K, TA:) and it signifies also strength. (TA.)

Oazama AlXRaIoCu The thing became contracted; became drawn together, or compressed; as also Oazima, aor.
Aazama
. (K.)
5. tOzRm Alqawomu, (TA,) or tOzRm Alqawomu daArahumo, (S,) The people, or company of men, stayed, remained, or dwelt, long in their abode. (S, TA.)
OazomN: see OazomapN.
OazimN [part. n. of Oazima; fem. with p]: see OazomapN.
OazomapN [inf. n. of un. of 1: and hence,] A single act of eating; (K, TA;) i. e. an eating but once in the course of the day; like wajobapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

Also, (Fr, S, Msb, K,) and OazamapN↓ and MzimapN↓, (Fr, K, [the last in the CK like the first,]) Straitness, hardness, or distress; (S, Msb, K;) drought, dearth, or sterility: (S, Msb:) pl. (of the first, TA) OazomN↓, (K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] like as tamorN is of tamorapN, (TA,) [but originally an inf. n. of Oazama. q. v.,] and UizamN, (K,) like as bidarN is of badorapN. (TA.) Hence the trad., AXotadRiI OazomapN tanofarijiI, meaning Become severe, O year of drought, or dearth, or sterility: then thou wilt pass away: though it has been strangely asserted that Azmp is here the proper name of a woman, to whom, on an occasion of her being taken with the pains of labour, these words were said by the Prophet. (TA.) You also say sanapN OazomapN and OazimapN↓, (K,) so in the copies of the K, there said to be like fariHapN, but correctly MzimapN↓, as in the M &c., (TA,) [or both are correct, being part. ns., respectively, of Oazima and Oazama,] and OazuwmapN↓, meaning A distressful, or an afflictive, year; (K;) a year of vehement drought or dearth or sterility. (TA.) And OawaAzimu [pl. of MzimapN↓, used as a subst.,] signifies Distressful, or afflictive, years. (TA.) OazaAmi↓, also, (K,) or, accord. to Aboo-'Alee, Oazuwmu↓, (IB,) [each a proper name, as denoting a kind of personification,] signifies The year of drought or dearth or sterility. (K.) And you say, nazalato bihimo OazaAm↓ and Oazuwmu↓ Severe straitness, or distress, befell them. (S, TA. *)
OazamapN: see OazomapN.
OazimapN: see OazomapN.
OazaAmi: see OazomapN, in two places.
OuzaAmN: see what next follows.
OazuwmN: see MzNm, in three places.
Oazuwmu: see OazomapN, in two places.
Also, the former, Cleaving to a thing; (K;) and so OuzaAmN↓. (Sgh, K.)
OazuwmapN: see OazomahN.

MzimN act. part. n. of Oazama Biting with the whole mouth, vehemently: [&c.:] as also OazuwmN↓: (K: [in the CK the former is erroneously written AazomN:]) or the latter signifies that has a habit of biting; or that bites much; syn. EaDuwDN: (Ham p. 532:) pl. of the former OuzuwmN: (Ham p. 360:) and of the latter OuzumN. (Ham p. 609.) [Hence,] AlOazuwmu↓ The biting lion; or the lion that bites much, or vehemently; AlOasadu AlEaDuwDu. (TA.)
[Hence also,] The canine tooth; syn. naAbN; and so MzimapN↓; and OazuwmN↓: pl. of the first OuzRamN; and of the second MwAzim; and of the third OuzumN. (M, K.)
Also Having his lips compressed, or put together. (AZ, S.)
MzimapN: see MzimN:
and see also OazomapN, in three places.

maOozimN A narrow, or strait, place; a place of narrowness or straitness; (S, K;) like maOozilN; (S;) of a land, and of the pudendum muliebre, and of life, (K,) or of the means of subsistence; (Lh, K;) or of any kind: (TA:) any narrow road between two mountains: (S, Msb:) a narrow place in mountains, such that one part meets another, and the place beyond widens: (TA:) pl. maMzimu. (S, K.)
And hence, (Msb,) A place of war or fight; (S, Msb;) because of the straitness of the state thereof, and the difficulty of escape from it. (Msb.)

mutaOazRimN Smitten, or afflicted, by Ouzomap [or straitness, &c.]: (K:) or expressing pain or grief, or lamenting, or complaining, on account of the straitness, or distressfulness, or afflictiveness, (Oazomap and XidRap,) of time, or fortune. (TA.)

2. OzRI AlHawoDa, inf. n. taOoziyapN (S, K) and taOoziIoCN, or tawoziIoCN, (accord. to different copies of the S, [the latter irregular,]) or both, (accord. to the TA,) He put, or made, an UizaMC [q. v.], to the watering-trough or tank; (S, K;) i. e. he put upon its mouth a stone, or a julRap [explained below, voce UizaMC], or the like; (TA;) as also MzAhu↓, inf. n. UiyzaMCN; (S, TA;) or tOzRAhu↓. (K.)

3. MzAhu, (S, K,) inf. n. muWaAzaApN, (Msb in art. Hcw, and TA in art. wzI, &c., [though it would seem from the K to be UiyzaMCN,]) He (a man, S) was, or became, over against it, or opposite to it; he faced, or fronted, him, or it. (S, * K, * TA in art. wzI.) Accord. to the S, one should not say, waAzaAhu: but it is said in a trad. respecting the prayer of fear, fawaAzayonaA AlEaduwRa, i. e. And we faced, or fronted, the enemy: (TA:) and the inf. n. is muwaAzaApN. (TA in art. wzI.) [Its syn. HaAcaAhu is more common.]
[Hence muWaAzaOoq signifying A conformity, a mutual resemblance, or a correspondence, with regard to sound, of two words occurring near together; like AizodiwaAjN &c.: see art. zwj.]

[Hence, likewise,] MziAhu also signifies He contended with him, syn. jaAraAhu; (K, TA;) and opposed, or withstood, him, syn. qaAwamahu. (TA.) Whence the saying in a trad., wafiroqapN Mzati Qlomuluwka faqaAtalatohumo EalaI diyni QllRehi [And a party contended with, and opposed, or withstood, the kings, and fought with them for the religion of God]. (TA.)
4. MzI AlHawoDa i. q. OazRaAhu, q. v. (S, TA.)
And He repaired, or put into a right or proper state, the UizaMC [q. v.] of the watering-trough or tank. (IAar, TA.)
And He poured forth the water from its UizaMC. (TA.)
And MzI fiyhi He poured forth upon its UizaAC. (TA.)
5: see 2.

naAqapN OaziyapN, (accord. to some copies of the S,) or MziyapN↓, (accord. to other copies of the S,) or both, (IAar, TA,) each after the manner of a relative noun, [having no verb,] (TA,) A she-camel that drinks from the UizaMC [q. v.]: (TA:) or that will not drink save from the UizaMC of the trough or tank; and EaqirapN signifies one “that will not drink save from the Euqor [thereof]:” (S, TA, and IAar in art. Eqr in the TA:) or, accord. to IAar, that will not come to the watering-trough or tank, to drink, until they leave it unoccupied for her; as also qacuwrN. (TA in the present art.)

AlUizaMCu i. q. AlHicaMCu [The front, as meaning the part, place, or location, that is over against, opposite, facing, fronting, or in front]. (Msb, and K &c. in art. Hcw.) You say, huwabiUizaAYihi He is over against, opposite to, facing, fronting, or in front of, him; syn. biHicaAYihi, (S,) or muHaAciyhi. (Msb.)

[Hence, biUizaMYihi signifies also Corresponding to it; as when one says,] AlOabojalu EiroqN mina Alfarasi wa AlbaEiyri biUizaMCi AlOakoHali mina AlUinosaAni [The Abjl is a vein of the horse and the camel, corresponding to the AkHl of man]. (TA in art. bjl.) [You say also, waDaEa lafoZFA biUizaMCi maEonRaI He applied a word, or phrase, as correspondent to an idea, or a meaning.]

UizaMCN is also applied to a man, and to a woman, and to a number of persons, in senses here following. (TA.) You say, huwa UizaMCu AlOamori He is the manager, conductor, orderer, regulator, or superintendent, of the affair. (S, Msb, TA.) And in the same sense the word is used by Homeyd, in the phrase UizaMCu maEaAXK [The manager, or orderer, of the means of subsistence], applied to a woman. (TA.) And in an instance in which a poet likens the UizaMC of a watering-trough or tank to the [stinking animal called] ZaribaAn: (S, TA:) in this case it means The water-drawer [of the trough or tank]. (As, IB, TA.) [But in relation to a watering-trough or tank, it generally has another meaning, which see below.] You say also, fulaAnN UizaMCN maAlK (S) [Such a one is] a manager, tender, or superintendent, of cattle, or camels &c.; (K, * TA;) a good pastor thereof. (TA.) And UizaMCu AlHarobi The vigorous wager, or prosecutor, of war. (K.) And fulaAnN UizaMCu fulaAnK Such a one is the fellow and assistant of such a one. (TA.) And humo UizaAWuhumo They are their fellows, (K, TA,) who assist them, and order, or set in order, their affairs: (TA:) or they are those who order, or set in order, their affairs. (Msb.) And UinRahu laUi zaMCu xayorK, and XRarK, Verily he is a possessor of goodness, and of evilness. (TA.)
Also, AlUizaMCu, (K,) or UizaMCu AlEyX, (TK,) The means of sustenance: or what has been caused, or occasioned, of plentifulness and easiness, and of superabundance, of sustenance. (K.)
