What is [essential, or] requisite, or needful: as when one says AlOaSolu fiI AlHayawaAni AlgicaMCu [What is essential, or requisite, or needful, in the case of the animal, is food]. (Kull ibid.)
A [primary, or] universal, or general, rule, or canon. (Kull ibid.)
An indication, an evidence, or a proof, in relation to that which is indicated, or evidenced, or proved. (Kull ibid.)
OaSalN: see its n. un., OaSalapN
OaSilN, (K,) or OaSiylN↓, (M,) i. q. musotaOoSilN↓. (M, K.) You say qaloEN OaSilN Eradicating, or extirpating, evulsion: (TA:) or qaToEN OaSiylN↓ extirpating excision. (M.)
OuSulN, said by some to be a pl., and by others to be a dial. var., of OaSiylN: see the latter word, in two places.
OaSalapN: see OaSiylapN.

Also A kind of serpent, the most malignant, or noxious, of serpents: (S:) or a serpent, (M, K,) short, (M, [where, in the only copy to which I have access, I find added, kaAlriYapi, app. a mistranscription, for kaAlrRumRapi, like the fragment of a rope,]) or small, (K,) red, but not intensely red, (M,) very deadly, of the most malignant, or noxious, kind, (TA,) having one leg, upon which it stands, (M, TA,) then turns round, then springs, (TA,) that springs upon a man, and blows, killing everything upon which it blows: (M:) or, as some say, a great serpent, (M, K,) that kills by its blowing: (K:) or one of the very crafty kinds of serpents, short and broad, said to be like the shaft of an arrow, and it springs upon the horseman: (Msb:) pl. OaSalN↓, (S, M. Msb, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and [pl. of pauc.] MSaAlN. (Msb.)
[Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) Short and broad: applied to a man and to a woman. (TA.)

OaSoliIRN [Radical; fundamental; primitive; original; underived: an epithet of extensive application; and particularly applied to a letter of a word, as opposed to augmentative; and to a signification]. (The Lexicons &c. passim.)
OaSoliyRapN [The quality denoted by the epithet OaSoliIRN; radicalness, &c.:] a term used by IJ [and others] in the place of taOaSRulN: see 5. (M.)

OaSiylN [Having root, or a foundation; and consequently, having rootedness, fixedness, immobility, stability, or permanence; rooted, fixed, immoveable, stable, or permanent]. You say, UinRa AlnRaxola fiI OaroDinaA laOaSiylN Verily the palm-trees in our land remain permanently, not perishing. (A, TA.)
A man having OaSol, (K, TA,) i. e., lincage, or pedigree: (TA:) or established in his OaSol: (Abu-l-BaKà, TA:) or noble, or generous. (Msb.)

A man firm of judgment, and intelligent. (M, K.* [Accord. to the copies of the latter, the signification is EaAqibN vaAbitu AlrRaOoIi: but I think that the right reading of the first word is EaAqilN, as in the M, in which this word occupies the last place in the explanation.]) And OaSiylu AlrRaOoIi A man firm, or sound, of judgment. (S.) And raOoIN OaSiylN Judgment having OaSol [i. e. firmness]. (M.) And majodN OaSiylN Glory, honour, dignity, or nobility, having a firm root or foundation. (S.) And XarRN OaSiylN Vehement evil or mischief. (Ibn-'Abbád.)
See also OaSilN, in two places.
[Hence, app.,] AlOaSiylu Destruction: and death: as also, in both senses, AlOaSiylapu↓. (K.)

[The evening; or] i. q. EaXiIRN; (M, K, Msb, TA;) i. e. (Msb, TA) the time from the EaSor, (S, TA,) from the prayer of the ESr, (Msb,) to sunset; (Sudot;, Msb, TA;) as also OaSiylapN↓: (R, TA:) the pl. is OuSulN, (S, M, R, Msb, K,) or ↓this is a sing., (TA,) or it may be a sing., (M,) for it is used as such, (M, TA,) and OuSolaAnN, (S, M, K,) and MSaAlN, (S, M, Sgh, K,) [a pl. of pauc.,] or, accord. to Es- Saláh Es-Safadee, this is a pl. of OuSulN, the sing., not the pl., (TA,) or it is pl. of OuSulN, (Zj, M,) which may be a pl. or a sing., (M,) and OaSaAYilu, (S, M, K,) as though pl. of OaSiylapN, (S,) or it is pl. of this last word. (R, TA.) You say, laqiytuhu OaSiylFA and OuSulFA↓, i. e. [I met him in the evening,] EaXiyRFA. (A, TA.) From the pl. OuSolaAnu is formed the dim. OuSayolaAnN↓, (S, M, K,) which is extr., (M, K,) because the dim. of a pl. is [regularly] formed only from a pl. of pauc., which ASlAn is not; or, if ASlAn be a sing., like rumRaAnN and qurobaAnN, this
dim. is regular: (M:) sometimes, (K,) one says also OuSayolaAlN↓, (S, M, K,) substituting l for the [final] n (S, M.*) You say, laqiytuhu OuSayolaAnFA↓ and OuSayolaAlFA↓, meaning, as above, EaXiyRFA: (A, TA:) and Lh mentions lqyth OuSayRaAlFA↓. (So in two copies of the S.)
OaSylapN A man's whole property: (M, K:) or his palm-trees: (K, TA: in the CK his palmtree:) thus in the dial. of El-Hijáz. (O, TA.)

Oaxacahu biOaSiylatihi, (S, M, K,) and biOaSalatihi↓, (IAar, M, K,) He took it altogether, (S, M, K,) [as it were] with its root, (S, M,) not leaving aught of it. (TA.) And jaAWuwA biOaSiylatihimo They came altogether; the whole of them. (S, Z.)
lifulaAnK OaroDN OaSiylapN To such a one belongs land long possessed, or inherited from his parents, by means of which he has his living: a phrase of the people of Et-Táïf. (TA.)
See also OaSiylN, in two places.
OuSuwliI One skilled in the science termed EilomN AlOuSuwli: see OaSolN. (TA.)
laqiytuhu OuSayRaAlFA: see OaSiylN, last sentence.
OuSayolaAnN and OuSaylaAlN: see OaSiylN, in four places, last two sentences.
laqiytuhu muWoSilFA I met him entering upon the time called the OaSiyl. (TA.) And OatayonaA muWoSiliyna We came entering upon the time so called. (S.)
OaSolN muWaSRalN [ A root, or foundation, or the like, made firm, or fixed, or established]. (S.) [See also OaSiylN.]
XaApN musotaOoSalapN A sheep, or goat, whose horn has been taken from its root. (TA.)
musotaOoSilN: see OaSilN.
yaOoSuwlN: see OaSolN, first sentence.

1. OaTRa, (S, K,) aor.
AaTiTa
, (K,) inf. n. OaTiyTN (S, K) and OaTRN, (TA,) It produced, made, gave, emitted, or uttered, a sound, noise, voice, or cry; (S, K;) [and particularly, it creaked; and it moaned;] said of a camel's saddle, (S, * K, [in the CK, AlrRajulu is put by mistake for AlrRaHolu]) [and particularly of a new camel's saddle,] and the like, (K,) such as a [plaited or woven girth called] nisoE and of everything of which the sound resembles that of a new camel's saddle, (TA,) and of a palm-trunk, and of a tree of the kind called sidor, (S TA,) or of the kind called saroH, (TA,) and of a cane or reed on the occasion of its being straightened, [in which instance it is said to be tropical, but if so it is tropical in several other instances,] and of a bow, (TA,) and of the belly by reason of emptiness, (S,* TA,) and, in a trad. of Aboo-Dharr, (tropical:) of heaven, or the sky, notwithstanding there being [really] no OaTiyT in this instance, for it is meant to denote [the presence of] multitude, and confirmation of the majesty of God. (TA.) [It is also said of other things, as will be shown by phrases here following, and by explanations of OaTiyTN below.] You also say, OaTRati AlUibilu, (K,) aor. as above, inf. n. OaTiyTN, (TA,) The camels moaned by reason of fatigue, or uttering their yearning cry to their young, (K, TA,) and sometimes by reason of fulness of their udders with milk. (TA.) And laA Mtiyka maA OaTRati AlUibilu I will not come to thee as long as camels utter cries [or moan] by reason of the heaviness of their loads. (S.) And laA OafoEalu celika maA OaTRati AlUibilu, meaning I will not do that ever. (TA.) And maA lanaA baEiyrN yaYiTRu We have not a camel that moans, or cries; meaning we have not any camel; for the camel cannot but do so. (TA, from a trad.) [See also OaTiyTN, below.] And OaTRato lahu raHimiI (tropical:) [My feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood,] became affected with tenderness, or compassion, and became moved, [or rather pleaded,] for him [or in his favour]: (K, TA:) and hence AltRaOaTRuTu↓ [inf. n. of the verb in the syn. phrase taOaTRaTato lahu raHimiI]. (Sgh, TA.) And OaTRato bika AlrRaHimu [The feeling of relationship, or sympathy of blood, pleaded, or hath pleaded, in thee;] i. e., inclined thee to favour. (Ham p. 765.) [See another ex. voce HaAsRapN.]
5: see 1, near the end.
OaTRN: see OaTiyTN, below.
nusuwEN OuTRaTN [pl. of MTRN, part. n. of 1,] Creaking [plaited, or woven, thongs]. (K.)

OaTiyTN [as explained in what here follows seems to be properly an inf. n., though, like all inf. ns., it may be used as a subst.:] The sounding, or the like, or the sound, or the like, [and particularly the creaking, or creaking sound, and the moaning, or moaning sound,] of a camel's saddle (S, K, TA) when new; (TA;) and so OaTRN↓ of the litters and saddles of camels when the riders are heavy thereon; and the former, also, of a door; said, in a trad., of the gate of paradise, by reason of its being crowded; (TA;) and of a plaited or woven thong when stretching; (Ez-Zejjájee, TA;) and of the back [when strained]; (K;) and of the bowels, (TA,) and of the belly, or inside, by reason of hunger, (K,) or by reason of vehement hunger; (TA;) and of camels, (S, K,) by reason of their burdens, (K,) or by reason of the heaviness of their burdens; (S;) and the prolonging of the cries of camels: (TA:) but 'Alee Ibn- Hamzeh says that the cry of camels is termed rugaMCN, and that OaTiyTN signifies the sounding, or sound, of their bellies, or insides, by reason of repletion from drinking. (IB, TA.) OaholN SahiylK WaOaTiyTK, occurring in a trad., means (assumed tropical:) Possessors of horses and of camels. (TA.)
Also (assumed tropical:) Hunger, (K, TA,) itself, as well as the sound of the bowels or belly by reason thereof: from EzZejjájee. (TA.)

OaTRaATN Sounding much; noisy; (K, TA;) having a sound: applied [to any of the things mentioned above in the explanations of OaTRa and OaTiyTN; and] to a hide; and to a camel repleted with drink; and to a road: fem. with p: which, applied to a woman, signifies one whose faroj has a sound UicaA juwmiEato. (TA.)

1. OaTarahu, aor.
AaTira
(S, Msb, K) and
AaTura
, (K,) inf. n. OaTorN; (S, Msb, K;) and OTRrhu↓ inf. n. taOoTiyrN; (K;) He bent it, or curved it; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) namely, a bow, (S, A,) and a twig, or the like: (A:) he laid hold upon one of its two extremities, and curved it: he bent it, or curved it; namely, anything; EalaI XRaIoCK upon a thing: and the latter verb, [or both,] he bent it into the form of a hoop, bringing its two extremities together. (TA.)
It is said of Adam, QllRehu kaAna TuwaAlFA faOaTRarahu↓ He was tall, and God bent him, and diminished his height. (TA.)

And one says, Oaxaca EalaI yadaIi AlZRaAlimi waOaTarahu EalaI AlHaqRi (tropical:) [He laid hold upon the two hands, or arms, of the wrongdoer, or prevented, restrained, or withheld, him from doing that which he desired,] and bent him to [conformity with] what was right. (AA, from a trad.) And OaTarota fulaAnFA EalaI mawadRatika (tropical:) [Thou hast bent such a one to love thee]. (A.)

OaTara AlsRahoma (S, K,) aor.
AaTira
and
AaTura
, (K,) inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He wound an OuTorap upon the arrow. (S, K.)
OaTara Albayota, (TK,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He made an UiTaAr, which is a thing resembling a zone or belt, to the tent or house. (K, TK.)
2: see 1, in two places.
OaTRarato, inf. n. taOoTiyrN She (a girl, IAar) remained in the house, or tent, of her father, some time, or long, (IAar, K,) without marrying. (IAar.) [See also 5.]
5. tOTRr It (a spear) bent: (S, K:) it (a thing) became crooked, curved, or bent; as also AnOTr↓: (K, TA:) it became bent into the form of a hoop, its two extremities being brought together. (TA.)
taOaTRarato She affected a bending of her person, body, or limbs, in her gait. (A.)
He confined himself (K, TA) in a place. (TA.)
taOaTRarato She (a woman) remained, or stayed, in her house, or tent; (S, K;) she kept to it. (TA.) [See also 2.]
7: see 5.

OaTorN The place of curvature (munoHanaI) of a bow, and of a cloud: (K, TA:) an inf. n. used as a subst., and, being so used, admitting the dual form: or the bent, or curved, part of the extremity of a bow; to which Tarafeh likens the curving of the ribs of a she-camel: (TA:) and what resembles a curvature, seen in the clouds: an inf. n. in the sense of a pass. part. n. (Skr, TA.)
OuTorapN The sinew that is wound immediately above the notch of an arrow; (S, K;) as also UiTaArN↓. (K.)
The edge of the glans of the penis; (K, * TA;) as also ↓the latter word. (K, TA.)
The flesh surrounding the nail: (K:) pl.OuTarN and UiTaArN. (TA.)
A mixture of ashes and blood with which a fracture in a cooking-pot is smeared (S, K) and repaired. (TA.)
UiTaArN Anything that surrounds another thing: (S, A, Msb, K:) as the hoop of a tambourine, (A, Mgh, TA,) and of a sieve. (S, A, Mgh, K.)

A ring of hair surrounding the head, the
middle of it being bald. (TA.)
The branches of a vine, bent, or wreathed, so as to form a covering over-head. (K.)
See also OuTorapN, in two places.
UiTaAru AlHaAfiri The part of the hoof of a horse or the like which surrounds, or extends around, the OaXoEar [q.v.]. (S.)

UiTaAru AlXRafapi (S, K, &c.) (tropical:) The part, (A,) or flesh, (Msb,) surrounding the lip: (A, Msb:) or the part that separates between the lip and the hairs of the mustache: (K:) or the edge of the upper lip, between the lip itself and the parts where the hair grows: (IAth:) or the rising edge, or ridge, between the part where the mustache is clipped and the lip, intermixing with the mouth. (A'Obeyd.) The Muslim should clip his mustache so that this part shall appear. (Msb, TA.)
UiTaAru bayotK A thing resembling a zone, or belt, of a tent or house. (K.)

UiTaAri mina AlnRaAsi (tropical:) A ring, or circle, of men. (K.) One says, humo UiTaArN libaniI fulaAnK (tropical:) They have alighted and taken up their abode [so that they form a ring] around the sons of such a one. (A, Msb.)
OaTiyrN A sin; a crime; an offence. (S, K.) One says, OaxacaniI biOaTiyri gayoriI He punished me for the sin, crime, or offence, of another than myself. (S.)
maOoTuwrapN A bow. (A.)

A milking-vessel of skin (EulobapN) for the head of which a twig is bent into the form of a hoop, and put round, after which its lip is covered; (K, TA;) or, sometimes, the edges of the skin of the Elbp are folded upon the hoop-formed twig, and dry upon it. (TA.)

OuTumN and OuTomN, (S, K,) like OujumN and OujomN, (S, and Mgh in art. Ajm) A fortress: or, as some say, any lofty building: (Mgh:) or a [building such as is termed] qaSor [q. v.]: (IAar, K:) and any fortress built of stones: and any square, roofed, house: (K:) pl. (of pauc., TA) MTaAmN (S, Mgh. K) and (of mult., TA) OuTuwmN: (K:) MTaAmN signifies fortresses of the people of El-Medeeneh: and one of these is termed OaTamapN↓: (S:) or this signifies [simply] a fortress; and its pl. is MTaAmN (TA.)
OaTamapN: see above.

MTaAmN muWaTRamapN Lofty [fortresses, &c.]: (A, TA:) [or it may signify fortresses, &c., disposed in order, or grouped together; for it is said to be] a phrase like OabowaAbN mubawRabapN, (O, TA,) or like OajonaAdN mujanRadapN. (K.)

1. OafRa, aor. yaWufRN (IDrd, M, Mgh, K,) and yaYifRu, (IDrd, M, K,) the latter agreeable with analogy, (TA,) [but the former, though irregular, is the more common,] inf. n. OafRN; (M, Mgh;) and OfRf↓, inf. n. tOofiyfN; (S, Mgh, K;) and tOfRf↓; (M, K;) He said OufRi [q. v.], (IDrd, S, M, Mgh, K,) by reason of anxiety, or disquietude of mind, or by reason of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust: (IDrd, M, K:) held by Sb to be of the same class as sabRaHa and halRala meaning “ he said suboHaAna QllRehi ” and “ he said laA Uileha UilRaA QllRehu. ” (M.) You say also, OafRafahu↓, and bihi OafRafa↓, and bihi taOafRafa↓, meaning He said to him OufRi. (M.) And jaEala mino riyHK wajadahaA fulaAnN yataOafRafu↓ Such a one began to say OufRi OufRi by reason of a smell which he perceived. (T.) And Ealayohi UinRahu yataOafRafu↓ Verily he is angry with him, or enraged against him. (TA.)
2: see 1, in three places.
5: see 2, in four places.
Oafo and OafRi and OafRK, or OafK: see OufRN.
Uifo and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see the next paragraph.

OufRN Dirt, or filth; as also OufRapN↓: (S:) you say, OufRaA lahu, and OufRapF↓, Dirt, or filth, to him; in which the tenween is for the purpose of rendering them indeterminate; (S;) and OufRa lahu wa tufRN; (T;) and watufRapF OufRapF↓; and OufRaA watufRaA; (T, S;) the latter of which is an imitative sequent: (S:) or OufRN signifies the dirt of the ear; and tufRN, the dirt of the nails; (As, T, M, K; but in the last, of the nail;) the phrases mentioned above being used on the occasion of deeming a thing dirty or filthy, and afterwards on the occasion of experiencing annoyance or disgust at anything; (As, T, M,* TA;) and OafafN↓, also, has the former of these two meanings: (TA:) or OufRN signifies the dirt around the nail; (M;) or the dirt of the nail; (K;) and tufRN, the dirt in the nail: (M:) or the former, a paring of the nail: and a piece of stick, or a reed, which one takes up from the ground: (K:) in these various senses they are explained as used in the saying, OufRaA lahu watufRaA: (TA:) or the former signifies stink: (Zj, TA:) or paucity; (T, M, K) as also OafafN↓; (M;) or from OafafN↓ signifying a thing little in quantity; (T; and the same meaning is assigned to this word in the K;) and tufRN is an imitative sequent, (T, M, K,) of the same meaning. (M.)

OufR, also, is a word expressive of vexation, distress of mind, or disgust; (M, Mgh;) or of dislike, displeasure, or hatred; (K;) and has six forms; (T, S;) mentioned by Akh; (S;) or ten; (M;) or forty; (K;) or more; (TA;) as follow: OufRi and OufRa and OufRu and OufRK and OufRaA and OufRN (T, S, M, K) and OufRi and Oufa and Oufu and OufK and OufFA and OufN (K) and Oufo (M, K) and OufRo and OufRaI↓, pronounced with imáleh, (M, K,) i. e. with pure imáleh, and OufRaI↓ with intermediate imáleh, and OufRaI↓ without imáleh, the alif [written I] in these three denoting the fem. gender, and OufRiI↓, with kesr to the f, (K,) i. e., as a prefixed noun with its complement, [the latter being the pronoun of the first pers.,] (TA,) and OufRuwoho↓, (K,) with damm to the O and f, which latter is with teshdeed, and with the w and h quiescent, (TA,) and OufRapo↓ [in a copy of the M OufRapF↓] and Oufiho↓ and OufRuho↓ (K) and Uifo↓ and UifRo↓ and Uifi↓ and UifK↓ and UifFA↓ and UifN↓ and UifRK↓ and UifRF↓ and UifRN↓ and UifRu↓, with damm to the f, which is with teshdeed, [in a copy of the M UifRa↓,] and UifRaA↓, like UinRaA, and UifRaI↓, pronounced with imáleh, and UifRiI↓, with kesr, (K,) i. e., prefixed to the pronoun of the first person, (IAmb,) and Oafo↓ and OafRi↓ (K) and OafRK↓ or OafK↓ and Mfi↓, or MfRi↓, and MfK↓, or MfRK↓, (accord. to different copies of the K,) [all these forms, making the number (forty) mentioned by the author of the K, I have drawn from a comparison of three copies of that work, and I believe them to be correct: some other forms are mentioned by SM as perhaps indicated in the K; but I see no good reason for this: he then adds,] and Oafaho↓ and Oafuwho↓ and OafRaho↓, the last mentioned by IB on the authority of IKtt. (TA.) OufRi, [with its variants,] in its primary sense, denotes one's blowing at a thing that falls upon him, such as dust or ashes; or at the place, to remove therefrom what is annoying; therefore people say, at anything that they deem troublesome, or displeasing, or hateful, OufRi lahu [as though meaning A puff, or blast of breath, to it]: (Kt, T:) or [rather] it is a word imitative of a sound; [like ugh in English, both in sound and meaning; and in meaning like our interjections foh and faugh;] (Bd on the ex. in the Kur which will be found below, and TA;) denoting vexation, or distress of mind, or disgust; (Bd ubi suprà) or denoting contempt: (TA:) or it is a verbal noun, meaning I am vexed, or distressed in mind, or disgusted: (Bd ubi suprà:) or it is an imperative verbal noun [denoting disgust or abhorrence, like out, and away]: (IJ, M:) or he who says OufRaA laka uses it in the manner of an imprecation, like as one says wayolFA lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says OufRN laka puts it in the nom. case because of the l, like as one says wayolN lilokaAfiriyna; and he who says OufRK laka puts it in the gen. case likening it to words imitative of sounds. (IAmb.) It is said in the Kur [xvii. 24], walaA taqulo lahumaA OufRi, (T, S, TA,) or OufRK, (TA, [in which other readings also are mentioned,]) [And say not thou to them (i. e. to thy father and mother) Ugh, &c.,] meaning, do not thou deem anything of their affairs burdensome, nor be contracted in bosom thereby, nor be rough, or harsh, or coarse, to them: (Kt, T:) or do not thou say to them anything expressive of the least disgust, when they have become old, but take upon thyself their service; OufRi signifying stink. (Zj, T.)
Uifo and its vars. (differing only in having the f movent): see OufRN.
For UifRN, see also UifRaAnN, in three places.
OafRapN: see UifRaAnN, in two places.
OufRapN: see OufRN, in four places.
Also A dirty, a filthy, an unclean, man: (K:) from OufRN signifying the “dirt of the nail.” (TA.)
One in want; poor; possessing little: (K:) from OafafN signifying “a thing little in quantity.” (TA.)

A coward: (K:) as though originally cuw OufRapK, i. e. holding back, by reason of disgust, (mutaOafRifN,) from fight: (TA:) or experiencing vexation or disgust, and languid or sluggish, in war: (IAar:) also heavy, or sluggish. (IAth.)
UifRapN: see UifRaAnN in three places.
OafafN Vexation, distress of mind, or disgust. (T, IAth, K.)
See also OufRN, in three places.
And see UifRaAnN, in three places.
Oafaho and OafRahN and ONfRahN and OufRiho and OufRuho: see OufRN.
OufRaI, pronounced in three different ways; and
OufRiI: see OufRN.
UifRaA: and UifRaI and UifRiI: see OufRN.
Oafuwho: see OufRN.
OufuwfapN: see what next follows.

OafRaAfN A man who says OufRi much or often; (M, TA;) as also OuwfuwfapN↓, accord. to the copies of the O and TS and K; but in other lexicons OuwfuwfapN↓: in the O, one who ceases not to say to another OufRi laka: in the Jm, the last of these three words is explained as meaning one who ceases no to say this at some of his affairs. (TA.)

UifRaAnN (T, S, M, K) and OafRaAnN (T, TS, L, K) and UifRN↓ (S, M, K) and OafafN↓ (T, L, K) and UifRapq↓ (L, M) and OafRapN↓ (M) and tiYifRapN↓, (T, M, S, K, &c.,) of the measure tafoEilapN, [being originally taOofifapN,] accord. to J, who appears to be right in saying so, (IB,) and so accord. to Aboo-'Alee, who states, on authority of Aboo-Bekr, that it is thus in some of the copies of the Book of Sb, (L,) though in other copies of that book said to be of the measure faEilRapN, (IB, L,) A time; (T, S, M, K;) as in the sayings, celika kaAna celika Ealay UifRi↓, and UifRaAnihi (S, TA) and Oafafihi↓, and UifRatihi↓, and taYifRatihi↓, (TA,) That was at the time of that; (S, TA;) and OataAniI fiI UifRaAni celika, (IAar, L,) and EalaI UifRaAni celika, (IAar, T, M, L,) and OafRaAnihi, (T, L,) and UifRihi↓, (M, L,) and Oafafihi↓, (IAar, T, L,) and UifRatihi↓, (M, L,) and OafRatihi↓, (M,) and taYifRatihi↓, (IAar, T, S, M, L,) preceded by ElI, (IAar, T, S, &c.,) and by fI, (L,) He came to me at the time of that. (IAar, T, &c.)
OufRuwoho: see OufRN.
Mfi and MfRi and MfK and MfRK: see OufRN.
OuwfuwfapN: see OafRaAfN.
taYifRapN: see UifRAnN, in three places.
mutaOafRifN Eani AlqitaAli [app. Holding back, by reason of disgust, from fight; as though saying OufR at the mention thereof: see OufRapN]. (TA.)

1. Oafaxahu, (A'Obeyd, S, L, &c.,) aor.
Aafixa
, inf. n.
OafoxN, (L,) He, [or it] struck him, or hit him, [or hurt him,] on the part of his head called the yaOofuwx. (A'Obeyd, S, L, Msb, K.) He who pronounces yAfwx without C says yafaxahu. (Msb.)
maOofuwxN A man having his head broken in the part called the yaOofuwx. (L.)

yaOofuwxN, (Lth, Az, S, Msb, K,) as also yaAfuwxN, without C, but the former is the more correct and the better, (Lth, Az, Msb,) and is of the measure yafoEuwlN, (Lth, Az, S, Msb,) whereas the latter is of the measure faAEuwlN, (Lth, Az, Msb,) [The top, vertex, or crown, of the head; or the part of the top of the head which is crossed by the coronal suture, and comprises a portion of the sagittal suture;] the part where the anterior and posterior bones of the head meet; (K;) the place that is in a state of commotion in the head of an infant; (S;) the place which, in the head of a child, does not close up until after some years; or does not become knit together in its several parts; and this is where the bone of the anterior part of the head and that of its posterior part meet; (Zj in his “ Khalk el-Insán; ”) the place that is soft, in a child's head, before the two bones called the namRaAgap and ramRaAEap meet, between the haAmap [or middle of the head] and the forehead: (L:) or the middle of the head when it has become hard and strong; before which it is not thus called: (Msb:) pl. yaMfiyxu; (S;) so in the old lexicons [in general]; but in the T and K yawaAfiyxu [which is pl. of yAfwx without C; or, as pl. of yOfwx, is like tawaAriyxu as pl. of taOoriyxN]; and because of this form of the pl., F says that J is in error in mentioning the word in the present art.: it has been shown, however, that J is not in error in this case. (TA.) — [Hence the saying,] Oanotumo yaMfiyxu AlXRarafi (tropical:) Ye are the centres and summits of the heads of nobility. (L, from a trad.) And yaOofuwxu AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) The main [or middle] part of the night. (S, K.) — [See also art. yfx.]

1. Oafaqa, (JK, S, K,) aor.
Aafiqa
, (JK, K,) inf. n. OafoqN, (TK,) He went his own way, at random, or heedlessly, (rakiba raOosahu,) and went away in the MfaAq [or regions, &c., of the land]: (Lth, JK, K:) or he went away in, or into, the land, or country: (S:) and he took his way into the MfAq [or regions, &c.,] of the land. (JK.)

[Hence, app.,] Oafaqa, aor. as above; thus, says IB, accord. to Kz, and thus it is given on the authority of Kr; (TA;) [see MfiqN;] or Oafiqa, aor.
Aafaqa
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. OafaqN; (S;) He attained the utmost degree, [as though he reached the Oufuq (or horizon, or furthest point of view,)] in generosity; (S, O, K;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities. (K.)

Also, Oafaqa, aor.
Aafiqa
, (Kr, Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K,) inf. n. OafoqN, (JK, TA,) He overcame, or surpassed. (Kr, Ibn-'Abbád, JK, K.)

And, inf. n, OufuwqN, He was goodly, or beautiful; he possessed the quality of exciting admiration and approval by his beauty and the pleasingness of his aspect; said of a camel, and of a horse. (JK.)

Oafaqa Ealayohi (JK, TA) He (a man) excelled him; namely, another man: (JK:) or he preceded him in excellence; or outwent him therein; as also Oafaqahu, aor.
Aafiqa
. (TA.) [It is like faAqahu.]

Oafaqa fiI AlEaTaMCi, aor.
Aafiqa
, (S, K,) inf. n. OafoqN, (TA,) He gave to some more than to others. (S, K.) So in the saying of El-Aashà,

[Nor the King En-Noamán, on the day that I met him, in his goodly, or happy, condition, giving gifts, or stipends, or written obligations conferring gifts, and giving to some more than to others]: (S:) or the meaning is, writing [writs of] gifts, and sealing them: or, as some say, taking his way into the MfAq [or regions, &c.,] of the land. (JK.)

Oafaqahu, aor.
Aafiqa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. OafoqN, (S, Msb,) He tanned it (namely a hide) until it became what is termed Oafiyq. (S, Msb, * K.)

5. tOfRq binaA He (a man, As, TA) came to us mino OufuqK [from a region, &c., of the land]: (As, K:) or came to us, and alighted at our abode as a guest: and in the Nawádir el-Aaráb, tOfRq bihi is said to signify he reached him, or overtook him; as also tlRfq bh (TA.)
OufoqN: see OufuqN.

OafaqN The main and middle part (sanan) of a road; (K;) the face, or surface, thereof: (IAar, K:) pl. MfaAqN. (K.) Hence the saying, qaEada fulaAnN EalaI Oafaqi AlTRariyqi [Such a one sat upon the main and middle part, or face, or surface, of the road]. (TA.)

The flanks, or ilia: or, as some say, skins; or skin; as in the saying, Xaribotu HatRaI malaOotu Oafaqiy I drank until I filled my skin: (JK:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of OafaqapN↓; (IAar;) which signifies the flank; (IAar, K;) as does also MfiqapN↓. (Th, K.)
Also pl., (S, K,) or [rather] quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) of OafiyqN, q. v. (S, M, K.)
OafiqN: see OafiyqN, in two places.

OufuqN (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.) and OufoqN↓ (S, K) A side; meaning a lateral, or an outward or adjacent, part or portion; or a part, region, quarter, or tract, considered with respect to its collocation or juxtaposition or direction, or considered as belonging to a whole; or a remote side; syn. naAHiyapN; (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and a border, or an extremity; (JK;) of a land, or of the earth; and of the sky, or heavens: (JK, Mgh, Msb:) [or the horizon, or part next to the horizon, of the sky and of the earth;] or what appears of the sides (AlnRawaAHiI) of the celestial sphere, (K, TA,) and of the borders, or extremities, of the earth: (TA:) or the place whence blows the south wind, and the north wind, and the west wind, and the east wind: (K, * TA:) pl. MfaAqN: (JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K:) and the sing. also is used as a pl.; like fulokN, as is said in
the Nh: (MF:) thus in the verse of El-'Abbás, in praise of the Prophet:

[When thou wast born, the earth became bright, and the tracts of the horizon, or the regions, shone with thy light]: or, as some say, AlAfq is made fem. by him as meaning AlnRaAHiyapu. (TA.) The phrase Hiyna yagiybu AlOufuqu means When the redness, or whiteness, in the Oufuq [or horizon] disappears. (Mgh.)

Also, in like manner, The side, or lateral part, of a tent: (JK:) or the part between the [two] anterior [pieces of wood called the] zirRaAni, in the [fore part called the] riwaAq, of a tent: (K:) and the sides, or lateral parts, of a tent of the kind belonging to the Arabs of the desert. (TA.)
OufuqN is also said to be a pl. of OafiyqN; but this is disallowed by Lh. (TA.)
See also MfiqN.
OafaqapN: see OafaqN.
Also A burying of a skin, or hide, in the earth, so that its hair may be removed, and it may become ready for tanning. (Lth, K,* TA.) [See OafiyqN.]

OafaqiIRN, (ISk, JK, T, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) contr. to rule, (T, Msb,) and OufuqiIRN↓, (As, ISk, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) agreeably with rule, (S,) being a rel. n. from OufuqN, (Msb,) and some (namely the lawyers, in relation to pilgrimage and the like, MF) say MfaAqiIRN↓, (Mgh, MF,) which is incorrect, (Mgh, Msb,) or whether it be correct, after the manner of OanoSaAriIRN and the like, requires consideration, (MF,) an epthet applied to a man, (ISk, S, Msb,) meaning One who is from the MfaAq [or lateral parts, or regions,] of the land; (ISk,* S, Msb;*) mentioned by Aboo-Nasr: (S, referring to the first form of the word:) or one who goes about in the MfaAq: (JK:) or one who goes through the MfAq of the land in search of sustenance: (K,* TA:) as also OafRaAqN↓. (K, TA.) OufuqiIRu makRapa or OafaqiIRu mkRp means He who is without the places where the pilgrims coming to Mekkeh enter upon the state of UiHoraAm. (Mgh.)
OufuqiIRN: see OafaqiIRN.
OafiyqN: see MfiqN.
Applied also to a bucket (dalow), meaning Excelling other buckets. (AA, K.)

Also, (As, Th, JK, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and OafiyqapN↓, (K,) or the latter is a more particular term than the former, like as jilodapN is more so than jilodN, (Mgh,) and OafiqN↓, (K, [but see what follows,]) The skin, or hide, that is not completely tanned, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) so that it is unsubstantial, not firm, or strong, or tough: (Mgh:) when its tanning is complete, and it becomes red, it is termed Oadiym: therefore OafiyqN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) or in the second stage of its tanning; for in the first stage it is termed maniyoYap; then, Afyq; and then, Adym: (TA:) or that is tanned, but before it is sewed: (As, S, K:) or before it is cut, or slit: (K:) or when it comes forth from the tan, its tanning being finished, (JK, TA,) its [original] odour being [still] in it: (TA:) or after it is tanned: (Msb:) or not tanned: (Th, TA:) or that is tanned without qaraZ or OaroTaI or any of the tans of the people of Nejd: (TA:) ISd says, I think that Th has mentioned OafiqN↓ as syn. with OafiyqN, and explained it as signifying the skin, or hide, that is not tanned; but I am not sure of it: (TA:) the pl. is OafaqN, (Lh, JK, S, Msb, K,) like as OadamN is pl. of OadiymN, (S,) or this is a quasi-pl. n., (M, K,) and OufuqN (JK, K) is allowable, (JK,) or, accord. to Lh, it is not allowable, (TA,) and [pl. of pauc.] MfiqapN, (As, S, K,) like as MdmapN and OarogifapN are pls. of OadiymN and ragiyfN. (As, S.) OafiyqapN↓ signifies also A siqaMC [or skin for water or milk &c.] made of a hide of the kind termed Oafiyq. (Mgh.) And OafiyqN also signifies The skin of a man, and of any beast. (TA.)
OafiyqapN: see OafiyqN, in two places.
OafRaAqN: see OafaqiIRN.

MfiqN, (S, K, &c.,) of the measure faAEilN, (S, Kz, TA, [in the CK AafiqN, and in like manner in a copy of the JK,]) from Oafiqa, (S, K,) or, as IB says, accord. to Kz, from Oafaqa, aor.
Aafiqa
, and so accord. to Kr, and shown to be of the measure faAEilN by several verses in which it occurs, (TA,) One who has attained the utmost degree in generosity; (S, K;) or in knowledge, or science; or in chasteness of speech, or eloquence, and in the combination of excellent qualities; (K;) as also OafiyqN↓: (K:) fem. with p. (IF, K.) Also applied to a horse, Generous with respect to both parents: fem. with p. (S.) And applied to a camel, That excites admiration and approval by his generousness, excellence, high blood, or the like; (JK;) and so OufuqN↓, (JK, S, K,) applied to a horse, (S, K,) and a mare, (JK, S, K,) and a she-camel. (JK.).
MfiqapN: see OafaqN.
MfaAqiIRN: see OafaqiIRN.

1. Oafakahu, aor.
Aafika
, inf. n. OafokN, (with fet-h, S, TA, its only form, TA, [in the CK Aifok,]) He changed his, or its, manner of being, or state; (S, K;) and he turned him, or it, (i. e., anything, Msb,) away, or back; (S, Msb, K;) Eani AlXRaIoCi [from the thing]; (S;) or Eano wajohihi [from his, or its, mode, or manner, of being, &c.]: (Msb:) so in the Kur xlvi. 21, OajiYotanaA litaOofikanaA Eano MlihatinaA Hast thou come to us to turn us away, or back, from our gods? (Bd:) or he turned him away, or back, by lying: (TA:) or he changed, or perverted, his judgment, or opinion: (K:) or he deceived him, or beguiled him, and so turned him away, or back: and simply he deceived him, or beguiled him: and Oufika signifies he was turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [li. 9], yuWofaku Eanohu mano Oufika, i. e., He will be turned away from it (namely, the truth,) who is turned away in the foreknowledge of God: (TA:) or, accord. to Mujáhid, yuWofanu Eanohu mano Oufina [he will be weak in intellect and judgment so as to be thereby turned away from it who is weak in intellect and judgment]. (S, TA.) You say also, Oufika AlrRajulu Eani Alxayori The man was turned away, or back, from good, or prosperity. (Sh.) And Oafakahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He forbade him what he wished, (K, TA,) and turned him away, or back, from it. (TA.)

Oafaka, aor.
Aafika
; (Msb, K;) and Oafika, aor.
Aafaka
; (IAar, K;) inf. n. UifokN (Msb, K) and OafokN and OafakN and OufuwkN; (K;) He lied; uttered a falsehood; said what was untrue; (Msb, K;) as also OfRk↓, (K,) inf. n. taOofiykN: (TA:) because a lie is a saying that is turned from its proper way, or mode. (Bd in xxiv. 11.)

Oafaka AlnRaAsa, aor.
Aafika
, inf. n. OafokN, He told the people what was false; Oafaka and Oafakotuhu being like kacaba and kacabotuhu. (Az, TA.)
Oafaka fulaAnFA, (K,) inf. n. OafokN; (TA;) or the verb is Mfaka↓; (so in the printed edition of Bd, xlvi. 27;) He, or it, made such a one to lie, or say what was untrue. (K.)
Oufika He was weak [as though perverted] in his intellect and judgment or opinion. (K,* TA.) But Oafakahu QllRehu as meaning God rendered weak his intellect is not used. (L, TA.)
(tropical:) It (a place) was not rained upon, and had no vegetation, or herbage. (K, TA.)
2: see 1.
4: see 1.

8. QYotafakati Albalodapu [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytafakat], (S, K,) biOaholihaA, (S,) The land, or district, or the town, or the like, was, or became, overturned, or subverted, (S, K,) with its inhabitants: (S:) as were the towns of the people of Lot. (TA.)
Hence it is said of El-Basrah, qadi QYotafakato biOaholihaA marRatayoni, meaning (tropical:) It has been submerged with its inhabitants twice; as though subverted. (Sh.)
You say also, Aiytafakato tiloka AlOaroDu (tropical:) That land has been burnt up by drought. (IAar.)

UifokN [an inf. n. used as a subst.;] A lie; a falsehood; (S, TA;) as also OafiykapN↓: pl. (of the latter, K) OafaAYiku. (S, K.) You say, yaA laloOafiykapi↓, and yaA liloOafiykapi↓; [and laloOafayRikapi↓, using the dim. form for the purpose of enhancement; i. e. O the lie! and O the great lie!] the l with fet-h denoting calling to aid; and with kesr denoting wonder, as though the meaning were, O man, wonder thou at this great lie. (TA.)

Afkp [so in the TA, without any syll. signs; app. either OafokapN, an inf. n. of un., or MfikapN↓, like daAhiyapN;] A punishment sent by God, whereby the dwellings of a people are overturned: occurring in a trad. relating to the story of the people of Lot. (TA.)

sanapN OafikapN (tropical:) A year of drought or sterility: (K,
TA:) pl. OawaAfiku [contr. to rule, as though the sing. were MfikapN↓]. (Z, TA.)
OafuwkN: see OafRaAkN.
OafiykN One who is turned from his judgment, or opinion, by deceit, or guile; as also maOofuwkN↓. (K.)
Lacking strength or power or ability, and having little prudence and artifice. (Lth, K.)
See also OafRaAkN.
OufayRikapN: see UifokN, in three places.
Also A severe, or distressing, calamity. (Ibn-Abbád.)
OufayRikapN: see UifokN.

OafRaAkN A great, or habitual, liar; (S, Msb, K;) as also Oafuwku↓, (Msb, K,) and OafiykN↓: (K:) fem. of the first [and last] with p: but the second is both masc. and fem.: (Msb:) the pl. of the second is Afk with damm [i. e. OufokN, accord. to the rule of the K, but the TA seems to indicate that it is OufukN, by likening it to the pl. of SabuwrN]. (K.)
MfikapN: see Afkp:
and see sanapN OafikpN.
OafiykN [Changed in his, or its, manner of being, or state: turned away, or back, from a thing: &c.]: see maOofuwnN.

Weak [as though perverted] in his intellect (AZ, S, K) and judgment or opinion; as also p: (AZ, S:) accord. to A'Obeyd, (or AA, as in one copy of the S,) a man who does not attain, or obtain, good, or prosperity. (S.)
Also, (K,) fem. with maOofuwnN, (S, K,) (tropical:) A place, (K,) or land, (OaroDN, S, Z,) not rained upon, and having no vegetation, or herbage. (S, Z, K.)

AlmuWotafikaAtu (S, K) and AlmuwotafikapN, (TA,) both occurring in the Kur, [the former in ix. 71 and lxix. 9, and the latter in liii. 54,] The cities overthrown, or subverted, by God, upon the people of Lot. (S, K.)

The former also signifies The winds that turn over [the surface of] the earth, or ground: (K:) or the winds that blow from different quarters: it is said (by the Arabs, S) that when these winds blow much, the earth (i. e. its seed-produce, TA) thrives, or yields increase. (S, K, TA.)

1. Oafala, (T, S, Msb, K,) said of a thing, (Msb,) or of the moon, (T,) and Oafalato, said of the sun, (T, S, M,) and of the stars, (M,) aor.
Aafila
and
Aafula
, inf. n. OufuwlN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OfolN, (M, Msb,) It was, or became, absent, or hidden, or concealed; (T, S, Msb, K;) it set; (T, S, M, &c.;) and so Oafila, aor.
Aafala
. (K.)
Hence, Oafala fulaAnN Eani Albaladi Such a one became absent, or went away, from the country, or town. (Msb.)

OafiylN A young camel such as is termed Aibonu maxaADK [i. e. that has entered its second year]; (As, ElFárábee, S, M, Msb, K;) and the like; (S;) or, and also such as is above this [in age]; (ElFárábee, M, Msb, K;) or, and also such as is termed Aibonu labuwnK [i. e. that has entered the third year]; beyond which it is not so called: (As, TA:) or that is seven months old, or eight: (As, Msb:) or a youthful camel: (AZ, Msb:) and also (M, K) a young weaned camel; syn. faSiylRN: (T, M, Msb, K:) fem. with p: (As, S:) pl. UifaAlN (T, S, M, K) and OafaAYilu, (Sb, S, M, K,) which latter they liken to canaAYibu as pl. of cnuwbN. (M.) [In my copy of the Msb, the pl. is said to be UfAlp: and it is also there said, on the authority of IF, that AfAlp signifies the young ones of sheep.] It is said in a prov., UinRamaA Alqaromi mina AlOafiyli [The stallion-camel is only that which has increased in growth from the young one in its second year, &c.]; i. e. what is great has begun small. (TA.)

MfilN part. n. of 1, (T, TA,) applied to the moon, and to any star: (TA:) fem. with p: (T, TA:) pl. Mfiluwna (Kur vi. 76 [the rational form of the pl. being there used because it is applied to stars as being likened to gods]) and OufRalN and OufuwlN. (TA.)
Oafaho and OafRaho and OufRaho and OufRiho and OufRuho and Oafuwho and OufRuwho: see OufRN.

OafoyuwnN, [like SaEofuwqN, but this is of a very extr. measure; or, as some write it, OufoyuwnN, like EuSofuwrN &c.;] or UifoyawonN, [like birocawonN;] (accord. to different copies of the K, art. fyn;) [an arabicized word, from the Greek OaPoyuwno, either immediately or through the Persian xaXoxaAX; meaning Opium:] the milk [or juice] of the black Egyptian xXxAX [or poppy, or papaver somniferum]; (K;) or the milk of the xXxAX, the best of which is the black Egyptian; (TA;) or the expressed juice of the black Egyptian xXxAX, dried in the sun: cold and dry in the fourth degree: (Ibn-Seenà, or Avicenna, i. 133:) beneficial for hot tumours, especially in the eye; torporific (to the intellect, TA): in a small quantity, beneficial, and soporific: in a large quantity, a poison: (K:) [the lexicographers regard the word as Arabic:] some, among whom is the author of the K, hold that it belongs to art. fyn: others, that it belongs to art. Afn. (TA.)
OuqoHuwaAnN: see art. qHw

1. OaqaTahu, aor
AaqiTa
(S, K,) inf. n. OaqoTN, (S,) He made it (namely food) with OaqiT q. v. infrà. (S, K.)

Also, (aor. and inf. n. as above, TA,) He fed him with OaqiT: (A'Obeyd, K:) like labanahu from labanN and labaOahu from libaON Lh mentions the verb in this sense as used without its being made transitive. (TA.)
[OaqiTa in the CK is a mistake for MqaTa q. v.]

4. MqaTa, (Lh, K, [in the CK, incorrectly, OaqiTa,]) of the measure OafoEala, agreeably with a common rule, applying to anything, (Lh, TA,) He had much OaqiT; his OaqiT became much, or abundant. (Lh, K.)
8. AYtqT [written with the disjunctive alif AiytaqaTa] He made, or prepared, OaqiT: (S:) strangely omitted in the O and in the K. (TA.)

OaqiTN (Fr, Az, S, Msb, K) and UiqiTN (Fr, O, K) and OaqaTN (Fr, K) and UiqoTN, (S, O, Msb, K,) the last sometimes occurring in poetry, and formed from the first, by transferring the vowel of the q to the preceding letter, (S,) or a contraction of the second, accord. to a common usage of [the tribe of] Temeem in the cases of words of this measure, (O,) and OaqoTN (K) and OuqoTN, (As, K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, and the last is strange, (TA,) [A preparation of dried curd;] a preparation of, or thing made from, milk (Az, Msb, K) of sheep or goats, (K,) which has been churned, and of which the butter has been taken, (Az, Msb, K,) cooked, and then left until it becomes concrete: (Az, Msb:) or made from the milk of camels, in particular: (IAar:) or milk which is dried, and has become hard, like stone; with which one cooks; repeatedly mentioned in trads.: (TA:) or a thing made from milk; being a kind of cheese: (Har p. 587:) pl. OuqoTaAnN. (K.)
OaqRaATN A maker of OaqiT. (TA.)
maOoquwTN Food made with OaqiT. (S.)
1. Oakada He trod wheat. (IAar, K.)
2. OkRd, inf. n. taOokiydN, i. q. wakRada, (S, Msb, K,) of which it is a dial. var.; (S;) but it is not so chaste as the latter, and by some is disallowed. (TA.)
4. Mkd i. q. Oawokada. (S in art. wkd.)
5. tOkRd i. q. tawakRada. (S and K in art. wkd.)

UkaAdN sing. of OakaAYidN and taMkiydN, (K,) both of which are irreg. in relation to their sing., (TA,) signifying (i. e. the pls.) Thongs, or straps, by which the qarabuws is bound to the two side-boards of a horse's saddle. (K.) [See also wikaAdN.]
Akr Firm; (K, TA;) applied to a covenant, or compact. (TA.)

1. Oakara, aor.
Aa^iaa
, inf. n. OakorN, He tilled the ground; ploughed it up for sowing. (Msb.)
He dug the ground. (TA.)
He cut, or dug, a river, or canal, or rivulet. (Msb.)

And Oakara, aor
Aa^uaa
, (TA,) inf. n. as above; (K;) and tOkRr↓; (K;) He dug a hollow, or cavity, in the ground, for water to collect therein and to be baled out therefrom clear: (K, TA:) or OukarRaA tOkRr↓ signifies he dug hollows, or cavities, in the ground. (S.)

3. Mkrhu, (TK.) inf. n. muWaAkarapN, (S, K,) He made a contract, or bargain, with him to till and sow and cultivate land for a share of its produce; syn. of the inf. n. muxaAbarapN. (S, K, TA.) The doing of this is forbidden. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places.
OukorapN A hollow, or cavity, dug in the ground, (S, Msb, K,) in which water collects, and from which it is baled out clear: (K:) pl. OukarN. (S, Msb.)
Also a dial. var. of kurapN, (K,) [A ball] with which one plays: (TA:) [and a sphere, or globe:] but it is of weak authority. (K.)
UikaArapN, as used in practical law, Land which is given by its owners to men who sow and cultivate it [app. for a certain share of its produce: see 3]. (Mgh.)
OakRaArN A tiller, or cultivator, of land: (Msb, K:) pl. OakarapN; as though it were pl. of MkirN, (S, Msb, K,) like as kafarapN is pl. of kaAfirN. (Msb.)
2. AkRf AlUikaAfa, inf. n. taOokiyfN, He made the AkAf; (K;) as also wkRfhu, inf. n. tawokiyfN; which latter, accord. to IF, is the original form. (TA.)
See also 4.

4. Mkf AlHimaAra, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiykaAfN, (K,) He bound, (S, K, TA,) or put, (Msb, TA,) the UikaAf upon the ass; (S, Msb, K;) as also OkRfhu↓; (Sgh, K;) and Awkfhu; (S, Mgh, K;) which is of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; the first being of the dial. of Benoo-Temeem: and in like manner, Albagola the mule. (Lh.)

UikaAfN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and OukaAfN, (K,) as also wikaAfN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and wukaAfN, (K in art. wkf,) The barocaEap, [i. e. pad, or stuffed saddle, generally stuffed with straw,] (K,) of the ass, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and also used for the mule, and for the camel; (TA in art. wkf;) a saddle like the raHol and qatab: (TA:) and a saddle of a horse made in the form of the ass's AkAf, having at its fore part [or pommel] a thing resembling a pomegranate: (Mgh:) [see also qatabN:] pl. [of pauc.] MkifapN (TA) and [of mult.] OukufN. (S, Mgh, Msb, TA.) Yaakoob asserts that the A in UikaAfN is a substitute for the w in wikaAfN. (TA.) A rájiz says,
meaning [Verily we have some lean asses] which eat every night the price of an AkAf. (TA.)
OakRaAfN The maker of the kind of saddle called UikaAf. (K.)

1. Oakalahu, [aor.
Aakula
,] inf. n. OakolN and maOokalN, [He ate it,] (S, K,) namely, food. (S.) Er-Rummánee says that OakolN properly signifies The swallowing food after chewing it; so that the swallowing of pebbles is not properly thus termed: (Msb:) or, accord. to Ibn-El-Kemál, the conveying, or transmitting, to the belly what may be chewed, whether [the thing be] chewed or not; so that it does not apply to milk, nor to sawiyq: and as to the saying of the poet,

L.foreign: mina AlMkiliyna AlmaMCa ZulomFA famaA OaraI

sense.s: (assumed tropical:) [Of the eaters of what they purchase with the price of water, wrongfully, I do not see any attain good after their eating of what they have purchased with the price of the water,] he means a people who used to sell water and purchase with the price thereof what they would eat: (TA:) [for you say, Oakala kacaA as meaning (assumed tropical:) He ate the price of such a thing: see another ex. voce UikaAfN; and another voce vadoIN.]

The saying, in the Kur [v. 70], laOakaluwA mino fawoqihimo wamino taHoti Oarojulihimo [They should eat things above them and things beneath their feet] means, their means of subsistence should be made ample; (Bd, TA;) by the pouring of the blessings of the heaven and the earth upon them; or by the abundance of the fruit of the trees, and the produce of the grains sown; or by their being blessed with gardens of ripe fruits, so that they should gather them from the upper part of each tree, and pick up what should have fallen upon the ground. (Bd.)
AinoqaTaEa Oakoluhu [lit. His eating became cut off, or stopped,] means (tropical:) he died; [see also OukulN;] and so AisotawofaI Oakolahu [lit. he completed his eating]. (TA.)
Oakala raWoqahu [lit. He ate his life,] means (tropical:) he became extremely aged, and his teeth fell out, one after another. (TA.)

huwa yaOokulu AlnRaAsa, and yaOokulu luHuwma AlnRaAsi [He eats men, and eats the flesh of men,] means (tropical:) he defames men; or does so in their absence: (TA:) and the action thus signified may be [with words, or by making signs] with the side of the mouth, and with the eye, and with the head. (TA in art. hmz.) It is said in the Kur [xlix. 12], OayuHibRu OaHadukumo Oano yaOokla laHoma Oaxiyhi mayotFA [lit. Would any one of you like to eat the flesh of his brother when dead?]; defamation, or defamation of the absent, being meant thereby. (S, * Ibn-' Arafeh, Bd, Jel.)

Oakala ganamiI wa XaribahaA (tropical:) [He ate the flesh of my sheep, and drank the milk of them, means, like Oakala maAliI, he ate, fed upon, devoured, or consumed, my wealth, or property: see 2]. (TA.)
Oakalati AlnRaAru AlHaTaba (tropical:) The fire devoured, or consumed, the firewood. (S, Mgh.)
Oakalato OaZofaArahu AlHijaArapu (tropical:) [The stones wore away his nails]. (TA.)
AlwaAwu fiI maroYIRK OakalatohaA AlyaMCu (assumed tropical:) [The w in maroYiIR, the I has swallowed it up]; because it is originally maroWuwIN: a phrase occurring in the 'Eyn. (TA.)
Oakala Eumurahu (tropical:) He consumed his life. (Mgh.)

It is said in a trad., (TA,) Oumirotu biqaroyapK taOokulu AlquraI (tropical:) [I have been commanded to have given unto me a town which shall devour the other towns]; (K, TA;) said to be Yethrib [afterwards called El-Medeeneh]; (TA;) i. e., the people of which shall conquer the [other] towns and make spoil of their possessions: or it denotes the superior excellence of that town; and is like the saying, hecaA HadiyvN yaOokulu AlOaHaAdiyva [This is a tradition which does away with, or overrules, the other traditions]. (Sgh. K, TA.)
Oakolu AlsRikRiyni AllRaHoma means (tropical:) The knife's cutting the flesh. (TA.)

Oakalaniy raOosiI, inf. n. UikolapN and OukaAlN and OakaAlN, (tropical:) My head itched. (K, TA.) An Arab was heard to say, [as is often said in the present day,] jilodiI yaOokuluniI (tropical:) My skin itches. (TA.)

Oakila, aor.
Aakala
, (K,) inf. n. OakalN, (TA,) (tropical:) It (a limb, or member, [and a sore,] and a piece of stick, or wood,) became corroded or cankered, or decayed, by the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also AYtkl↓ [written with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala], and tOkRl↓. (K, TA.)

Oakilati AlOasonaAnu, (S, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding sentence, (Msb,) (tropical:) The teeth rubbed together and wasted away; by reason of age; (S;) or fell out, one after another: (Msb:) or broke in pieces, or became much broken: (K:) and tOkRlt↓ signifies the same; (S, Msb;) and so AYtklt↓. (S.)

Oakilati AlnRaAqapu, aor.
Aakala
, inf. n. OakaAlN, (assumed tropical:) The she-camel experienced an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, O, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S, O,) or from the growth of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, O, K.)
2: [OkRlhu, inf. n. taOokiylN, He made him to eat a thing.]

OakRala maAliI wa XrRabahu, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) [lit. He made people to eat my property, and made them to drink it,] means (tropical:) he fed men, or the people, with my property, or cattle. (S, K, TA.)

ZalRa maAliI yuWakRalu wa yuXarRabu, (so in some copies of the K and in the TA,) or yuWakRilu wyuXarRibu, (so in two copies of the S and in a copy of the K,) [of which the former is app. the right reading, as the lit. meaning seems to be My cattle passed the day made to eat and made to drink,] i. e., (tropical:) pasturing as they pleased. (S, K, TA.)

OkRlhu AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) He charged against him, or accused him of doing, the thing; as also Mklhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. UiykaAlN. (TA.) In [some of] the copies of the K, for AidRaEaAhu, we here find, erroneously, daEaAhu. (TA.) You say, OakRalotaniI maA lamo Mkulo [lit. Thou hast made me to eat what I have not eaten,] meaning (tropical:) thou hast charged against me, or accused me of doing, what I have not done; as also MkalotaniI↓. (S, TA.) So too, OaXorabotaniI maA lamo OaXorabN. (S and K in art. Xrb.)
3. Mklhu, inf. n. muWaAkalapN (S, K) and UikaAilN, (K,) He ate with him; (S, K;) as also waAkalahu, though of weak authority; (K;) or this latter is not allowable. (S, Sgh.)
muWaAkalapN which is forbidden in a trad. is (assumed tropical:) A debtor's giving a thing to his creditor in order that he may abstain from taking the debt. (TA.)
4. Mkl, [inf. n. UiykaAlN,] said of the palm-tree, and of seed-produce, (S, K,) and of anything, (S,) It had ripe fruit; it supplied food. (S, K.)
Mklhu AlXRaIoCa, (S, K,) inf. n. as above, (S,) He gave him to eat the thing; he fed him with the thing. (S, * K.)
See also 2, in two places.
Mkl AlnRaAra (assumed tropical:) He fed, or supplied, the fire with fuel. (S.)

Mkl bayona AlnRaAsi, (A, K,) inf. n. as above, (S, O,) (tropical:) He busied himself among the people with propagating calumnies: (S, O, TA:) or he created, or excited, disagreement, dissension, or
strife, among them; or made, or did, mischief among them: (A, TA:) or he incited them, one against another. (K.)

Mkalotuka fulaAnFA, (S,) or Mkala fulaAnN fulAnFA, (K, [in the CK, erroneously, fulaAnN fulaAnFA,]) (tropical:) I made thee, (S,) or he made such a one, (K,) to have dominion, or authority, or power, over such a one. (S, K.)
5. tOklR: see 1, latter part, in two places:
and see also 8.

Also, said of a sword, (S, K,) and of silver (K, TA) molten, (TA,) and of lightning, and of collyrium, and of aloes, (K,) and of anything shiny, (TA,) (tropical:) It shone, gleamed, or glistened, (S, K, TA,) much, or intensely; (K;) when said of a sword, by reason of its sharpness. (S, TA.)
8. AYtkl [with the disjunctive alif Aiytakala]: see 1, latter part, in two places.
OamaA tanofakRu taOotakilu Dost thou not cease to eat our flesh, [i. e., to wound our reputations, (see 1,)] and to defame us? (Aboo-Nasr, TA.) But see below.
AYtklti AlnRaAru (tropical:) The fire flamed, or blazed, vehemently; as though one part thereof devoured another. (TA.)

AYtkl gaDabFA, (K,) or mina AlgaDabi, (S,) (tropical:) He burned, or burned fiercely, with, or by reason of, anger. (S, K.) The phrase mentioned above, AmA tnfkR tOtkl, is also cited as an ex. of this meaning. (S, TA.) You say likewise, AYtkl minohu (tropical:) He was, or became, angry with him, and excited, or provoked, against him, (K, TA,) and vehement, or severe; (TA;) as also mnh tOkl↓. (K.)
10. AstOklhu AlXRaIoCa (tropical:) He asked, or begged, of him to assign to him the thing, or to make it be to him, as a means of subsistence, or a thing to be eaten. (K, TA.)
yasotaOokilu AlDRuEafaMCa (tropical:) He takes (S, K, TA) and devours (TA) the possessions of the weak ones. (S, K, TA.)
OukolN: see OukulN.
OakalN inf. n. of Oakila [q. v.].
fiI OasonaAnihi OakalN (tropical:) In his teeth is a rubbing together and wasting away; by reason of age. (S, TA.) See also OukulN
OakilN [part. n. of Oakila].

naAqapN OakilapN (assumed tropical:) A she-camel experiencing an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S,) or from the growth of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, K.)
[AlAakilu is erroneously put, in the CK, for AlMkilu, in a sense explained below.]

OukulN and OukolN↓; (S, Msb, K, &c.;) the latter a contraction of the former; (Msb;) What is eaten; (S, Msb, TA;) as also OukolapN↓ and OakolapN↓ (Lh, TA) and maOokalapN↓ and maOokulapN↓ (Msb, K) and maOokuwlN↓; (Lh, Msb;) any eatable; i. e. anything that is eaten; (S;) and OakaAlN↓ signifies [the same, an eatable, or] food. (S, TA.) You say of one who is dead, AinoqaTaEa Oukuluhu [His food has become cut off, or stopped: in the TA, Oakoluhu: see 1]. (S.) And maA cuqotu OakaAlRaA↓ I have not tasted food. (S, TA.)

Fruit (S, K [in the latter of which, in some copies, AltRamoru is put for AlvRamaru, erroneously, as is said in the TA]) of palmtrees and other trees [&c.]. (S.) So in the Kur [xiii. 35], OukuluhaA daAYimN [Its fruit shall be perpetual]: (S, TA:) meaning that the fruits thereof shall be not as those of the present world, which come to one at one time and not at another. (TA.) [Pl. MkaAlN; occurring in the M and K in art. Atw.]

(tropical:) Means of subsistence: (K:) worldly good fortune, (S, K,) and ample means of subsistence. (S.) You say, fulaAnN cuw OukulK (tropical:) Such a one is possessed of worldly good fortune, and ample means of subsistence: (S:) and EaZiymu AlOukuli (tropical:) possessed of [great] good fortune; or of a [great and] good share of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

(tropical:) Thickness, substantialness, or closeness or compactness of texture, of a garment, or piece of cloth; (S, K, TA;) and strength thereof. (K.) You say vawobN cuw OukulK (tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, having thickness, &c.: and qiroTaAsN cuw OukulK (tropical:) paper having thickness, &c. (S, TA.)
(tropical:) Intelligence; judgment; (Aboo-Nasr, S, K;) firmness of intellect. (K, TA.) You say rajulN cuw OukulK (tropical:) A man possessing intelligence and judgment. (Aboo-Nasr, S, TA.)

OakolapN A single act of eating (S, Mgh, Msb, K) until one is satisfied. (S.) Hence the saying, AlmuEotaAdu OakolataAni AlgadaMCu waAlEaXaMCu, meaning That to which people are accustomed is two acts of eating, the eating of the morning-meal and that of the evening-meal. (Mgh.)
See also OukolapN, in two places.
And see OukulN, first sentence.

OukolapN A morsel, or small mouthful, of food. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [For the pl., see below.] You say, Oakalotu OukolapF waAHidapF I ate one morsel. (S.) And Oakla biOaxiyhi OukolapF (assumed tropical:) [He ate a morsel by means of defaming his brother] is said, in a trad., of a man who is on terms of brotherhood with another, and then goes to his enemy, and speaks of him in a manner not good, in order that he may give him a present for doing so. (TA.)
A small round cake of bread; syn. quroSapN; (S, K;) a single quroS: (Mgh:) pl. OukalN, as below. (TA.)
See also OukulN.

Also (assumed tropical:) i. q. TuEomapN; (S, K;) which is also syn. with maOokalapN↓; (S, Msb, K, in art. TEm;) i. e. An assigned, or appointed, means of subsistence; such as a grant of a tract of land; and a tax, or portion of a tax or taxes; and the like; (Mgh in explanation of TuEomapN, and TA in explanation of the same and of maOokalapN in art. TEm;) and [it is also said that] maOokalapN↓ signifies a thing that is assigned, or appointed, or granted, to a man, so that he is not to be reckoned with, or called to account, for it: (TA in the present art.:) [thus it applies to any absolute grant, either of land, (as an allodium, an appanage, &c.,) or of revenue:] pl. OukalN (K) [and app. also MkaAlN, which see below]. You say, hecaA AlXRaIoCu OuklapN laka This thing is a TuEomap to thee, or for thee. (S.)
See also OakiylapN.

Also, and UikolapN↓ (S, Z, Sgh, K) and OakolapN↓, (Kr, K,) (tropical:) Defamation; or defamation of the absent. (S, Z, Sgh, K.) You say, UinRahu lacuw OukolapK and UikolapK↓ (S, TA) and OakolapK↓ (TA) (tropical:) Verily he is one who defames men; or, who does so in their absence. (S, TA.)

UikolapN A mode, or manner, (K,) or state, or condition, (S, K,) in which one eats: (S, K: *) like jilosapN and rikobapN: (S, TA:) and the posture of the eater, reclining or sitting. (TA.) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlUikolapi [Verily he has a good mode, &c., of eating]. (S.)
See also OukolapN, last two sentences.

(tropical:) The itch: or an itching: (S, K:) as also OukaAlN↓, (As, S, K,) [see OakalaniI raOosiI, of which both are said to be inf. ns.,] and OakilapN↓: (K:) so the last is written accord. to the correct copies of the K: accord. to Esh-Shiháb, in the Shifá el-Ghaleel, it would seem to be OukolapN; but this is at variance with the authority of the leading lexicologists: the same word, OakilapN, is also explained in the K as signifying a disease in a limb, or member, in consequence of which one part is [as it were] eaten by another; [a meaning which I believe to be correct, (see OukaAlN,) although SM says,] but this is identical with the itch, or an itching: and OakalaAnN↓ is a vulgar term for the same; and so is MkilapN↓, with medd, given as correct by Eth-Tha'álibee, in [his book entitled] the Mudáf and Mensoob, but disallowed by ElKhafájee. (TA.) One says, UinRiI laOajidu fiI jasadiI UikolapF (tropical:) [Verily I experience in my body an itching.] (S.)
OakilapN: see UikolapN.
OukalapN: see OakuwlN.
OakalaAnN: see UikolapN.
OakaAlN: see OukulN, first and second sentences.

OukaAlN (tropical:) A corrosion, or cankering, or decaying, of a limb, or member, [and of a sore,] from the mutual eating away of its several parts; as also UikaAlN↓. (K, TA.) [See also OakilapN, voce UikolapN, where a similar meaning is assigned to the former of these two words; and the same seems to be indicated in the Msb.]
See also another signification voce UikolapN.
bahaA OukaAlN, said of a she-camel, (tropical:) She has an itching and annoyance in her belly, (S, K,) from the growth of the hair, (S,) or of the fur, (K,) of her fœtus. (S, K.)
UikaAlN: see OukaAlN.
rajulN OakuwlN and OukalapN↓ and OakiylN↓ all signify the same; (K;) i. e. A man who eats much; [who is a great eater; edacious; voracious;] as also OakRaAlN↓. (TA.)
OakiylN One who eats with another. (S, TA.)
See also MkilN:
and see OakuwlN.
I. q. maOokuwlN↓ [as signifying Eaten]. (TA.)
See also OakiylapN.

OakuwlapN A sheep, or goat, which is set apart (S, Msb, K) to be eaten, (S, Mgh, K,) [i. e.] to be slaughtered, (Msb,) and which is fattened, (S, Mgh,) and the taking of which by the collector of the poor-rate is disapproved; (S;) not left to pasture by itself, being of the best of the beasts: (Msb:) and OakiylapN↓ occurs in the same sense,
applied to a sheep, or goat, fattened to be eaten. (Mgh.) Hence the prov., maroEFI walaA OakuwlapF [lit. Pasturage, and no Akwlp]; meaning (assumed tropical:) wealth collected together, and none expended. (TA.)
Also Barren; applied to a sheep or goat [app. because such is generally eaten]. (K.)
OukuwlapN: see what next follows.

OakiylapN and OakiylN↓ and OukuwlapN↓, with two dammehs, (K,) so in the copies of the K, but perhaps a mistake for OukolapN↓, (TA,) a word of a bad dial., (K, * TA,) and maOokuwlN↓ and muWaAkilN↓, (K, TA, [in some copies of the former of which, instead of wahiIa qabiyHapN wa AlmaOokuwli wa AlmaWaAkili, meaning, as is said in the TA, wahiIa lugapN qabiyHapN &c., we find wahiIa qabiyHapN AlmaOokuwli wa AlmaWaAkili,]) A sheep, or goat, which is set (K, TA) in the lurking-place of a hunter (TA) for the purpose of catching thereby the wolf and the like. (K, TA.)

And the first two words, (K,) or OakiylapN sabuEK, (S, Mgh, Msb,) A beast which has been eaten, (S, * K,) or partly eaten, (Mgh, Msb,) by a beast or bird of prey, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and then rescued from it: (Mgh, TA:) the p in Akylp being added because the quality of a subst. is predominant in it. (S.)
See also OakuwlapN.
OakRaAlN: see OakuwlN.

MkilN Eating; or an eater; as also OakiylN↓: pl. OakalapN. (S, K.) You say, humo Oakalapu raOosK [lit. They are eaters of a head]; meaning (assumed tropical:) they are few; one head satisfying their stomachs. (S.)
MkilapN (tropical:) Pasturing beasts. (K, TA.)

Mkilapu AllRaHomi (assumed tropical:) The knife; (K, TA;) because it cuts the flesh: (TA:) and the pointed staff or stick; (K, TA;) as being likened thereto: (TA:) and fire: (K:) and whips; (Sh, K;) because they burn the skin. (TA.)
AlMkilu, [in the CK, erroneously, AlAakilu,] (tropical:) The king. (K, TA.) [Opposed to AlmaOokuwlu, q. v.]

Mkilu AlrRibaA (tropical:) [The receiver of usury]: occurring in a trad., in which it is said, luEina Mkilu AlrRibaA wa muWokiluhu↓ (tropical:) [The receiver of usury is cursed, and the giver thereof]. (TA.)
MkilapN fem. of MkilN, q. v.
See also UikolapN.

MkaAlN [app. a pl. of pauc. of OukulN, q. v., and of OukolN, agreeably with analogy,] (tropical:) The [grants termed] maMkil of kings; (K;) their TuEam [pl. of TuEomapN, explained above, voce OukolapN]. (TA.)
(assumed tropical:) The stipends of soldiers. (K.)

cawwAlMkaAli, for which J has erroneously put AlMkAl, [in the S,] (TS, K,) without cww, (TA,) (tropical:) The lords, or chiefs, of the tribes, who take the mirobaAE [or fourth part of the spoil, which was the chief's portion in the time of ignorance] (S, TS, K, TA) &c. (TA.)
maOokalN, (S,) [in measure] like maqoEadN, (TA,) [an inf. n. of Oakala, q. v.:
and also signifying] Gain. (S, TA.)
Also A place, and a time, of eating: pl. maMkilu.]
muWokalN (assumed tropical:) Fortunate; possessed of good fortune; prosperous. (Aboo-Sa'eed, K.)
muWokilu AlrRibaA (tropical:) [The giver of usury: see MkilN, last sentence]. (TA.)
maOokalapN and maOokulapN↓: see OukulN:
and for the former, see also OukolapN, in two places.
Also, both words, i. q. miyrapN i. e. Corn, or any provision, which a man brings, or purveys, for himself or his family, or for sale]. (K.)
Also used in the sense explained above, voce OukulN, [as a subst.,] and likewise as an epithet, so that one says XaApN mOklhN [as meaning A sheep, or goat, that is eaten]. (K.)
Both words signify [also] A place whence one eats. (S, O.)
[And hence] one says, AitRaxacotu fulaAnFA maOokalapF and maOokalapN (assumed tropical:) [I took for myself such a one as a person from whom to obtain what to eat]. (S, O.)
[The pl. is maMkilu: of which see an ex. voce MkaAlN.]
maOokulapN: see the paragraph next preceding, throughout.

miYokalapN Anything in [i. e. out of] which one eats: (Lh, K:) or [bowls of the kind called] SiHaAf, (S,) or a [bowl of the kind called] SaHofap, (TA,) in which the tribe find it easy to cook, (so in a copy of the S and in the TA,) or to put, (so in another copy of the S,) flesh-meat and [the kind of porridge called] EaSiydap: (S, TA:) or a bowl not so large as a SaHfp, but next to it in size, that satisfies the stomachs of two men, or three: (S voce SaHofapN:) [or] a small [bowl of the kind called] qaSoEapN, that satisfies the stomachs of three: and a small [cooking-pot such as is called] buromah. (K.)
maOokuwlN: see OakiylN:
and OukulN:
and OakiylapN.
(assumed tropical:) The subjects of a king. (Z, K, TA.) Hence the trad., maOokuwlN Himoyara xayorN mino MkilihaA (tropical:) The subjects of Himyer are better than their king, or ruler. (Z, TA.)
miYokaAlN A spoon: (K:) because one eats with it. (TA.)
muWaAkilN: see OakiylapN.
Also, [like musotaOokilN↓,] (assumed tropical:) One who takes and devours the possessions of men. (TA.)
musotaOokilN: see what next precedes.
2. taOokiymN The being big in the kafal [i. e. the hinder parts, or posteriors, also termed maOokamapN]. (O, K.) You say, OakRamati AlmaroOapN The woman was large in the kafal. (TK.)
10. AstOkm It (a place) became what are termed Oakam, q. v. (K.)
AstOkm majolisahu He (a man, TA) found his sitting-place to be plain, smooth, soft, or easy to sit upon. (K.)
OakamN: see what next follows.

OakamapN A hill, or mound, syn. talRN, (Msb, K,) [in an absolute sense, or] of what is termed qufR [q. v.], (K,) or, as in the M, (TA,) of a single collection of stones: or it is inferior to mountains: or a place that is more elevated than what is around it, and is rugged, not to the degree of being stone: (K:) or an isolated mountain: (K voce jabalN:) or an eminence like what is termed raAbiyap: a collection of stones in one place, sometimes rugged and sometimes not rugged: (Msb:) or i. q. qufRN, except that the Akmp is higher and greater: (ISh, TA:) or what is higher than the qufR, compact and round, rising into the sky, abounding with stones: (TA:) pl. OakamaAtN (S, Msb) and OakamN↓, [or this is rather a coll. gen. n. of which OakamapN is the n. un.,] (S, Msb, K,) and UikaAmN, (K, TA,) or this is pl. of OakamN, (S, Msb, TA,) and OukumN, (K, TA,) or this is pl. of UikaAmN, (S, Msb, TA,) and MkaAmN [a pl. of pauc.], (K,) or this is pl. of OukumN, (S, Msb, TA,) and MkumN [which is also a pl. of pauc.], (IJ, K,) or this is a pl. of OakamN: (TA:) IHsh says that OakamN is the only word like vamarN in its series of pls.; for its sing. [or n. un.] is OakamapN, and the pl. of this [or the coll. gen. n.] is OakamN, and the pl. of this is UikaAmN, and the pl. of this is OukumN, and the pl. of this is MkaAmN, and the pl. of this is OakaAmiymu [or OawaAkiymu?]. (MF in art. vmr.) It is said in a prov., used in ridiculing any one who has told of his committing some fault, not desiring to reveal it, jusotumuwniI wawaraMCa AlOakamapi maA waraMCahaA [in which I think the first word to be a mistranscription, for jiYotumuwniI, and the literal meaning to be, Ye have come to me; but behind the hill is what is behind it]: related on the authority of Zeyd Ibn-Kethweh. (TA.) And one says, laA tabulo EalaI OakampK, meaning (tropical:) Publish not what is secret of thine affair. (TA.)
maOokamN and maOokimN: see what next follows.

maOokamapN, (El-Fárábee,) or maOokimapN, (S,) or both, and maOokamN↓ and maOokimN↓, (IAth, K,) The hinder part, posteriors, buttocks, or rump, of a woman; syn. EajiyzapN: (S:) or a portion of flesh on the head of the warik [or haunch]; one of two such portions: (Zj in his “Khalk el-Insán,“ and K:) or these are two protuberances of flesh on the heads of the upper parts of the warikaAni [or haunches]; on the right and left: (TA:) or they are two portions of flesh conjoining the Eajuz [or buttocks] and the matonaAni [or two portions of flesh and sinew next the back-bone, on each side]; (K, TA;) or, as in the Nh, conjoining the Eajob [or rump-bone] and the mtnAn: or two portions of flesh at the root of the warikaAi: (TA:) pl. maMkimu. (S, K.) Lh mentions the saying, UinRahu laEaZiymu AlmMkimi [Verily he is big in the hinder parts]; as though they called every portion thereof mOkm. (TA.) And one says in reviling a person, yaA Qbina OaHomari AlmaOokamapi, meaning O son of him who is red in the safilapi. (TA.)
muWakRimapN: see what follows.
muWaAkimapN [in the CK, erroneously, muWAkamap] and muWakRimapN↓ She who is large in the maOokamataAni. (K.)

Aalo is a particle of determination: (Mughnee &c.:) or, accord. to some, it is a conjunct noun, and this is the correct opinion; but some say it is a conjunct particle; and some, a particle of determination: (I 'AK p. 40:) [it is equivalent to our article The;] as in AlrRajulu [The man]: (S and K in art. lwm, and I 'Ak p. 48:) accord. to Kh, [what is termed] the determinative is Aalo [altogether, and therefore it is called by some “the determinative alif and lám“]; but accord. to Sb, it is the l alone; [wherefore it is called by some, as in the S &c., “the lám of determination;”;] so that accord. to Kh, the hemzeh is a hemzeh of disjunction; but accord. to Sb, it is a hemzeh of conjunction: (I 'Ak ubi suprà:) [J says,] the l being quiescent, the conjunctive A is prefixed to it in order that it may commence therewith; but when it is conjoined with what precedes it, the A is dropped, as in lilrRajuli. (S in art. lwm.) Sometimes the Arabs suppress hemzeh after it; and sometimes they also suppress the A of the article itself: thus, for AlOaHomaru, they say AlaHomaru, and laHomaru. (Zj, cited in TA in art. Ayk.) In the dial. of some of the people of El-Yemen, (TA in art. Am, q. v.,) or in the dial. of Himyer, (TA in art. Tyb,) Amo is used in the sense of Al. (TA.)

It is used to distinguish a noun as known [to the hearer or reader in a particular and definite sense]: (Mughnee, I 'Ak ubi suprà:) first, by its being mentioned [before]; (Mughnee;) as in [the words of the Kur lxxiii. 15 and 16,] kama OarosalonaA UilaI firoEawona rasuwlFA faEaSaI firoEawonu AlrRasuwla [Like as we sent unto Pharaoh an apostle, and Pharaoh disobeyed the apostle]; (Mughnee, I 'Ak;) in which case, the pronoun may supply the place which it and the noun that it accompanies occupies: secondly, by its being conceived in the mind; as in [the Kur ix. 40,] Uico humaA fiI AlgaAri [When they two were in the cave]: and thirdly, by its being applied to a thing present; and accord. to Ibn-'Osfoor, this does not occur except after nouns of indication, as in jaMCa niI hecaA AlrRajulu [This man (lit. this, the man,) came to me]; or after OaIR in calling, as in yaA OayRuhaA AlrRajulu [O man]; or after UicaA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly, as in xarajotu faUicaA AlOasadu [I went forth, and lo, there was the lion]; or after the noun denoting the present time, as AaloMna [Now]: but this requires consideration; for you say to the reviler of a man in you presence, laA taXotimi AlrRajula [Revile not thou the man]; and because that which is after UicaA does not render determinate anything present at the time of speaking; and because that in AlMn is really redundant, being inseparable, which the determinative is never known to be: the good example in this case is the saying in the Kur [v. 5], Aaloyawoma Oakomalotu lakumo diyonakumo [This day I have completed for you your religion]. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to denote the species: first, to denote the totality of the individuals of the species; and this may have its place supplied by kulR used in its proper sense; (Mughnee, I 'Ak * ubi suprà;) as in [the Kur iv. 32,] waxuliqa AlUinosaAnu DaEiyfFA [For man was created weak]: secondly, to denote the totality of the properties of the individuals, or the combination of all those properties in one thing; and this may have its place supplied by kulR used in a tropical sense; as in zayodN AlrRajulu EilomFA [Zeyd is the man in respect of knowledge; as though he combined in himself the knowledge of all the individuals of his species]; i. e., he is the complete, or perfect, [or we would rather say, preeminent,] in knowledge; and hence, [in the Kur ii. 1,] celika AlkitaAbu [That is the book, or scripture; as though combining in itself the excellences of all other books or scriptures; or meaning that is preeminently the book, or scripture]: and thirdly, to denote the quiddity, or essence; and this may not have its place supplied by kulR used either properly or tropically; as in the saying, [in the Kur xxi. 31,] wajaEalonaA mina AlmaMCi kulRa XaIoCK HaIRK [And we have made of water (meaning, accord. to common opinion, sperma genitale,) everything living]; or, accord. to some, it is used in this case to distinguish a thing as known [in a particular sense] by its being conceived in the mind. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to denote predominance of application; as in Almadiynapu [The city], meaning the city of the Apostle; and AlkitaAbu [The book], meaning the book of Seebaweyh: and in this case, it may not be suppressed, except when the noun is used vocatively, or when it is prefixed to another noun which it governs in the gen. case; and in some anomalous instances, as in hecaA EayRuwqN TaAliEFA [This is the star Capella, rising], originally AlEayRuwqN. (I 'Ak p. 51.) [In a case of this kind, it is said in the Mughnee to be redundant; but I think it is clearly not so in any of the instances here mentioned, except the last; and this I would rather assign to a category yet to be noticed, in which Al is certainly redundant, and, by rule, inseparable.]

It is also prefixed to a noun transferred from its original application to that of a proper name; it being so prefixed to convey an allusion to the original signification; and such noun being generally an epithet, as HaArivN; but sometimes an inf. n., as faDolN; and sometimes a generic noun, as nuEomaAnN; so that in any of these cases you may prefix Al, saying AlHaArivu and AlfaDolu and AlnRuEomaAnu, with a view to the original signification; and you may suppress it, with a view to the actual state [which is that of a proper name]: for when you mean that a name of this kind is given as one ominous of good, you prefix the Al in order to indicate this; as when you say AlHaArivu with a view to a person's being thus named to prognosticate that he will live and be a tiller, or cultivator; but when you only consider it as a proper name, you do not prefix the Al: thus the prefix Al conveys a meaning not obtained without it; and therefore it is not redundant, as some assert it to be. (I 'Ak p. 50.) [The author of the Mughnee is one of those who consider Al redundant in this case.]

It is in some cases redundant: and in some of these, it is inseparable; as in [a proper name which cannot be used with a view to an original application from which it has been transferred to that of a proper name though it may have been so transferred, such as] AllRaAtu, which is the name of a certain idol that was at Mekkeh [so called because a man used to moisten sawiyq with clarified butter, for the pilgrims, at the place thereof]; and, accord. to some, [as before mentioned,] in AlMni; and in the conjunct nouns AlRaciI and its variations, accord. to those who hold that a noun of this kind is rendered determinate by its complement: in other cases, where it is redundant, it is separable; and this is when it is prefixed to a proper name by poetic licence, as in banaAtu AlOawobari for banaAtu Oawobara, a species of truffle; or, accord. to Mbr, this is not a proper name, and the Al is not redundant; and when it is prefixed to a specificative, as in Tibota AlnRafosa for Tibota nafosFA, accord. to the Basrees, who hold, in opposition to the Koofees, that the specificative may only be indeterminate; (I 'Ak p. 49;) [and, in like manner, as redundant and separable,] it is irregularly prefixed [by poetic licence] in AlOamosi [q. v.], when it is left in its original form with kesr. (T.)

Accord. to the Koofees, and some of the Basrees, and many of the later authors, it may also supply the place of the affixed pronoun; and such they hold to be the case in the saying in the Kur [lxxix. 41], faUinRa QlojanRapa hiIa QlomaOwiI [Verily Paradise, it shall be his place of abode]; and in mararotu birajulK HasanK Alwajohu [I passed by a man beautiful in his face]; and Duriba zayodN AlZRahoru waAlbaTonu [Zeyd was beaten, his back and his belly]; when Alwjh and AlZhr and AlbTn are thus in the nom. case: but those who deny its being used in this manner hold that lahu is to be understood in the verse of the Kur, and minohu in the other examples: and Ibn-Málik restricts the licence to cases not including the Silap [or complement of Al used in the manner which is here next to be explained]. (Mughnee.)

It is also a conjunct noun in the sense of AlRaciI and its variations; and as such is prefixed to an act. part. n., and to a pass. part. n., and, as some say, to a simple epithet; (Mughnee, and I' Ak p. 43;) as AlDRaAribu [which is equivalent to AlRaciI yaDoribu], and AlmaDoruwbu [which is equivalent to AlRaciI Duriba], and AlHasanu Alwajohi: (I 'Ak:) but this last not to be regarded, as it cannot be rendered by means of a verb. (Mughnee.) As such, also, it is sometimes prefixed to an adverbial noun, (Mughnee and I 'Ak,) extraordinarily; (I 'Ak;) as in the saying,

L.foreign: mano laA yazaAlu XaAkirFA EalaI ylomaEaho
