flagged, or was remiss; syn. qaSRara: (S, M, K; and Fr, IAar, T, Mgh, in explanation of the first of these verbs:) and he was slow, or tardy: (M, K; and AA, T, S, in explanation of the second verb:) or he flagged, or was remiss, or languid, and weak. (A Heyth and T in explanation of all of the above-mentioned verbs except the last.) You say, OalaA fiI AlOamori, (Mgh,) and AYtlI↓ fiyhi, (S,) He fell short, &c., (qaSRara,) in the affair. (S, Mgh.) In the saying, lam yaOolu Oano yaEodila fiI clika, i. e. He did not fall short, &c., (lamo yuqaSRaro,) in acting equitably and equally in that, fiI is suppressed before An: but in the phrase, lamo yaOoluw mina AlEadoli, as some relate it, [the meaning intended seems to be, They did not hold back, or the like, from acting equitably; for here] the verb is made to imply the meaning of another verb: and such is the case in the saying, laA Mluwka nuSoHFA, meaning I will not refuse to thee, nor partially or wholly deprive thee of, sincere, honest, or faithful, advice: (Mgh:) or this last signifies I will not flag, or be remiss, nor fall short, to thee in giving sincere, honest, or faithful, advice. (T, S. *) It is said in the Kur [iii. 114], laA yaUoluwnakumo xabaAlFA, meaning They will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in corrupting you. (IAar, T.) And the same meaning is assigned to the verb in the saying Ouwluw AlofaDoli minokumo walaA yaOotali↓, in the Kur [xxiv. 22], by A'Obeyd: but the preferable rendering in this case is that of A Heyth, which will be found below: see 4. (T.) Ks mentions the phrase, Oaqobala biDarobapK laA yaOolu [He came with a blow, not falling short, &c.], for lA yaOoluw; like laA Oadori [for lA OadoriI]. (S, M: [but in the copies of the former in my hands, for biDarobapK, I find yaDoribuhu.]) OalRaI↓ [with teshdeed] is also said of a dog, and of a hawk, meaning He fell short of attaining the game that he pursued. (TA.) And of a cake of bread, meaning It was slow in becoming thoroughly baked. (IAar, IB.) [See also the phrase laA daryota walaA AYotalyota in a later part of this paragraph.]

You say also, maA Oalawotu AlXRayoCa, (K,) or maA Oalawotu Oano OafoEalahu, (M,) inf. n OalwN (M, K) and OuluwRN, (K, TA, [in a copy of the M OulowN,]) meaning I did not leave, quit, cease from, omit, or neglect, (M, K,) the thing, (K,) or doing it. (M.) And fulaAnN laA yaOoluw xayorFA Such a one does not leave, quit, or cease from, doing good. (M.) And maA Oalawotu jahodFA I did not leave, omit, or neglect, labour, exertion, effort, or endeavour: and the vulgar say, maA Mluwka jahodFA; but this is wrong: so says As. (T. [See, however, similar phrases mentioned above.])

OalaA, aor. as above, (TA,) inf. n. OalowN, (IAar, T, TA,) also signifies He strove, or laboured; he exerted himself, or his power or ability; (IAar, T, TA;) as also taOalRaI↓: (T, TA:) the contr. of a signification before mentioned; i. e. “he flagged;,” or “was remiss, or languid, and weak.” (TA.) You say, OataAniI fiI HaAjapK faOalawotu fiyhaA He came to me respecting a want, and I strove, or laboured, &c., to accomplish it. (T.)

And OalaAhu, aor. as above, (T, S,) inf. n. OalowN, (IAar, T, S,) He was, or became, able to do it: (IAar, T, S:) and OlRI↓, inf. n. taOoliyapN, also signifies he was, or became, able; (TA;) and so AYtlI↓. (ISk, S, TA.) You say, huwa yaOoluw hcaA AlOamora He is able to perform, or accomplish, this affair. (T.) And maA Oalawotuhu I was not able to do it. (T, M, K.) And OataAniI fulaAnN fiI HaAjapK famaA Oalawotu radRahu Such a one came to me respecting a want, and I was not able to rebuff him. (T.) It is said in a trad., mano SaAma
AldRahora falaA SaAma walaA OalRaI↓ [He who fasts ever, or always, may he neither fast] nor be able to fast: as though it were an imprecation: or it may be enunciative: another reading is walaA Mla, explained as meaning walaA rajaEa: [See art. Awl:] but El-Khattábee says that it is correctly OalRaI and OalaA. (TA.) And the Arabs used to say, (S, M,) [and] accord. to a trad. it will be said to the hypocrite [in his grave], on his being asked respecting Mohammad and what he brought, and answering “I know not,” (T in art. tlw,) laA darayota walaA AYtalayota↓, (T, S, M, K,) meaning, accord. to As, (T,) or ISk, (S,) Mayest thou not know, nor be able to know: (T, S: *) or, accord. to Fr, nor fall short, or flag, in seeking to know; that the case may be the more miserable to thee: (T:) or walaA Oalayota, as an imitative sequent [for wlA Oalawota, to which the same explanations are applicable]: (MK:) or laA darayota walaA talayota, the latter verb being assimilated to the former, (ISk, T in art. tlw, S,) said to mean walaA talawota, i. e. nor mayest thou read nor study: (T in art. tlw :) or laA darayota walaA Oatolyota, i. e. [mayest thou not know,] nor mayest thou have camels followed by young ones. (Yoo, ISk, T, S, M, K.)

Also, (IAar, T,) inf. n. OalowN, (IAar, T, K,) He gave him a thing: (IAar, T, K: *) [doubly trans.:] the contr. of a signification before mentioned, (also given by IAar, T and TA,) which is that of “refusing” [a person anything: see, above, laA Mluwka nuSoHFA]. (TA.)
2: see 1, in four places.

4. MlI, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor. yuWoliI, inf. n. UiylaMCN, (T, S, Mgh,) [and in poetry UilaMCN, (see a reading of a verse cited voce OaliyRpN,)] He swore; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also tOlRI↓, and AYtlI↓. (T, S, M, K.) You say, Mlayotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi and Mlayotuhu [I swore to do the thing]. (M.) [And Mlayotu laA OafoEalu kacaA I swore that I would not do such a thing; and, emphatically, I swear that I will not do such a thing. And MlaI yamiynFA He swore an oath.] It is said in the Kur [xxiv. 22], Ouwluw walaA yaOotali↓ QlofaDoli minokumo, meaning, accord. to A Heyth and Fr, And let not those of you who possess superabundance swear [that they will not give to relations &c.]; for Aboo-Bekr [is particularly alluded to thereby, because he] had sworn that he would not expend upon Mistah and his relations who had made mention of [the scandal respecting] 'Áïsheh: and some of the people of El-Medeeneh read walaA yataOalRa↓, but this disagrees with the written text: A'Obeyd explains it differently: see 1: but the preferable meaning is that here given. (T.) And it is said in a trad., Mlay mino nisaAYihi XahorFA He swore that he would not go in to his wives for a month: the verb being here made trans. by means of mn because it implies the meaning of AimotinaAE, which is thus trans. (TA.) [See also an ex. of the verb thus used in the Kur ii. 226.] EalaI AllRehi AltRaOalRiI↓ is said to mean One's saying, By God, such a one will assuredly enter the fire [of Hell], and God will assuredly make to have a good issue the work of such a one: but see the act. part. n. below. (TA.)
Mlato, inf. n. as above, She (a woman) took for herself, or made, or prepared, a miYolaAp, q. v. (TA.)
5: see 1, in two places:
and see 4, in three places.
8: see 1, in five places:
and see 4, in two places.
OalowN, or UilowN: see UilFI in art. AlI.

Ouluw, (so in some copies of the S, and so in the K in the last division of that work, and in the CK in art. Al, [and thus it is always pronounced,] but in some copies of the K in art. Al it is written Ouluwna, [as though to show the original form of its termination,]) or Ouwluw, (so in the M, and in some copies of the S, [and thus it is generally written,]) i. q. cawuw [Possessors of; possessed of; possessing; having]; a pl. which has no sing. (S, M, K) of its own proper letters, (S, K,) its sing. being cuw: (S:) or, as some say, a quasi-pl. n., of which the sing. is cuw: (K:) the fem. is OulaAtu, (so in some copies of the S and K, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) or OuwlaAtu, (so in other copies of the S and K, [and thus it is generally written,]) of which the sing. is caAtu: (S, K:) it is as though its sing. were OulN, (M, K, [in the CK AlN,]) the [final] w [in the masc.] being the sign of the pl., (M,) for it has w [for its termination] in the nom. case, and I in the accus. and gen. (M, K.) It is never used but as a prefixed noun. (M, K.) The following are exs. of the nom. case: naHonu Ouwluw quwRapK waOuwluw baOosK XadiydK [We are possessors of strength, and possessors of vehement courage], in the Kur [xxvii. 23]; and Ouwluw AloOaroHaAmi baEoDuhumo OawolaI bibaEoDK [The possessors of relationships, these have the best title to inheritance, one with respect to another], in the same [viii. last verse and xxxiii. 6]; (TA;) and jaMCa niI Ouwluw AlOalobaAbi [The persons of understandings came to me]; and OuwlaAtu AlOaHomaAli [Those who are with child; occurring in the Kur lxv. 4]: (S:) and the following are exs. of the accus. and gen. cases: wacaroniI waAlomukacRabiyna OuwliI AlnRaEomapi [And leave thou me, or let me alone, with the beliers, or discrediters, (i. e., commit their case to me,) the possessors of ease and plenty], in the Kur [lxxiii. 11]; and latanuwCu biAloEuSobapi OuwliI AlquwRapi [Would weigh down the company of men possessing strength], in the same [xxviii. 76]. (TA.) waOuwliI AloOamori minokumo, in the Kur [iv. 62], [And those, of you, who are possessors of command], (M, K, *) accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, (M,)
means the companions of the Prophet, and the men of knowledge their followers, (M, K,) and the possessors of command, who are their followers, when also possessors of knowledge and religion: (K:) or, as some say, [simply] the possessors of command; for when these are possessors of knowledge and religion, and take, or adopt and maintain, and follow, what the men of knowledge say, to obey them is of divine obligation: and in general those who are termed Ouwluw AlOamori, of the Muslims, are those who superintend the affairs of such with respect to religion, and everything conducing to the right disposal of their affairs. (M.)

UilaI, accord. to Sb, is originally with w in the place of the [I, i. e. the final] alif; and so is EalaI; for the alifs [in these two particles] are not susceptible of imáleh; [i. e., they may not be pronounced ilè and 'alè;] and if either be used as the proper name of a man, the dual [of the former] is UilawaAni and [that of the latter] EalawaAni; but when a pronoun is affixed to it, the alif is changed into yé, so that you say Uilayoka and Ealayoka; though some of the Arabs leave it as it was, saying UilaAka and EalaAka. (S.) It is a prep., or particle governing a noun in the gen. case, (S, Mughnee, K,) and denotes the end, as opposed to [mino, which denotes] the beginning, of an extent, or of the space between two points or limits; (S, M;) or the end of an extent (T, Mughnee, K) of place; [signifying To, or as far as;] as in the phrase [in the Kur xvii. 1], mina Almasojidi AlHaraAmi UilaI Almasojidi AlOaqoSaI [From the Sacred Mosque to, or as far as, the Furthest Mosque; meaning from the mosque of Mekkeh to that of Jerusalem]; (Mughnee, K;) or in the saying, xarajotu mina Alkuwfapi UilaI makRapa [I went forth from El-Koofeh to Mekkeh], which may mean that you entered it, [namely, the latter place,] or that you reached it without entering it, for the end includes the beginning of the limit and the furthest part thereof, but does not extend beyond it. (S.) [In some respects it agrees with HatRaI, q. v. And sometimes it signifies Towards; as in naZara UilaIRa He looked towards me; and maAla Uilayohi He, or it, inclined towards him, or it.

It also denotes the end of a space of time; [signifying To, till, or until;] as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 183], vumRa OatimRuwA AlSRiyaAma UilaI AllRayoli [Then complets ye the fasting to, or till, or until, the night]. (Mughnee, K.) [Hence, UilaI Oano (followed by a mansoob aor.) Till, or until: and UilaI mataI Till, or until, what time, or when? i. e. how long? and also to, till, or until, the time when. See also the last sentence in this paragraph.]
[In like manner it is used in the phrases UilaI gayori clika, and UilaI Mxirihi, meaning, (And so on,) to other things, and to the end thereof; equivalent to et cœtera.]

Sometimes, (S,) it occurs in the sense of maEa, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) when a thing is joined to another thing; (Mughnee, K;) as in the phrase [in the Kur iii. 45 and lxi. 14], mano OanoSaAriI UilaI AllRehi [Who will be my aiders with, or in addition to, God?], (S, Mughnee, K,) accord. to the Koofees and some of the Basrees; (Mughnee;) i. e. who will be joined to God in aiding me? (M, TA;) and as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 2], walaA taOokuluwA OamowaAlahumo UilaI OamowaAlikumo [And devour not ye their possessions with, or in addition to, your possessions]; (T, S;) and [in the same, ii. 13,] waUicaA xalawoA UilaI XayaA Tiynihimo [And when they are alone with their devils]; (S;) and in the saying, AlcRawodu UilaI AlcRawodi UibilN [A few she-camels with, or added to, a few she-camels are a herd of camels], (S, Mughnee, K,) a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) a little with a little makes much; (S and A in art. cwd, q. v.;) though one may not say, UilaI zayodK maAlN meaning maEa zayodK maAlN: (Mughnee:) so too in the saying, fulaAnN HaliymN UilaI OadabK wafiqohK [Such a one is clement, or forbearing, with good education, or polite accomplishments, and intelligence, or knowledge of the law]; (M, TA;) and so, accord. to Kh, in the phrase, OaHomadu AllReha Uilayoka [I praise God with thee: but see another rendering of this phrase below]. (ISh.) In the saying in the Kur [v. 8], faAgosiluwA wujuwhakumo waOayodiyakumo UilaI AlmaraAfiqi, it is disputed whether [the meaning be Then wash ye your faces, and your arms with the elbows, or, and your arms as far as the elbows; i. e., whether] the elbows be meant to be included among the parts to be washed, or excluded therefrom. (T.) A context sometimes shows that what follows it is included in what precedes it; as in qaraOotu AlquroMna mino OawRalihi UilaI Mxirihi [I read, or recited, the Kurán, from the beginning thereof to the end thereof]: or that it is excluded; as in vumRa OatimRuwA AlSRiyaAma UilaI AllRayoli [explained above]: when this is not the case, some say that it is included if it be of the same kind [as that which precedes]; some, that it is included absolutely; and some, that it is excluded absolutely; and this is the right assertion; for with the context it is in most instances excluded. (Mughnee.)

It is also used to show the grammatical agency of the noun governed by it, after a verb of wonder; or after a noun of excess importing love or hatred; [as in maA OaHabRahu UilaIRa How lovely, or pleasing, is he to me! (TA in art. Hb,) and maA OabogaDahu UilaIRa How hateful, or odious, is he to me! (S in art. bgD;) and] as in the saying [in the Kur xii. 33], rabRi AlsRijonu OaHabRu UilaIRa [O my Lord, the prison is more pleasing to me]. (Mughnee, K.) [This usage is similar to that explained in the next sentence.]

It is syn. with Einoda; (S, M, Mughnee, Msb, K;) as in the phrase, huwa OaXohaI UilaIRa mino kacaA [It is more desirable, or pleasant, in my estimation than such a thing]; (Msb;) and in the saying of the poet,

L.foreign: Oamo laA sabiyla UilaI AlXRabaAbi wacikoruhu

sense.s: [Is there no way of return to youth, seeing that the remembrance thereof is more pleasant to me, or in my estimation, than mellow wine?] (Mughnee, K:) and accord. to this usage of UilaI in the sense of Einoda may be explained the saying, Oanoti TaAliqN UilaI sanapK, meaning Thou art divorced at the commencement of a year. (Msb.)

It is also syn. with li; as in the phrase, waAlOamoru Uilayoka [And command, or to command, belongeth unto Thee, meaning God, as in the Kur xiii. 30, and xxx. 3], (Mughnee, K,) in a trad. respecting supplication: (TA:) or, as some say, it is here used in the manner first explained above, meaning, is ultimately referrible to Thee: and they say, OaHomadu AllReha Uilayoka, meaning, I tell the praise of God unto thee: (Mughnee:) [but see another rendering of this last phrase above:] you say also, caAka Uilayoka That is committed to thee, or to thy arbitration. (Har p. 329.)

It also occurs as syn. with EalaI; as in the saying in the Kur [xvii. 4], waqaDayonaA UilaI baniI UisoraAYiyla [And we decreed against the children of Israel]: (Msb:) or this means and we revealed to the children of Israel (Bd, Jel) decisively. (Bd.)

It is also syn. with fiI; (M, Mughnee, K;) as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 89 and vi.12], layajomaEanRakumo UilaI yawomi AlqiyaAmapi [He will assuredly collect you together on the day of resurrection]: (K:) thus it may be used in this instance accord. to Ibn-Málik: (Mughnee:) and it is said to be so used in the saying [of En-Nábighah, (M, TA,)]

L.foreign: Uilay AlnRaAsi maToliIRN bihi AlqaAru Oajorabu

sense.s: [Then do not thou leave me with threatening, as though I were, among men, smeared with tar, being like a mangy camel]; (M, Mughnee;) or, accord. to some, there is an ellipsis and inversion in this verse; AlI being here in dependence upon a word suppressed, and the meaning being, smeared with pitch, [like a camel,] yet being united to men: or, accord. to Ibn-'Osfoor, mTlIR is here considered as made to import the meaning of rendered hateful, or odious; for he says that if AlI were correctly used in the sense of fI, it it would be allowable to say, zayodNUilaI Alkuwfapi: (Mughnee:) [or the meaning may be, as though I were, compared to men, a mangy camel, smeared with pitch: for] I'Ab said, after mentioning 'Alee, EilomiI UilaI Eilomihi kaAlqaraArapi fiI AlmuvuEanojari, meaning My knowledge compared to his knowledge is like the qrArp [or small pool of water left by a torrent] placed by the side of the middle of the sea [or the main deep]. (K in art. vEjr.) It is also [said to be] used in the sense of fI in the saying in the Kur [1xxix. 18], halo laka UilaI Oano tazakRaI [Wilt thou purify thyself from infidelity?] because it imports the meaning of invitation. (TA.)
It is also used [in a manner contr. to its primitive application, i. e.,] to denote beginning, [or origination,] being syn. with mino; as in the saying [of a poet],

L.foreign: Oayusoqay falaA yarowaI UilaIRa Abonu OaHomaraA

sense.s: [She says, (namely my camel,) when I have raised the saddle upon her, Will Ibn-Ahmar be supplied with drink and not satisfy his thirst from me? i. e., will he never be satisfied with drawing forth my sweat?]. (Mughnee, K.)

It is also used as a corroborative, and is thus [syntactically] redundant; as in the saying in the Kur [xiv. 40], faAjoEalo OafoYidapF mina AlnRaAsi tahowaI Uilayohimo, with fet-h to the w [in thwI], (Mughnee, K,) accord.
to one reading, (Mughnee,) meaning tahowaAhumo [i. e. And make Thou hearts of men to love them]: (K:) so says Fr: but some explain it by saying that thwI imports the meaning of tamiylu; or that it is originally tahowiI, with kesr, the kesreh being changed to a fet-hah, and the yé to an alif, as when one says raDaA for raDiIa, and naASaApN for naASiyapN: so says Ibn-Málik; but this requires consideration; for it is a condition in such cases that the I in the original form must be movent. (Mughnee.) [See art. hwI.]
AallRehumRa Uilayoka, occurring in a trad., [is elliptical, and] means O God, I complain unto Thee: or take Thou me unto Thee. (TA.)
And OanaA minoka waUilayoka means I am of thee, and related to thee. (TA.)

You say also, Aicohabo Uilayoka, meaning Betake, or apply, thyself to, or occupy thyself with, thine own affairs. (T, K. *) And similar to this is the phrase used by El-Aashà, faAcohabiI maA Uilayoki. (TA.) And Uilayokumo [alone is used in a similar manner, elliptically, or as an imperative verbal noun, and] means Betake, or apply, yourselves to, or occupy yourselves with, your own affairs, (AicohabuwA Uilayokumo,) and retire ye, or withdraw ye, to a distance, or far away, from us. (ISk.) And Uilayoka EanRiI means Hold, or refrain, thou from me: (T, K:) or remove, withdraw, or retire, thou to a distance from me: Alyk used in this sense is an imperative verbal noun. (Har p. 508.) Sb says, (M,) or Akh, (Har ubi suprà,) I heard an Arab of the desert, on its being said to him Uilayoka, reply, UilaIRa; as though it were said to him Remove, withdraw, or retire, thou to a distance, and he replied, I will remove, &c. (M.) Aboo-Fir' own says, satirizing a Nabathæan woman of whom he asked for water to drink,

[When thou shalt demand water, she will say, Retire thou to a distance]; meaning, [by lykA, i. e. layoka with an adjunct alif for the sake of the rhyme,] Uilayoka, in the sense last explained above. (M.)
One also says, Uilayoka kacaA, meaning, Take thou such a thing. (T, K.)

When UilaI is immediately followed by the interrogative maA, both together are written UilaAma [meaning, To what? whither? and till, or until, what time, or when? i. e. how long?]; and in like manner one writes EalaAma for EalaI maA, (S * and K voce mA,) and HatRaAma for HatRaI. (S voce HatRaI.)
OalowapN and OulowapN and UilowapN: see OaliyRapN.
OalIRu One who swears much; who utters many oaths: (IAar, T, K:) mentioned in the K in art. AlI; but the present is its proper art. (TA.)

OaliyRapN [A falling short; or a falling short of what is requisite, or what one ought to do; or a flagging, or remissness; and slowness, or tardiness:] a subst. from OalaA as signifying qaSRara and OaliyRapF. (M.) Hence the prov., (M,) UilRaA HaDiyRapF falaA OaliyRapF, i. e. If I be not in favour, and high estimation, I will not cease seeking, and labouring, and wearying myself, to become so: (M, K: *) or if thou fail of good fortune in that which thou seekest, fall not short, or flag not, or be not remiss, in showing love, or affection, to men; may-be thou wilt attain somewhat of that which thou wishest: originally relating to a woman who becomes displeasing to her husband: (S in art. HZw:) it is one of the proverbs of women: one says, if I be not in favour, and high estimation, with my husband, I will not fall short, or flag, or be remiss, in that which may render me so, by betaking myself to that which he loveth: (T and TA in art. HZw:) Meyd says that the two nouns are in the accus. case because the implied meaning is UilRaA Oakuno HaZiyRapF falaA Oakuno OaliyRapF; the latter noun being [accord. to him] for MliyapN↓, for which it may be put for the sake of conformity [with the former]; and the former having the signification of the pass. part. n. of OaHoZaI, or that of the part. n. of HaZiIa [or HaZiyato]. (Har p. 78.)

An oath; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also OaliyRaA↓ (M, K) and OalowapN↓ (T, S, M, K) and OulowapF↓ and UiliywapN↓: (S, M, K: [in the CK, wAlAuluwRapu muvalRavapF is erroneously put for wAliOalowapu mvlRvpF:]) it is [originally OaliywapN,] of the measure faEiylapN: (S:) pl. OalaAyaA. (S, Mgh.) A poet says, (namely, Kutheiyir, TA,)

[A person of few oaths, who keeps his oath from being uttered on ordinary or mean occasions; but if the oath has proceeded from him at any former time, or hastily, it proves true]: (S, TA:) or, as IKh relates it, qaliylu AlUilaMCi; meaning, he says, qaliylu AlUylaMCi; the I being suppressed: see 4. (TA.)
OaliyRaA: see the latter part of the paragraph next preceding.

MlK Falling short; or falling short of what is requisite, or what one ought to do; or flagging, or remiss: [and slow, or tardy: &c.: see 1:] fem. with p: and pl. of this latter OawaAlK. (S, TA.) See OaliyRapN, used, accord. to Meyd, for Mliyap.
Niggardly, penurious, or avaricious; impotent to fulfil duties or obligations, or to pay debts. (Har p. 78.)

miYolaApN The piece of rag which a woman holds in wailing, (S, TA,) and with which she makes signs: (TA:) [it is generally dyed blue, the colour of mourning; and the woman sometimes holds it over her shoulders, and sometimes twirls it with both hands over her head, or before her face:] pl. maMlK: (S, TA:) which also signifies rags used for the menses. (TA in art. gbr.)

mutaOalR [part. n. of 5]. It is said in a trad., wayolN lilomutaOalRiyna mino OumRatiI, explained as meaning Woe to those of my people who pronounce sentence against God, saying, Such a one is in Paradise, and such a one is in the fire [of Hell]: but see the verb. (TA.)
1. OaliIa, (S, K,) aor. yaOolaI, inf. n. OalFI, (S,) He (a man, S) was, or became, large in the Ouloyap, q. v. (S, K. *)
Oalayota: see 1 in art. Alw.
OaloIN: see UilFI:
and see also OalayaAnN.
OalFI: see UilFI:
and see also OalayaAnN.
OuloIRN: see UilFI.

OulaI, (so in some copies of the S and in the M,) accord. to Sb, or OulaA, (so likewise in the M, in which it is mentioned in art. AlI, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) or OuwlaI; (so in several copies of the S and in the K, in the last division of each of those works, [and thus it is generally written;]) and with the lengthened A, [and this is the more common form of the word, i. e. OulaMCi↓, as it is always pronounced, or OuwlaMCi, as it is generally written, both of which modes of writing it I find in the M.,] (S, M, K,) of the same measure as guraAb, (M,) indecl., with a kesreh for its termination; (S;) [These and those,] a pl. having no proper sing., (S, K,) or a noun denoting a pl., (M,) or its sing. is caA for the masc. and ciho for the fem., (S, K,) for it is both masc. and fem., (S,) and is applied to rational beings and to irrational things. (M.) [Thus,] humo OuwlaMCi EalaI OavariI, in the Kur xx. 86, means [They are these, following near after me; or] they are near me, coming near after me. (Jel, and Bd says the like.) And in the same, iii. 115, haAOanotumo OuwlaMCi tuHibRuwnahumo walaA yuHibRuwnakumo Now ye, O ye these believers, love them, and they love not you. (Jel.)

The particle (M) haA (S, K) used as an inceptive to give notice of what is about to be said is prefixed to it, [i. e., to the form with the lengthened A,] (S, M, K,) so that you say, hWulaMCi↓ [meaning These, like as hcaA means “this”]. (S, K.) And AZ says that some of the Arabs say, hWalaMCi qawomuka [These are thy people], (S, M, *) and raOayotu hWulaMCK↓ [I saw these], (M,) with tenween and kesr (S, M) to the hemzeh; (S;) and this, says IJ, is of the dial. of Benoo-'Okeyl. (M.)

And the k of allocution is added to it, so that you say, OuwlYika, [or MuwlaMYika, which is the same, and OuwlYikumo, or OuwlaMYikumo, &c.,] and OuwlaAka, (S, K,) and OuwlaAlika, (so in some copies of the S and in the K,) or OulaAlika, (so in some copies of the S and in the M,) in which the [second] l is augmentative, (M,) and OulRaAka↓, with teshdeed, (K,) [all meaning Those, like as caAka and clika mean “that” and hence] Ks says that when one says OuwlaMYka, the sing. is clika; and when one says OuwlaAka, the sing. is caAka; (S;) or OulaAlika [or OuwlaAlika, each with an augmentative l, like clika, (and this, I doubt not, is the correct statement,)] is as though it were pl. of clika: (M:) but one does not say haAWulaAlika, or hOuwlaAlika, (M,) [nor haWulaAYika, or the like.] [Thus it is said in the Kur ii. 4, OuwlaMYika Eala hudFI mino rabRihimo waOuwlaMYika humu AlmufoliHuwna Those follow a right direction from their Lord, and those are they who shall prosper.] And sometimes OuwlaMYika is applied to irrational
things, as in the phrase baEod OuwlaMYika AlOayRaAmi [After those days]; and in the Kur [xvii. 38], where it is said, UinRa AlsRamoEa waAlobaSara waAlofuWaAda kulRu OuwlaMYika kaAna Eanohu masoWuwlFA [Verily the ears and the eyes and the heart, all of those shall be inquired of]. (S.)

The dims. are UulayRaA↓ and OulayRaMCi↓ (S, M) and hWulayRaMCi↓: (M:) for the formation of the dim. of a noun of vague application does not alter its commencement, but leaves it in its original state, with fet-h or damm, [as the case may be,] and the I which is the characteristic of the dim. is inserted in the second place if the word is one of two letters, [as in the instance of cayRaA, dim. of caA,] and in the third place if it is a word of three letters. (S.)

AlOulaI, (as in some copies of the S and T,) of the same measure as AlEulaI; (S; [wherefore the author of the TA prefers this mode of writing it, which expresses the manner in which it is always pronounced;]) or AlOulaA; (ISd, TA;) or AlOuwlaI; (so in some copies of the S and T;) is likewise a pl. having no proper sing., [meaning They who, those which, and simply who, and which,] its sing. being AlRaciI; (S;) or is changed from being a noun of indication so as to have the meaning of AlRaciyna; as also AlOulaMCi↓; wherefore they have the lengthened as well as the shortened alif, and that with the lengthened alif is made indecl. by terminating with a kesreh. (ISd.) A poet says,

L.foreign: waUinRa AlUuwlaI biAlTRafRi mino Mli haAXimK

sense.s: [And they who are in Et-Taff, of the family of Háshim, shared their property, one with another, and so set the example, to the generous, of the sharing of property]. (T, and S in art.
Asw, where, in one copy, I find AlOulaI in the place of AlOuwlaI.) And another poet says,
[And verily they who know thee, of them]: which shows what has been said above, respecting the change of meaning. (ISd.) Ziyád El-Aajam uses the former of the two words without Al, saying,

L.foreign: faOanotumo OuwlaI jiYotumo maEa Albaqoli waAldRabaI

sense.s: [For ye are they who came with the herbs, or leguminous plants, and the young locusts, and they have gone away, while these, yourselves, are not going away]: (T:) he means that their nobility is recent. (Ham p. 678; where, instead of fOntm and AwlI, we find waOanotumu and OulaA.)

In the phrase AlEarabu AlOuwlaI, (as in the L, and in some copies of the S and K,) or AlOulaI, (as also in the L, and in other copies of the S and K, [and thus it is always pronounced,]) AlAwlI or AlAlI may also signify AlRaciyna, the verb salafuwA being suppressed after it, because understood; [so that the meaning is, The Arabs who have preceded, or passed away;] so says Ibn-EshShejeree: (L:) or it is formed by transposition from AlOuwalu, being pl. of OuwlaI [fem. of OawRalu], like as Ouxaru is pl. of Mxa: and it is thus in the phrase, cahabati AlEarabu AlOuwlaI or AlOulaI [The first Arabs have passed away]. (S, K.) 'Obeyd Ibn-ElAbras uses the phrase, naHonu AlOulaI [as meaning We are the first]. (TA.)
UiloIN: see UilFI.
UilaI: see UilFI:
and see also art. Alw.

UilaI (T, S, M, K) and OalFI↓, (S, M, K,) the latter said by Zekereeyà to be the most common, and the same is implied in the S, but MF says that this is not known, (TA,) and UilowN↓, (T,) or OalowN↓, (Es-Semeen, K,) like dalowN, (Es-Semeen, TA,) [belonging to art. Alw,] and UiloIN↓ (T, M, K) and OaloIN↓ (M, K) and OuloyN↓ (Es-Sakháwee, Zekereeyà, TA) and UilaI↓, (the same,) or UilaA, occurring at the end of a verse, but it may be a contraction of UilRaA, meaning EahodFA, (M,) A benefit, benefaction, favour, boon, or blessing: pl. MlaMCN. (T, S, M, K, &c.) IAmb says that UilFI and OalFI are originally wilFA and walFA. (TA.)

OaloyapN The buttock, or buttocks, rump, or posteriors, syn. EajiyzapN, (K,) or [more properly] EajuzN, (M,) of a man &c., (M,) or of a sheep or goat, (Lth, T, S,) and of a man, (Lth, T,) or of a ewe: (ISk, T:) or the flesh and fat thereon: (M, K:) you should not say UiloyapN↓, (T, S, K,) a form mentioned by the expositors of the Fs, but said to be vulgar and low; (TA;) nor liyRapN, (T, S, K,) with kesr to the l, and with teshdeed to the I, as in the S, [but in a copy of the S, and in one of the T, written without teshdeed,] a form asserted to be correct by some, but it is rarer and lower than UiloyapN, though it is the form commonly obtaining with the vulgar: (TA:) the dual. is OaloyaAni↓, (AZ, T, S,) without t; (S;) but OaloyataAni sometimes occurs: (IB:) OalaSRu AlOaloyatayoni is an epithet applied to the Zenjee, (K in art. lS,) meaning having the buttocks cleaving together: (TA in that art.:) the pl. is OaloyaAtN (T, M, K) and OalaAyaA; (M, K;) the latter anomalous. (M.) Lh mentions the phrase, UinRahu lacuw OaloyaAtK [Verily he has large buttocks]; as though the term UaloyapN applied to every part of what is thus called. (M.)
Fat, as a subst.: (M:) and a piece of fat. (M, K.)

The tail, or fat of the tail, (Pers. dunobahN,) of a sheep. (KL.) [Both of these significations (the “tail,” and “fat of the tail,” of a sheep) are now commonly given to liyRap, a corruption of OaloyapN mentioned above: and in the K, voce TunobuwrN, it is said that the Pers. dunobaho barRaho signifies Oaloyapu AlHamali.]
Oaloyapu AlsRaAqi The muscle of the shank; syn. HamaApu AlsRaAqi [which see, in art. Hmw]. (AAF, M, K.)

Oaloyapu AlUibohaAmi The portion of flesh that is at the root of the thumb; (S, M;) and which is also called its DarRap; (M;) or the part to which corresponds the DarRap; (S;) and which is also called Oaloyapu AlkafRi; the DarRap being the portion of flesh in fiI, [app. a mistranscription for mino from]) the little finger to the prominent extremity of the ulna next that finger, at the wrist: (TA:) or the portion of flesh in the DarRap of the thumb. (K.)

Oaloyapu AlxanoSiri The portion of flesh that is beneath the little finger; [app. what is described above, as called the DarRap, extending from that finger to the prominent extremity of the ulna, at the wrist;] also called Oaloyapu Alyadi. (Lth, T.)

OaloyataA AlkafRi The Oaloyap of the thumb [described above as also called by itself Oaloyapu AlkafRi] and the DarRap of the little finger [respecting which see the next preceding sentence]. (TA, from a trad.)
Alqadami Oaloyapu The part of the human foot upon which one treads, which is the portion of flesh beneath [or next to] the little toe. (M.)
Oaloyapu AlHaAfiri The hinder part of the solid hoof. (S, M.)
UiloyapN: see OaloyapN.
OaloyaAnu: see OalayaAnN.
OaloyaAni an irreg. dual of OalayaAnN, q. v.

OalayaAnN (T, S, M, K) and OaloyaAnu↓ (M, K) and MlaI↓, (T, S, K,) of the measure OafoEalu, (S,) and MlN↓, (M,) or OalFI↓, (so in some copies of the K, and so accord. to the TA,) or OaloIN↓, (so in a copy of the K,) or OaliIN↓, (accord. to the CK,) and MlK↓, (M, K,) applied to a ram, Large in the Oaloyap, q. v.: (T, * S, M, * K, * TA:) and so, applied to a ewe, OalayaAnapN, (T, M, K, [in the CK AaloyaAnapN,]) fem. of OalayaAnN; (T;) and OaloyaMCN↓, (T, S, M, K,) fem. of MlaI: (T, S:) and in like manner these epithets [masc. and fem. respectively, MlaI, however, being omitted in the M,] are applied to a man and to a woman; (M, K;) or, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák, (M,) MlaI is applied to a man, and EajozaMCu to a woman, but not OaloyaMCu, (S, M,) though [it is asserted that] some say this, (S,) Yz saying so, accord. to A 'Obeyd, (IB,) but A 'Obeyd has erred in this matter: (M:) the pl. is OuloIN, (T, S, M, K, [in the CK erroneously written with fet-h to the A,]) pl. of MlaI, (T, S, M,) or of MlK; of the former because an epithet of this kind is generally of the measure OafoEalu, or of the latter after the manner of buzolN as pl. of baAzilN, and EuwdN as pl. of EaAYidN; (M;) applied to rams (T, S M) and to ewes, (T, S,) and to men and to women; (M, K) and OalayaAnaAtN, (S, M, K, [in the CK AaloyAnAt,]) pl. of OalayaAnapN, (TA,) [but] applied to rams (S) [as well as ewes], or to women, (M, K,) and, also applied to women, UilaMCN, (M, and so in a copy of the K, [in the CK AalMC,]) or MlaMCN, (so in some copies of the K, and in the TA,) with medd, pl. of OalFI, (TA,) and OalaAyaA, (K,) pl. of OaloyaAnu. (TA.)
OulaMCi and hWulaMCi and hWulaMCK and AlOulaMuCi: see OulaI.
OaliIu, mentioned in this art. in the K: see art.
Alw:
and see also OalayaAnN.
OulayRaA and OulayRaMCi and hWulayRaMCi: see OulaI.
OalRaMCK A man who sells fat, which is termed AlOaloyapu. (M.)
OulRaAka: see OulaI.
MlN: see OalayaAnN.
MlK: see OalayaAnN.
MlaI, and its fem. OaloyaMCu: see OalayaAnN, in two places.

1. OamRahu, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor
Aamuma
, (T, M, Msb,) inf. n. OamRN, (T, S, M, Msb,) He tended, repaired, betook himself, or directed his course, to, or towards, him, or it; aimed at, sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain or obtain, him, or it; intended it, or purposed it; syn. qaSadahu, (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and tawaxRaAhu, (T,) and taEamRadahu, (Mgh,) and tawajRaha Uilayohi; (TA;) as also OamRamahu↓, and tOmRmhu↓, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and AYtmRhu↓, (M, K,) and yamRamRhu↓, (T, M, K,) and tayamRamahu↓; (T, M, Mgh, K;) the last two being formed by substitution [of I for O]. (M.) Hence, yaAAallRehu OumRanaA bixayorK [O God, bring us good]. (JK in art. Alh, and Bd in iii. 25.) And laOamRa maA huwa, occurring in a trad., meaning He has indeed betaken himself to, or pursued, the right way: or it is used in a pass. sense, as meaning he is in the way which ought to be pursued. (TA.) And rasuwla AllRehi AnoTalaqotu OataOamRamu↓, in another trad., I went away, betaking myself to the Apostle of God. (TA.) Hence, also, AlSRaEiyda lilSRalaAhi tayamRama↓ [He betook himself to dust, or pure dust, to wipe his face and his hands and arms therewith, for prayer]: (T, * M, * Mgh, TA:) as in the Kur iv. 46 and v. 9: (ISk, M, TA:) whence AlRatRayamRumu as meaning the wiping the face and the hands and arms with dust; (ISk, T, * M, * Mgh, TA;) i. e. the performing the act termed tawaDRuWN with dust: formed by substitution [of I for M]: (M, K:) originally AltRaOamRumu. (K.)
See also 8.

OamRahu, (S, M, Mgh, &c.,) aor.
Aamuma
, (M, Mgh,) inf. n. OamRN, (M, Mgh, K,) He broke his head, so as to cleave the skin, (S, Msb,) inflicting a wound such as is termed MmRap [q. v.]; (S;) [i. e.] he struck, (M, Mgh, K,) or wounded, (M, K,) the OumR [q. v.] of his head, (M, Mgh, K,) with a staff, or stick. (Mgh.)

OamRahumo (S, M, K) and OamRa bihimo, (M, K,) [aor.
Aamuma
,] inf. n. UimaAmapN, (S, [but in the M and K it seems to be indicated that this is a simple subst.,]) He preceded them; went before them; took precedence of them; or led them, so as to serve as an example, or object of imitation; syn.

taqadRamahumo; (M, K;) [and particularly] fiI AlSRalaApi [in prayer]. (S.) And OamRahu and bihi OamRa He prayed as UimaAm [q. v.] with him. (Msb.) And OamRa AlSRufuwfa He became [or acted as] UimaAm to the people composing the ranks [in a mosque &c.]. (Har p. 680.) You say also, laA yaWumRu AlrRajulu AlrRajula fiI suloTaAnihi [A man shall not take precedence of a man in his authority]; meaning, in his house, and where he has predominance, or superior power, or authority; nor shall he sit upon his cushion; for in doing so he would show him contempt. (Mgh in art. slT.)

OamRatN, (S, M, K,) [first pers. Oamumotu,] aor.
Aamuma
, (M,) inf. n. OumuwmapN, (M, K,) She (a woman, S) became a mother; (S, M, K;) [as also OamRatN having for its first pers. Oamimotu, aor.
Aamama
; for] you say, maA kunoti OumRaA walaqado Oamimoti [Thou wast not a mother, and thou hast become a mother], (S, M, K, [in the last faOamimoti,]) with kesr, (K,) inf. n.
OumuwmapN. (S, M, K.)

Oamamotuhu I was to him a mother. (A in art. rbD.) IAar, speaking of a woman, said, kaAnato lahaA EamRapN taWumRuhaA, meaning [She had, lit. there was to her, a paternal aunt] who was to her like the mother. (M.)
2. OamRamahu yamRamahu: see 1, first sentence, in two places.
3. MmRhu It agreed with it, neither exceeding nor falling short. (M.)
[See also the part. n. muWaAmRN, voce OamamN; whence it seems that there are other senses in which MmRa may be used, intransitively.]
5. taOamRama tayamRama: see 1, former part, in four places.
tOmRm bihi: see 8.
tamRamotu I took for myself, or adopted, a mother. (S.) And taOamRamahaA He took her for himself, or adopted her, as a mother; (S, * M, K;) as also AstMmRhA↓, (M, K,) and taOamRahahaA. (M.)
8. AYtmRhu [written with the disjunctive alif AiytamRahu]: see 1, first sentence.

AYtmR bihi He followed his example; he imitated him; he did as he did, following his example; or taking him as an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation; (S, Mgh, Msb;) as also OamRahu↓: (Bd in xvi. 121:) the object of the verb is termed UimaAmN; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a learned man, (Msb,) or a head, chief, or leader, or some other person. (M, K.) He made it an OumRap or UimRap [i. e. a way, course, or rule, of life or conduct; as explained immediately before in the work whence this is taken]; as also bh tOmRm↓. (M.) You say, AYtmR biAlXRayoCi and AYotamaI bh, by substitution [of I for m], (M, K,) disapproving of the doubling [of the m]. (M.)

Oamo is a conjunction, (S, M, K,) connected with what precedes it (Msb, Mughnee) so that neither what precedes it nor what follows it is independent, the one of the other. (Mughnee.) It denotes interrogation; (M, K;) or is used in a case of interrogation, (S, Msb,) corresponding to the interrogative Oa, and meaning OaIR, (S,) or, as Z says, OaIRu AlOamorayoni kaAYinN; [for an explanation of which, see what follows;] (Mughnee;) or, [in other words,] corresponding to the interrogative Oa, whereby, and by Oamo, one seeks, or desires, particularization: (Mughnee:) it is as though it were an interrogative after an interrogative. (Lth, T.) Thus you say, OazayudN fiI AldRaAri Oamo EamorNw [Is Zeyd in the house, or 'Amr?]; (S, Mughnee;) i. e. which of them two (OayRuhumaA) is in the house? (S;) therefore what follows Am and what precedes it compose one sentence; and it is not used in commanding nor in forbidding; and what follows it must correspond to what precedes it in the quality of noun and of verb; so that you say, OazayodN qaAYimN OamE qaAEidN [Is Zeyd standing, or sitting?] and OaqaAma zayodN Oamo qaEada [Did Zeyd stand, or sit?]. (Msb.) It is not to be coupled with Oa after it: you may not say, OaEinodaka zayodN Oamo OaEinodaka EamorNw. (S.)

As connected in like manner with what goes before, it is preceded by Oa denoting equality [by occurring after sawaMCN &c.], and corresponds thereto, as in [the Kur lxiii. 6,] sawaMCu Ealayohimo Oasotagofarota lahumN lamN tasotagufiro lahumN [It will be equal to them whether thou beg forgiveness for them or do not beg forgiveness for them]. (Mughnee.)

It is also unconnected with what precedes it, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) implying always digression, (Mughnee,) preceded by an enunciative, or an interrogative, (S, Msb, Mughnee,) other than Oa, (Mughnee,) or by Oa not meant [really] as an interrogative but to denote disapproval, (Mughnee,) and signifies balo, (Lth, Zj, T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) or balo and Oa together, (Msb,) and this is its meaning always accord. to all the Basrees, but the Koofees deny this. (Mughnee.) Thus, using it after an enunciative, you say, UinRahaA laUibilN Oamo XaMCN [Verily they are camels: nay, or nay but, they are sheep, or goats: or nay, are they sheep, or goats?]: (S Msb, Mughnee:) this being said when one looks at a bodily form, and imagines it to be a number of camels, and says what first occurs to him; then the opinion that it is a number of sheep or goats suggests itself to him, and he turns from the first idea, and says, Oamo XaMCN, meaning balo, because it is a digression from what precedes it; though what follows bl is [properly] a thing known certainly, and what follows Am is opined. (S, TA.) And using it after an interrogative in this case, you say, halo zyodN munoTaliqN Oamo EamorNw [Is Zeyd going away? Nay rather, or, or rather, is 'Amr?]: you digress from the question respecting Zeyd's going away, and make the question to relate to 'Amr; so that Am implies indecisive opinion, and interrogation, and digression. (S.) And thus using it, you say, halo zayodN qaAma Oamo EamorNw [Did Zeyd stand? Nay rather, or or rather, did 'Amr?]. (Msb.) And an ex. of the same is the saying [in the Kur xiii. 17], halo yasotawiI AloOaEomaI waAlobaSiyru Oamo halo tasotawiI AlZRulumaAtu waAlnRuwru [Are the blind and the seeing equal? Or rather are darkness and light equal?]. (Mughnee.) And an ex. of it preceded by Oa used to denote disapproval is the saying [in the Kur vii. 194], Oalahumo OarojulN yamoXuwna bihaA Oamo lahumo OayodK yaboTiXuwna bihaA [Have they feet, to walk therewith? Or have they hands to assault therewith?]: for Oa is here equivalent to a negation. (Mughnee.) [It has been shown above that] Oamo is sometimes introduced immediately before halo: (S, K:) but IB says that this is when hl occurs in a phrase next before it; [as in the ex. from the Kur xiii. 17, cited above;] and in this case, the interrogative meaning of Am is annulled; it being introduced only to denote a digression. (TA.)

It is also used as a simple interrogative; accord. to the assertion of AO; in
the sense of halo; (Mughnee;) or in the sense of the interrogative Oa; (Lth, T, K) as in the saying, Oamo Einodaka gadaMCi HaADirN, meaning Hast thou a morning-meal ready? a good form of speech used by the Arabs; (Lth, T;) and allowable when preceded by another phrase. (T.)
And sometimes it is redundant; (AZ, T, S, Mughnee, K) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen; (T;) as in the saying,

L.foreign: yaA dahona Oamo maA kaAna maXoyiI rqaSaA

sense.s: (T, S, * [in the latter, yA hinodu, and only the former hemistich is given,]) meaning O Dahnà, (the curtailed form dahona being used for dahonaMC,) my walking was not, as now in my age, [a feeble movement like] dancing: but in my youth, my manner of walking used to be a bounding: (T:) this is accord. to the opinion of AZ: but accord. to another opinion, Am is here [virtually] conjoined with a preceding clause which is suppressed; as though the speaker had said, yaA dahona OakaAna maXoyiI raqaSRaA Oamo maA kaAna kaclika. (A 'Hát, TA.)

It is also used (T, Mughnee) in the dial. of the people of El-Yemen, (T,) or of Teiyi and Himyer, (Mughnee,) in the sense of Al, (T,) to render a noun determinate. (Mughnee.) So in the trad., layosa mina AmobirR AmoSiyAmu fiI Amosafari, (T, Mughnee,) i. e. Alayosa mina AlbirRi AlSRiyaAmu fiI AlsRafari [Fasting in journeying is not an act of obedience to God]. (T, and M in art. br.) So too in the trad., AaloMna TaAba AmoDarobu Now fighting has become lawful; as related accord. to the dial. of Himyer, for AlDRarobu. (TA in art. Tyb.) It has been said that this form Am is only used in those cases in which the l of the article does not become incorporated into the first letter of the noun to which it is prefixed; as in the phrase, xuci AlrRumoHa waArokabi Amofarasa [Take thou the spear, and mount the mare, or horse], related as heard in El-Yemen; but this usage may be peculiar to some of the people of that country; not common to all of them; as appears from what we have cited above. (Mughnee.)
Oama for OamaA, before an oath: see art. AmA.
And Oama AllRehi and Oamu AllRehi &c.: see Oayomunu AllRehi, in art. ymn.

OumRN A mother (T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.) [of a human being and] of any animal; (IAar, T;) as also UimRN↓, (Sb, M, Msb, K) and UumRapN↓, (T, M, Msb, K,) and OumRahapN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) which last is the original form (S, Msb) accord. to some, (Msb,) or the h in this is augmentative (M, Msb) accord. to others: (Msb:) the pl. is OumRahaAtN (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K) and OumRaAtN; (S, M, Msb, K;) or the former is applied to human beings, and the latter to beasts; (T, S;) or the former to rational beings, and the latter to irrational; (M, K;) or the former is much applied to human beings, and the latter to others, for the sake of distinction; (Msb;) but the reverse is sometimes the case: (IB:) IDrst and others hold the latter to be of weak authority: (TA:) the dim. of OumRN is OumayomapN↓ (T, S, K) accord. to some of the Arabs; but correctly, [accord. to those who hold the original form of OumRN to be OumRahapN,] it is OumayomihapN↓. (Lth, T, TA. [In a copy of the T, I find this latter form of the dim. written Amyhp.])

OumRa laka denotes dispraise; (S;) being used by the Arabs as meaning Thou hast no free, or ingenuous, mother; because the sons of female slaves are objects of dispraise with the Arabs; and is only said in anger and reviling: (A Heyth, T:) or, as some say, it means thou art one who has been picked up as a foundling, having no Known mother: (TA:) [or] it is also sometimes used in praise; (A 'Obeyd, T, S, K;) and is used as an imprecation without the desire of its being fulfilled upon the person addressed, being said in vehemence of love; [lit. meaning mayest thou have no mother!], like vakilatoka OumRuka, and laA OabaA laka, [and qaAtalaka AllRehu,] &c. (Har p. 165.)
Some elide the A of OumR; as in the saying of 'Adee Ibn—Zeyd.

[O thou who art blaming in my presence the mother of Zeyd]; meaning, EinodiI OumRa zayodK; the I of EndI being also elided on account of the occurrence of two quiescent letters [after the elision of the A of OumR]: (Lth, T, S:) and as in the phrase wayolumRihi, (S,) which means wayolN liOumRihi. (S, and K in art. wyl, q. v.)

humaA OumRaAkR means They two are thy two parents: or thy mother and thy maternal aunt. (K.) [But] fadRaAhu biOumRayohi is said to mean [He expressed a wish that he (another) might be ransomed with] his mother and his grandmother. (TA.)

One says also, laA tafoEaliI yaA OumRati↓ [O my mother, do not thou such a thing], and [in like manner] yaA Oabati AfoEalo; making the sign of the fem. gender a substitute for the [pronominal] affix I; and in a case of pause, you say yaA OumRaho. (S.)

And one says, maA OumRiI waOumRuhu, and maA XakoliI waXakoluhu, meaning [What relationship have I to him, or it? or what concern have I with him, or it? or] what is my case and [what is] his or its, case? because of his, or its, remoteness from me: whence, (T,)

[And what concern have I with the wild animals when hoariness hath spread in the places where my hair parts?]; (T, S;) i. e. maA OanaAwaTalabu AlwaHoXi baEoda maA kabirotu [i. e. maA Omoriy waTalabu AlwaHoXi: in one copy of the S, waTalaba, i. e. with wa as a prep. denoting concomitance, and therefore governing the accus. case: both readings virtually meaning what concern have I with the pursuing of the wild animals after I have grown old?]: he means, the girls: and the mention of OumR in the verse is superfluous. (S.)

OumRN also relates to inanimate things that have growth; as in OumRu AlXRajarapi [The mother of the tree]; and OumRu AlnRaxolapi [the mother of the palm-tree]; and OumRu Almawozipa [the mother of the banana-tree; of which see an ex. in art. mwz]; and the like. (M, TA.)

And it signifies also The source, origin, foundation, or basis, (S, M, Msb, K,) of a thing, (S, Msb, [in the former of which, this is the first of the meanings assigned to the word,]) or of anything; (M, K) its stay, support, or efficient cause of subsistence. (M, K.)

Anything to which other things are collected together, or adjoined: (IDrd, M, K:) anything to which the other things that are next thereto are collected together, or adjoined: (Lth, T:) the main, or chief, part of a thing; the main body thereof: and that which is a compriser, or comprehender, of [other] things: (Ham p. 44:) the place of collection, comprisal, or comprehension, of a thing; the place of combination thereof. (En-Nadr, T.)

And hence, (IDrd, M,) The head, or chief, of a people, or company of men; (IDrd, S, M, K;) because others collect themselves together to him: (IDrd, TA:) so in the phrase OumRu EiyaAlK [lit. the mother of a household], in a poem of Esh-Shenfarà: (IDrd, M:) or in this instance, it has the signification next following, accord. to Esh-Sháfi'ee. (T.)
A man who has the charge of the food and service of a people, or company of men; accord. to EshSháfi'ee: (T:) or their servant. (K.)
A man's aged wife. (IAar, T, K.)

A place of habitation or abode. (K.) So in the Kur [ci. 6], faOumRuhu haAwiyapN His place of habitation or abode [shall be] the fire [of Hell]: (Bd, Jel, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is OumRu raOosihi haAwiyapN fiyhaA [his brain shall fall into it, namely, the fire of Hell]. (TA.)
The ensign, or standard, which an army follows. (S.) [See OumRu AlrRumoHi, below.]

It is said in a trad., respecting the prophets, OumRahaA tuhumo XatRaI, meaning that, though their religion is one, their laws, or ordinances, or statutes, are various, or different: or the meaning is, their times are various, or different. (TA in art. Xt.)
See also OumRapN, in two places.

OumR is also prefixed to nouns significant of many things. (M.) [Most of the compounds thus formed will be found explained in the arts. to which belong the nouns that occupy the second place. The following are among the more common, and are therefore here mentioned, with the meanings assigned to them in lexicons in the present art., and arranged in distinct classes.]

OumRu AlrRajuli The man's wife; and the person who manages the affairs of his house or tent. (TA.) And OumRu mavowaI AlrRajuli The man's wife, to whom he betakes himself for lodging, or abode: (T:) the mistress of the man's place of abode. (S, M.)

OumRu EaAmirK The hyena, or female hyena; as also OumRu EamorKw; (TA;) and OumRu AlTRariyqi. (S, TA. [See also other significations of the first and last below.]) OumRu HilosK [or OumRu AlHilosi (as in the S and K in art. Hlas)] The she-ass. (TA.) OumRu AlbayoDi The female ostrich. (S, K.)

OumRu AlrRaOusi The brain: (T, M, K:) or the thin skin that is upon it: (IDrd, M, K:) or the bag in which is the brain: (T:) or the skin that comprises the brain; [the meninx, or dura mater and pia mater;] (S, Mgh;) which is called
OumRu AldRimaAgi (S, Msb) likewise. (S.)

OumRu AlnRujuwmi The Milky way; (S, M, K) because it is the place where the stars are collected together [in great multitude]: (M:) or, as some say, the sun; which is the greatest of the stars. (Ham pp. 43 and 44.) Because of the multitude of the stars in the Milky way, one says, maA OaXobaha majolisaka biOumRi AlnRujuwmi (assumed tropical:) [How like is thine assembly to the Milky way!]. (TA.)

OumRu AlquraI [The mother of the towns; the metropolis: particularly] Mekkeh; (T, S, M, K) because asserted to be in the middle of the earth; (M, K;) or because it is the Kibleh of all men, and thither they repair; (M, K; *) or because it is the greatest of towns in dignity: (M, K:) and every city is the OumR of the towns around it. (T.) OumRu AltRanaAYifi The most difficult of deserts or of waterless deserts: (T:) or a desert, or waterless desert, (S, K,) far extending. (S.) OumRu AlTRariyqi (T, S, M) and OumRapN↓ AlTRariyqi (M, K) The main part [or track] of the road: (T, S, M, K:) when it is a great road or track, with small roads or tracks around it [or on either side], the greatest is so called. (T. [The former has also another signification, mentioned above.]) OumRu EaAmirK The cemetery, or place of graves. (T. [This, also, has another signification, mentioned before.]) OumRu AlrRumoHi The ensign, or standard; (M, K;) also called OumRu AlHarobi; (TA;) [and simply AlOumRu, as shown above;] and the piece of cloth which is wound upon the spear. (T, M. *) OumRu jaAbirK Bread: and also the ear of corn. (T.) OumRu AlxabaAYivi [The mother of evil qualities or dispositions; i. e.] wine. (T.) OumRu AlkitaAbi [in the Kur iii. 5 and xiii. 39] (S, M, &c.) The original of the book or scripture [i. e. of the Kur-án]: (Zj, M, K:) or the Preserved Tablet, AllRawoHu AlmaHofuwZu: (M, Msb, K:) or it signifies, (M, K,) or signifies also, (Msb,) the opening chapter of the Kur-án; the faAtiHap; (M, Msb, K;) because every prayer begins therewith; (M;) as also OumRu AlquroMni: (Msb, K:) or the former, the whole of the Kur-án, (I'Ab, K,) from its beginning to its end: (TA:) and the latter, every plain, or explicit, verse of the Kur-án, of those which relate to laws and statutes and obligatory ordinances. (T, K.) OumRu AlXRarRi Every evil upon the face of the earth: and OumRu Alxayori every good upon the face of the earth. (T.)
UimRu: see OumRN, first sentence.
OamRapN: see MmRapN.

OumRapN A way, course, mode, or manner, of acting, or conduct, or the like; (AZ, S;) as also UimRapN↓: (AZ, S, K:) Fr assigns this meaning to the latter, and that next following to the former: (T:) a way, course, or rule, of life, or conduct; (Fr, T, M, K;) as also UimRapN↓. (M, K.)

Religion; as also UimRapN↓: (AZ, S, M, K: [one of the words by which this meaning is expressed in the M and K is XiroEap; for which Golius found in the K srEp:]) one course, which people follow, in religion. (T.) You say, fulaAnN laA OumRapa lahu Such a one has no religion; no religious persuasion. (S.) And a poet says,
[And are one who has religion and one who is an infidel equal?]. (S.)
Obedience [app. to God]. (T, M, K.)

The people of a [particular] religion: (Akh, S:) a people to whom an apostle is sent, (M, K,) unbelievers and believers; such being called his OumRap: (M:) any people called after a prophet are said to be his OumRap: (Lth, T:) the followers of the prophet: pl. OumamN. (T, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 209], kaAna AlnRaAsu OumRapK wAHidapF, meaning Mankind was [a people] of one religion. (Zj, T, TA.)

A nation; a people; a race; a tribe, distinct body, or family; (Lth, T, M, K;) of mankind; (Lth, T;) or of any living beings; as also OumRN↓: (M, K:) a collective body [of men or other living beings]; (T, S;) a sing. word with a pl. meaning: (Akh, S:) a kind, genus, or generical class, (T, S, M, K,) by itself, (T,) of any animals, or living beings, (T, S, M, TA,) others than the sons of Adam, (T,) as of dogs, (T, S, M,) and of other beasts, and of birds; (T, M, * TA;) as also OumRN↓; (M, K;) pl. of the former OumamN; (S, M;) which occurs in a trad. as relating to dogs; (S;) and in the Kur vi. 38, as relating to beasts and birds. (T, M, * TA.)
A man's people, community, tribe, kinsfolk, or party; (M, K, TA;) his company. (TA.)
A generation of men; or people of one time: pl. OumamN: as in the saying, qado maDato OumamN Generations of men have passed away. (T.)
The creatures of God. (M, K.) You say, maA raOayotu mino OumRapi AllRehi OaHosana minohu [I have not seen, of the creatures of God, one more beautiful than he]. (M.)
I. q. UimaAmN; (T, M, K;) accord. to A 'Obeyd, applied in this sense to Abraham, in the Kur xvi. 121. (T.)
A righteous man who is an object of imitation. (T.)
One who follows the true religion, holding, or doing, what is different from, or contrary to, all other religions: (M, K:) [said to be] thus applied to Abraham, ubi suprà. (M.)

One who is known for goodness: (Fr, T:) and so explained by Ibn-Mes'ood as applied to Abraham: (TA:) or, so applied, it has the signification next following: (TA:) a man combining all kinds of good qualities: (T, M, K:) or, as some say, repaired to: or imitated. (Bd:)
A learned man: (T, M, K:) one who has no equal: (T:) the learned man of his age, or time, who is singular in his learning: (Msb:) and one who is alone in respect of religion. (T.)
See also UumRN, first sentence. Hence, yaAOumRati which see in the same paragraph.

The stature of a man; tallness, and beauty of stature; or justness of stature; syn. qaAmapN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) and XaTaATF: (M, TA: [in the K, the signification of naXaATN is assigned to it; but this is evidently a mistake for XaTaATK; for the next three significations before the former of these words in the K are the same as the next three before the latter of them in the M; and the next five after the former word in the K are the same as the next five after the latter in the M, with only this difference, that one of these five is the first of them in the M and the third of them in the K:]) pl. OumamN. (T, S, M. *) You say, UinRahu laHasanu AlOumRapi, i. e. AlXRaTaATi [Verily he is beautiful in justness of stature]. (M.) And El-Aashà says,
[Beautiful in respect of the faces,] tall in respect of the statures. (T, S, M. * [In the last, byDu Alwujuwhi.])
The face. (T, M, K.)

OumRapu AlMwajohi The form of the face: (AZ, T:) or the principal part thereof; (M, K;) the part thereof in which beauty is usually known to lie. (M) You say, UinRahu laHasanu OumRapi AlMwajohi Verily he is beautiful in the form of the face: and UinRahu lMaqabiyHu OumRapi AlMwajohi verily he is ugly in the form of the face. (AZ, T.)
OumRapu AlTRariyqi: see OumRN.

A time; a period of time; a while. (T, S, M, K.) So in the Kur [xii. 45], waAdRakara baEoda OumRapK [And he remembered, or became reminded, after a time]: (S, M:) or, after a long period of time: but some read UimRapK↓, i. e., after favour had been shown him, in his escape: and some read OamapK, i. e., forgetting. (Bd.) And so in the same [xi. 11], walaYino OxRaronaA Eanohumu AlEacaAba UilMaI OumRapK maEoduwdap [And verily, if we kept back from them the punishment] until a short period of time. (S * Bd.)
UimRapN: see OumRapN, in three places; first and second sentences.

I. q. UimaAmapN↓ (K) [i. e. The office of UimaAm, q. v.: or] the acting as, or performing the office of, UimaAm: (T in explanation of UimRapN, and M and Msb in explanation of UimaAmapN:) and the mode, or manner, of performing that office. (T.)

I. q. hayoYapN (Lh, M, K) and XaOonN (M, K) and HaAlN (M) and HaAlapN (M, K) [all as meaning State, condition, or case: or by the first may be here meant external state or condition; form, or appearance; or state with respect to apparel and the like].

An easy and ample state of life; (T;) easiness, or pleasantness of life; ampleness of the conveniences of life, or of the means of subsistence; ease and enjoyment; plenty; prosperity; welfare. (IAar, M, K. *) You say of an old man when he has strength remaining, fulaAnN biUimRapK, meaning Such a one is returning to a state of well-being and ease and enjoyment. (TA.)
Dominion; mastership; authority. (Fr, T, IKtt.)

A blessing, or what God bestows upon one; a benefit, benefaction, favour, or boon; a cause of happiness; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) as being that which men aim at, pursue, or endeavour to obtain, (T.) See OumRapN, last sentence but one.
Accord. to IKtt, it signifies also i. q. OamamN [but in what sense is not said]. (TA.)
OamamN Nearness. (S, M, K.)

[Near; nigh.] You say, Oaxacotu clika mino OamamK I took that from near; from nigh. (S, TA.) And daArukumo OamamN Your house is near, or nigh. (M, TA.) And huwa OamamN minoka He, or it, is near to thee: and in like manner you say of two: (M, TA:) and of
a pl. number. (S, M, TA.) And daAriI Oamama daArihi My house is opposite to, facing, or in front of, his house. (S.)
Easy: (S, M, K:) near at hand; near to be reached, or laid hold of. (T, TA.)
Between near and distant. (ISk, T, S.)

Conforming, or conformable, to the just mean: (M, K: *) and muWaAmRN↓, (AA, T, S, M, K,) [in form] like muDaArRN, (S,) originally muWaAmimN, (TA,) the same; (T;) of a middle, or middling, kind or sort; neither exceeding, nor falling short of, what is right; (AA, T, S, M;) applied to an affair, or a case, (T, S,) and a thing [of any kind]; (S;) as also muWamRN↓; (TA;) and convenient, or suitable: (M, K:) and OamamN and muWaAmRN↓ both signify an affair, or a case, that is manifest, clear, or plain, (M, K,) not exceeding the due bounds or limits. (M.)

AlOamaAmu The location that is before; (M, Msb, * K;) contr. of AlwaraMCu. (M, K.) It is used [absolutely] as a noun, and adverbially, (M, Msb, * K,) necessarily prefixed to another noun: (Mgh:) and is fem., (Ks, M,) and sometimes mase.: (M, K:) or it is mase., and sometimes fem. as meaning the jihap: or, as Zj says, they differ as to making it masc. and making it fem. (Msb.) You say, kunotu OamaAmahu I was before him, in respect of place. (S.) In the saying of Mohammad, to Usámeh, AlSlaApu OamaAmaka, the meaning is The time of prayer [is before thee], or the place thereof; and by the prayer is meant the prayer of sunset. (Mgh.) You also say, OamaAmaka [i. c. Look before thee; meaning beware thou; or take thou note;] when you caution another, (M, K,) or notify him, of a thing. (M.)

UimaAmN A person, (S, Mgh,) or learned man, (Msb,) whose example is followed, or who is imitated; (S, Mgh, Msb;) any exemplar, or object of imitation, (T, M, K,) to a people, or company of men, (T,) such as a head, chief, or leader, or some other person, (M, K,) whether they be following the right way or be erring therefrom: (T:) applied alike to a male and to a female: (Mgh, Msb:) applied to a female, it occurs in a phrase in which it is written by some with p: (Mgh:) but this is said to be a mistake: (Msb:) it is correctly without p, because it is a subst., not an epithet: (Mgh, Msb:) or it is allowable with p, because it implies the meaning of an epithet: (Msb:) and OumRapN↓ signifies the same: (T, M, K:) the pl. of the former is OayimRapo, (T, S, M, K, [but omitted in the CK,]) originally OaOomimapN, (T, S,) of the measure OafEilapN, like OamovilapN, pl. of mivaAlN, (T,) but as two meems come together, the former is incorporated into the latter, and its vowel is transferred to the hemzeh before it, which hemzeh, being thus pronounced with kesr, is changed into I; (T, S; *) or it is thus changed because difficult to pronounce; (M;) or, as Akh says, because it is with kesr and is preceded by another hemzeh with fet-h: (S:) but some pronounce it OaYimRapN, (Akh, T, S, M, K,) namely, those who hold that two hemzehs may occur together; (Akh, S;) the Koofees reading it thus in the Kur ix. 12; (M;) but this is anomalous: (M, K:) it is mentioned as on the authority of Aboo-Is-hák, and [Az says,] I do not say that it is not allowable, but the former is the preferable: (T:) or the pl. is OaYimRapN, originally OaOomimapN like OamovilapN: one of the two meems being incorporated into the other after the transfer of its vowel to the hemzeh [next before it]; some of the readers of the Kur pronouncing the [said] hemzeh with its true sound; some softening it, agreeably with analogy, in the manner termed bayona bayona; and some of the grammarians changing it into I; but some of them reckon this incorrect, saying that there is no analogical reason for it: (Msb:) and accord. to some, (M,) its pl. is also UimaAmu, (M, K,) like the sing., (K,) occurring in the Kur xxv. 74; (M;) not of the same category as EadolN (M, K) and riDRaI, (M,) because they sometimes said UimaAmaAni, but a broken pl.: (M, K: *) or, accord. to A 'Obeyd, it is in this instance a sing. denoting a pl.: (M, S: *) or it is pl. of MmRN, [which is originally Mmimo,] like as SiHaAbN is pl. of SaAHibN: (M:) the dim. of OayimRapN is OuwayomRapo↓; or, as El-Mázinee says, OuyayomRapN↓. (S.)

AlUmaAmu also signifies The Prophet: (K:) he is called UimaAmu [the exemplar, object of imitation, leader, or head, of his nation, or people]; (T;) or UimaAmu AlOmRapi [the exemplar, &c., of the nation, or people]; (M;) it being incumbent on all to imitate his rule of life or conduct. (T.)

The Khaleefeh: (Msb, K:) he is called UmaAmu AlrRaEiyRapi [the exemplar, &c., of the people, or subjects]. (M.) The title of AlUmaAmu is still applied to the Kings of El-Yemen: Aboo-Bekr says, you say, fulaAnN UimaAmu Alqawomi, meaning such a one is the first in authority over the people, or company of men: and UimaAmu Almasolimiyna means the head, chief, or leader, of the Muslims. (TA.)
The person whose example is followed, or who is imitated, [i. e. the leader,] in prayer. (Msb.)

[The leading authority, or head, of a persuasion, or sect. The four OyimRap or OaYimRap are the heads of the four principal persuasions, or sects, of the Sunnees; namely, the Hanafees, Sháfi'ees, Málikees, and Hambelees. And the Hanafees call the two chief doctors of their persuasion, after Aboo- Haneefeh, namely, Aboo-Yoosuf and Mohammad, AlUimaAmaAni The two Imáms.]
The leader of an army. (M, K.)
The guide: (K:) he is called UimaAmu AlUibili [the leader of the travellers]. (M.)
The conductor, or driver, of camels (M, K) is called UimaAmu AlUibili, though he be behind them, because he guides them. (M.)
The manager, or conductor, and right disposer, orderer, or rectifier, of anything. (M, K. *)

The Kur-án (M, K) is called UimaAmu Almusolimyna [the guide of the Muslims]; (M;) because it is an exemplar. (TA.) [The model-copy, or standard-copy, of the Kur-án, namely the copy of the Khaleefeh 'Othmán, is particularly called AlUimaAmu.]

[The scripture of any people: and, without the article, a book, or written record.] It is said in the Kur [xvii. 73], yawoma nadoEuw kulRa OunaAsK biUmaAmihimo The day when we shall call every one of mankind with their scripture: or, as some say, with their prophet and their law: or, as some say, with their book in which their deeds are recorded. (T.) It is also said in the Kur [xxxvi. 11], kulRa XayoCK OaHoSayonaAhu fiI UimaAmK mubiynK, meaning, says El-Hasan, [And everything have we recorded] in a perspicuous book, or writing; (S, Jel;) i. e., on the Preserved Tablet. (Bd, Jel.)
The lesson of a boy, that is learned each day (T, M, K) in the school: (T:) also called AlsRabaqu. (TA.)
The model, or pattern, of a semblance, or shape. (M, K.)
The builder's wooden instrument [or rule] whereby he makes the building even. (S, K. *)

The cord which the builder extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones or bricks of the building; also called AltRurRu and AlmiToharu; (T;) the string which is extended upon, or against, a building, and according to which one builds. (M, K. *)

UimaAmN signifies also A road, or way: (S, [but omitted in some copies,] M, K:) or a manifest road, or way. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xv. 79], wa UinRahumaA labiUmaAmK mubiynK (S, M) And they were both, indeed, in a way pursued and manifest: (M:) or in a way which they travelled in their journeys. (Fr.)
The direction (taloqaMC) of the Kibleh. (M, K. *)
A tract, quarter, or region, of land, or of the earth. (S.)
A string [of a bow or lute &c.]; syn. watarN. (Sgh, K.)
OamiymN Beautiful in stature; (K;) applied to a man. (TA.)

I. q. maOomuwmN↓; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. e. one who raves, or is delirious, (yahociI, [in two copies of the S yahodiI, but the former appears, from a remark made voce MmRapN, to be the right reading,]) from [a wound in] what is termed OumRu raOosihi [see OumRN]: (S:) or wounded in what is so termed; (M, K;) having a wound such as is termed MmRap, q. v. (Msb.) It is also used, metaphorically, in relation to other parts than that named above; as in the saying,

L.foreign: wa HaXaAIa mino HarRi AlfiraAqi Oamiymu

sense.s: (tropical:) [And my bowels are wounded by reason of the burning pain of separation]. (M.)

A stone with which the head is broken: (S, O:) but in the M and K OmayomapN↓, [in a copy of the M, however, I find it without any syll. signs, so that it would seem to be OamiymapN↓,] explained as signifying stones with which heads are broken: (TA:) pl. OamaAYimu. (S, TA.)
OumaAYimu Three hundred camels: (M, K:) so explained by Abu-l-'Alà. (M.) UimaAmapN: see UimRapN. OamiymapN: see OamiymN
Also, (Sgh,) or OumayomapN↓, (K,) A blacksmith's hammer. (Sgh, K.)
OumayomapN dim. of OumRN, q. v. (T, S, K.)
See also OamiymN:
and OmaymapN.
AlUimiAmiyRapu One of the exorbitant sects of the Shee'ah, (TA,) who asserted that 'Alee was expressly appointed by Mohammad to be his successor. (Esh-Shahrastánee p. 122, and KT.)
OumayomihpN [dim. of OumRahpN]: see OumRN, first sentence.

OumRiIRN (T, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and OumRaAnN↓ (K) [the former a rel. n. from OumRapN, and thus properly meaning Gentile: whence, in a secondary, or tropical, sense,(assumed tropical:) a heathen;] (assumed tropical:) one not having a revealed scripture; (Bd in iii. 19 and 69;) so applied by those having a revealed scripture: (Bd in iii.69:) [and particularly] an Arab: (Jel in iii. 69, and Bd and Jel in lxii. 2:) [or] in the proper language [of the Arabs], of, or belonging to, or relating to, the nation (OumRap) of the Arabs, who did not write nor read: and therefore metaphorically applied to (tropical:) any one not knowing the art of writing nor that of reading: (Mgh:) or (assumed tropical:) one who does not write; (T, M, K;) because the art of writing is acquired; as though he were thus called in relation to the condition in which his mother (OumRahu) brought him forth: (T:) or (assumed tropical:) one who is in the natural condition of the nation (AlOumRap) to which he belongs, (Zj, * T, M, * K, *) in respect of not writing, (T,) or not having learned writing; thus remaining in his natural state: (M, K:) or (assumed tropical:) one who does not write well; said to be a rel. n. from OmRN; because the art of writing is acquired, and such a person is as his mother brought him forth, in respect of ignorance of that art; or, as some say, from OumRapu AlEarabi; because most of the Arabs were of this description: (Msb:) the art of writing was known among the Arabs [in the time of Mohammad] by the people of Et-Táïf, who learned it from a man of the people of El-Heereh, and these had it from the people of El-Ambár. (T.) OumRiyRuwn laA yaEolamuwna, AlkitaAba, in the Kur ii. 73, means Vulgar persons, [or heathen,] who know not the Book of the Law revealed to Moses: (Jel:) or ignorant persons, who know not writing, so that they may read that book; or, who know not the Book of the Law revealed to Moses. (Bd.) Mohammad was termed OumRiIR [meaning A Gentile, as distinguished from an Israelite: or, accord. to most of his followers, meaning illiterate;] because the nation (OumRap) of the Arabs did not write, nor read writing; and [they say that] God sent him as an apostle when he did not write, nor read from a book; and this natural condition of his was one of his miraculous signs, to which reference is made in the Kur [xxix. 47], where it is said, “thou didst not read, before it, from a book, nor didst thou write it with thy right hand:” (T, TA:) but accord. to the more correct opinion, he was not well acquainted with written characters nor with poetry, but he discriminated between good and bad poetry: or, as some assert, he became acquainted with writing after he had been unacquainted therewith, on account of the expression “ before it ” in the verse of the Kur mentioned above: or, as some say, this may mean that he wrote though ignorant of the art of writing, like as some of the kings, being OumRiyRuwn, write their signs, or marks: (TA:) or, accord. to Jaafar Es-Sádik, he used to read from the book, or scripture, if he did not write. (Kull p. 73.) [Some judicious observations on this word are comprised in Dr. Sprenger's Life of Mohammad (pp. 101-2); a work which, in the portion already published (Part I.), contains much very valuable information.]

Also, (K,) or [only] OumRiIRN, (AZ, T, M,) applied to a man, (AZ, T,) Impotent in speech, (EayiIR, in the K incorrectly written gabiIR, TA,) of few words, and rude, churlish, uncivil, or surly. (AZ, T, M, K.)

OumRiyRapN The quality denoted by the epithet OumRiIRN: (TA:) [gentilism: (assumed tropical:) heathenism: &c.:] (assumed tropical:) the quality of being [in the natural condition of the nation to which one belongs, or] as brought forth by one's mother, in respect of not having learned the art of writing nor the reading thereof. (Kull p. 73.) OumRaAnN: see OumRiIRN; and see also art. Amn OumRahadN: see OumRN.

MmRN [act. part. n. of 1;] i. q. qaASidN: [see 1, first sentence:] (TA:) pl. UimaAmN, like as SiHaAbRN is pl. of SaAHibN, (M, K,) accord. to some, but others say that this is pl. of UimaAmN [q. v.; the sing. and pl. being alike]; (M;) and MmRuwna. (TA.) Hence, in the Kur [v. 2], walaA MmRiyna Alobayota AloHaraAma [Nor those repairing to the Sacred House]. (TA.)

MmRapN (S, Msb) and maOomuwmapN↓, as some of the Arabs say, (IB, Msb,) because it implies the meaning of a pass. part. n., originally; (Msb;) but 'Alee Ibn-Hamzeh says that this is a mistake; for the latter word is an epithet applied to the part called OumRu AldRimaAgi when it is broken; (IB;) or XajRapN MmRapN and maOomuwmapN↓; (M, Mgh, K;) A wound by which the head is broken, (S, M, Msb, K,) reaching to the part called OumRu AldRimaAgi, (S, Msb,) or, [which means the same,] OumRu AlrRaOosi, (M, K,) so that there remains between it and the brain [only] a thin skin: (S:) it is the most severe of XijaAj [except that which reaches the brain (see XajRapN)]: ISk says that the person suffering from it roars, or bellows, (yaSoEaqu,) like thunder, and like the braying of camels, and is unable to go forth into the sun: (Msb:) the mulct for it is one third of the whole price of blood: (TA:) IAar assigns the meaning of [this kind of] XajRap to OamRapN↓; which seems, therefore, to be either a dial. var. or a contraction of MmRapN: (Msb:) the pl. of MmRapN is OawaAmRu (Mgh, Msb) and mMYimu↓; or this latter has no proper sing.: (M, TA:) the pl. of mOomuwmapN↓ is maOomuwmaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.)

OawamRu and OayamRu Better in the performance of the office termed UimaAmapN; followed by mino: (Zj, T, M, K:) originally OaOamRu: the second hemzeh being changed by some into w and by some into I. (Zj, T, M.)
OuyayomRapN, or OuyayomRapN, dim. of OayimRapN, pl. of UimaAmN, q. v. (S.) muWmRN: see OamamN.

miYamRN A camel that leads and guides: (M:) or a guide that shows the right way: and a camel that goes before the other camels: (K:) fem. with p; (M, K;) applied to a she-camel (M, TA) that goes before the other she-camels, and is followed by them. (TA.)
mOomuwmN: see OamiymN.

Also A camel having his hump bruised internally by his being much ridden, or having his hump swollen in consequence of the galling of the saddle and the cloth beneath it, and bruised, and having his hump corroded: (S:) or whose fur has gone from his back in consequence of beating, or of galls, or sores, produced by the saddle or the like. (M, K.)

mOomuwmapN: see MmRapN, in three places. muWaAmRN: see OamamN, in two places. mWotamRN act. part. n. of AYotamRa bihi; Following as an example; imitating; taking as an example, an exemplar, a pattern, or an object of imitation. (Msb.)
muWotamRN bihi pass. part. n. of the same; Followed as an example; imitated; &c.: thus distinguished from the former by the preposition with the object of its government. (Msb.)
maMYimu: see MmRapN.

OamaA, used to denote an interrogation, is a compound of the interrogative hemzeh and the negative maA: (M:) it is a mere interrogative [respecting a negative, like OalaA]; as in the saying, OamaA tasotaHoyiI mina AllRehi [Art not thou ashamed for thyself, or of thyself, with respect to God?]. (Lth, T.)

[IHsh says, after explaining two other usages of OamaA which we have yet to mention,] El-Málakee adds a third meaning of OamaA, saying that it is a particle denoting EaroDN [or the asking, or requiring, a thing in a gentle manner], like [OalaA (q. v.) and] lawolaA; and is connected peculiarly with a verb; as in OamaA taquwmu [Wherefore wilt not thou do stand?], and OamaA tafoEalu [Wherefore wilt not thou do such a thing?]; which may be explained by saying that the hemzeh is used as an interrogative to make one confess, or acknowledge, a thing, as it is in Oalamo and OalaA, and that maA is a negative. (Mughnee.)

It is also an inceptive word, used in the manner of OalaA: (M:) followed by OalaA, it is syn. with OalaA: (S:) [meaning Now: or now surely: or] both of these meaning verily, or truly; i. c. HaqRFA: and for this reason Sb allows one's saying, OamaA UnRah munoTalqN and OamaA OanRahu munoTalqN [Verily, or truly, he is going away]; with kesr after the manner of OalaA UinRahu, and with fet-h after the manner of HaqRFA OanRahu: and hamaA waAllRehi laqado kaAna kacaA is mentioned as meaning OamaA wa AllRehi [&c., i. e. Verily, or truly, by God, such a thing did indeed happen]; the h being a substitute for the hemzeh: (M:) so too HamaI wAllReh [or HamaA wAllReh]: (Sgh and K in art. HmI:) it denotes the truth of the words which follow it; as when you say, OamaA UinRa zayodFA EaAqilN, meaning Truly, or properly speaking, not tropically, Zeyd is intelligent; and OamRaA w AllReh qad Daraba zayodN EamorFA [Truly, &c., by God, Zeyd beat, or struck, Amr]: (S in art. Amw:) [in other words,] it corroborates an oath and a sentence; as in
