One who trusts, or confides, in another; (ISk, T, K;) [as also MminN↓, of which see an ex. voce HacirN;] so accord. to ISk in the verse cited above in this paragraph: (T:) thus it bears two contr. significations. (K.)
See also MminN, in five places.
And see Mmiyna.
OamaAnapN: see OamonN, first sentence.

Trustiness; trustworthiness; trustfulness; faithfulness; fidelity; (M, Mgh, K;) as also OamanapN↓. (M, K.) OamaAnapu AllRehi [for OamaAnapu AllRehi qasamiy or maA Ouqosimu The faithfulness of God is my oath or that by which I swear] is composed of an inf. n. prefixed to the agent, and the former is in the nom. case as an inchoative; the phrase being like laEamoru AllRehi, as meaning an oath; and the enunciative being suppressed, and meant to be understood: accord. to some, you say, OamaAnapa AllRehi [app. for naXadotuka OamaAnapa AllRehi I adjure thee, or conjure thee, by the faithfulness of God, or the like], making it to be governed in the accus. case by the verb which is to be understood: and some correctly say, waOamaAnapi AllRehi [By the faithfulness of God], with the w which denotes an oath: (Mgh:) or this last is an oath accord. to Aboo-Haneefeh; but Esh-Sháfi'ee does not reckon it as such: and it is forbidden in a trad. to swear by AlOamaAnap; app. because it is not one of the names of God. (TA.) [Or these phrases may have been used, in the manner of an oath, agreeably with explanations here following.]

A thing committed to the trust and care of a person; a trust; a deposite; (Mgh, Msb;) and the like: (Msb:) property committed to trust and care: (TA:) pl. OamaAnaAtN. (Mgh, Msb.) It is said in the Kur [viii. 27], wataxuwnuwA OamaAnaAtikumo [Nor be ye unfaithful to the trusts committed to you]. (Mgh.) And in the same [xxxiii. 72], UinRaA EaraDonaAAlOamaAnapa EalaI AlsRmwaAti waAloOaroDiwaAlojibaAli faOabayona Oano yaHomilonahaA waOaXofaqona minohaA waHamalahaA AloUinosaAnu [Verily we proposed, or offered, the trust which we have committed to man to the heavens and the earth and the mountains, and (accord. to explanations of Bd and others) they refused to take it upon themselves, or to accept it, and they feared it, but man took it upon himself, or accepted it: or, (accord. to another explanation of Bd, also given in the T, and in the K in art. Hml, &c.,) they refused to be unfaithful to it, and they feared it, but man was unfaithful to it: but in explaining what this trust was, authors greatly differ: accord. to some,] AlAmAnp here means obedience; so called because the rendering thereof is incumbent: or the obedience which includes that which is natural and that which depends upon the will: [for] it is said that when God created these [celestial and terrestrial] bodies, He created in them understanding: or it may here [and in some other instances] mean reason, or intellect: [and the faculty of volition: and app. conscience: these being trusts committed to us by God, to be faithfully employed: (see an ex. voce jacorN:)] and the imposition of a task or duty or of tasks or duties [app. combined with reason or intellect, which is necessary for the performance thereof]: (Bd:) or it here means prayers and other duties for the performance of which there is recompense and for the neglect of which there is punishment: (Jel:) or, accord. to I'Ab and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, (T,) the obligatory statutes which God has imposed upon his servants: (T, K: *) or, (T, K,) accord. to Ibn-'Omar, [the choice between] obedience and disobedience was offered to Adam, and he was informed of the recompense of obedience and the punishment of disobedience: but, in my opinion, he says, (T,) it here means the intention which one holds in the heart, (T, K,) with respect to the belief which he professes with the tongue, and with respect to all the obligatory statutes which he externally fulfils; (K;) because God has confided to him power over it, and not manifested it to any [other] of his creatures, so that he who conceives in his mind, with respect to the acknowledgment of the unity of God, (T, K,) and with respect to belief [in general], (T,) the like of that which he professes, he fulfils the AmAnp [or trust], (T, K,) and he who conceives in his mind disbelief while he professes belief with the tongue is unfaithful thereto, and every one who is unfaithful to that which is confided to him is [termed] HaAmilN, (T,) or HaAmilu AlOamaAnapi, and muHotamiluhaA: (Bd:) and by AlUinosaAnu is here meant the doubting disbeliever. (T.)
Also, [as being a trust committed to him by God, A man's] family, or household; syn. OaholN. (TA.)
OumRaAnN: see OamynN, in two places.
Also One who does not write; as though he were (kaOanRahu [in the CK lAanRahu because he is]) an OumRiI. (K, TA.) [But this belongs to art. Am; being of the measure fuEolaAnN, like EuroyaAnN.]
And A sower, or cultivator of land; [perhaps meaning a clown, or boor;] syn. zarRaAEN: (CK:) or sowers, or cultivators of land; syn. zurRaAEN: (K, TA:) in one copy of the K ziraAE. (TA.)

MminN Secure, safe, or free from fear; as also OamiynN↓ (Lh, T, * S, * M, Msb, K) and OaminN↓. (M, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xcv. 3], wahcaA Alobaladi AloOamiyni↓ [And this secure town]; (Akh, Lh, T, S, M;) meaning Mekkeh. (M.) baladN MminN and OamiynN↓ means A town, or country, or district, of which the inhabitants are in a state of security, or confidence, therein. (Msb.) It is also said in the Kur [xliv. 51], UinRa AlomutRaqiyna fiy maqaAmK OamiynK↓, meaning [Verily the pious shall be in an abode] wherein they shall be secure from the accidents, or casualties, of fortune. (M.) [And hence,] AlOamiynu↓ is one of the epithets applied to God, (Mgh, K,) on the authority of El-Hasan; (Mgh;) an assertion requiring consideration: it may mean He who is secure with respect to the accidents, or casualties, of fortune: but see AlmuWominu, which is [well known as] an epithet applied to God. (TA.) Mminu AlmaAli means What is secure from being slaughtered, of the camels, because of its being highly prized; by AlmAl being meant AlUibil: or, as some say, (tropical:) what is highly esteemed, of property of any kind; as though, if it had intellect, it would feel secure from being exchanged. (M.) You say, OaEoTayotuhu mino Mmini maAliy, (K, TA, [in the CK Mmani,]) meaning (tropical:) I gave him of the choice, or best, of my property; of what was highly esteemed thereof; (K, TA;) and maAliI mino Oamoni↓ which Az explains as meaning of the choice, or best, of my property. (TA: [in which is given a verse cited by ISk showing that Oamon, thus used, is not a mistranscription for Mmin.]) And Mminu AlHilomi means Steadfast in forbearance or clemency; of whose becoming disordered in temper, and free from self-restraint, there is no fear. (M.)
See also OamiynN, in three places:
and see AaminN.
See also OamiynN, in two places.

Mmiyna [in the CK, erroneously, Mmiynu] and Oamiyna↓; (Th, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) both chaste and well known, (TA,) the latter of the dial. of El-Hijáz, (Msb, TA,) as some say, (TA,) [and this, though the less common, is the original form, for] the medd in the former is only to give fulness of sound to the fet-hah of the O, (Th, M, Msb, TA,) as is shown by the fact that there is no word in the Arabic language of the measure faAEiylN; (Msb, TA;) and some pronounce the former MmRiyna, (K,) which is said by some of the learned to be a dial. var., (Msb,) but this is a mistake, (S, Msb,) accord. to authorities of good repute, and is one of old date, originating from an assertion of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà, [i. e. Th,] that Mmiyna is like EaASiyna, by which he was falsely supposed to mean its having the form of a pl., [and being consequently MmRiyna,] (Msb, [and part of this is said in the M,]) whereas he thereby only meant that the m is without teshdeed, like the S in EaASiyna; (M;) beside that the sense of qaASidiyna [which is that of MmRiyna, from OamRa,] would be inconsistent after the last phrase of the first chapter of the Kur [where Mmyna is usually added]; (Msb;) and sometimes it is pronounced with imáleh, [i. e. “émeena,”] as is said by ElWáhidee in the Beseet; (K;) but this is unknown in works on lexicology, and is said to be a mispronunciation of some of the Arabs of the desert of El-Yemen: (MF:) each form is indecl., (S,) with fet-h for its termination, like Oayona and kayofa, to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together: (T, S, TA:) it is a word used immediately after a prayer, or supplication: (S, * M:) [it is best expressed, when occurring in a translation, by the familiar Hebrew equivalent Amen:] El-Fárisee says that it is a compound of a verb and a noun; (M;) meaning answer Thou me; [i. e. answer Thou my prayer;] (M, Mgh;*) or O God, answer Thou: (Zj, T, Msb, K:) or so be it: (AHát, S, Msb, K:) or so do Thou, (K, TA,) O Lord: (TA:) it is strangely asserted by some of the learned, that, after the Fátihah, [or Opening Chapter of the Kur-án,] it is a prayer which implies all that is prayed for in detail in the Fátihah: so in the Towsheeh: (MF:) or it is one of the names of God: (M, Msb, K:) so says El-Hasan (M, Msb) El-Basree: (Msb:) but the assertion that it is for yaA AallRehu [O God], and that AsotajibN [answer Thou] is meant to be understood, is not correct accord. to the lexicologists; for, were it so, it would be with refa, not nasb. (T.)
UiymaAnN [inf. n. of 4, q. v.
Used as a simple subst., Belief; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faith: trust, or confidence: &c.]

Sometimes it means Prayer; syn. SalaApN: as in the Kur [ii. 138], where it is said, wamaA kaAna AllRehu liyuDiyEa UiyamAnakumo, (Bd, Jel, TA,) i. e. [God will not make to be lost] your prayer
towards Jerusalem, (Bd, * Jel,) as some explain it. (Bd.)
Sometimes, also, it is used as meaning The law brought by the Prophet. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
maOomanN A place of security or safety or freedom from fear; or where one feels secure. (M, TA.)

muWomanN pass. part. n. of Mmanahu. (T.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 96], accord. to one reading, (T, M,) that of Aboo-Jaafar El-Medenee, (T,) lasota muWomanFA [Thou art not granted security, or safety, &c.; or] we will not grant thee security, &c. (T, M.)

muWominN [act. part. n. of 4; Rendering secure, &c.]. AlmuWominu is an epithet applied to God; meaning He who rendereth mankind secure from his wronging them: (T, S:) or He who rendereth his servants secure from his punishment: (M, IAth:) i. q. Almuhayominu, (M,) which is originally AlmuWaOominu; [for the form mufoEilN is originally muWafoEilN;] the second C being softened, and changed into I, and the first being changed into h: (S:) or the Believer of his servants (Th, M, TA) the Muslims, on the day of resurrection, when the nations shall be interrogated respecting the messages of their apostles: (TA:) or He who will faithfully perform to his servants what He hath promised them: (T, TA:) or He who hath declared in his word the truth of his unity. (T.)
[Also Believing, or a believer; particularly in God, and in his word and apostles &c.: faithful: trusting, or confiding: &c.: see 4.]
maOomuwnN: see OamiynN, in three places.
maOomuwnapN A woman whose like is sought after and eagerly retained because of her valuable qualities. (M.)
maOomuwniyRapN A certain kind of food; so called in relation to El-Ma-moon. (TA.)
muWotamanN: see OamiynN, in two places.

1. Oamiha, aor.
Aamaha
, inf. n. OamahN, He forgot. (S, K.) Hence the reading of I'Ab, [in the Kur xii. 45,] waAdRakara baEoda OamahK [And he remembered, or became reminded, after forgetting]. (S.) AHeyth is said to have read baEoda OamohK; and accord. to AO, OamohN signifies nisoyaAnN [like OamahN]; but this is not correct. (Az, TA.)

He confessed, or acknowledged: (S, K:) occurring in this sense in a trad. of Ez-Zuhree; but not well known. (S.) The reading of I'Ab, mentioned above, baEoda OamahK, is explained by A'Obeyd as meaning after confessing, or acknowledging. (TA.)
5. tOmRh OumRaA He adopted a mother; (M, K;) as also taOamRamahaA. (M in art. Am.)

OumRahapN i. q. OumRN [A mother of a human being and of any animal]: (M, K:) the former is [said by some to be] the original of the latter: (S:) Aboo-Bekr says that the h in the former is a radical letter: (TA:) or the former applies to a rational creature; and the latter, to [a rational and] an irrational: (K:) or, accord. to Az, the pl. of the former applies to the rational; and that of the latter, to the irrational: (TA:) the former sing. sometimes applies to an irrational creature: (IJ, TA:) [for some further remarks on both of these words and their pls., see the latter of them:] the pl. [of the former] is OumRahaAtN and [that of the latter is] OumRaAtN: (T, S:) Az says that the Amw is added in the former for the purpose of distinguishing between the daughters of Adam [to whom it is generally applied] and other animate beings. (TA.)

1. Mmato, (S, * M, K, [in the CK, erroneously, Mmato,]) second pers. Oamawoti; (S;) and Oamiyato, (M, K,) like samiEato; (K;) and Oamuwato, (Lh, M, K,) like karumatN; (K;) inf. n. OumuwRapN; (S, M, K;) She (a woman) became a slave; (S, * M, K;) as also taOamRato↓. (Msb.)
Oamati AlsRinRaworu, aor. taOomuw, inf. n. OumaMCN, The cat [mewed, or] uttered a cry; (S, K;) like maMCa to, aor. tamuwoCu, inf. n. muwaMCN. (S.)
2. OamRaAhaA, (M, K,) inf. n. taOomiyapN, (K,) He made her a slave. (M, K.)
5. taOamRatu: see 1.
tOmRI OamapF He took for himself a female slave; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also AisotaOomaAhaA↓. (S, K.)

8. huwayaOotamiI bihi He follows his (another person's) example; imitates him; i. q. yaOotamRu bihi (TA in the present art.) And AYtmI biAlXRaIoCi [written with the disjunctive alif AiytamaI] is used for AYtamRa bihi [He made the thing to be a rule of life or conduct], by substitution [of I for m], (M and K in art. Am,) the doubling [of the m] being disapproved. (M in that art.)

OamapN, originally Amwp, (Msb,) [but whether OamawapN or OamowapN is disputed, as will be seen in what follows,] A female slave; (M, K;) a woman whose condition is that of slavery; (T;) contr. of HurRapN: (S:) [in relation to God, best rendered a handmaid:] dual OamataAni: (Msb:) pl. MmK, (Lth, T, S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) like qiADK, (Msb,) a pl. of pauc. [respecting which see what follows after the other pls.], (Lth, T,) and UimaMCN [the most common form] (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and UimowaAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OumowaAnN (K, and so in some copies of the M) and OamowaAnN (K, and so in some copies of the M) [the last, or last but one, accord. to different copies of the M, on the authority of Lh,] and OamawaAtN, (M, Msb, K,) for which one may say OamaAtN. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) Accord. to Sb (M) and Mbr (TA) it is originally OamawapN, (S, M, K,) because it has for a pl. MmK, (S, M,) which is [originally OaOomuwN,] of the measure OafoEulN, (Lth, T, S,) like MkumN, pl. of OakamapN, (Sb, M,) and like OayonuqN, [pl. of naAqpN, which is originally nawaqpN,] for a sing. of the measure faEolapN has not a pl. of this form; (S;) and Mbr says that there is no noun of two letters but a letter has been dropped from it, which it indicates by its pl. or dual, or by a verb if it is derived therefrom: (TA:) or it is originally faEolapN: (AHeyth, T, K:) AHeyth says that they suppressed its final radical letter, and, forming a pl. from it after the manner of naxolapN and naxolN, instead of saying OamN, which they disliked as being of only two letters, they transposed the suppressed w, changing it into A, and placing it between the A and m. (T: [in which this opinion, though it does not account for the termination of the pl. MmK, is said to be preferable.]) One says, jaMCa toniIF Oamapu AllRehi [The handmaid of God came to me]: and in the dual, jaMCa toniI OmataA AllRehi: and in the pl., jaMCa niI UimaMCu AllRehi and UimowaAnu AllRehi and OamawaAtu AllRehi; and one may also say, OamaAtu AllReh. (Ibn-Keysán, TA.) [ISd says,] wamaAhu AllRehu mino kulRi OamapK bHajarK is mentioned by IAar as said in imprecating evil on a man; but I think it is mn klR Oamoti [May God cast a stone at him from every elevated place, or the like]. (M.)
OamawiIRu Of, or relating or belonging to, a female slave. (S.)
OumayRapN dim. of OamapN; (S, Msb;) originally OumayowapN. (Msb.)
1. OanRa, aor. yaYinRu, inf. n. OaniynN and OunaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and taOonaAnN (S, K) and OanRN, (M, K,) He moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; or said, Ah! syn.
taOawRaha; (M, K;) by reason of pain: (S, TA:) he complained by reason of disease or pain: (TA:) he uttered a cry or cries: (Msb:) said of a man. (S, Msb.)
OanRiti Alqawosu, aor. taYinRu, inf. n. OaniynN, The bow made a gentle and prolonged sound. (AHn, M.)

laA OafoEaluhu maA OanRa fiI AlsRamaMCi najomN means I will not do it as long as there is a star in the heaven: (S, M, K:) OanRa being here a dial. var. of EanRa. (S.) You say also, maA OanRa fiy AlfuraAti qaTorapN As long as there is a drop in the Euphrates. (T, S.) And laA OafoEaluhu maA OanRa fiI AlsRamaMCN [I will not do it as long as there is rain in the heaven]. (S.) [It is said in the M that Lh mentions the last two sayings; but it is there indicated that he read qaTorapF and samaMCF: and] ISk mentions the saying, laA OafoEaluhu maA OanRa fiI AlsRamaMCi najomFA, (T, M,) and maA EanRa fiI AlsRamaMCi najomN; (T;) [in the former of which, OanR must be a particle (which see below); but it seems that it should rather be UinRa, in this case, as ISd thinks; for he says,] I know not for what reason AnR is here with fet-h, unless a verb be understood before it, as vabata or wujida: [and he adds,] Lh mentions maA OanRa clika Aljabala makaAnahu [as long as that mountain is in its place]: and maA OanRa HiraMCF makaAnahu [as long as Mount Hirà is in its place]: but he does not explain these sayings. (M.)

OanN is a pronoun, denoting the speaker, [I, masc. and fem.,] in the language of some of the Arabs: they say, Oano faEalotu [I did], with the n quiescent: but most of them pronounce it [Oana↓] with fet-h when conjoined with a following word; (Mughnee, K;) saying, Oana faEalotu: (TA:) and [OanaA↓] with A in a case of pause: (Mughnee, K:) and
some pronounce it with A also when it is conjoined with a following word; saying, OanaA faEalotu; [as we generally find it written in books;] but this is of a bad dialect: (TA:) [this last assertion, however, requires consideration; for the dial. here said to be bad is that of Temeem, accord. to what here follows:] the Basrees hold that the pronoun consists of the C and the n, and that the [final] A is redundant, because it is suppressed in a case of conjunction with a following word; but the Koofees hold that the pronoun is composed of all the three letters, because the A is preserved in a case of conjunction with a following word in the dial. of Temeem. (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee.) [Accord. to Az,] it is best to say OanaA↓ in a case of pause; and Oana↓ in a case of conjunction with a following word, as in Oana faEalotu caAka [I did that]; but some of the Arabs say, faEalotu caAka OanaA↓; and some make the n quiescent in a case of this kind, though this is rare, saying, Oano qulotu caAka [I said that]; and Kudá'ah prolong the former A, saying, qulotuhu Mna↓. (T.) [Accord. to J,] OanaA↓ is a pronoun denoting the speaker alone, and is made to end invariably with fet-h to distinguish it from the particle Oano which renders the aor. mansoob; the final A being for the purpose of showing what is the vowel in a case of pause; but when it occurs in the middle [or beginning] of a sentence, it is dropped, except in a bad dialect. (S.) [Accord. to ISd,] Oana↓ is a noun denoting the speaker; and in a case of pause, you add A at the end, [saying OanaA↓,] to denote quiescence; (M;) [or] it is better to do this, though it is not always done: (TA:) but it is said, on the authority of Ktr, that there are five dial. vars. of this word; namely, faEalotu Oana↓, and OanaA↓, and Mna↓, and OanN, and OanahN↓, all mentioned by IJ; but there is some weakness in this: IJ says that the h in OanahN↓ may be a substitute for the A in OanaA, because the latter is the more usual, and the former is rare; or it may be added to show what is the vowel, like the h, and be like the h in kitaAbiyaho and HisaAbiyahN. (M.) For the dual, as well as the pl., only naHonu is used. (Az, TA.)

It is also a pronoun denoting the person addressed, or spoken to, by assuming the form Oanota↓ [Thou, masc.]; t being added to it as the sign of the person addressed, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) and Oano being the pronoun, (M, Mughnee, K,) accord. to the general opinion; (Mughnee, K;) the two becoming as one; not that one is prefixed to the other as governing it in the gen. case: (S:) and so Oanoti↓, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to the female: (S, M:) and OanotumaA↓, (M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to two; not a regular dual, for were it so it would be OanotaAn; but like kumaA in DarabotukumaA: (M:) and OanotumN↓ and OanotunRa↓, (S, Mughnee, K,) which are [respectively] the masc. and fem. pls. (TA.)

To each of these the k of comparison is sometimes prefixed; so that you say, Oanota kaOanaA↓ [Thou art like me, or as I], and OanaA kaOanota↓ [or Oana kaOanota I am like thee, or as thou]; as is related on the authority of the Arabs; for though the k of comparison is not prefixed to the [affixed] pronoun, and you say, Oanota kazayodK but not Oanota kiy, yet the separate pronoun is regarded by them as being in the same predicament as the noun; and therefore the prefixing it to the latter kind of pronoun is approved. (S.) It is said in the Book of layosa, by IKh, that there is no such phrase, in the language of the Arabs, as Oanota kiI, nor as OanaA kaka, except in two forged verses; wherefore Sb says that the Arabs, by saying Oanota mivoliI and OanaA mvoluka, have no need of saying Oanota kiI and OanaA kaka: and the two verses are these:
[And but for the sense of shame, we had been like them, or as they: and but for trial, or affliction, they had been like us, or as we]: and

L.foreign: Uino takuno kiI fiUinRaniy kaka fiyhaA

sense.s: [If thou art like me, or as I, verily I am like thee, or as thou, in respect of her, or it, or them: verily we, in respect of blame, are companions]. (TA.) Az mentions his having heard some of the Benoo-Suleym say, kamaA Oanotaniy, [the latter word being a compound of the pronoun Oanota, regularly written separately, and the affixed pronoun niI,] meaning Wait thou for me in thy place. (TA.)

It is also a particle: and as such, it is—First, a particle of the kind called maSodariIRN, rendering the aor. mansoob: (Mughnee, K:) i. e., (TA,) it combines with a verb [in this case] in the future [or aor.] tense, following it, to form an equivalent to an inf. n., and renders it mansoob: (S, TA:) you say, Ouriydu Oano taquwma [I desire that thou stand, or that thou wouldst stand, or that thou mayest stand]; meaning Ouriydu qiyaAmaka [I desire thy standing]. (S.) It occurs in two places: first, in that of the inchoative, or in the beginning of a phrase, so that it is in the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 180], waOano taSuwmuwA xayorN lakumo [And that ye fast is better for you]; (Mughnee, K;) i. e. SiyaAmukumo [your fasting]. (TA.) And, secondly, after a word denoting a meaning which is not that of certainty: and thus it is the place of a nom. case; as in the saying [in the Kur lvii. 15], Oalamo yaOani lilRaciyna MmanuwA OanN taxoXaEa quluwbuhumo [Hath not the time that their hearts should become submissive, i. e. the time of their hearts' becoming submissive, yet come unto those who have believed?]: and in the place of an accus. case; as in the saying [in the Kur x. 38], wamaA kaAna hcaA AlqoroMnu Oano yufotaraC [And this Kur-án is not such that it might be forged; i. e., AfutiriMCN; so in Bd and Jel; and so in a marginal note to a copy of the Mughnee, where is added, meaning mufotarFI forged]: and in the place of a gen. case; as in the saying [in the Kur lxiii. 10], mino qaboli Oano yaOotiIa OaHadakumu Alomawotu [Before that death come unto any one of you; i. e. before death's coming unto any one of you]. (Mughnee, K.) Sometimes it makes the aor. to be of the mejzoom form, (Mughnee, K,) as some of the Koofees and AO have mentioned, and as Lh has stated on the authority of certain of the Benoo-Sabbáh of Dabbeh; (Mughnee;) as in this verse:

L.foreign: UicaA maA gadawonaA qaAla wilodaAnu OaholinaA
taEaAlwogA UilaI Oano yaOotinaA AlSRayodu naHoTibi

sense.s: [When we went away in the morning, the youths of our family, or people, said, Come ye, until that the chase come to us, (i. e. until the coming of the chase to us,) let us collect firewood]. (Mughnee, K.) And sometimes it is followed by an aor. of the marfooa form; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 233], accord. to the reading of Ibn-Moheysin, limano OaraAda Oano yutimRu AlrRaDaAEapa [For him who desireth that he may complete the time of sucking; i. e. the completing thereof]; (Mughnee, K;) but this is anomalous, (I 'Ak p. 101, and TA,) or Oano is here a contraction of OanRa [for OanRahu]: (I 'Ak:) and in the saying of the poet,

L.foreign: minRiI AlsRalaAma waOano laA tuxobiraA OaHadaA

sense.s: [That ye two convey, or communicate, to Asmà, (mercy on you! or woe to you!) from me, salutation, and that ye inform not any one]; but the Koofees assert that OanN is here [in the beginning of the verse] a contraction of OanRa, and anomalously conjoined with the verb; whereas the Basrees correctly say that it is OanN which renders the aor. mansoob, but is deprived of government by its being made to accord with its co-ordinate maA, termed maSodariyRap; (Mughnee;) or, as IJ says, on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, OanN is here used by poetic licence for OanRakumaA; and the opinion of the Baghdádees [and Basrees], that it is likened to maA, and therefore without government, is improbable, because Oano is not conjoined with a verb in the present tense, but only with the preterite and the future. (M.) When it is suppressed, the aor. may be either mansoob or marfooa; but the latter is the better; as in the saying in the Kur [xxxix. 64], Oafagayora AllRehi taOomuruwnRiI OaEobudu [Other than God do ye bid me worship?]. (S.) If it occurs immediately before a preterite, it combines with it to form an equivalent to an inf. n. relating to past time; being in this case without government: you say, OaEojayaniyOano qumota [It pleased me that thou stoodest]; meaning thy standing that is past pleased me: (S:) and thus it is used in the saying [in the Kur xxviii. 82], lawolaA OanN manRa AllRehu EalayonaA [Were it not for that God conferred favour upon us; i. e., for God's having conferred favour upon us]. (Mughnee.) It is also conjoined with an imperative; as in the phrase mentioned by Sb, katabotu Uilayhi biOanp qumN [I wrote to him, Stand; i. e. I wrote to him the command to stand]; which shows that AHei is wrong in asserting that whenever it is conjoined with an imperative it is an explicative [in the sense of OayN], and that in this particular instance the b may be redundant, which it cannot here be, because, whether redundant or not, it is not put immediately before anything but a noun or what may be rendered by a noun. (Mughnee.)

Secondly, it is a con-
traction of OanRa; (Mughnee, K;) and occurs after a verb denoting certainty, or one used in a manner similar to that of such a verb: (Mughnee:) so in the saying [in the Kur lxxiii. 20], Ealima OanN sayakuwnu minokumN maroDay [He knoweth that (the case will be this:) there will be among you some diseased; the affixed pronoun hu, meaning AXRaOona, being understood after Oano, which therefore stands for OanRahu, i. e.

OanRa AlXRaOona]: (Mughnee, K: *) and in the phrase, balaganiI Oano qado kaAna kacaA wkacaA [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge, &c., that (the case is this:) such and such things have been]; a phrase of this kind, in which Oano occurs with a verb, not being approved without qado, unless you say, balaganiI OanRahu kaAna kacaA wakacaA: (Lth, T:) [for] when the contracted Oano has for its predicate a verbal proposition, of which the verb is neither imperfectly inflected, like layosa and EasaI, nor expressive of a prayer or an imprecation, it is separated from the verb, according to the more approved usage, by qado, or the prefix sa, or sawofa, or a negative, as laA &c., or lawo: (I 'Ak pp. 100 and 101:) but when its predicate is a nominal proposition, it requires not a separation; so that you say, Ealimotu Oano ziayodN qaAYimN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was standing]; (I 'Ak p. 100;) and balaganiI Oano zaydN xaArijN [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, &c., that (the case is this:) Zeyd is going, or coming, out, or forth]; (TA;) except in the case of a negation, as in the saying in the Kur [xi. 17], wOano laA Uilha UilRaA huwa [And that (the case is this:) there is no deity but He]. (I 'Ak p. 100.) Thus used, it is originally triliteral, and is also what is termed maSodariyRap; [Ealima Oano, in the first of the exs. above, for instance, meaning Ealima OanRahu, i. e. Ealima OanRa AlXRaOona, which is equivalent to Ealima kawona AlXRaOoni;] and governs the subject in the accus. case, and the predicate in the nom. case: and its subject must be a pronoun, suppressed, [as in the exs. given above, where it means AlXRaOoni, and in a verse cited before, commencing Oano taqoraMni, accord. to A'boo-'Alee,] or expressed; the latter, accord. to the more correct opinion, being allowable only by poetic license: and its predicate must be a proposition, unless the subject is expressed, in which case it may be either a single word or a proposition; both of which kinds occur in the following saying [of a poet]:

[he is speaking of persons coming as guests to him whom he addresses, when their provisions are exhausted, and the horizon is dust-coloured, and the north wind is blowing, (as is shown by the citation of the verse immediately preceding, in the T,) and he says, They know that thou art like rain that produces spring-herbage, and like plenteous rain, and that thou, there, art the aider and the manager of the affairs of people]. (Mughnee. [In the T, for rabiyEN, I find AlRarbiyEu; and for waOanoka, I there find waqidomFA: but the reading in the Mughnee is that which is the more known.]) [J says,] Oano is sometimes a contraction of OanRa and does not govern [anything]: you say, balaganiI OanN zayodN xaArijN [explained above]; and it is said in the Kur [vii. 41], wanuwduwA Oano tilokumu AljanRapu [And it shall be proclaimed to them that (the case is this:) that is Paradise]: (S:) [here, however, Oanp is regarded by some as an explicative, as will be seen below:] but in saying this, J means that it does not govern as to the letter; for virtually it does govern; its subject being meant to be understood; the virtual meaning being OanRahu tilokumu AljanRapu. (IB.) [In another place, J says,] You may make the contracted Oano to govern or not, as you please. (S.) Aboo-Tálib the Grammarian mentions an assertion that the Arabs make it to govern; as in the saying [of a poet, describing a beautiful bosom],
[As though its two breasts were two small round boxes]: but [the reading commonly known is

(this latter reading is given in De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Ar. p. 104 of the Ar. text; and both are given in the S;) kaOano here meaning kaOanRahu; and] Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern except with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent. (T.) The author of the K says in the B that you say, Ealimotu Oano zyodFA lamunoTaliqN [I knew that Zeyd was indeed going away], with l when it is made to govern; and Ealimotu Oano zayodN munoTaliqN [I knew that (the case was this:) Zeyd was going away], without l when it is made to have no government. (TA. [But in the latter ex. it governs the subject, which is understood, as in other exs. before given.]) [See an ex. in a verse ending with the phrase wakaOano qadi cited voce qad, where kaOano is for kaOanRahu, meaning kaOanRa AlXROna, and a verb is understood after qd. And see also OanRa, below.]

Thirdly, it is an explicative, (Mughnee, K,) meaning Oayo (S, M, and so in some copies of the K,) or [rather] used in the manner of Oayo; (Mughnee, and so in some copies of the K;) [meaning qaAYilFA, or qaAYiliyna; or yaquwlu, or yaquwluwna; or some other form of the verb qaAla; i. e. Saying; &c.;] as in the saying [in the Kur xxiii. 27], faOawoHayonaA Uilayohi Oani ASonaEi Aloquloka [And we revealed, or spake by revelation, unto him, saying, Make thou the ark]; (Mughnee, K) and [in the Kur vii. 41,]wanuwduwA Oano tilokumu AlojanRapu [And it shall be proclaimed to them, being said, That is Paradise]; or in these two instances it may be regarded as what is termed maSodariyRap, by supposing the preposition [bi] understood before it, so that in the former instance it is the biliteral, because it is put before the imperative, and in the second it is the contraction of OanRa because it is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee;) and [in the Kur xxxviii. 5,] waAnoTalaqa AlomalaOu minohumo Oani AmoXuwA(S, M, Mughnee) i. e. [And the chief persons of them] broke forth, or launched forth, with their tongues, or in speech, [saying,] Go ye on, or continue ye, in your course of action &c. (Mughnee.) For this usage of Oano certain conditions are requisite: first, that it be preceded by a proposition: secondly, that it be followed by a proposition; so that you may not say, cakarotu EasojadFA Oano cahabFA, but you must say OaIN in this case, or must omit the explicative: thirdly, that the preceding proposition convey the meaning of Alqawolu, as in the exs. above; in the last of which, AnTlq has the meaning assigned to it above; not that of walking or going away: fourthly, that there be not in the preceding proposition the letters of Alqawolu; so that one may not say, qulotu lahu Oani AfoEalo; or, if there be in it those letters, that the word which they compose shall be interpreted by another word; as in the saying, in the Kur [v, 117], maA qulotu lahumo UilRaA maA OamarotaniI bihi Oani AEobuduwA AllReha which may mean, as Z says, I have not commanded them [aught save that which Thou commandedst me, saying, Worship ye God]; (Mughnee;) in which instance Fr says that it is an explicative: (T:) fifthly, that there be not a preposition immediately before it; for if you say, katabotu Uilayohi biOani AfoEalo kacaA, it is what is termed maSodariyRap [as we have before shown]. (Mughnee.) When it may be regarded as an explicative and is followed by an aor. with lA as in OaXarotu Uilayohi Oano laA tafoEal kacaA, it may be marfooa, [namely, the aor.,] on the supposition that lA is a negative; or mejzoom, on the supposition that it is a prohibitive; and in both cases An is an explicative; [so that the meaning is, I made a sign to him, as though saying, Thou wilt not do such a thing, in the former case; or, in the latter, Do not thou such a thing;] or mansoob, on the supposition that lA is a negative and that An is what is termed maSodariyRap: but if lA is wanting, it may not be mejzoom, but may be marfooa [if we use An as an explicative] or mansoob [if An be what is termed maSodariyRap]. (Mughnee.)

Fourthly, it is redundant, as a corroborative, (Mughnee, K,) like whatever else is redundant: and thus it is in four cases: one of these, which is the most common, being when it occurs after lamRaA denoting time; [and this is mentioned in the M;] as in the saying [in the Kur xxix. 32], walmRaA Oano jaMCa to rusulunaA luwTFA [And when our apostles came to Lot]: (Mughnee:) [or,] accord. to J, (TA,) it is sometimes a connective to lamRaA; as in the saying in the Kur [xii. 96], falamRaA Oano jaMCa AlobaXiyru [And when that (like as we say, " now that,") the announcer of good tidings came]: and sometimes it is redundant; as in the saying in the Kur [viii. 34], wamaA lahumo Oano laA yuEacibahumu AllRehu [as though it might be rendered But what reason have they, God should not punish them?]: (S, TA:) but IB says that the connective is redundant; and [that An is not redundant in the latter instance, for] if it were redundant in this verse of the Kur it would not render the [aor.] verb mansoob. (TA. [The author of the Mughnee, like IB, disallows that An is redundant in a case of this kind, which Kh asserts it to be; and says that fiI is under-
stood before it.]) The second case is when it occurs between lawN and a verb signifying swearing, the latter being expressed; as in this verse:

L.foreign: lakaAna lanaA yawomN mina AlXRarRi muZolimu

sense.s: [And I swear, had we and you met, there had been to us a dark day of evil]: and when that verb is omitted; as in the following ex.:

L.foreign: OamaA waQllRehi Oano lawo kunota HurRiA

sense.s: [Verily, or now surely, by God, if thou wert freeborn; but thou art not the freeborn nor the emancipated]: so say Sb and others: Ibn-'Os- foor holds it to be a particle employed to connect the complement of the oath with the oath; but this is rendered improbable by the fact that it is in most cases omitted, and such particles are not. (Mughnee.) The third case, which is extr., is when it occurs between the k [of comparison] and the noun governed by it in the genitive case; as in the saying,

L.foreign: kaOanN ZaboyapK taEoTuw UilaI waAriqi AlsRalamo

sense.s: [And on a day thou comest to us with a beautiful face, like a doe-gazelle raising her head towards the goodly green-leaved tree of the selem kind], accord. to the reading of him who makes Tbypo to be governed in the genitive case [instead of the accus. or the nom.; for if we read it in the accus. or the nom., Oano is a contraction of OanRa; in the former case, Zbyp being its subject, and its predicate being suppressed; and in the latter case, the meaning being kaOanRahaA ZaboyapN, so that the subject of An is suppressed]. (Mughnee.) The fourth case is when it occurs after UicaA; as in the following ex.:

L.foreign: muEaATiI yadK fiy lujRapi AlmaMCi gaAmiru

sense.s: [And I leave him alone until when he is as though he were a giver of a hand to be laid hold upon, in the fathomless deep of the water immerged]. (Mughnee.)

[Fifthly,] among other meanings which have been assigned to it, (Mughnee,) it has a conditional meaning, like UinN: (Mughnee, K:) so the Koofees hold; and it seems to be most probably correct, for several reasons: first, because both these forms occur, accord. to different readings, in several instances, in one passage of the Kur; as in [ii. 282,] Oano taDilRN UiHodaAhumaA [If one of them twain (namely, women,) err]; &c.: secondly, because [the prefix] fa often occurs after it; as in a verse commencing with OabaA xuraAXapa [as cited voce OamRaA, accord. to some who hold that OmRaA in that verse is a compound of the conditional Oano and the redundant maA; and as in the Kur ii. 282, where the words quoted above are immediately followed by fatucakRira UiHodaAhumaA QloOuxoraI]: thirdly, because it is conjoined with UinN [which forms a part of the compound UikRaA] in this ex.:

L.foreign: faQllRehu yakolaOu maA taOotiI wamaA tacaru

sense.s: [If thou remain, and if thou be going away (OamRaA meaning Oano kunota, as syn. with Uino kunota), may God guard thee (yakolaOu being marfooa because of the f) as long as thou doest and as long as thou leavest undone]: thus related, with kesr to the former An [in UinRaA] and with fet-h to the latter [in OamRaA]. (Mughnee.)

[Sixthly,] it is a negative, like Uino: (Mughnee, K:) so, as some say, in [the Kur iii. 66,] OanE yuWotaI OaHadN mivola maA Ouwtiytumo [meaning accord. to them Not any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given]: but it is said [by others] that the meaning is, [taken with what precedes it,] And believe not ye that (biOano) any one is given the like of that scripture which ye have been given, except it be given to him who followeth your religion; and that the phrase “ say thou, Verily the direction is the direction of God, ” is parenthetic. (Mughnee.)

[Seventhly,] it is syn. with Uico, (AZ, T, Mughnee, K, [in Freytag's Lex., from the K, Uico qiyla, but qyl in the K relates to what there follows,]) as some say, in [the Kur l. 2,] balo EajibuwA OanN jaMCahumo munocirNminohumo [Verily they wonder because a warner from among themselves hath come unto them]; (Mughnee, K;) and in other instances; but correctly, in all these instances, An is what is termed maSodariyRap, and li denoting cause is understood before it. (Mughnee.) [See also OamRaA and UimRaA.]

[Eighthly,] it is syn. with liYalRA, accord. to some, in [the Kur iv. last verse,] yubayRinu QllRehuOano taDilRuwA [God explaineth to you (the ordinances of your religion, Jel), lest ye should err, or in order that ye may not err]; (Mughnee, K;) and in the saying,

[Ye became, or have become, in the condition of our guests; so we hastened, or have hastened, the entertainment, lest ye should revile us, or in order that ye should not revile us]: (Mughnee:) but correctly, in such a case [likewise], An is what is termed maSodariyRap, and the original wording is karaAhapa Oano taDilRuwA [from a motive of dislike that ye should err], (Mughnee, K,) and maxaAfapa Oano taXotimuwnaA [from a motive of fear that ye should revile us]: so say the Basrees: some say, extravagantly, that l is meant to be understood before it, and AlRaciI after it. (Mughnee.)

[Ninthly,] it occurs in the sense of AlRaciI; as in the saying, zayodN OaEoqalu minN Oano yakocib [Zeyd is more reasonable than he who lies; which is equivalent to saying, Zeyd is too reasonable to lie: but respecting its usage in a phrase of this kind, and respecting the form of the aor. after it in such a case, see mino]. (Kull p. 78.)
By a peculiarity of pronunciation termed EanoEatapN, the tribe of Temeem say Eano instead of OanN. (M.)

UinN is used in various ways: first, as a conditional particle, (S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) denoting the happening of the second of two events in consequence of the happening of the first, (S, Msb, *) whether the second be immediate or deferred, and whether the condition be affirmative or negative; (Msb;) [and as such it is followed by a mejzoom aor., or by a pret. having the signification of an aor.;] as in the saying, [Uino tafoEalN OfoEalN If thou do such a thing, I will do it; and] Uino taOotiniI Mtika [If thou come to me, I will come to thee]; and UinN jiYotaniI Oakoramotuka [If thou come to me, I will treat thee with honour]; (S;) and Uino faEalota faEalotu [If thou do, I will do] for which the tribe of Teiyi say, as IJ relates on the authority of Ktr, hino faEalota faEalotu; (M;) and Uino daxalot AldRaAra OawN [If thou stand, I will stand]; and Uino daxaloti AldRaAra Oawo lamo tadoxuliI AldRaArD faOanoti TaAlqN [If thou enter the house, or if thou enter not the house, thou shalt be divorced]; (Msb;) and [in the Kur viii. 39,] Uino yanotahuwA yugofarN lahumo maA qad salafa [If they desist, what hath already past shall be forgiven them]; and [in verse 19 of the same ch.,] waUino taEuwduwA naEudo [But if ye return to attacking the Apostle, we will return to assisting him]. (Mughnee, K.) [On the difference between it and UicA, see the latter.] When either it or UicaA is immediately followed by a noun in the nom. case, the said noun is governed in that case by a verb necessarily suppressed, of which it is the agent; as in the saying, in the Kur [ix. 6], waUino OaHadN mina QlomuXorikiyna QstajaAraka; the complete phrase being waUini AsotajaAraka OaHadN mina QlomuXorikiyna QsotajaAraka [And if any one of the believers in a plurality of gods demand protection of thee, (if) he demand protection of thee]: so accord. to the generality of the grammarians. (I 'Ak p. 123.) Sometimes it is conjoined with the negative laA, and the ignorant may imagine it to be the exceptive UilRaA; as in [the saying in the Kur ix. 40,] UilRaA tanoSuruwhu faqad naSarahu QllRehu [If ye will not aid him, certainly God did aid him]; and [in the next preceding verse,] UilRaA tanofiruwA yuEacRibokumo [If ye will not go forth to war, He will punish you]. (Mughnee, K. *) It is sometimes used to denote one's feigning himself ignorant; as when you say to one who asks, “ Is thy child in the house? ” and thou hast knowledge thereof, Uino kaAna fiI AldRaAri OaEolamotuka bihi [If he be in the house, I will inform thee thereof]. (Msb.) And to denote one's putting the knowing in the predicament of the ignorant, in order to incite to the doing or continuing an action; as when you say, UinN kunota QbuniI faOaTiEoniI [If thou be my son, obey me]; as though you said, “ Thou knowest that thou art my son, and it is incumbent on the son to obey the father, and thou art not obedient; therefore do what thou art commanded to do. ” (Msb.) And sometimes it is divested of the conditional meaning, and becomes syn. with law; as in the saying, SalRi waUinN Eajazota Eani AlqiyaAm [Pray thou though thou be unable to stand;] i. e. pray
thou whether thou be able to stand or unable to do so; and in the saying, OakorimN ziyodFA waUino qaEada i. e. [Treat thou Zeyd with honour] though he be sitting; or, whether he sit or not. (Msb.) [UimRaA as a compound of the conditional UinN and the redundant maA, see in an art. of which AmA is the heading.]

[Secondly,] it is a negative, (S, Mughnee, K,) syn. with maA; (S;) and is put before a nominal proposition; (Mughnee, K;) as in the saying [in the Kur lxvii. 20], Uini QlokaAfiruwna UilRaA fiI guruwrK [The unbelievers are not in aught save in a deception]; (S, Mughnee, K;) and before a verbal proposition; as in [the Kur ix. 108,] Uino OaradonaA UilRaA QloHusonaI [We desired not, or meant not, aught save that which is best]. (Mughnee, K.) The assertion of some, that the negative UinN does not occur except where it is followed by UilRaA, as in the instances cited above, or by lamRaA, with tesh-deed, which is syn. therewith, as, accord. to a reading of some of the Seven [Readers], in the saying [in the Kur lxxxvi. 4], Uino kulRu nafosK lamRaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN, i. e., maA kulRu nafosK UilRaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [There is not any soul but over it is a guardian], is refuted by the sayings in the Kur [x. 69 and lxxii. 26], Uino Eindakumo mino suloTaAnK bihecaA [meaning, accord. to the Jel., Ye have no proof of this that ye say], and Uino OadoriyOaqariybN maA tuwEaduwna [I know not whether that with which ye are threatened be nigh]. (Mughnee, K. *) The conditional and the negative both occur in the saying in the Kur [xxxv. 39], walaYino zaAlataA Uino OamosakahumaA mino OaHadK mino baEodihi [And I swear that, if they should quit their place, not any one should withhold them after Him]: the former is conditional; and the latter is negative, and is [part of] the complement of the oath which is denoted by the l prefixed to the former; the complement of the condition being necessarily suppressed. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a nominal proposition, it has no government, accord. to Sb and Fr; but Ks and Mbr allow its governing in the manner of layosa; and Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr reads, [in the Kur vii. 193,] Uini QlRaciyna tadoEuwna mino duwni QllRehi EibaAdFA OamovaAlakumN [Those whom ye invoke beside God, or others than God, are not men like you]: also, the people of El-'Áliyeh have been heard to say, UinN OaHadN xayorFAmino OaHdK UilRaA biAlEaAfiyapi [Any one is not better than any other one, except by means of health, or soundness]; and Uino celika naAfiEaka walaA DaArRaka [That is not profitable to thee nor injurious to thee]: as an ex. of its occurrence without government, which is mostly the case, the saying of some, qaAYmN UinRa↓ may be explained as originally UinN OanaA qaAYimN [I am not standing]; the O of OanaA being elided for no reason in itself, and the n of UinN being incorporated into the n of OanaA, and the A of this latter being elided in its conjunction with the following word; but UinRa qaAYimFA has also been heard. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it occurs [as a negative] in the complement of an oath: you say, waQllRehi UinN faEalotu, meaning maA faEalotu [By God, I did not]. (S.)

[Thirdly,] it is a contraction of UinRa, and is put before a nominal and before a verbal proposition. (Mughnee, K.) In the former case, it is made to govern and is made to have no government: (S, * K:) [i. e.] in this case, it is allowable to make it govern; contr. to the opinion of the Koofees: (Mughnee:) Lth says that he who uses the contracted form of UinRa uses the nom. case with it, except that some of the people of El-Hijáz use the accus. case with it: (T:) thus it is said, accord. to one reading, [in the Kur xi. 113,] Uino kulRaA lamaA layuwafRiyanRahumN rabRuka OaEomaAlahumN [Verily all of them, thy Lord will indeed fully render them the recompense of their works]: (T, Mughnee:) Fr says, We have not heard the Arabs use the contracted form and make it to govern, unless with a pronoun, in which case the desinential syntax is not apparent; and he adds that in the instance cited above, they make kulRA to be governed in the accus. case by lywfRynRhm; as though the phrase were layuwafRiyanRahumo kulRaA; and that kulRu would be proper; for you say, Uino zayodN laqaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]: (T:) the ex. given by Sb is, Uino EamorFA lamunTaliqN [Verily 'Amr is going away]. (Mughnee.) But it is [most] frequently made to have no government; as in the saying [in the Kur xliii. 34 accord. to one reading], waUino kulRu celika lamaA mataAEu QloHayaApi QldRunoyaA [And verily all that is the furniture of the present life]; and, accord. to the reading of Hafs, [and of 'Ásim and Kh, in the Kur xx. 66, respecting which see UinRa,] Uino hecaAni lasaAHiraAni [Verily these two are enchanters]; &c. (Mughnee.) When it is put before a verbal proposition, it is necessarily made to have no government: (Mughnee, K:) and in most cases the verb is a preterite and of the kind called naAsix [which effects a change of the grammatical form or of the meaning in a nominal proposition before which it is placed]; as in the saying [in the Kur ii. 138], waUino kaAnatN lakabiyrapF [And verily it was a great matter]; and [in the Kur xvii. 75,] waUino kaAduwA layafotinuwnaka [And verily they were near to seducing thee]; (Mughnee;) in which last ex. AZ says, it means laqado, i. e. without doubt; and so in the same ch. vv. 78 and 108: (T:) less frequently it is an aor. of a verb of this kind; as in the saying [in the Kur xxvi. 186], waUino naZunRuka lamina QlokaAcibyna [And verily we think thee to be of the number of the liars]: and both these kinds of expression may be taken as exs. to be imitated: less frequently than this it is a preterite of a verb not of the kind termed nasx; as in the saying [of a poet],

[May thy right arm, or hand, dry up, or become unsound! verily thou hast slain a Muslim]; but this may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated; contr. to the opinion of Akh; for he allows the phrase, Uino qiAma laOanaA [Verily I stood], and UinN qaEada lOanota [Verily thou sattest]: and less frequently than this it is an aor. of a verb not of the kind termed nAsx; as in the saying, Uino yaziynuka lanafosuka waUinN yaXiynuka lahiyahN [Verily thy soul is that which beautifies thee, and it is that which deforms thee]; and this, by common consent, may not be taken as an ex. to be imitated. (Mughnee.) Wherever you find UinN with la after it, decide that it is originally UinRa; (Mughnee, K;) as in the exs. above: but respecting this l there is a difference of opinion: see this letter. (Mughnee.) J says, (TA,) UinN is sometimes a contraction of UinRa, and this must have l put before its predicate, to compensate for what is elided, of the doubled letter; as in the saying in the Kur [lxxxvi. 4, accord. to him who reads lamaA instead of lamRaA], Uino kulRu nafosK lamaA EalayohaA HaAfiZN [Verily every soul hath over it a guardian]; and in the saying, UinN zaydN laOaxuwka [Verily Zeyd is thy brother]; in order that it may not be confounded with UinN which is syn. with the negative maA: (S, TA:) but IB says, l is here introduced to distinguish between negation and affirmation, and this Uino has neither subject nor predicate; so J's saying that the l is put before its predicate is without meaning: and this l is sometimes introduced with the objective complement of a verb; as in Uino Darabotu lazayodFA [Verily I struck, or beat, Zeyd]; and with the agent; as in Uino qaAma lazayodN [Verily Zeyd stood]. (TA.) When the contracted Uino governs, this l is not necessary; so you may say, Uino zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]; because in this case it cannot be confounded with the negative; for the negative does not render the subject mansoob and the predicate marfooa: and when it does not govern, if the meaning is apparent, the l is not needed; as in

L.foreign: wanaHonu OubaApu AlDRayomi mino Mli maAlikK

sense.s: [And we are persons who refuse to submit to injury, of the family of Málik: and verily the family of Málik are generous in respect of their origins]; kaAnato being here for lakaAnatN. (I 'Ak p. 99.)
[Fourthly,] it is redundant, (S, Mughnee, K,) occurring with maA; as in the saying, maA Uino yaquwmu zayodN [Zeyd does not stand]; (S;) and in the saying [of a poet],

L.foreign: kaA Uino Oatayota biXoICK Oanota takorahuhu

sense.s: [Thou didst not a thing which thou dislikest]. (Mughnee, K: in the CK Aatotu.) It is mostly thus used after the negative mA, when put before a verbal proposition; as above; or before a nominal proposition; as in the saying,
[And our habit is not cowardice; but our destinies and the good fortune of others caused our being defeated]: and in this case it prevents the government of mA, as in this verse: but in the saying,

L.foreign: baniI gudaAnapa maA Uino Oanotumu cahabFA

sense.s:
[Sons of Ghudáneh, ye are not indeed gold, nor silver, or pure silver, but ye are pottery], accord. to him who relates it thus, saying chbFA and SryfFA, in the accus. case, it is explained as a negative, corroborative of mA: (Mughnee:) and accord. to J,
(TA,) the negatives maA and UinN are sometimes thus combined for corroboration; as in the saying of the rájiz, (El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee, TA,)

[We have not indeed seen a king who has made a hostile incursion possessing more numerous sheep, or goats, and camels, than he]; (S, TA;) but IB says that An is here redundant, not a negative. (TA.) Sometimes it is redundant after the conjunct noun maA; as in the saying,

L.foreign: yurajiIR AlmaroUu maA UinN laA yaraAhu

sense.s: [Man hopes for that which he will not see; for calamities intervene as obstacles in the way to what is nearest thereof]. (Mughnee.) And after the maA termed maSodariyRap, (Mughnee,) [i. e.,] after the adverbial maA [which is of the kind termed mSdryRp]; (TA;) as in the saying (of Maaloot El-Kurey'ee, cited by Sb, TA),

L.foreign: warajRi AlfataI liloxayori maA Uino raOayotahu

sense.s: [And hope thou that the youth is destined for good as long as thou hast seen him not ceasing to increase in good with age]. (Mughnee.) And after the inceptive OalaA; as in the saying,

L.foreign: OalaA Uino saraI layoliI fbitRu kaYiybaA

sense.s: [Now he journeyed on, or during, that my night, and I passed the night in an evil state, broken in spirit by grief, being fearful that the distance to which he was going with Ghadoob (a woman so named) would become far]. (Mughnee.) And before the meddeh denoting disapproval: [for] Sb heard a man, on its being said to him, “ Wilt thou go forth if the desert become plentiful in herbage? ” reply, OaOanaA UiniyhN [What, I, indeed?] disapproving that he should think otherwise than that. (Mughnee. [See also art. AnI.])

[Fifthly,] it is syn. with qado: so it is said to be in the saying [in the Kur lxxxvii. 9], Uino nafaEati QlcRikoraI [Admonition hath profited], (T, Mughnee, K,) by IAar (T) and by Ktr: (Mughnee:) and Abu-l-' Abbás relates that the Arabs say, UinN nafaEati QlcRikoraI meaning qadoqaAma zayodN [Zeyd has stood]; and he adds, that Ks states his having heard them say so, and having thought that it expressed a condition, but that he asked them, and they answered that they meant qadoqaAma zayodN, and not maA qaAma zayodN. (T.) [So too, accord. to the K, in all the exs. cited in the next sentence as from the Mughnee; but this is evidently a mistake, occasioned by an accidental omission.]

[Sixthly,] it is asserted also by the Koofees, that it is syn. with Uico, in the following exs.: in the Kur [v. 62], waQtRaquwA QllReha UinN kunotumo muWominiyna [And fear ye God, because ye are believers: and so, accord. to AZ, as is said in the T, in a similar instance in the Kur ii. 278: and in the same, iv. 62]: and [in the Kur xlviii. 27,] latado xulunRa Qlmasojida QloHaraAma Uino XaMCa Mminiyna [Ye shall assuredly enter the sacred mosque, because God hath willed, in security]: and in like instances, when the verb therein expresses what is held sure to happen or to have happened: and in the saying,

L.foreign: jihaArFA walamo tagoDabo liqatoli Qboni HaAzimi

sense.s: [Art thou angry because the ears of Kuteybeh have been cut, openly, or publicly, and wast not angry for the slaughter of Ibn-Házim?]: (Mughnee:) but in all these instances [it is sufficiently obvious that] An may be otherwise explained. (Mughnee, K.)

[Seventhly,] it is sometimes syn. with UicaA; as in the Kur [ix. 23], laA tatRaxicuwA MbaMCakumo waUixowaAnakumo OawoliyaMCa Uini QsotaHabRuwA QlokuforaEalaI QloUiymaAni [Take not ye your fathers and your brethren as friends when they love unbelief above belief]; and in the same [xxxiii. 49], waQmoraOapF muWominapF Uino wahabato nafosahaA lilnRabiIR [And a believing woman when she giveth herself to the Prophet]: so says AZ. (T.)

[Eighthly,] it is used for UimRaA, (Mughnee and K, voce UimRaA,) distinct from UimRaA which is a compound of the conditional UinN and the redundant maA. (Mughnee ibid.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce UimRaA in the present work, commencing with the words saqatohu AlrRawaAEidu.]
Oana: see Oano, in four places.

OanRa is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative; and is originally UinRa; therefore Sb has not mentioned it among those particles [as distinct from UinRa, from which, however, it is distinguished in meaning]: (I 'Ak p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle; (I 'Ak, Mughnee;) a particle governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case, (S, I 'Ak, Mughnee, K,) combining with what follows it to form an equivalent to an inf. n., (S,) [for,] accord. to the most correct opinion, it is a conjunct particle, which, together with its two objects of government, is explained by means of an inf. n. (Mughnee.) If the predicate is derived, the inf. n. by means of which it is explained is of the same radical letters; so that the implied meaning of balaganiy OanRaka tanoTaliqu [It has come to my knowledge, or been related to me, or been told to me, or it came to my knowledge, &c., that thou goest away], or OanRaka munoTaliqN [that thou art going away], is balaganiy AlAinoTilaAqu [or rather QnoTilaAquka thy going away has come to my knowledge, &c.]; and hence, the implied meaning of balaganiI OanRaka fiy AldRaAri [It has come to my knowledge, &c., that thou art in the house] is balaganiI QsotiqoraAruka fiy AldRaAri [thy remaining in the house has come to my knowledge, &c.], because thea predicate is properly a word suppressed from AistaqarRa or musotaqirRN: and if the predicate is underived, the implied meaning is explained by the word kawoni; so that the implied meaning of balaganiI OanRa hecA zayodN [It has come to my knowledge, &c., that this is Zeyd] is balaganiI kawonuhu zayodFA [his being Zeyd has come to my knowledge, &c.]; for the relation of every predicate expressed by an underived word to its subject may be denoted by a word signifying “ being; ” so that you say, hecaA zayodN and, if you will, hecaA kaAYinN zayodFA; both signifying the same. (Mughnee.) There are cases in which either OanRa or UinRa may be used: [see the latter, in twelve places:] other cases in which only the former may be used: and others in which only the latter. (I 'Ak p. 91.) The former only may be used when the implied meaning is to be explained by an inf. n. (I 'Ak, K.) Such is the case when it occurs in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the nom. case; as in yuEojibuniI OanRaka qaAYimN [It pleases me that thou art standing], i. e. qiyaAmuka [thy standing pleases me]: or in the place of a noun governed by a verb in the accus. case; as in Earafotu OatRaka qaAYimN [I knew that thou wast standing], i. e. qiyaAmaka [thy standing]: or in the place of a noun governed in the gen. case by a particle; as in Eajibotu mino OanRaka qaAYimN [I wondered that thou wast standing], i. e. mino qiyaAmka [at, or by reason of, thy standing]: (I 'Ak p. 91:) [and sometimes a preposition is understood; as in laA XakRa OanRahu kacaA, for laA XakRa fiI OanRahu kacaA There is no doubt that it is thus, i. e. laA XRkRa fiI kawonihi kacaA There is no doubt of its being thus:] and OanRa must be used after lawo; as in lawo OanRaka qaAYimN laqumotu [If that thou wert standing, I had stood, or would have stood, i. e. lawo vabata qiyaAmuka, or lawo qiyaAmuka vaAbitN, accord. to different opinions, both meaning if thy standing were a fact: see I 'Ak pp. 305 and 306]. (K.) Sometimes its O is changed into E; so that you say, Ealimotu EanRaka munoTaliqN [meaning I knew that thou wast going away]. (M.)

With k prefixed to it, it is a particle of comparison, (S, * M, TA,) [still] governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case: (TA:) you say, kaOanRa zayodFA EamorNw [It is as though Zeyd were 'Amr], meaning that Zeyd is like 'Amr; as though you said, UinRa zayodFA kaAYinN kaEamorKw [verily, Zeyd is like 'Amr]: [it is to be accounted for by an ellipsis: or] the k is taken away from the middle of this proposition, and put at its commencement, and then the kesreh of UinRa necessarily becomes changed to a fet-hah, because UinRa cannot be preceded by a preposition, for it never occurs but at the commencement [of a proposition]. (IJ, M.) Sometimes, kaOanRa denotes denial; as in the saying, kaOanRaka OamiyrunaA fataOomuranaA [As though thou wert our commander so that thou shouldst command us], meaning thou art not our commander [that thou shouldst command us]. (TA.) It also denotes wishing; as in the saying, kaOonRaka biy qado qulotu AlXRiEora faOujiydahu, meaning Would that I had poetized, or versified, so that I might do it well: (TA:) [an elliptical form of speech, of which the implied meaning seems to be, would that I were as though thou sawest me that I had poetized, &c.; or the like: for] you say [also], kaOanRiI bika meaning kaOanRiI OaboSuru bika [It is as though I saw thee]; i. e. I know from what I witness of thy condition to-day how thy condition will be tomorrow; so that it is as though I saw thee in that condition: (Har p. 126: [see also bi; near
the end of the paragraph:]) [thus,] kaOanRa also denotes knowing; and also thinking; [the former as in the saying immediately preceding, and] as when you say, kaOanRa QllReha yafoEalu maA yaXaMCu [I know, or rather it appears, as though seen, that God does what He wills]; and [the latter as when you say,] kaOanRaka xaArijN [I think, or rather it seems, that Thou art going forth]. (TA.)

[When it has The affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. Or Pl., you say, OanRiI and OanRaniI, and OanRaA and OanRanaA: and When it has also the k of comparison prefixed to It,] you say, kaOanRiI and kaOanRaniI, [and kaOanRaA and kaOanRanaA,] like as you say, lekinRiI and lekinRaniI [&c.]. (S.)

As OanRa is a derivative from UinRa, it is correctly asserted by Z that OanRamaA imports restriction, like UinRamaA↓; both of which occur in the saying in the Kur [xxi. 108], yuwHaI UilaIRa OanRamaA qulo UinRamaA↓
Uilehukumo UilehF waAHidN [Say thou, It is only revealed to me that your God is only one God]: the former is for the restricting of the quality to the qualified; and the latter, for the reverse: (Mughnee, K:) i. e. the former is for the restricting of the revelation to the declaration of the unity; and the latter, for the restricting of “ your God ” to unity: (Marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee:) but these words of the Kur do not imply that nothing save the unity was revealed to the Prophet; for the restriction is limited to the case of the discourse with the believers in a plurality of gods; so that the meaning is, there has not been revealed to me [aught], respecting the godhead, except the unity; not the attribution of any associate to God. (Mughnee.) [OanRamaA, however, does not always import restriction; nor does always even UinRamaA↓: in each of these, mA is what is termed kaAfRapN; i. e., it restricts the particle to which it is affixed from exercising any government; and sometimes has no effect upon the signification of that particle: (see art. maA; and see UinRamaA, below, voce UinRa:) thus, for instance, in the Kur viii. 28, waQEolamuwA OanRamaA OamowaAlukumo fitonapF means And know ye that your possessions and your children are a trial; not that they are only a trial. When it has the k of comparison prefixed to it, it is sometimes contracted; as in the following ex.:] a poet says,
[As though, by reason of their mincing gait, they were walking upon tragacanthas; and they were laughing so as to discover teeth like hailstones: kaOamRaA being for kaOanRamaA. (IAar.)
OanRa is someTimes contracted into Oano; (S, Mughnee;) and in This case, it governs in the manner already exPlained, voce Oano. (Mughnee.)

It is also syn. with laEalRa; (Sb, S, M, Mughnee, K;) as in the saying, Aiyti AlsRuwqa OanRaka taXotariI lanaA XayoYFA [Come thou to the market; may-be thou wilt buy for us something; Aiyti being originally AiYoti]; i. e. laEalRaka: (Sb, M, Mughnee, K: *) and, accord. to some, (M, Mughnee, K,) so in the Kur [vi. 109], where it is said, wamaA yuXoEirukumo OanRahaA UicaA jaMCato laA yuWominuwna [And what maketh you to know? (meaning, maketh you to know that they will believe when it cometh? i. e. ye do not know that: Jel:) Maybe, when it cometh, they will not believe]: (S, M, Mughnee, K:) thus accord. to this reading: (Mughnee, K:) and Ubeí here reads laEalRahaA. (S.) OanRa and laOanRa and lawo OanRa are all syn. with EalRa and laEalRa; and OanRiI and OanRaniI, and laOanRiI and lOanRaniI, and luwo OanRiI and lawo OanRiniI, with EalRiI and laEalRiI. (K voce laEalRa.)
It is also syn. with Oajalo [Yes, or yea; or it is as thou sayest]. (M, TA.) [See also UinRa as exemplified by a verse commencing with wayaqulona and by a saying of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr.]

UinRa is one of the particles which annul the quality of the inchoative, like OanRa, of which it is the original: (I 'Ak p. 90:) it is a corroborative particle, (I 'Ak, Mughnee,) corroborating the predicate; (S, K;) governing the subject in the accus. case and the predicate in the nom. case; (S, I 'Ak, Mughnee, K;) [and may generally be rendered by Verily, or certainly, or the like; exactly agreeing with the Greek ὃτι, as used in Luke vii. 16 and in many other passages in the New Testament; though it often seems to be nothing more than a sign of inception, which can hardly be rendered at all in English; unless in pronunciation, by laying a stress upon the predicate, or upon the copula;] as in the saying, UinRa zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily, or certainly, Zeyd is standing; or simply, Zeyd is standing, if we lay a stress upon standing, or upon is]. (I 'Ak p. 90.) But sometimes it governs both the subject and the predicate in the accus. case; as in the saying,

L.foreign: UicaA QXotadRa junoHu AllRayoli falotaOoti walotakunN

sense.s: [When the darkness of night becomes, or shall become, intense, then do thou come, and let thy steps be light: verily our guardians are lions]; (Mughnee, K; [but in the latter, for QXotadRa, we find QsowadRa, so that the meaning is, when the first portion of the night becomes, or shall become, black, &c.;]) and as in a trad. in which it is said, AnRa qaEora jahanRama saboEiyna xariyfFA [Verily the bottom of Hell is a distance of seventy years of journeying]: (Mughnee, K:) the verse, however, is explained by the supposition that it presents a denotative of state [in the last word, which is equivalent to XijoEaAnFA or the like], and that the predicate is suppressed, the meaning being, taloqaAhumo OusodFA [thou wilt find them lions]; and the trad. by the supposition that qaEora is an inf. n., and saboEiyna is an adverbial noun, so that the meaning is, the reaching the bottom of hell is [to be accomplished in no less time than] in seventy years. (Mughnee.) And sometimes the inchoative [of a proposition] after it is in the nom. case, and its subject is what is termed Damiyru XaOonK, suppressed; as in the saying of Mohammad, UinRa mino OaXadRi AlnRaAsi EacaAbFA yawoma Alqiyemapi AlmuSawRiruwna [Verily, (the case is this:) of the men most severely to be punished, on the day of resurrection, are the makers of images], originally UinRahu, i. e. UinRa AlXRaOona; (Mughnee, K; *) and as in the saying in the Kur [xx. 66], UinRa hecaAni lasaAHiraAni, [accord. to some,] as will be seen in what follows. (TA.)

Of the two particles UinRa and OanRa↓, in certain cases only the former may be used; and in certain other cases either of them may be used. (I' Ak p. 91.) The former must be used when it occurs inceptively, (Kh, T, I' Ak p. 92, Mughnee, K,) having nothing before it upon which it is syntactically dependent, (Kh, T,) with respect to the wording or the meaning; (K;) as in UinRa zayodFA qaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing]. (I' Ak, K.) It is used after OalaA, (I' Ak, K,) the inceptive particle, (I' Ak,) or the particle which is employed to give notice [of something about to be said]; (K;) as in OalaA UinRa zayodFA qaAYimN [Now surely Zeyd is standing]. (I' Ak K.) And when it occurs at the commencement of the complement of a conjunct noun; (I' Ak, K; *) as in jaMCa AlRaciI UinRahu qaAYimN [He who is standing came]; (I' Ak;) and in the Kur [xxviii. 76], waMtayonaAhu mina Qlokunuwri maA UinRa mafaAtiHahu latanuwoCu biQloEuSobapi OuwliI AlquwRapi [And we gave him, of treasures, that whereof the keys would weigh down the company of men possessed of strength]. (I' Ak, * K, * TA.) And in the complement of an oath, (I' Ak, K,) when its predicate has la, (I' Ak,) or whether its subject or its predicate has la or has it not; (K;) as in waQllRehi UinRa zayodFA laqaAYimN [By Allah, verily Zeyd is standing], (I' Ak,) and UinRahu qaAYimN: or, as some say, when you do not employ the l, the particle is with fet-h; as in qaAYimN waQllRehi OanRaka↓ [I swear by Allah that thou art standing]; mentioned by Ks as thus heard by him from the Arabs: (TA:) but respecting this case we shall have to speak hereafter. (I' Ak.) And when it occurs after the word qawolN or a derivative thereof, in repeating the saying to which that word relates; (Fr, T, I' Ak, * K; *) as in the saying [in the Kur iv. 156], waqawolihimo UinRaA qatalonaA QlomasiyHa [And their saying, Verily we have slain the Messiah]; (Fr, T;) and qulotu UinRa zayodFA qaAYimN [I said, Verily Zeyd is standing]; (I' Ak;) and [in the Kur v. 115,] qaAla QllRehu UinRI munRzRiluhaA Ealayokumo [God said, Verily I will cause it to descend unto you]; accord. to the dial. of him who does not pronounce it with fet-h: (K:) but when it occurs in explaining what is said, you use OanRa↓; as in the saying, qado qulotu laka kalaAmFA HasanFA OanRa OabaAka XariyfN waOanRaka EaAqilN [I have said to thee a good saying; that thy father is noble and that thou art intelligent]; (Fr, T;) or when the word signifying “ saying ” is used as meaning “ thinking; ” as in Oataquwlu OanRa zayodFA qaAYimN [Dost thou say that Zeyd is standing?], meaning OataZunRu [Dost thou think?]. (I' Ak.) Also, when it occurs in a phrase denotative of state; (I' Ak;) [i. e.,] after the w denotative of state; (K;) as in zurotuhu waUinRiI cuwOamalK [I visited him, I verily having hope, or expectation]; (I' Ak;) and in jaMCa ziyodN wa UinRa yadahu EalaI raOosihi [Zeyd came, he verily having his hand upon his head]. (K.) And when it occurs in a phrase which is the predicate of a proper (as
opposed to an ideal) substantive; (I' Ak, K; *) as in zayodN UinRahu qaAYimN [Zeyd, verily he is standing], (I' Ak,) or caAhibN [going away]; contr. to the assertion of Fr. (K.) And when it occurs before the l which suspends the grammatical government of a verb of the mind, preceding it, with respect to its objective complements; (I' Ak, K; *) as in Ealimotu UinRa zayodFA laqaAYimN [I knew Zeyd verily was standing]; (I' Ak;) and in [the Kur lxiii. 1,] waQllRehu yaEolamu UinRaka larasuwluhu [And God knoweth thou verily art his apostle]: (K:) but if the l is not in its predicate, you say, OanRa↓; as in Ealimotu OanRa zayodFA qaAYimN [I knew that Zeyd was standing]. (I' Ak.) And in the like of the saying in the Kur [ii. 171], waUinRa QlRaciyna QxotalafuwA fiI QlokitaAbi lafiI XaqaAqK baEiydK [And verily they who differ among themselves respecting the book are in an opposition remote from the truth]; because of the l [of inception] which occurs after it, in lafiI: (Ks, A 'Obeyd:) the l of inception which occurs before the predicate of UinRa should properly commence the sentence; so that UinRa zayodFA laqaAYimN [Verily Zeyd is standing] should properly be laUinRa zayodFA qaAYimN; but as the l is a corroborative and UinRa is a corroborative, they dislike putting two particles of the same meaning together, and therefore they put the l later, transferring it to the predicate: Mbr allows its being put before the predicate of OanRa↓; and thus it occurs in an unusual reading of the saying [in the Kur xxv. 22], UilRaA OanRahumo layaOokuluwna QlTRaEaAma [But they ate food]; but this is explained by the supposition that the l is here redundant: (I' Ak p. 95:) this is the reading of Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr: others read, UilRaA UinRahumo layaOokuluna AlTRaEaAma [but verily they ate food]: and UinRa [as well as OanRa↓] is used after the exceptive UilRaA when it is not followed by the l [of inception]. (TA.) Also, When it occurs after Hayovu; as in Aijoliso Hayovu UinRa zayodFA jaAlisN [Sit thou where Zeyd is sitting]. (I' Ak p. 92, and k) And after HatRaI; as in mariDa zayodN HatRaI UinRahumo laA yarojuwnahu [Zeyd has fallen sick, so that verily they have no hope for him: whereas after a particle governing the gen. case, [i. e. a preposition,] you say, OanRa↓. (IHsh in De Sacy's Anthol. Gr. Ar. P. 76.)

Either of these two forms may be used after UicaA denoting a thing's happening suddenly, or unexpectedly; as in xarajotu faUicaA UinRa zayodFAqaAYimN [I went forth, and lo, verily Zeyd was standing], and zayodFA qaAYimN faUicaA OanRa↓ [and lo, or at that present time, Zeyd's standing]; in which latter case, OanRa with its complement is [properly] an inchoative, and its enunciative is UicaA; the implied meaning being, and at that present time was the standing of Zeyd: or it may be that the enunciative is suppressed, and that the implied meaning is, [and lo, or at that present time,] the standing of Zeyd was an event come to pass. (I' Ak p. 93.) Also, when occurring in the complement of an oath, if its enunciative is without l: (I' Ak:) [see exs. given above:] or, as some say, only OanRa↓ is used in this case. (TA.) Also, when occurring after fa denoting the complement of a condition; as in mano yaOotiniI faUinRahu mukoramN [He who cometh to me, verily he shall be treated with honour], and mukoramN OanRahu↓; in which latter case, OanRa with its complement is an inchoative, and the enunciative is suppressed; the implied meaning being, honourable treatment of him shall be an event come to pass: or it may be an enunciative to an inchoative suppressed; the implied meaning being, his recompense shall be honourable treatment. (I' Ak p. 94.) Also, when occurring after an inchoative having the meaning of a saying, its enunciative being a saying, and the sayer being one; as in xayoru Alqawoli UinRI OaHomadu [The best saying is, Verily I praise God], and OaHomadu OanRiI↓; in which latter case, OanRa with its complement is an enunciative of xayoru; the implied meaning being, the best saying is the praising of God [or my praising of God]. (I' Ak ubi suprà.) You also say, labRayoka UinRa AlHamodalaka [At thy service! Verily praise belongeth to Thee! O God]; commencing [with UinRa] a new proposition: and sometimes one says, OanRa↓; meaning biOanRa AlHamoda laka [because praise belongeth to Thee]. (Msb.)
The cases in which Uin may not be used in the place of OanRa have been mentioned above, voce OanRa.

[When it has the affixed pronoun of the first person, sing. or pl.,] you say, UinRiI and UinRaniI, (S,) and UinRaA and UinRanaA, (TA,) like as you say lekinRiI and lekinRiniI [&c.]. (S.) UinRa as a contraction of UinRa OanaA has been mentioned above, as occurring in the phrase UinRa qaAYimN, voce Uino, q. v.

Accord. to the grammarians, (T,) UinRamaA is a compound of UinRa and maA, (T, S,) which latter prevents the former's having any government: (T:) it imports restriction; like OanRamaA, which see above, voce OanRa, in three places: (Mughnee, K:) [i. e.] it imports the restriction of that which it precedes to that which follows it; as in UinRamaA zayodN munoTaliqN [Zeyd is only going away], and UinRamaA yanoTaliqu zayodN [Only Zeyd goes away]: (Bd in ii. 10:) [in other words,] it is used to particularize, or specify, or distinguish a thing from other things: (S:) it affirms a thing in relation to that which is mentioned after it, and denies it in relation to other things; (T, S;) as in the saying in the Kur [ix. 60], UinRamaA QlSRadaqaAtu lilofuqaraMCi [The contributions levied for pious uses are only, or but, for the poor]: (S:) but El- Ámidee and AHei say that it does not import restriction, but only corroboration of an affirmation, because it is a compound of the corroborative UinRa and the redundant maA which restrains the former from exercising government, and that it has no application to denote negation implied in restriction, as is shown by the trad., UinRamaA AlRiribaA fiI AlnRasiyoYapi [which must mean, Verily usury is in the delay of payment], for usury is in other things beside that here mentioned, as ribaA AlfDoli [or profit obtained by the superior value of a thing received over that of a thing given], by common consent: (Kull p. 76:) some say that it necessarily imports restriction: J says what has been cited above from the S: some say that it has an overt signification in denoting restriction, and is susceptible of the meaning of corroboration: some say the reverse of this: El-Ámidee says that if it were [properly] restrictive, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import; but to this it may be replied, that if it were [properly] corroborative, its occurrence in another sense would be at variance with the original import: it [therefore] seems that it is susceptible of both these meanings, bearing one or the other according as this or that suits the place. (Msb.) UinRamaA is to be distinguished from UinRa with the conjunct [noun] maA, which does not restrain it from governing [though its government with this is not apparent, and which is written separately]; as in UinRa maA Einoka HasanN meaning Verily what is with thee is good, and in UinRa maA faEalota HasanN meaning Verily thy deed is good. (I' Ak pp. 97 and 98.)
