OuwlaI fem. of OawRalu: see the latter in art. wOl.
OuwlaI as a pl., and its var. OuwlaMCa; and OuwleYika, or OuwlaMYika; &c.: see OulaI, in art. AlI.
OawamRu for OaOamRu: see art. Am.
1. Mna, aor. yaWuwnu, inf. n. OawonN, He was, or became, at rest, or at ease; he rested in a journey. (IAar, T.)

Ounotu, aor. and inf. n. as above, I enjoyed a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, S, M, K.)
I was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (S, K.)

I was, or became, gentle; or I acted gently: (T, S, M, Msb, K:) and I acted, or proceeded, with moderation, without haste or hurry, in pace or journeying: (M:) I went gently, softly, or in a leisurely manner: (S, K:) OawonN [the inf. n.] is formed by substitution [of O for h] from hawonN. (S.) You say, Ounotu biAlXRaIoCi, and EalaI AlXRaIoCi, I was gentle, or I acted gently, with the thing; (M;) and fiI AlOamori in the affair. (Msb.) And Ouno EalaI nafosika Act thou gently with thyself, or be thou gentle, in pace or journeying: and proceed thou with moderation, without haste or hurry: (T, S:) said in the latter sense to one who has become unsteady, or irresolute. (T.) [In like manner,] you say, EalaI qadorika OawRino↓, meaning AitRaYido EalaI naHowika [app. Act thou with moderation, gentleness, deliberation, or in a leisurely manner, according to thine ability, or to the measure of thine ability; for qadorN and naHowN are both syn. with miqodaArN]. (T, K.) And fiI sayorikumo OawRinuwA↓ Proceed ye with moderation in your course or pace or journeying. (ISk, T.) And fiI taOawRana↓ AlOamori He paused, or was patient, in the affair. (M.)
OawonN also signifies The being weary, or fatigued; like OayonN. (M.) [Whether, in this sense, it have a verb, is doubtful: see its syn. here mentioned.]

Also The putting oneself to trouble, or inconvenience, for the sake of what one may expend upon himself and his family. (M.) And hence, accord. to one [whose name is imperfectly written in the TA], the word maWuwnapN↓, [as being originally maOowunapN,] of the measure mafoEulapN: but others say that it is of the measure faEuwlapN, from maOanotu. (TA.)
Mna Oawonuka↓ and OawaAnuka [and Oayonuka] signify the same. (M.) [See art. Ayn.]
2: see 1, in two places.
5: see 1.
AlMna and its vars.: see art. Ayn. [Accord. to some, it belongs to the present art., in which it is mentioned in the Msb.]
OawonN: see 1 [of which it is the inf. n.]: and see also what next follows.

OawaAnN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and UiwaAnN↓, (T, M, Msb, K,) the latter mentioned by Ks on the authority of Aboo-Jámi', but the former is the usual mode of pronouncing it, (T,) and OawonN↓, (M,) A time; a season: pl. MwinapN; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) but Sb says MwnAtN; (M; [so in a copy of that work; app. MwinaAtN, as though pl. of MwinapN;]) and MyinapN is syn. with MwinapN. (AA, T, K.) You say, jaMCa OawaAnu Albarodi [The time, or season, of cold came]. (T.) And fulaAnN yaSonaEu celika AlOamora MwinapF, (S, K, *) and MyinapF, (K, [in the CK MYinapF,]) Such a one does that thing sometimes, leaving it undone sometimes. (S, K. *) And Oatayotuhu MynapF baEoda MyinapK I came to him times after times. (AA, T.) And MwinapF signifies Time after time. (TA, from a trad.) In the saying (of Aboo-Zubeyd, L),

(M,) or UiwaAnK, (L,) [They sought our reconciliation with them, but it was not the time that reconciliation should be sought], accord. to Abu-l- 'Abbás, the tenween of the last word is not a sign of the genitive case, but is, as in the instance of UicK, because of the suppression of a proposition to which the word should be prefixed, as when you say, jiYotu OawaAna qaAma zayodN I came at the time that Zeyd stood. (M, L.)
[Hence, OawaAnaYicK At that time or season; then; like HiynaYicK.]
UiwaAnN: see OawaAnN:
and see also UiyawaAnN.
MYinN [part. n. of 1:] A man enjoying a life of ease and plenty; a state of freedom from trouble or inconvenience, and toil or fatigue; a state of ease, repose, or tranquillity. (AZ, T, S, K.)

[Hence the saying,] riboEN MYin xayorN mino gibRK HaSoHaASK [An easy, or a gentle, journey in which the camels are watered only on the first and fourth days is better than a laborious, or quick, journey in which they are watered only on the first and third days]. (TA.) [The fem. is MYinapN: the pl. of which is OawaAYinu and MYinaAtN.] You say, bayonanaA wabayona makRFpa valaAvu layaAlK OawaAYinu Between us and Mekkeh are three nights of easy, or gentle, journeying: (S, K: *) and EaXorulayaAl MYinaAtN ten nights of easy journeying. (S, M, K.)

UiywaAnN and UiwaAnN↓ (T, S, M, Msb, K) [each] a foreign word, [i. e. Persian,] (M,) A chamber, or an apartment, (T, Msb,) or a large SufRap [i. e. porch, or roofed vestibule, or the like], (S, K,) similar to an Oazaj [or oblong arched or vaulted structure, or a portico], (T, S, M, K,) or built in the form of an Oazaj, (Msb,) not closed in the front, or face: (T, M, Msb: *) [and a palace; often used in this sense in Arabic as well as in Persian: and in the present day, the former, and more commonly liywaAn, which is Persian, is also applied to an estrade; a slightly-raised portion of the floor, generally extending nearly from the door to the end, or to each end, of a room:] pl. of the former, OawaAwiynu, (T, S, K,) because the sing. is originally UiwowaAnN, (S,) and UiywaAnaAtN; and pl. of the latter, OuwnN. (T, S, K.) Hence, UiywaAnu kisoraI [The great porch, or the palace, of Kisrà, or Chosroes, who is called SaAHibu AlUiywaAni]. (T, S, Msb.)
Also the latter, [and app., accord. to the Msb, the former also,] Any prop, or support, of a thing: (T, Msb:) particularly, a pole of a [tent of the kind called] xibaMC. (T.)
The UiywaAn of the lijaAm [is The headstall of the bridle; and] has for its pl. UiywaAnaAtN. (T, K.)
maWuwnapN: see 1, and see art. mOn.
1: and 2: see 5.

5. tOwRh; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and OwRh↓, (S, Mgh, K,) inf. n. taOowiypN; (S, K;) and Mha↓, inf. n. OawohN; (K;) He said Mhi or Oawohi &c. [i. e. Ah! or alas!]; (S, Mgh, K;) he moaned; or uttered a moan, or moaning, or prolonged voice of complaint; (S, TA;) i. q. tawajRaEa. (Msb.)

Mhi, (Az, S, Msb, K, &c.,) as also MhK, (IAmb, K,) and MhFA, and MhapF↓, (TA,) and Oawohi↓, (S, Msb, K,) and Oawoha↓, (ISd, K,) and Oawohu↓, (K,) and OawRiho↓, (S,) or OawRihi↓, (K,) and OawRaho↓, (Hr, Mgh, Msb, K,) so in some copies of the S, but in a copy in the author's handwriting MwRaho↓, there said to be with medd, and with teshdeed and fet-h to the w, and with the h quiescent, (TA,) [or,] accord. to Aboo- Tálib, MwRaho, with medd, thus pronounced by the vulgar, is wrong, (T in art. Aw,) and OawRaAh↓, and OawRuwh↓, [in both of which, and in some other forms which follow, it is doubtful whether the h be quiescent or movent, and if movent, with what vowel,] (TA,) and Mwuwhu↓, (K, TA,) or Oawuwhu↓, but said by ISd to be with medd, and mentioned by AHát as heard from the Arabs, (TA,) and OawataAh↓, (K, TA,) or OawataAhu↓, (CK,) or OawRataAh↓, and MwRataAh↓, (S, [in one copy of which the h is marked as quiescent,]) and MwayRaAh↓, (K, TA,) with medd, (TA,) or OawiyRaAhu↓, (CK,) and OawRi (S, Msb, K,) and Mwi, and MwK, (K, TA,) and waAhFA, and haAhN or haAhu, (TA,) [Ah! or alas!] a word imitative of the voice, cry, or exclamation, of the mutaOahRih; (Az and TA in explanation of Mhi;) [i. e.] a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) denoting the prolongation of the voice with complaint: (S, TA, after OawRaho or MwRaho:) sometimes, also, a man says Mhi from a motive of affection, or pity, or compassion, and of impatience: (Az, TA:) [and it is also said that] MhFA is a word expressive of grief or lamentation, or of most intense grief or lamentation or regret; [that] it is put in the accus. case as being used in the manner of inf. ns.; and [that] the hemzeh is originally w: but IAth says, MhFA is a word expressive of pain, grief, sorrow, lamentation, complaint, or moaning, used in relation to evil, like as waAhFA is used in relation to good: (TA in art. Ah:) and MwRaho and Mwi and MwK are cries uttered to horses, to make them return. (ISh and TA in art. AwI. See 2 in that art. in the present work.) You say, Mhi mino kacaA [Ah, or alas, on account of, or for, such a thing!]; (S, Msb;) and in like manner, Oawohi [&c.], followed by mino, and by li, (S, TA,) and by EalaI. (TA.) [See also OawRi in art. Aw.]
MhapN a subst. from taOawRaha; occurring in the saying of El-Muthakkib El-'Abdee,

[When I arise to saddle her, by night, she moans with the moaning of the sorrowful man]: (S, ISd:) ISd says that, in his opinion, the subst. is here put in the place of the inf. n., i. e. taOawRuh: (TA:) but some recite the verse differently, saying, OahRapa, from OahRa meaning tawajRaEa: (S:) and some say, tahawRahu haAhapa. (TA.) And hence the saying, in imprecating evil on a man, MhapF laka [May God cause moaning to thee!], and OawRapF laka, with the h suppressed, and with teshdeed to the w. (S.) [See also OawRapN in art. Aw.] And see Mhi above.

[Also] Measles: thus in the phrase, used in imprecating evil on a man, MhapF wamaAhapF [May God cause] measles and small-pox [to befall thee]! (K, * TA,) mentioned by Lh on the authority of Aboo-Khálid. (TA.)
Oawohi and eOawoha and Oawohu and OawRih &c.: see Mhi.

OawRaAhN A man often saying Ah! or alas! or often moaning: (Mgh:) or one who says Ah! or alas! from a motive of affection, or pity, or compassion, and fear: or mourning, or sorrowing, much, or often: (TA:) or compassionate; tender-hearted: or often praying, or frequent in prayer: (K, * TA:) or one who celebrates the praises of God, or praises Him greatly, or glorifies Him: or who praises much, or often: or who abases himself, or addresses himself with earnest supplication, [to God], confident of his prayer's being answered: (TA:) or one having certain knowledge (K, TA) of his prayer's being answered: (TA:) or inviting much, or often, to what is good: (TA:) or skilled in the law: or a believer; so in the Abyssinian language: (K:) occurring in the Kur [ix. 115 and xi. 77]. (TA.)
See also Mhi.
Oawuwhu, or Mwuwhu, and OawRuwh: see Mhi.
OawataAh, or OawataAhu, or OawRataAh, and MwRataAh: see Mhi.
OawiyRaAhu, or MwayRaAh: see Mhi.
mutaOawRihN [Saying Ah! &c.: (see the verb:) and] abasing himself; or addressing himself with earnest supplication [to God]. (TA.) [See also OawRaAhN.]

1. OawaI Uilayohi, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and OawaAhu, (M, Msb, K,) aor. yaOowiI, (T, S, Msb,) imperative Aiywi (T,) inf. n. OuwiIRu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) with damm, (K,) of the measure fuEuwlN, [originally OuwuwIN,] (S,) and UiwiIRN, (Fr, M, K,) with kesr, (K,) and UiwaMCN; (S;) and Alyh OwRI↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taOowiyapN; (K;) and tOwRI↓; (M, K;) and QOotawaI↓, (thus [more commonly AYtwI] accord. to a copy of the M,) or QtRawaI↓, (K,) like QtRaxaca, (TK,) and AiytawaI↓, (M, K,) both of the measure AftEl; (TA;) and MwaI↓ is used by some in the same sense, but rejected, in this sense, by several; (Msb;) the pronoun relating to a place of abode; (T, S, M, Msb, K;) He betook himself to it, or repaired to it, for lodging, covert, or refuge; (Mgh;) and [simply] he got him or got himself, betook himself, repaired, or resorted, to it; (T, Mgh;) he returned to it; (M;) he took up his abode in it; he lodged, or abode, or dwelt, in it. (Msb, K.) Hence, in the Kur [xi. 45], saMwiI UilaI jabalK yaEoSimuniI mina AlmaMCi [I will betake myself for refuge to a mountain that shall preserve me from the water]. (S.) AlOuwiIRu properly relates to living beings; but is used otherwise, metaphorically. (M.) In the saying of Lebeed,

[With a morning-potation of clear wine (xamorK being understood), and a female singer's straining of her chords, with a stringed instrument to which her thumb returns after the straining], he means taOotawiI lahu, of the measure tafotaEilu, from Oawayotu Uilayohi signifying Eudotu; the w being changed into A [written I], and the I, which is the final radical, being elided. (M. [But see another reading near the end of the first paragraph of art. Awl.]) OawaI, aor. as above, inf. n. OuwiIN, also signifies He turned away: and hence, [it is said,] Uico OawaI Alfitoyapu UilaI Alkahofi [When the young men turned away to the cave: though the verb may be here well rendered betook themselves for refuge]. (Har p. 246.) You say also, Oawayotu UilaI fulaAnK, (A'Obeyd, T,) or lahu, (as afterwards written in a copy of the T,) [I betook myself to such a one, or repaired to him, for lodging, covert, or refuge; or] I joined myself, got myself, betook myself, repaired, or resorted, to such a one: and accord. to AHeyth, Oawayotu fulaAnFA signifies the same; but he did not know Oawayotu to be syn. with Mwayotu as explained below. (T.) And OawaI UilaI QllRehi He returned unto God. (TA, from a trad.)
OawaI said of a wound: see 5.
See also 4, in seven places.

OawaI lahu, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) like rawaI, (K, TA,) but it would have been more explicit if the author of the K had said like ramaI, (TA,) [as is shown by the false reading in the CK, OwiIa lahu karawiIR,] aor. yaOwiI, (T, S, Mgh,) inf. n. OawoyapN (S, K) and UiyRapN, (S, Mgh, K,) with kesr, (TA,) [originally UiwoyapN,] the w being changed into I because of the kesreh before it, (S,) or because combined with I and preceded by sukoon [a mistake for “kesreh”], (IB as cited in the TA,) [in a copy of the T written AyRap, and in a copy of the M and in the CK AayRap,] and maOowiyapN, (S, M, K,) without teshdeed, (S, TA,) [in my copy of the Mgh written with tesh-deed,] and maOowaAhN, (S, M, K,) He compassionated him; felt compassion, or pity, for him; (T, S, M, Mgh, K;) as also AYtwI↓, (T, K,) of the measure AftEl. (TA.) In using the imperative form, you say, Aiwi lahu, [unless this be a mistranscription for Aiywi lahu,] meaning Be thou compassionate to him. (T, TA.)
2: see 1, first sentence:
and see 4.

OawRayotu biAlxayoli (ISh, T) [I drew together the horses: this meaning seems to be indicated in the T, by the context: or] I called out to the horses MwRaho, in order that they should return at hearing my voice: (ISh:) and in like manner one says to them Mwi↓ or MwK; (ISh, T, TA;) a well-known call of the Arabs to horses; and sometimes MI, with a long meddeh, is said to them from afar. (T, TA.) [See also 5.]

4. MwAhu, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UywaMCN; (T, S, Mgh;) and OwRAhu↓; (K;) and OawaAhu↓; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) the first of which is the [most] approved; (T;) the last used by some; (T, Msb;) both given on the authority of AZ, (S,) and of A'Obeyd, accord. to whom you say, Oawayotu Uilayohi, with the short A only; (T, M;) He, or it, gave him, or afforded him, lodging, covert, or refuge; harboured him; sheltered him; protected him; (Mgh;) he lodged him, or lodged him with himself; made him his guest; or gave him refuge or asylum, absolutely, or with himself; syn. Oanozalahu; (K;) or Oanozalahu. (T, S, TA.) You say also, AlrRajula UilaIRa Oawayotu↓ and Mwayotuhu [I took the man to me to lodge, to be my guest, or to give him refuge or asylum]. (M.) And MwaAhu saqofN [A roof shel-tered him]. (Mgh.) And AlUibila Oawayotu↓ and MwayotuhaA [I lodged the camels in their nightly resting-place]; both meaning the same. (T.) And it is said in a trad., AlHamodu lilRhi AlRaciI kafaAnaA waMwaAnaA i. e. [Praise be to God who hath sufficed us and] hath brought us to a place of abode for us, and not made us to be scattered like the beasts. (TA.) AHeyth disallowed Oawayotu↓ as syn. with Mwayotu; but it is correct. (T.) It is said in a form of divorce, laA yaOowiyniI↓ waUiyRaAki bayotN [A house, or tent, shall not lodge, or comprise, me with thee]. (Mgh.) And among other instances, is the saying of the Prophet, (T,) AlDRaAlRapN UlRaA DaAlRN laA yaOowiI↓ [No one will harbour the stray beast but a person straying from the right course of conduct]. (T, Mgh.) And his saying, Aljariynu laA qaToEa fiI vamarK HatRaI yaOowiyih↓ i. e. [There shall be no cutting off of the hand in the case of stealing fruit] unless the place where the fruit is dried contain it [at the time of the stealing thereof]. (TA.)
Hence, UiywaMCu xaXabi AlfaHomi The throwing of dust, or earth, upon the wood of which charcoal is made, and covering it therewith. (Mgh.)
See also 1, first sentence.
5: see 1, first sentence.

taOawRati AlTRayoru The birds collected, or flocked, together; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) as also taMwat↓: (K:) the latter is allowable. (T.) And in like manner one says of other things. (M.) [Thus,] one says, taOawRati Alxayolu The horses drew, or gathered, themselves together: and tOwRI AlnRaAsu The men did so. (T.) You say also, of a wound, tMwI↓, and OawaI↓, meaning It drew together, for healing; and so tMzI, and OazaI: so in the Nawádir el-Aaráb. (T.)
One may also say, yataOawRaI, without saying it with h, [i. e. yataOawRahu,] meaning He says Oawohi. (Fr and T in art. Aw.) [See also 2; and see art. Awh.]
6: see 5, in two places.
8. QOotawI, or AYtwI, or QtRawaI, and AiytawaI, and taOotaI for taOotawiI: see 1, first part of the paragraph, in four places.
See also the last sentence but one of the same paragraph.
10. QsotaOowayotuhu I asked him, or desired him, to compassionate me, or have mercy on me; syn. QsotaroHamotuhu. (T.) A poet (namely, Dhu-r-Rummeh, TA) says,

L.foreign: walawo OanRanI QsotaOowayotuhu maA OawaI liyaA

sense.s: [And if I had asked him, or desired him, to compassionate me, he would not have compassionated me]. (T, S.)
OuwayRapN dim. of MCN: see the letter A.
Mwi or MwK: see 2.

MwK [the part. n. of 1] has for its pl. OuwiIRN [like one of the inf. ns. of 1]. (T, S.) The latter is applied to birds, signifying Collecting, or flocking, together; (T, S, M, * K; *) syn. mutaOawRiyapN↓ (Lth, T) and mutaOawRiyaAtN. (Lth, T, S, M, K.)

Aibonu MwaI, a determinate noun, (S, M,) [The jackal; vulgarly called in the present day waAwiI;] a certain small beast, (M, K,) called in Persian XagaAlo, (S,) or in that language [or in Turkish] JaqaAlo: (TA:) it has been said to be the offspring of the wolf; but is well known to be not of the wolf-kind: (Msb;) MwaI is inseparable from Abn: (M:) it is imperfectly decl., (T, S, Msb,) being of the measure OafoEalu, (S,) or regarded as such; (Lth, T;) or because it has the quality of a proper name and the measure of a verb: (Msb:) the pl. is banaAtu MwaI, (T, S, Msb, K,) though applying to males [as well as females], like banaAtu OaEowaja and banaAtu labuwn. (AHeyth, T.)
MwiIN and OawawiIRN, said to be rel. ns. of MyapN; which see, in, art. AI.
MyapN, said by some to be originally OawayapN:see art. A I.

maOowFI (S, M, Msb, K) and maOowK↓ and maOowaAhN↓ (M, K [but respecting these two forms see what follows]) nouns of place from the first of the verbs in this art.; (M, K;) [A place to which one betakes himself, or repairs, for lodging, covert, or refuge; a refuge; an asylum; a place of resort; (see 1;)] any place to which a thing betakes itself, &c., (yaOowiI Uilayohi,) by night or. by day; (S;) the lodging-place, or abode, of any animal; the nightly resting-place of sheep or goats; (Msb;) and of camels: (Idem in art. rwH:) maOowK↓ is used peculiarly in relation to camels: (S;) maOowiI AlUibili being a dial. var. of maOowaI AlUibili, but anomalous, (Fr, T, S, Msb,) and the only instance of the kind except maOoqiI AlEayoni: (Fr, T, M: [but see art. mOq:]) maOowaI and muWoq and maOoq are the forms preferred: (Fr, T:) [Az also says,] I have heard the chaste in speech of the Benoo-Kiláb use, for maOowaI AlUibili, the word maOowaAp↓. (T.) janRapu AlmaOowaI, in the Kur [liii. 15], is said to mean The paradise to which repair the souls of the martyrs, (M, Bd, Jel, TA,) or the pious, (Bd, Jel,) or the angels: (Jel:) or that in which the night is passed. (TA.)
maOowK: see maOowFI, in four places.
maOowaApN: see maOowFI, in four places.
maAwiyRapN: see art. mwh.
mutaOawRiyapN: see MwK.
2. OayRaA MyapF, [inf. n., by rule, as below,] He put, or set, a sign, token, or mark, by which a person or thing might be known. (M.)
OayRaA bilUibili, (inf. n. taOoyyapN, Lth, T,) He chid the camels, saying to them OayaAyaA, (Lth, T, M, and K in art. OayaA,) or OayaAyaho, (M,) or yaAyaA, (K,) or yaAyaho. (M, K.)
5. tOyRA, as a trans. verb: see 6.

He paused, stopped, stayed, remained, or tarried, (T, S, M, K, *) biA lmakaAni in the place; (M, K; * [in the latter explained by talabRava Ealayohi; but this seems to be a mistake, arising from the omission of part of a passage in the M, (one of the chief sources of the K,) running thus; taOayRaA biA lmakaAni talabRava watamakRava wataOayRaA Ealayohi QnoSarafa fiI tuWadapK;]) and confined, restricted, limited, restrained, or withheld, himself. (T.) In the sense of its inf. n., [by rule taOaIR, originally taOayRuIN,] they said taOayRapN↓, or taUiyRapN or taYiyRapN; [thus differently written in different places in copies of the T and S;] as in the ex. layosa manozilukumo bidaAri taOayRapK or taUiyRapK, (IAar, T,) or layosa manozilukumo hecaA bimanozili taOayRapK or taUiyRapK, (S,) i. e. Your abode, or this your abode, is not an abode of tarriance and confinement. (IAar, T, S.)

He expected, or waited for, a thing: (Lth, T:) and he acted with moderation, gently, deliberately, or leisurely; without haste; or with gravity, staidness, sedateness, or calmness; (Lth, T, K;) fiI AlOamori in the affair; inf. n. taOIK. (Lth, T.) taOayRayotu Ealayohi, in a verse of Lebeed, means I acted with moderation, &c., as above, and paused, stopped, stayed, remained, or tarried, upon him, i. e., upon my horse: (T:) or I remained firm upon him: (TA, as on the authority of Az:) but it is explained by Lth as meaning I turned away, or back, deliberately, or leisurely, upon him. (T: and the like is said in the M.)

6. taMyayotuhu, (T, S, M, * K,) and taOayRayotuhu↓, (S, K,) I directed my course, or aim, to, or towards, (T, S, M, * K,) his Myap, (S, M,) i. e., (M,) his XaxoS [or body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, seen from a distance; or person]. (T, M, K.) The following is an ex., as some relate it, of the former verb; and as others relate it, of the latter:

[Modest behaviour were more proper, if thou directedst thy course towards his person, than thy throwing dust upon the rider]: (S, TA: [in two copies of the former of which, for OawolaI, I find OadonaI:]) said by a woman to her daughter, on the latter's relating, in a couplet, that a rider, passing along, had seen her, and she had thrown dust in his face, purposely. (IB.)

OaIo a vocative particle, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) addressed to the near, (S, K,) not to the distant: (S:) or to the near, or the distant, or the intermediate; accord. to different authorities. (Mughnee.) You say, OaIo zayodu Oaqobilo [O Zeyd, advance: or, if it may be used in addressing one who is distant, ho there, soho, or holla: and if used in addressing one who is between near and distant, ho, or what ho]: (S:) and OaIo rabRi [O my Lord]; occurring in a trad.: and sometimes it is pronounced MIo↓. (Mughnee.)

Also an explicative particle. (S, M, Mughnee, K.) You say, OaIo kacaA in the sense of yuriydu kacaA [He means such a thing, or yaEoniI kacaA, which has the same signification; or Ouriydu, or OaEoniI, I mean; or the like; for all of which, we may say, meaning; or that is]; (S;) as in EinodiI EasojidN OaIo cahabN [I have Easojad, that is, (I have) cahaba, or gold]. (Mughnee.) What follows it is an adjunct explicative of what precedes it, or a substitute. (Mughnee.) AA says that he asked Mbr respecting what follows it, and he answered that it may be a substitute for what precedes, and may be a word independent of what precedes it, and may be a noun in the accus. case: and that he asked Th, and he answered that it may be an explicative, or a word independent of what precedes it, or a noun governed in the accus. case by a verb suppressed: you say, jaMCaniI Oaxuwka OaIo zayodN [Thy brother came to me; that is, Zeyd]; and you may say, OaIo zayodFA [I mean Zeyd]: and raOayotu OaxaAka OaIo zayodFA [I saw thy brother; I mean, or that is, Zeyd]; and you may say, OaIo zayodN [that is, Zeyd]: and mararotu biOaxiyka OaIo zayodK [I passed by thy brother; that is, by Zeyd]; and you may say, OaIo zaydFA [I mean, Zeyd]; and OaIo zayodN [that is, Zeyd]. (T, TA.) When it occurs after taquwlu, in a case like the following, [i. e., when a verb following it explains a verb preceding it,] one says, taquwlu Aisotakotamotuhu AlHadiyva OaIo saOalotuhu kitomaAnahu [Thou sayest, Astktmth AlHdyv, meaning sOlth ktmAnh I asked of him the concealment of it, namely, the discourse, or story; and so when taquwlu is understood, as is often, or generally, the case in lexicons]; with damm to the t: but if you put UicaA in the place of OaIo, you say, UicaA saOalotahu, with fet-h, because OacA is an adverbial noun relating to taquwlu. (Mughnee.)
See also OaIRN, near the beginning of the paragraph, in three places.

UiIo is a particle denoting a reply, meaning naEamo [Yes, or yea]; importing acknowledgment of the truth of an enunciation; and the making a thing known, to him who asks information; and a promise, to him who seeks or demands; therefore it occurs after such sayings as “Zeyd stood” and “Did Zeyd stand.?” and “Beat thou Zeyd,” and the like; as does naEamo: Ibn-El-Hájib asserts that it occurs only after an interrogation; as in the
saying [in the Kur x. 54], wayasotanobiWunaka OaHaqRN huwa qulN Ui Io warabiIR [And they will ask thee to inform them, saying, Is it true? Say, Yea, by my Lord!]: but accord. to all, it does not occur otherwise than before an oath: and when one says, Ui Io waQllRehi [Yea, by God!], and then drops the w the I may be quiescent, and with fet-h, and elided; [so that you say, Ui Io QllRehi, and Ui Ia QllRehi, and Ui QllRehi;] in the first of which cases, two quiescent letters occur together, irregularly. (Mughnee.) Lth says, Ui Io is an oath, as in U iIo warabRiI meaning, says Zj, naEamo warabRiI: IAar is also related to have said the like; and this is the correct explanation. (T.) [J says,] It is a word preceding an oath, meaning balaI [q. v.]; as in Ui Io warabRiI and Ui Io waQllReh. (S.) [ISd and F say,] It is syn. with naEamo, and is conjoined with an oath: and one says also hiIo. (M, K.)

OaIRN is a noun, used in five different manners. (Mughnee.) One of its meanings is that of an interrogative, (T, S, M, Mughnee, K,) relating to intellectual beings and to non-intellectual things; [meaning Who? which? and what?] (S, M, K;) and as such, it is a decl. noun: (S:) it is said in the K to be a particle; (MF;) and so in the M; (TA;) but this is wrong: (MF:) and it is added in the K that it is indecl.; (MF;) and it is said to be so in the M, accord. to Sb, in an instance to be explained below; (TA;) but this is only when it is a conjunct noun [like AlRaciI], or denotes the object of a vocative: (MF:) or, accord. to some, it is decl. as a conjunct noun also. (Mughnee.) You say, OayRuhumo Oaxuwka [Who, or which, of them, is thy brother?]. (S.) Another ex. is the saying [in the Kur vii. 184, and last verse of lxxvii.], fabiOaIRi HadiyvK baEodahu yuWominuwna [And in what announcement, after it, will they believe?]. (Mughnee.) Sometimes it is without teshdeed; as in the saying (of El-Farezdak, M),

[I looked for rain, or aid from the clouds, and the two Simáks (stars so called). Of which of them two did the rains pour vehemently upon me from the clouds?]: (M, Mughnee, K: * [in the last of which, only the former hemistich is given, with nasorFA (meaning the star or asterism so called) instead of naSorFA:]) so by poetic licence: (M:) IJ says that for this reason the poet has elided the second I, but should have restored the first I to w, because it is originally w. (TA. [But this assertion, respecting the first I, I regard as improbable.]) Oayoma↓, also, is a contraction of OaIRu maA, meaning OaIRu XaIoCK: so in the saying, Oayoma huwa yaA fulaAnu [What thing is it, O such a one?]: and Oayoma taquwlu [What thing sayest thou?]. (TA in art. Aym.) In like manner, also, OayoXa↓ is used as a contraction of OaIRu XaIoCK. (Ks, TA in art. jrm.) A poet speaks of his companions as being biOaIa waOayonamaA; making OaIR the name of the quarter (jihap); so that, being determinate and of the feminine gender, it is imperfectly declinable. (M. [See OaynN; under which head two other readings are given; and where it is said that the verse in which this occurs is by Homeyd Ibn-Thowr.]) OaIR is never without a noun or pronoun to which it is prefixed, except in a vocative expression and when it is made to conform with a word to which it refers, as in cases to be exemplified hereafter. (Mughnee.) Being so prefixed, it is determinate; but sometimes, [as in the latter of the cases just mentioned,] it is not so prefixed, yet has the meaning of a prefixed noun. (S.) When used as an interrogative, it is not governed, as to the letter, though it is as to the meaning, by the verb that precedes it, but by what follows it; as in the saying in the Kur [xviii. 11], linaEolama OaIRu AlHizobayoni OaHoSaI [That we might know which of the two parties was able to compute]; and in the same [xxvi. last verse], wasayaEolamu QlRacayna ZalamuwA OaIa munoqalabK yanoqalibuwna [And they who have acted wrongly shall know with what a translating they shall be translated]: (Fr, * Th, Mbr, T, S: *) when it is governed by the verb before it, it has not the interrogative meaning, as will be shown hereafter. (Fr, T.) In the saying of the poet,

[Haneefeh (the tribe so named) shout to us when they see us. And to what place of the earth, or land, will they go for the shouting?], OaIR is in the accus. case because the prep. UilaI is suppressed before it. (S.) When they separate it [from what follows it, not prefixing it to another noun], the Arabs say OaIN, and in the dual OayRaAni, and in the pl. OayRuwna; and they make it fem., saying OayRapN, and [in the dual] OayRataAni, and [in the pl.] OayRaAtN: but when they prefix it to a noun, properly so called, not a pronoun, they make it sing. and masc., saying OaIu AlrRajulayoni [Who, or which, of the two men?], and OaIu AlmaroOatayoni [Who, or which, of the two women?], and OaIRu AlRrijaAli [Who, or which, of the men?], and OaIRu AlnRisaMCi [Who, or which, of the women?]: and when they prefix it to a fem. pronoun, they make it masc. [as when they prefix it to a masc. pronoun] and fem., saying OayRuhumaA and OayRatuhumaA [Who, or which, of them two?], meaning women; (Fr, T;) [the latter of which seems to be the more common; for ISd says,] sometimes they said OayRuhunRa [Who, or which, of them? referring to women], meaning OayRatuhunRa. (M.) It is said in the Kur [xxxi. last verse], wamaA tadoriI nafosN biOaIRi OarDK tamuwtu [And a person knoweth not in what land he will die]: (S:) but some read biOayRapi OaroDK; and Sb compares this fem. form to kulRatuhunRa. (Bd.) When it is used as an interrogative relating to an indeterminate noun in a preceding phrase, OaIR is made to conform with that indeterminate noun in case-ending and in gender and in number; and this is done [alike, accord. to some,] in the case of its connexion with a following word and in the case of a pause; so that, [in the case of a pause,] to him who says, jaMCaniI rajulN [A man came to me], you say, [accord. to the authorities alluded to above,] OaIRN [Who?]; and to him who says, raOayotu rajulFA [I saw a man], OayRaA [Whom?]; and to him who says, mararotu birajlK [I passed by a man], OaIRK [Whom?]: and in like manner, [accord. to all authorities,] in the case of its connexion with a following word; as OaIRu yaA fataI [Who, O young man?], and OayRaA yaA fataI [Whom, O young man?], and OaIK yaA fataI [Whom, O young man?]: and in the case of the fem. you say, OayRapN and OayRapF and OayRapK [in the nom. and accus. and gen. respectively]; and in the dual, OayRaAni and OayRataAni in the nom. case [masc. and fem. respectively], and OayRayoni and OayRatayoni in the accus. and gen. cases [masc. and fem. respectively]; and in the pl., [with the like distinction of genders,] OayRuwna and OayRaAtN in the nom. case, and OayRiyna and OayRaAtK in the accus. and gen. cases. (I' Ak p. 319.) [Exs. in cases of pause, agreeing with the foregoing rules, are given in the T; and exs. in cases of connexion with following words, agreeing with the foregoing, are given in the Mughnee: but J gives rules differing from the foregoing in some respects; and IB gives rules differing in some points both from the foregoing and from those of J.] It is said in the S, OaIR is made to conform with indeterminate nouns significant of intellectual beings and of nonintellectual things, and is used as an interrogative; and when it is thus used in reference to an indeterminate noun, you make it to have a caseending like that of the noun respecting which it demands positive information; so that when it is said to you, marRabiI rajulN [A man passed by me], you say, OaIRN yaA fataI [Who, O young man?], thus giving it a case-ending [like that of rajulN] when it is in connexion with a following word; and you indicate the case-ending [by the pronunciation termed AlrRawomu, saying OaIRu, with a somewhat obscure utterance of the final vowel,] in pausing; and if one says, raOayotu rajulFA [I saw a man], you say, OayRaA yaAfataI [Whom, O young man?], giving it a case-ending [like that of rajulFA], with tenween, when it is [thus] in connexion with a following word; and you pause upon the A, saying OayRaA; and when one says, mararotu birajulK [I passed by a man], you say, OaIRK yaAfataI [Whom, O young man? in a case of connexion with a following word; and OaIRi in a case of pausing]: you conform with what the other has said, in the nom. and accus. and gen. cases, in the case of connexion with a following word and in that of pausing: but IB says that this is correct only in the case of connexion with a following word; for in the case of a pause, you say only OaIRo, in the nom. and gen., with sukoon; and you imitate in both of these cases only when you use the dual form or the pl.: it is added in the S, you say in the cases of the dual and pl. and fem. like as we have said respecting mano: when one says, jaMCaniI rijaAlN [Men came to me], you say, OayRuwno [Who?], with the n quiescent; and Oayiyno in the accus. and gen.: but IB says, the correct
mode is to say, OayRuwna and OayRina, with fet-h to the n in both; [meaning that this is the only allowable mode in the case of connexion with a following word, and app. that it is the preferable mode in the case of a pause;] the quiescent n being allowable only in the case of a pause, and with respect to mano, for you say manuwno and maniyno with the quiescent n only: it is then added in the S, you say, also, OayRaho [Who? and whom?] in using the fem. [in a case of pause]; but in a case of connexion with a following word, [when referring to a noun in the accus.,] you say, OayRapF yaA hecaA [Whom, O thou? in the sing.], and OayRaAtK [in the pl.; and in like manner, OayRapN in the nom. sing., and OayRapK in the gen. sing.; and OayRaAtN in the nom. pl., and OayRaAtK in the gen. pl.]: but when the interrogation refers to a determinate noun, OaIR is in the nom. case (with refa) only. (TA.) [See also OayRaAna, below.]
[In other cases, now to be mentioned, it is used alike as sing., dual, and pl.]

It also denotes a condition; (T, S, M, Mughnee;) in which case, also, it is a decl. noun, applied to an intellectual being and to a non-intellectual thing. (S.) So in the saying, OayRuhumo yukorimoniI Oukorimohu [Whichever of them treats me with honour, I will treat him with honour]. (S.) So, too, in the saying [in the Kur xvii. 110], OayRFA maA tadoEuwA falahu AlOasomaMCu AlHusonaI [Whichever ye call Him, He hath the best names]. (T, * Mughnee.) And in the saying [in the same, xxviii. 28], OayRamaA QloOajalayoni qaDayotu falaA EudowaAna EalaIRa [Whichever of the two terms I fulfil, there shall be no wrongdoing to me]. (Mughnee.) One says also, SaHibahu QllRehu OayRaA maA tawajRaha, meaning OayonamaAtawajRaha [May God accompany him wherever he goeth]. (AZ, T.) And Zuheyr uses the expression OayRapF salakuwA for OayRapa wijohapK salakuwA [Whatever tract they travelled, or travel]. (T.) The saying, OayRiI waOayRuka kaAna XarRaA faOaxozaAhu QllRehu [Whichever of me and thee be evil, may God abase him!] was explained by Kh to Sb as meaning OayRunaA kaAna XarRFA [whichever of us two be evil]; and as being like the saying, OaxozaI QllRehu AlkaAciba miniIR waminoka, meaning minRaA. (M. [And in a similar manner, the former clause of that saying, occurring in a verse, with maA after OayRiI, is said in the T to have been explained by Kh to Sb.])

It is also a conjunct noun; (Mughnee;) [i. e.] it is sometimes used in the manner of AlRaciI, and therefore requires a complement; as in the saying, OayRuhumo fiI AldRaAri Oaxuwka [He, of them, who is in the house is thy brother]: (S:) [i. e.] it is syn. with AlRaciI. (M, Mughnee.) So in the saying [in the Kur xix. 70], vumRa lananoziEanRa mino kulRi XiyEapK OayRuhumo OaXadRu EalaI AlrRaHomeni EutiyRaA [Then we will assuredly draw forth, from every sect, him, of them, who is most exorbitantly rebellious against the Compassionate]: so says Sb: but the Koofees and a number of the Basrees disagree with him, holding that the conjunct noun OaIR is always decl., like the conditional and the interrogative: Zj says, “It has not appeared to me that Sb has erred except in two instances, whereof this is one; for he has conceded that it is decl. when separate, and how can he say that it is indecl. when it is a prefixed noun?” and El-Jarmee says, “I have gone forth from El-Basrah, and have not heard, from my leaving the Khandak to Mekkeh, any one say, laOaDoribanRa OayRuhumo qaAYimN [as meaning I will assuredly beat him, of them, who is standing], with damm:” these assert, that it is, in the verse above, an interrogative, and that it is an inchoative, and AXd is an enunciative: but they differ as to the objective complement of the verb: Kh says that this is suppressed, and that the implied meaning is, we will assuredly draw forth those of whom it will be said, Which of them is most &c.? and Yoo says that it is the proposition [AyhRm &c.], and that the verb is suspended from governing, as in the instance in the Kur xviii. 11, cited above: and Ks and Akh say that it is klR XyEp, that mn is redundant, and that the interrogative proposition is independent of what precedes it; this being grounded on their saying that the redundance of mino is allowable in an affirmative proposition: but these [following] facts refute their sayings; viz. that the suspension of government is peculiar to verbs significant of operations of the mind; and that it is not allowable to say, laOaDoribanRa AlfaAsiqu, with refa, as meaning by implication “I will assuredly beat him of whom it is said, He is the transgressor;” and that the redundance of mino in an affirmative proposition is not correct. (Mughnee. [Some further remarks on the same subject, in that work, mentioning other opinions as erroneous, I omit. Another reading of the passage in the Kur cited above (xix. 70) will be found in what here follows.]) [ISd states that] they said, laOaDorbanRa OayRuhumo OafoDalu [I will assuredly beat him, of them, who is most excellent], and OaIRN OafoDalu [him who is most excel-lent]; AIR being indecl., accord. to Sb, and therefore the verb does not govern it [save as to the meaning]. (M.) And [that] you say, AiDoribo OayRuhumo OafoDalu [Beat thou him, of them, who is most excellent], and OayRahumo OafoDalu [meaning the same, or whichever of them, &c.]; suppressing the relative huwa after AyRhm. (M in a later part of the same art.) Fr says that when OaIR is governed by the verb before it, it has not the interrogative meaning; and you may say, laOaDoribanRa OayRahumo yaquwlu celika [I will assuredly beat him, of them, or whichever of them, says that]: and he says that he who reads OayRahumo, in the accus. case, in the passage of the Kur cited above (xix. 70) makes it to be governed by lananoriEanRa. (T.) Ks says, you say, laOaDoribanRa OayRahumo fiI AldRaAri [I will assuredly beat him, of them, or whichever of them, is in the house]; but you may not say, Darabotu OayRahumo fiI AldRaAri: thus he distinguishes between the actual occurrence and that which is expected. (S.) Akh says, also, that it may be indeterminate and qualified by an epithet; as when one says, mararotu biOaIRK muEojibK laka, like as one says, bimano muEojibK laka [I passed by one pleasing to thee]: but this has not been heard [from the Arabs]. (Mughnee.)

It also denotes perfection, or consummateness: and in this case it is an epithet applying to an indeterminate noun; as in zayodN rajulN OaIRu rajulK (tropical:) [Zeyd is a man; what a man!], meaning that he is complete, or consummate, in the qualities of men: and it is a denotative of state relating to a determinate noun; as in mararotu biEabodi QllRehi OaIRa rajulK (tropical:) [I passed by 'Abd-Allah; what a man was he!]: (Mughnee:) and used in this sense, it is tropical. (Har p. 534.) [J says,] it is sometimes an epithet applying to an indeterminate noun: you say, mararotu birajulK OaIRi rajulK and OayRimaArajulK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a man; what a man!]; and mararotu biQmoraOapK OayRapi QmoraOapK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a woman; what a woman!], and biQmoraOatayoni OayRatimaA QmoraOatayoni [by two women; what two women!]; and hecihi QmoraOapN OayRapu QmoraOapK (assumed tropical:) [This is a woman; what a woman!]: and OayRatumaA QmoraOa OayRapu QmoraOapK (assumed tropical:) [What two women!]; mA being redundant: and in the case of a determinate noun, you say, hecaA zayodN OayRamaA rajulK (assumed tropical:) [This is Zeyd; what a man is he!]; putting it in the accus. case as a denotative of state; and hecihi Oamapu QllRehi OayRatamaA jaAriyRpK (assumed tropical:) [This is the handmaid of God; what a girl, or young woman, is she!]: you say, also, [in using an indeterminate noun,] OaIRu QmoraOapK jaMCatoka and jaMCaka, and OayRapu QmoraOapK jaMCatoka (assumed tropical:) [What a woman came to thee!]; and mararotu bijaAriyapK OaIRi jaAriyapK (assumed tropical:) [I passed by a girl, or young woman; what a girl, or young woman!]; and jiYotuka bimulaMCapK OaIRi mulaMCapK and OayRapi mulaMCipK (assumed tropical:) [I brought thee a body-wrapper; what a body-wrapper!]: all are allowable. (S.) [In all these it evidently denotes admiration, or wonder, at some good or extraordinary quality in the person or thing to which it relates; notwithstanding that J says afterwards,] and sometimes it is used to denote wonder; as in the saying of Jemeel,

L.foreign: buvayona QlozamiI laA UanRa laA Uino lazimotihi

sense.s: (assumed tropical:) [O Butheyneh, (buvayona being a curtailed form of buvayonap, a woman's name,) adhere thou to “No:” verily “No,” if thou adhere to it, notwithstanding the numbers of the slanderers, what a help will it be!]: (S:) i. e., an excellent help will be thy saying “No” in repelling, or rebutting, the slanderers, though they be many. (TA in art. Ewn.) Fr gives as exs. of its use to denote wonder the sayings, OaIRu rajulK zayodN [What a man is Zeyd!], and OaIRu jaAriyahK zayonabu [What a girl, or young woman, is Zeyneb!]. (T.) It denotes wonder at the sufficiency, and great degree of competence, of the person [or thing] to whom [or to which] it relates. (M.) El-Kattál El-Kilábee says,

[And when I saw that I had slain him, I repented of it; in what an hour, or time, of repentance!]: i. e., when I slew him, I repented of it, in a time when repentance did not profit: AIR being here in
the accus. case as an adv. n.; for, as it denotes the part of a whole, its predicament is made to be the same as that of the affixed noun, of whatever kind this may be. (Ham p. 95.)

It also has k prefixed to it; and thus it becomes changed in signification so as to denote numerousness, being syn. with the enunciative kamo [How many!]; (S, K;) or syn. with rubRa [as meaning many]: (Sb, M:) [and sometimes it is syn. with the interrogative kamo, meaning how many? or how much? as will be shown below:] thus it is written kaOaIRK, (M,) or kaOayRino, (S, M, K,) its tenween being written n; (S, K;) and kaMCK, (M,) or [more commonly] kaAYino, (S, M, K, [in some copies of the S and K kaAyino,]) like kaAEino, (S,) said by IJ, on the authority of Aboo-'Alee, to be formed from kaOayRino, by putting the double I before the C, after the manner of the transposition in qisiIRN and a number of other words, so that it becomes kayRaOK [or kayRaYino], then suppressing the second I, as is done in mayRitN and hayRinN and layRinN, so that it becomes kaIoCK [or kaIoCino], and then changing the [remaining] I into A, as in [TayoYiIRN, which becomes] TaAdiIRN, and in [HiyriIRN, which becomes] HaAriIRN, so that it becomes kaMCK [or kaAYino]; (M;) and it has other dial. vars.; namely kayoYinN [one of the intermediate forms between kaOayRino and kaAYino mentioned above]; (K; [in one copy of the K written kayayRino, and so accord. to the TK;]) and kaOoIK, (M, K,) of the measure of ramoIK, and most probably formed by transposition from kaIoCK, mentioned above; (M;) and kaO, of the measure of EamK, (M, TA,) incorrectly written in the copies of the K kaACK, i. e. like kaAEK, (TA,) formed by the suppression of I in kaIoCK; a change not greater than that from Oayomunu QllRehi to mu QllRehi and mi QllRehi. (M.) You say, kaOayRino rajulFA laqiytu [How many a man have I met! or many a man &c.], (S, K, *) putting the noun following kOyRn in the accus. case as a specificative; (S;) and kaOayRino mino rajulK laqiytu; (S, K; *) and the introduction of mino after kaOyRn is more common, and better. (S. [And Sb, as cited in the M, says the like.]) You say also, kaOayRino qado OataAniI rajulFA [How many a man has come to me! or many a man &c.]. (Sb, M.) And bikaOayRino tabiyEu hecaA AlvRawoba, i. e. bikamo tbyE [For how much wilt thou sell this garment, or piece of cloth?]. (S.) Kh says that if any one of the Arabs made it to govern the gen. case, perhaps he did so by making mino to be implied, as is allowable with kamo: (M:) [so that you may say, bikaOayRino dirohamK QXotarayota hecaA For how many a dirhem didst thou buy this? for] it is allowable to make the noun that follows kamo to be governed in the gen. case by mno implied, when km immediately follows a preposition; as in bikDmo dirohamK QXotarayota hecaA; but when it is not thus preceded by a preposition, the noun after it must be in the accus. case. (I 'Ak p. 317.) It always holds the first place in a proposition, like kamo. (Idem, next p.)

It is also a connective of the vocative yaA with the noun signifying the person or persons or thing called, when this noun has the article Al prefixed to it; (S, M, Mughnee, K;) and with a noun of indication, as caA; and with a conjunct noun having Al prefixed to it, as AlcRiI: (I 'Ak p. 268:) it is a noun formed for serving as such a connective; (M, K;) and has haA affixed to it. (S, M, &c.) You say, yaA OayRuhaA AlrRajulu [which seems to be best rendered O thou man; more agreeably with the original, O thou, the man; or, accord. to Akh, O thou who art the man; lit., O he who is the man; often written yaOayRuhaA]; (T, S, M, Mughnee, K;) and yaAOayRuhaA AlrRajulaAni [O ye two men]; and yaAOayRuhaA AlrRijaAlu [O ye men]; (M;) and yaAOayRatuhaAAlmaroOapu [O thou woman]; (S, M;) and yaA OayRatuhaA AlmaroOataAni [O ye two women]; and OayRatuhaA AlnRsowapu [O ye women]; and yaAOayRuhaA AlmaroOapu, and AlmaroOataAni, and AlnRisowapu; (M;) and yaAOayRuhaA caA [O thou, this person or thing]; and yaA OayRuhaA AlRaciI faEala kacaA [O thou who didst, or hast done, thus]. (I 'Ak p. 267.) In the first of the exs. here given, OaIR is a noun of vague signification, (Zj, T, S,) denoting the person called, (Zj, T,) of the sing. number, (Zj, T, S,) rendered determinate by the vocative [yA], (S,) indecl., with damm for its termination; (Zj, T, S;) and haA is a particle employed to rouse attention, or to give notice, a substitute for the noun to which OaIR is in other cases prefixed; and AlrRajulu is a qualificative to OaIR, (Zj, T, S,) wherefore it is in the nom. case. (S.) Akh asserts, [as we have indicated above,] that OaIR is here the conjunct noun, and that the first member of its complement, namely the relative huwa, is suppressed; the meaning being, yaA mano huwa AlrRajulu: but this assertion is refuted by the fact that there is no relative pronoun that must be suppressed, nor any conjunct noun that necessarily requires that its complement should be a nominal proposition: though he might reply to these two objections by arguing that mA in the saying laA siyRamaA zayodN is in like manner [virtually] in the nom. case [as a conjunct noun syn. with AlRaciI, and that the first member of its complement, namely huwa, an inchoative of which zayodN is the enunciative, is suppressed]. (Mughnee.) The putting of the qualificative of OaIR in the accus. case, as in the saying yaA OayRuhaA AlrRajula Oaqobilo [O thou man, advance], is allowed (M, K) by El-Mázinee; but it is not known [as heard from the Arabs]. (M.) OayRuhaA and OayRatuhaA are also used for the purpose of particularizing; [in which case they are not preceded by yA;] as when one says, OamRaA OanaA faOafoEalu kacaA OayRuhaA AlrRajulu [As for me, I will do thus, or such a thing, thou man], meaning himself; and as in the saying of Kaab Ibn-Málik, related in a trad., fataxalRafonaA OayRatuhaA AlvRalaAvahu [And we remained behind, or held back, ye three], meaning, by the three, those particularized as remaining behind [with him], or holding back. (TA.)
OayaA: see art. AyA.
OayFA: see the next paragraph.

UiyaA AlXRamosi, [the former word, when alone and indeterminate, perhaps (as when determinate) without tenween, for it is-explained (with its dial. vars.) in the S and K in bAb AlAlf AllyRnp, though it is also explained in some copies of the S in the present art.,] and AlXms OayaApu↓, (T, S, M, Mgh, K,) and AlXms OayaApu↓, (S, M, K,) and OayaMCu↓ AlXms, (T, M, Mgh, K, and in a copy of the S,) with fet-h and medd, (T, Mgh, K, and so in a copy of the S,) The light of the sun, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and its beauty: (M, K:) or its rays, and its light: (T:) or, as some say, AlXms AyAp↓ signifies the halo of the sun; that, with respect to the sun, which is like the haAlap with respect to the moon; i. e. the daArap around the sun: (S:) the pl. [of OayaApN] is OayFA↓ and UiyaMCN; [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n.;] like OakamN and UikaAmN in relation to OakamapN. (M.) Tarafeh says, (T, S, Mgh,) describing the fore teeth (vagor) of his beloved, (EM p. 62,)
[The light of the sun has shed its lustre upon them, except their gums]. (T, S, Mgh.)

And hence, by way of comparison, (M,) UiyaA AlnRabaAti, and OayaAWuhu↓, (M, K,) and UiyaAtuhu↓, and OayaAtuhu↓, (K,) (tropical:) The beauty of herbage, (M, K,) and its blossoms, (M,) and brightness, (K, TA,) in its verdure and growth. (TA.)
OayaA UiyaAhu Oaqobilo: see OayaA, in art. AyA.
OayaMC: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
OayaApN: se the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
UiyaApN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.
OuyayRapN dim. of MCN: see the letter A.
UiyayRapN dim. of MyapN, q. v. (T.)
OayRaA: see UiyRaA, in art. AyA.

UiyRaA: see art. AyA. [Az says,] I have not heard any derivation of UiyRaA; but I think, without being certain, that it is from taMyayotuhu as explained above; as though it were a noun from that verb, of the measure fiEolaI, like cikoraI from cakarotu; so that the meaning of UiyRaAka is I direct myself, or my aim, to, or towards, thee, and thy person. (T.)

OayRiIRN [a rel. n. of OaIRN]. When you ask a man respecting his kuwrap [i. e. district, or city, or town], you say, AaloOayRiIRu [The person of what district, &c., art thou?]; like as you say, in asking him respecting his qabiylap [or tribe], AalomaniIRu [from mano]: and you say also, OayRiIRN Oanota [A person of what district, &c., art thou?]; and manIRN (T.) [See also maniIRN, in art. mn.]

OayRaAna: see art. Ayn. Lth says that it is used in the manner of mataI; [signifying When?]; and that some say its n is radical; others, that it is augmentative: (T:) IJ says, it must be from OaIRN, not from Oayona, for two reasons: first, because Oayona denotes place; and OayRaAna, time: and secondly, because nouns of the measure faERaAl are few; and those of the measure faEolaAn, many: so that if you
name a man OayRaAn, it is imperfectly decl.: and he adds, that OaIRN means a part of a whole; so that it applies as properly to times as it does to other things: (TA:) Fr says that it is originally OaIRa OawaAnK [at what time?]. (T.) One says, of a stupid, or foolish, person, laA yaEorafu OayRaAna [He knows not when]. (IB.)
MIo: see OaIo:
and see also 2 in art. AwI.
IN: see what next follows, in two places.

MyapN A sign, token, or mark, by which a person or thing is known; syn. EalaAmapN (IAar, T, S, M, Msb, K) and OamaArapN: (M, K:) it properly signifies any apparent thing inseparable from a thing not equally apparent, so that when one perceives the former, he knows that he perceives the other, which he cannot perceive by itself, when the two things are of one predicament; and this is apparent in the object of sense and in that of the intellect: (Er-Rághib, TA:) it is of the measure faEolapN, (M, K,) originally OayRapN; the [former] I being changed to A because the letter before it is with fet-h, though this is an extraordinary change: (M:) this is related as on the authority of Sb: (TA:) or it is of the measure faEalapN, (M, K,) accord. to Kh; (M;) originally OawayapN; (S;) [for, accord. to J and Fei,] Sb said that its medial radical letter is w, and that the final is I, because words of this class are more common than those of which the medial and final radical letters are both I; (S, Msb;) and the rel. n. is OawawiIRu: (S:) but IB says, Sb did not state that the medial radical letter of MyapN is w, as J states; but he said that it is originally OayapN, and that the quiescent w is changed into A; and he relates of Kh, that he allowed the rel. n. of MyapN to be MYiIRN↓ and MyiIRN↓ and MwiIRN; but as to OawawiIRN, he says, I know not any one who has said it except J: (TA:) or it is of the measure faAEilapN, (S, Msb, K,) originally MyayapN, contracted by the suppression of its final radical letter [with the preceding kesreh]: so accord. to Fr: [but see what follows (after the pls.), where this is said to be the opinion of Ks, and disallowed by Fr:] (S, Msb:) the pl. is MyaAtN and MIN↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) [or the latter is rather a coll. gen. n.,] and pl. pl. MyaMCN: (M, K:) J says that one of its pls. is MyaAIN; [and we find the same also in some copies of the K;] but this is a mistake for MyaMCN, which is pl. of MIN, not of MyapN: (IB, TA:) and this pl., being of the measure OafoEaAlN, has been adduced as evidence that the medial radical letter is I, not w: (TA:) the dim. is UiyayRapN↓, [of the measure fuEaylapN changed to fEayolapN because of the medial radical I,] which, accord. to Fr, shows the opinion of Ks, that MyapN is of the measure faAEilapN rendered defective by the suppression of its final radical letter, to be incorrect, because [Fr holds, in opposition to some others, that] a noun of this measure has not its dim. formed on the measure fuEayolapN unless it is a proper name. (T.) They said, AifoEalohu biMyapi kacaA [Do thou it at the sign of such a thing]; like as you say, biEalaAmapi kacaA and biOamaArapi. (M.) And [in this sense, as is indicated by the context in the M,] it is one of the nouns that are prefixed to verbs [as virtually governing the gen. case], (M, K, *) because of the nearness of its meaning to the meaning of time: (K:) as in the saying [of a poet],
[At the sign of your urging forward the horses, unsmoothed in their coats, or not curried; which means nearly the same as “at the time of your urging” &c.]. (M.)
A sign as meaning an indication, an evidence, or a proof. (TA.)
A sign as meaning a miracle; [and a wonder; for] MyaAtu QllRehi means the wonders of God. (TA.)
An example, or a warning; (Fr, T, M, Msb, K;) as, for instance, the case of Joseph and his brethren, related in the Kur: (Fr, T:) pl. MIN↓ (M, K) and MyaAtN. (Fr, T.)
A message, or communication sent from one person or party to another; syn. risaAlapN. (TA.)
The body, or corporeal form or figure or substance, (S, M, K,) of a man, (S,) which one sees from a distance; [as being a kind of sign;] or a person, or an individual; syn. XaxoSN. (S, M, K.)
A whole company of people: as in the saying, xaraja Alqawomu biMyatihimo The people, or party, went forth with their whole company, not leaving behind them anything. (AA, S, M.)

[Hence, accord. to some, A verse of the Kur-án; as being] a collection of words of the Book of God: (S:) or a connected form of words of the Kur-án continued to its breaking off; (K, TA;) accord. to Aboo-Bekr, so called because it is a sign of the breaking off: (TA:) or a portion of the Kur-án after which a suspension of speech is approvable: (Msb:) or a portion of the Kur-án denoting any statute, or ordinance, of God, whether it be [what is generally termed] an Myap, [i. e. a verse,] or a chapter (suwrap), or an aggregate [and distinct] portion of the latter. (Er-Rághib, Kull, TA. *) [AlMyapa, written after a quotation of a part of a verse of the Kur-án, means AiqoraOi AlMyapD Read thou the verse.]
MyaA: see OayaA, in art. AyA.
MYiIRN and MyiIRN, accord. to Kh, rel. ns. of MyapN, q. v. (IB.)
taOayRapN, or taUiyRapN or taYiyRapN: see 5.

OayaA a vocative particle, (S, M, K,) used in calling him who is near and him who is distant: [in the former case, like O: in the latter, like ho there, or soho, or holla:] you say, OayaA zayodu Oaqobilo [O Zeyd, advance: or ho there, or soho, or holla, &c.]: (S:) or J is in error in saying this: it is used in calling to him who is distant: (Mughnee, K:) so say Ibn-El-Hájib, in the Káfiyeh, and ElFakhr El-Járabardee; and the latter adds, or to him who is in a predicament like that of him who is distant, being sleeping or inadvertent; the person who calls thereby being eager for the person called to advance to him: (TA:) or not used in calling to him who is near: (K:) and h is substituted for its hemzeh; (M, K;) so that one says, hayaA. (M.) AZ says, I have heard them say, OayaA UiyaAhu Oaqobilo. (T in baAbu AlOalifaAti.) [Accord. to the TA, (art. A,) one says also MyaA.]
UiyaA AlXRamosi, and AlnRabaAti; and UiyaAp, and OayaAp, and OayRaA: see art. AI.

UiyRaA (S, M, K, &c.) and OayRaA, (M, K,) the latter form used by some, as related on the authority of Ktr; (M;) accord. to some, (M,) a noun of vague signification, (S, M, K,) used metonymically for a noun in the accus. case, (M,) with which are connected all the affixed pronouns that denote the accus. case: you say UiyRaAnA [Thee] and UiyRaAhu [him] and UiyRaAIa [me] (S, K) and UiyRaAnaA [us, &c.]: (S:) and the hemzeh is changed into w, so that you say wiyRaAka (S, M, K *) and wayRaAka; (Ktr, IJ, M, K; *) and sometimes into w, so that you say wiyRaAka [and app. wayRaAka also; both of which are used by some of the Arabs in the present day, very commonly in Egypt, for waUiyRaAka as meaning maEaka; like as one says wazayodFA, meaning maEa zayodK]: (K:) the k and h and I [&c.] are put to show the object meant, in order that the person addressed may be known from the absent [&c.]; and have no place in the analysis of a sentence, like the k in celika and OaraOayotaka: (S, M: in the former of which is added, and like the A and n in Oanota:) and this is identical with the opinion of Akh: (M, TA:) thus AyRA is the noun, and what follows it is to denote allocution, [&c.,] and the two become as one thing; for nouns of vague signification are not prefixed to other nouns to govern them in the gen. case, nor are any of the pronouns, being themselves determinate. (S.) Ibn-Keysán says, (S, M,) some of the grammarians say that UiyRaAka, altogether, is a noun; and he adds, but some say (M) that the k and h &c. are the nouns, and that AyRA is a support thereto, because they cannot stand by themselves, (S, M,) like the k &c. which occupy the latter place in yaDoribuka &c.; so when the k &c. are put first, [as in UiyRaAka Darabotu Thee I beat, or struck,] they are supported by AyA, and the whole becomes as one thing: (S:) and you may also say, Darabotu UiyRaAIa [I beat, or struck, me]; because it is not allowable to say, DarabotuniI: (S as corrected by IB:) but you may not say, Darabotu UiyRaAka [I beat, or struck, thee]; because you only require AyRAk when you cannot use the k [alone]; though you may say, Darabotuka UiyRAka [I beat, or struck, thee, thee]; because the k is made to be syntactically dependent upon the verb, so when you repeat it you require AyRA. (S.) In the saying of the poet, (S,) Dhu-l-Isba' El-'Adwánee, (TA,)

[As though we, on the day of Kurrà, only killed ourselves], he has separated it from the verb only because the Arabs do not make the action of the agent to fall upon the agent itself by the adjunction of the pronoun: they do not say, qatalotuniI, but only qatalotu nafosiI: so the poet has used AyRAnA in the same manner as OanofusanaA. (S, TA.) Some of the grammarians say that UiyRaA is prefixed to what follows it, governing it in the gen. case; and adduce as an evidence thereof a saying which see below, commencing with UicaA balaga AlrRajulu. (S.)
Zj says that it is an explicit noun, [not a pronoun,] which is prefixed to all the pronouns, governing them in the gen. case; but only to pronouns; so that if one said, UiyRaA zayodK HadRavotu, it would be bad. (M.) Kh holds that it is a pronoun prefixed to the k [&c.], governing it in the gen. case; (M, K;) and the like is related to have been the opinion of El-Mázinee: and Sb relates of Kh that he said, if any one were to say UiyRaAka nafosaka [Thee, thyself], I would not severely blame him, for this k is [virtually] governed in the gen. case. (M.) But accord. to Akh, it is a simple, or uncompounded, pronoun, the ending of which becomes altered, as the endings of pronouns are wont to become, because of the varying of the numbers of the persons using them; (M, K; [in both of which the last of the word thus rendered is AlmDmryn; accord. to a copy of the M, AlmDmryn, i. e. AlmuDomiryna; in a copy of the K, without any syll. signs; and in the CK, AlmuDomarayoni; of which readings, I have followed that found in the M; supposing the meaning to be, that AyRA has different endings according as it is used by one speaking to another, or by one speaking of another, or by one speaking of himself, or to, or of, two or more, and the like;]) and the k of AyRaAk is like the k of celika, inasmuch as it is an indication of allocution only, divested of the idea of its being a sign of the pronoun. (M.) Of all these varying opinions, IJ says that he has found none to be correct when investigated, except that of Akh; with whose opinion, that stated in the begining of this art. is identical [except as to the affix, which is there said to be a pronoun, not merely a particle of allocution]. (M, TA.) Zj, being asked to explain the meaning of the phrase UiyRaAka naEobudu, [in the Kur i. 4,] answered, Haqiytataka naEobudu [Thine essence we worship]; and said that it is derived from MyapN, meaning “a sign by which a thing is known:” but IJ does not approve of this. (M.) [Respecting the phrase, faUicaA huwa UiyRaAhaA, in which AyRAhA is used in the place of a noun in the nom. case, and which is therefore disallowed by Sb, see UicaA.]

It is also used for the purpose of cautioning, or putting one on his guard. (T, S.) You say, UiyRaAka waAlOasada [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, the lion]: it is a substitute for a verb; as thou you said, baAEido: and you say also, hiyRaAka; like as you say OaraAqa and haraAqa: (S:) [or AyRAk in this case is governed by a verb understood: for] Ibn-Keysán says, when you say, UiyRaAka wazayodFA [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, or remove thyself far from, Zeyd], you caution him whom you address against Zeyd, and the verb governing the accus. case is not apparent: the meaning is, OuHacRiruka zayodFA [I caution thee against Zeyd]; as though you said, OuHacRiruka UiyRaAka wazayodFA [I caution thee, thee with Zeyd]; or as though you said, baAEido nafosaka Eano zayodK wabaAEid zayodFA Eanoka [Remove thyself far from Zeyd, and remove Zeyd far from thee]; so that the verb governs the word signifying the person cautioned and that signifying him against whom that person is cautioned: (TA:) [and Az says,] when you say, UiyRaAka warukuwba AlfaAHiXapi, the verb is suppressed: it is as though you said, OuHacRiruka rukuwba AlfaAHiXapi [I caution thee against the committing of that which exceeds the bounds of rectitude]. (T.) Kh is related to have heard an Arab of the desert say, (T, * M, the latter on the authority of Sb.,) UicaAbalaga AlrRajulu AlsRitRiyna faUyRaAhu waUiyRaA AlXRawAbR [When the man attains to sixty years, I caution him against, or let him avoid, the young women]; (T, S, M;) prefixing AyRA to AlXwAbR, and putting the latter in the gen. case: (S:) but accord. to Akh, it is not allowable to say [thus, or] UiyRaAka waUiyRaA zayodK. (M.) Sometimes the w is suppressed, as in the saying of the poet,

[Then avoid thou, avoid thou obstinate disputation, for it is wont to invite to evil, and an attracter of evil]; meaning, UiyRaAka waAlmiraMCa: i. e., UiyRaAka waOano tumaAriya. (TA.) You say [properly], UiyRaAka waOano tafoEala kacaA [Beware thou of, or avoid thou, doing such a thing]: but [in strict propriety] you should not say, UiyRaAka Oano tafoEala kacaA, without w. (S.) See also art. Ay.
OayaAyaA (Lth, T, S, M, K) and OayaAyaho, (M,) or yaAyaA, (K,) and yaAyaho, (M, K,) A cry by which camels are chidden. (Lth, T, S, M, K.) [See 2 in art. Ay.]

dictScrap.label: Ayb: For words which might be supposed to be properly mentioned under this head, see art. AwRb.

sense.s: 1. Mda, aor. yaYiydu, inf. n. OayodN, He, (a man, AZ, T, &c.,) or it, (a thing, L,) was, or became, strong: (AZ, T, S, M, K, &c.:) and Myd↓, inf. n. UiyaAdN, he became possessed of strength. (AHeyth, T, L.)
MdatN DiyaAfatuhu (tropical:) His coming as a guest was, or became, frequent. (A.) [See OayRidN.]

2. OyRd, inf. n. taOoyiydN; (T, S, M, &c.;) and Myd↓, (T, S, K,) of the measure faAEala, (S,) inf. n. muWaAyadapN; (K;) or He strengthened: (S, M, L, Msb, K:) he aided, or rendered victorious. (L.) You say, OyRdhu EalaI AlOamori He strengthened him to accomplish the affair. (M, L.)
3: see 2.
4: see 1.
5. tOyRd He, or it, (a thing, S,) became strengthened. (T, S, K.)
MdN Strength; syn. SulobN, (M, L, K,) and quwRapN [which is one of the significations of SulobN, and that which is here meant]; as also OayodN↓ [which is an inf. n.: see 1]. (S, M, K.)
OayodN: see MdN.
OayRidN Strong: (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K:) an epithet applied [to God, and] to a man. (S.) A poet says,

[lit. When a strong one strings the bow, he shoots, and hits the kidneys, and the tops of the humps of the camels]; meaning, when God strings [or stretches] the bow that is in the clouds, He casts fat into the kidneys and humps of the camels, by means of the herbage that is produced by the rain. (S.)
UinRahu laOayRidu AlgadaMCi waAlEaXaMCi means (tropical:) Verily he is often present at the morning and evening meals. (A.)

UiyaAdN Anything by which a person or thing is strengthened, (M, L, K,) or guarded, defended, or protected: (T, L:) a thing by which one is protected, or veiled, or concealed: the side; shade, or shadow; or protection: a place of refuge: (M, L, K:) either side of anything, that strengthens it: (Lth, T:) anything that is in the vicinity of a thing: (T:) each wing of an army: (S, M, L, K:) earth that is put round a watering-trough or tank, or round a tent, (S, M, L, K,) to strengthen it, or to keep away from it the rain-water: (S, L:) any fortification: a fortified mountain: (M, L, K:) a mountain that is inaccessible, or difficult of access. (IAar, T.) [In the place of one signification, Golius gives “ cortex; ” having found lHAh in the place of lajaO.]
An elevated tract, or a heap, of sand. (M, K.)
Abundance of camels [because they strengthen their owner]. (K.)
The air; syn. hawaMC. (K.)
muWoyadN: see muWayRadN:
and see what next follows.

muWoyidN, of the same measure as muWominN, A great, mighty, or severe, thing; (S, L, K;) a calamity: (T, S, M, L, K:) or, accord. to As, it is muWoyadN↓, with fet-h to the I, and signifies anything rendered strong, or hard, or severe. (L.) [See maMwidu, in art. Awd.)
muWayRadN and muWoyadN↓ (the latter irreg., by rule being muWaAyadN, TK,) Strengthened: (S, L, K:) aided; or rendered victorious: (L:) and the former, strong, applied to a building. (M.)
muWayRidN Strengthening: (S, L:) aiding; or rendering victorious. (L.) The dim. also has this form. (S.)
1. MrahaA, aor. yaYiyru, (T, S, and K in art. Awr,) inf. n. OayorN; (T, TA;) or MrahaA, aor. yaWuwru; (ISk, T;) or both; (K ubi suprà;) Inivit eam; he compressed her. (ISk, T, S, K.)
OayorN The membrum virile; penis; veretrum: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] MyurN and MyaArN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] OuyuwrN (S, K) and OuyurN. (L.)
kaAna Oayoruhu TawylFA is a phrase meaning (tropical:) He had many male children. (T, TA.)
OuyaAriIRN Having a large membrum virile, or penis; (T, S, M, K;) like OunaAfiIRN signifying “ having a large nose. ” (T.)
OayRaAru The [Syrian] month [corresponding to May, O. S.;] preceding HaziyraAnu, or (as written by Saadee Efendee, TA) HuzayoraAnu. (So in different copies of the K.)
MYirN Iniens. (T, S, TA.)
maYiyrN pass. part. n. of 1, (T, S, TA,) of the same measure as maSiyrN; i. q. manoyuwkN. (TA.)
miYoyarN (K, TA, [in the CK maYiyr, and in Gol. Lex. miYoyarN,]) Qui multum coit. (K.)

1. Oayisa minohu, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. yaOoyasu (S, Msb, K) and yaOoyisu, (Msb,) inf. n. OayasN, (Msb,) or UiyaAsN, (K,) or it has the same inf. n. as yaYisa, namely yaOosN, (S,) with which UiyaAsN↓ is syn., (Mgh,) but this last is a contraction of UiyMsN, of the measure UiyEaAsN, as determined by Az, and is not an inf. n. of Oayisa as some think it to be, (Mgh, art. yYis,) He despaired of it; syn. qniT: (K:) a dial. var. of yaYisa: (ISk, S, TA:) or it is not so, but is formed by transposition from yaYisa, because it has no [proper] inf. n.; and UiyaAsN, the proper name of a man, is not to be adduced in evidence, for it is of the measure fiEaAlN from AlOawosu, “ the act of giving: ” (Preface to the M, quoted in the TA:) if it were a dial. var. of yaYisa, they would say Uisotu for Oayisotu: (M, TA:) and Ouyisa, incorrectly written Ouwysa, also signifies the same. (Mgh.)
Oayosa: see layosa.
2: see 4.
4. Myasahu He made him to despair; (K;) like OayoOasahu; (S, Mgh;) and so OyRshu↓, (S * K,) inf. n. taOoyiysN. (S.)
OayisN and MyisN↓ [Despairing]; part. ns. of Oayisa. (Msb.)
[Hence,] MyisapN [and accord. to Golius OayosaMCu↓, both properly meaning Despairing of the recurrence of the menstrual flux;] who has not menstruated in a period of five and fifty years. (KT.)
OayosaMWu: see OayisN.
UiyaAsN: see 1.
MyisN: see OayisN.
OayoXa, for OaIRu XaIoCK: see OaIRN, in art. AI.

1. MDa, aor. yaYiyDu, inf. n. OayoDN, i. q. EaAda; (ISk, S, M, Msb, * K;) as in the phrase MDa UilaI AlXRaIoCi [He returned to the thing, i. e. to the doing of the thing; he did the thing again, or a second time]. (K.)
And i. q. rajaEa; (S, M, Msb, K;) as in the phrase MDa UilaI Oaholihi [He returned to his family]. (S, M.)

In the phrase faEalotu kacaA OayoDFA↓, the last word is the inf. n. of MDa in the sense of EaAda, (ISK, IDrd, S, M, Msb, *) and in the sense of rajaEa: (IDrd, M:) and the meaning is, [I did such a thing again, or a second time;] I returned to the doing of such a thing: (IDrd, M:) or I did such a thing returning to what had preceded. (Msb, K. *) [It also, and more commonly, signifies I did such a thing also.] When one says, faEalotu celika OayoDFA↓ [I did that again, &c.], you say, qado Oakoyarota mino OayoDK↓ [Thou hast made much use of the expression OayoDFA], and daEoniI mino OayoDK↓ [Let me alone and cease from using the expression OayoDFA]. (ISk, S.)

OayoDN also signifies (tropical:) A thing's becoming another, or a different, thing; and being changed from its state or condition [to another and a different state or condition]: (Lth, K: *) so says Kh. (Ham p. 356.) And MDa kacaA (tropical:) He, or it, became such a thing. (Lth, S, M, * K.) You say, MDa sawaAdu XaEarihi bayaADFA (A, TA) (tropical:) The blackness of his hair became whiteness. (TA.) And Zuheyr says, speaking of a land which he traversed,
[I traversed, when the mirage, or the mirage of the morning, became as though it were swords which were removed a while, then met]. (S.)
OayoDN and OayoDFA: see above, in four places.

1. Oayika AlOaraAku, aor.
Aayaka
, The [trees called] ArAk became what is termed Oayokap [n. un. of OayokN, q. v.]; as also AstOyk↓. (K.) The former occurs in poetry contracted into Oayoka. (ISd, Sgh.)

OayokN Numerous, luxuriant or tangled or dense, trees: (S, K:) or a place where water collects and sinks into the ground (gayoDapN) producing [trees of the kinds called] sidor and OaraAk (Lth, K) and similar soft trees: (Lth:) or a collection of any trees; even, of palm-trees: (K:) or, as some say, a place where [trees of the kind called] Oavol grow, and where is a collection of them: or, accord. to AHn, an abundant collection of OaraAk in one place: (TA:) or trees; said to be of the [kind called] OaraAk: (Msb:) n. un. with p: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) IAar says, [you say,] OayokapN OavolK and rahoTN, and qaSiymapN. (Sh.) OaSoHaAbu QloOayokapi occurs in the Kur in four chapters: [xv. 78 and xxvi. 176 and xxxviii. 12 and 1.13:] (Sgh:) he who reads thus means, by the latter word, AlgayoDap [explained above, and also signifying the thicket, or collection of tangled trees, &c.]; (S, K;) or the tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense, trees: (TA:) another reading is layokapa; accord. to which, this is the name of the town [in which the people here mentioned dwelt]: (S, K:) or, as some say, the two words are [applied to the same place,] like bakRapu and makRapu: (S:) but Zj says that another reading is allowable, and very good; i. e. OaSoHaAbu layokapi, as being originally AlOyokapi; for the Arabs say, AalaHomaru qado jaMCaniI and laHomaru jaMUaniI for AlOaHomaru; so that layokap is like laHomar. (TA.)

OayokN OayikN, (K, TA,) like katifo, (TA, [agreeably with the verb, but in the CK AeyikN,]) is a phrase in which the latter word signifies muvomirN [Putting forth fruit; &c.]: (K, TA:) or, as some say, it is an intensive epithet [signifying very abundant or luxuriant or tangled &c.]. (M, TA.)

Uiylu a name of God; (Lth, T, S, M, K;) a Hebrew word; (Lth, S;) or Syriac: (S:) it is a dial. var. of UilRu [q. v.]: or the latter may be an arabicized form of the former: (Az, TA:) Ibn-El-Kelbee says that jaboraYiylu and miykaAYiylu and the like are similar to Eabodu QllRehi and Eaboda AlrRaHomaAni; (M;) [and J says,] they are like Eabodu QllRehi and tayomu QllRehi: (S:) so that jabor signifies “ servant, ” and is prefixed to Ayl, governing it in the gen. case: (M:) but this is not a valid assertion; for were it so, such names would be perfectly decl.: (M in art. Al:) Suh says, in the R, that jibrYyl is Syriac, and means Eabodu AlrRaHomaAni, or Eabodu AlEziyzi, as is related on the anthority of I'Ab: that most persons hold Ayl in this case to be a name of God: but that some hold names of this kind to be constructed inversely, after the manner of the language of the 'Ajam; Ayl meaning servant. (TA. [See what is said of UilRu.])
UiylapN: see art. Awl.
Oayoluwlu [written by some Uiyluwlu] One of the Greek [or Syrian] months; (T, * M, Kzw;) the last thereof [corresponding with September, O. S.]. (Kzw.)
UiyaAlN: see art. UiyaAlapN.

1. Mmato, (T, M, Mgh, K,) aor. taYiymu, (T, K,) inf. n. OayomapN, (T, M, Mgh, K,) or this is a simple subst., (Msb,) and UiymapN and OayomN and OuyuwmN, (M, K,) She had no husband; said of a virgin and of one who is not a virgin; (IAar, T, M, Mgh, K;) as also tOyRmt↓ (Lth, T, M) and AYtAmt↓: (M:) or, as some say, tOyRmt↓ signifies she lost her husband by his death, she being still fit for husbands, having in her a remaining force of youth: (T:) and you say, Mmato mino zawojihaA, aor. taYiymu, inf. n. OayomapN and OayomN and OuyuwmN, (S, TA, [accord. to the former app. signifying the same as Mmato alone as explained above: or]) meaning she became bereft of her husband by his death, or by his being slain, and remained without marrying. (TA.) And Mma, (T, S, Msb,) aor. yaYiymu, (T, Msb,) inf. n. OayomapN, (T,) He had no wife: (T, Msb:) or he lost his wife by her death: (S, * K, * and Ham p. 650:) and he did not marry; as also tOyRm↓. (Ham ubi suprà.) It is said of the Prophet, in a trad., kaAna yataEawRacu mina AlOayomapi (T, S) He used to pray for preservation from remaining long without a wife. (T.) And Yezeed Ibn-El-Hakam Eth-Thakafee says,

L.foreign: kulRu QmoriICK sataYiymu minohu AlEirosu OawominohaA yaYiymu

sense.s:
(S) i. e. Every man, the wife will be bereft of him by his death, or he will be bereft of her by her death. (Ham p. 531.) One says also,
maA lahu Mma waEaAma, meaning [What aileth him?] May his wife and his cattle die, or perish, so that he shall have no wife (HatRaI yaYyima) and be vehemently desirous of milk (yaEiyma). (S, K: [in the CK, erroneously, AmN w EAmN; and in a MS. copy of the K MmN wlAEAmN.])

2. OayRamahu QllRehu inf. n. taOoyiymN, God made him to have no wife. (K, * TK.) And OayRamotu AlmaroOapa, inf. n. as above; (Ham p. 11, and TA; *) or OaOa motuhaA↓, like OaEamotuhaA; (T, S;) I made the woman to be a widow, by slaying her husband. (T, * S, and Ham ubi suprà.) Taäbata-sharrà says,
[And I have made women widows, by slaying their husbands; and children fatherless]. (TA.)
4. OaOamotu AlmaroOapa: see 2.

5. taOayRamato tOyRm: see 1, in three places. The former is also explained as signifying She became forlorn (taHawRaXato) of her husband. (K in art. HwX.) And also, (TA,) or taOayRamato zamaAnFA, (ISk, T, S,) She remained some time without marrying. (ISk, T, S, TA.) And tOyRm, (Msb, K,) or tOyRm zamaAnFA, (ISk, T, S,) He remained some time without marrying. (ISk, T, S Msb, K.)
8. QYotaAmato, written with the disjunctive alif AiytaAmato: see 1.
QYotamotuhaA, (M, K,) like QEotamotuhaA, (TA,) I took her as my wife, she being what is termed OayRim [without a husband]. (M, K.)
Oayoma is a contraction of OaIRu maA, meaning OaIRu XaIoCK: it is thus in the saying, Oayoma huwayaA fulaAnu [What thing is it, O such a one?]: and Oayoma taquwlu [What thing sayest thou?]. (TA.)
Aayomu QllRehi [for Aayomunu QllRehi]: see in art. ymn. (K.)
OayamRu, for OaOamRu: see art. Am.
OayomaA: see OamRaA:
and UimRaA.
UymaA: see UimRaA.

OayomaAnu A man whose wife has died: and OayomaI A woman whose husband has died: pl. OayaAmaI, of both; like as sakaAray is pl. of sakoraAnu: accord. to ISk, OayaAmaI is originally OayaAYimu. (Msb.) [See also OayRimN.] OayomaAnu EayomaAnu are epithets applied to a man, (M, K, TA,) meaning Whose wife [and cattle] have died or perished [so that he has no wife and is vehemently desirous of milk; as shown above; see 1, last signification]: (TA:) the former relates to wives; and the latter, to milk: (S, K, TA:) fem. OayomaI EayomaI, applied to a woman. (M, K.)
