OayRimN A woman having no husband; (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether she be a virgin or not; (IAar, T, S, M, Mgh, K;) or whether she have married before or not; (Sgh, Msb;) as also OayRimapN; (Msb;) [said to be] applied to one who has not married: (IAar, T:) or if not a virgin; accord. to [the Imám] Mohammad; agreeably with a reading of a trad. by which the OayRim is distinguished from the virgin: (Mgh:) also, the former, a man having no wife; (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) whether he have married before or not: (S, Sgh, K:) or who has not married: (IAar, T:) pl. OayaAmaI (S, M, K) and OayaAYimu; (M, K;) the latter of which is the original form: (S, M:) [or both, accord. to the Msb, are pls. of OayomaAnu, q. v.:] and OayRimuwna is a pl. applied to men, and OayRimaAtN applied to women: and MmapN, also, signifying men having no wives, is pl. of MYimN↓ for OayRimN. (TA.)
Also A free woman: (K:) pl., in this sense also, OayaAmaI, used in this sense in the Kur xxiv. 32, (T, TA,) accord. to some. (TA.)
And A female relation; (K;) in which sense also OayaAmaI is pl.; (T, TA;) meaning such as the daughter and the sister and the maternal aunt. (T, K.)
MYimN: see OayRimN.
AlHarobu maOoyamapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) lilnRisMCa (M, K) War is a cause of widowing to women; it slays the men, and leaves the wives without husbands. (T, S, M, Msb.)
muWoyamapN A rich, or wealthy, woman, or one possessing competence or sufficiency, having no husband. (Sgh, K.)
maMYimu: see MmRapN, in art. Am.

1. Mna, [aor. yaYiynu,] inf. n. OayonN, [in a copy of the Msb, Oayina, aor. yaACanu, inf. n. OayanN, but as this is at variance with all other authorities known to me, I regard it as a mistranscription,] He was, or became, fatigued, or tired: (T, M:) so says IAar: (T:) and As says the like: (TA, from a marginal note in a copy of the S:) [see also what I have cited from the Mughnee voce UinRa, last sentence:] in proof of this, IAar cites the following ex., from a poet:

[We were, or have become, fatigued, by the Lord of the lean and lank-bellied youthful she-camels]: but Lth says that there is no verb derived from OayonN, in this sense, except in poetry: (T:) Aboo-Mohammad says that the only instance is that cited above: (TA:) [it is not disputed that] OayonN signifies fatigue, or the being fatigued or tired: (S, K:) AZ says that it has no verb formed from it; but on this point he has been contradicted: (S:) A 'Obeyd also says that it has no verb. (M.)

Mna, aor. yaYiynu, inf. n. OayonN, (S, M, Msb, K, &c., [but see what follows,]) also signifies Its time came; (OataI waqotuhu;) as also OanaI: (Bd lvii. 15:) it was, or became, present: it came, or attained, to its time; to its full, or final, time, or state; to maturity: it was, or became, or drew, near: syn. OanaI: (M:) and Oadoraka; like OanaI: (Ham p. 455:) and HaAna: (S, M, Msb, K:) and qaruba. (Mughnee voce UinRa.) You say, Mna laka Oano tafoEala kacaA, aor. and inf. n. as above, (AZ, S,) i. e. HaAna [The time has come, or has drawn near, for thee to do, or that thou shouldst do, such a thing]; like OanaI: and it is formed from it by transposition: (S:) [i. e.] OanaI is formed by transposition from Mna: (Msb:) or Mna is a dial. var. of OanaI; not formed from it by transposition, [nor is the reverse the case,] because of the existence of the inf. n. [of each]: (M:) or Mna is formed by transposition from OanaI, because the latter has an inf. n. and the former has not: so says As: for OayonN does not belong to this; its meaning being only UiEoyaMCN and taEabN: or, accord. to AZ, Mna has an inf. n., namely OayonN; and if the case be so, the two [verbs] are equal; neither being the original of the other: (IJ in the Khasáïs:) Suh, in the R, asserts that Mna is formed by transposition from OanaI: (TA:) the assertion of El-Bekree, that Mna is originally with w [for its medial radical letter], and that it is of the class of waliIa, aor. yaliI, requires consideration, and involves what is contrary to rule. (MF.) You say also, Mna Oayonuka, (S, M, K,) and Uiynuka, (M, K,) and Mnuka, (S, K,) i. e. HaAna Hiynuka [Thy time, or season, came, or hath come: or drew near, or hath drawn near]. (S, M, K.)
MnN: see OayonN.

QloMna is a noun denoting the present time; (S, M, Msb, K;) [signifying At the present time; now; for] it is an adverbial noun; (S, Msb, K;) one which, in a place where it is fitting to be used as such, may not be used otherwise; occurring in a determinate sense; (S, K;) the Al being inseparable from it; (IJ, M, Msb;) not prefixed to it for the purpose of rendering it determinate, because it has not that which participates in its meaning: (S, Msb, K:) as Ibn-Es-Sarráj says, there is not one Mn and another Mn: (Msb:) [accord. to ISd, who quotes a long disquisition by IJ on this word,] the Al which is expressed in this case is redundant, because the noun is determinate without it, but it is rendered so by another Al, which is understood, as in the case of Oamosi: so says IJ, following Aboo-'Alee; and his is the correct opinion: (M:) Fr says that it is a particle, compounded with Al, which is inseparable from it; and that it is originally OawaAna [or QloOawaAna]: or that it may have originated from the phrase Mna laka Oano tafoEala [explained above], and is therefore mansoob, like qiyla and qaAla when used as nouns: but Zj disallows its originating from Mna; and says that the right opinion is that of Kh, that QloMna is indecl. with fet-h for its termination, and that the Al is prefixed because the meaning is hecaA Alwaqot; and this is the opinion of Sb. (T.) You say, OanaA QloMna OafoEalu kacaA [I, at the present time, or now, do, or will do, thus, or such a thing]. (M.) And kunotu QloMna Einodahu, meaning I was, in this time, of which part is present and some portions have passed, with him, or in his presence. (IJ, M.) And when you mean the kind of expression which is used in this saying, you say, AaloMnu HadRu AlzRamaAnayoni [The term “ now ” is the limit of the two times; namely the past and the future]; thus pronounced, marfooa: so says IJ: but in the Book of Sb we read, AlMna HadRu AlzRamaAnayoni, with nasb: and in like manner, in the same, AlMna Mnuka [Now is thy time]; the former with nasb and the
latter with refa. (M.) You say also, hecaA OawaAnu QloMna [This is the present time]: and maA jiYotu UilRaA OawaAna QloMna, meaning I came not save at the present time, or now: with the last word mansoob in both instances. (ISh, T.) [And UilaI QloMna and HatRaI QloMna To the present time and until the present time; i. e. hitherto. And mina QloMna From the present time; henceforward.] Sometimes the hemzeh [after the l] is suppressed, and its vowel is transferred to the l; so that you say AlaAna. (Bd ii. 66.) And sometimes also the l is pronounced with fet-h and both the hemzehs are suppressed; so that you say laAna. (S, K.) And sometimes ta is prefixed to it, like as it is to Hiyna; so that you say talaAna, like as you say taHiyna. (El-Umawee, A 'Obeyd. [See art. tln.])

OayonN Fatigue. (S, K, &c.) [Whether it be a simple subst., or an inf. n., and, if the latter, whether it be an inf. n. of Mna only in the former of the two senses assigned to that verb above, or in both these senses, is doubted: see 1, throughout.]
A time; a season; syn. HiynN; (S, M, K;) as also UiynN↓ (M, K) and MnN↓. (S, K.) [See 1, last sentence.]

Oayona is an adverbial noun, (Msb,) an interrogative respecting a place: (S, M, Msb, K:) [signifying Where? in what place?]: Zj says that it is an interrogative particle, like kayofa: (T:) [ISd says,] it is a noun, because you say, mino Oayona [meaning From what place? whence?]: (M:) [and you say also, UilaI Oayona To what place? whither?]: it is always mansoob, unless you prefix the article to it, saying AlOayonu [which means The place where]: (Lth, T:) it is fem.; but may be made masc. (Lh, M.) You say, Oayona zayodN Where, or in what place, is Zeyd? (S, Msb.) And Oayona bayotuka [Where is thy house, or tent?]. (M.) And Oayona yucohabu bika, which may mean Where, or whither, wilt thou be taken away, and what will be done with thee and made to come to pass with thee, if this be thine intellect? or, accord. to Mtr, it is a saying of the people of Baghdád, addressed to him whom they charge with foolish judgment or opinion, as meaning Oayona yucohabu biEaqolika [Where, or whither, is thine intellect taken away?]. (Har p. 574.) [And Oayona hecaA mino caAka and Eano caAka and wa caAka What place does this hold in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what is this in relation to that, or in comparison with that? what has this to do with that? what has this in common with that?]

It also denotes a condition: when you say, Oayona tajoliso Oajoliso [Where thou sittest, I will sit], the sitting must be in one place: and maA is added to it; so that you say, OayonamaA taqumo Oaqumo [Wherever thou standest, I will stand]. (Msb.)

It also occurs used as a proper name of a particular place: thus the poet Homeyd Ibn-Thowr speaks of his companions as being biOayona wa OayonamaA [app. meaning In certain places: where and wherever those places were, there were my companions]: in which case it is divested of the meaning of an interrogative, and is imperfectly decl. because determinate and of the fem. gender. (M, L. [In one copy of the former, biOanRaI wa OayonamaA, which may mean the same; and voce OaIRN, q. v., biOaIRa wa OayonamaA.])
UiynN: see OayonN.

OayRaAna, (T, S, M, &c.,) of the measure faERaAl, or it may be of the measure faEolaAn, (Msb,) also pronounced UiyRaAna↓, (T, S, M, K,) the latter of the dial. of Suleym, mentioned by Fr, (T, S,) and by Zj, (M,) is an interrogative respecting a time, (T, S, Msb,) but only respecting a time not come: (T:) signifying When? (S, M, Msb;) at what time? (Msb, K:) it is fem.; but may be made masc.: (Lh, M:) and it may be pronounced with imáleh, though not belonging to a class of words regularly subject to imáleh. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [xvi. 22 and xxvii. 67], accord. to different readings, OayRaAna yuboEavuwna or UiyRaAni↓ [When they shall be raised to life]; (T, S, M;) i. e. when shall be the resurrection. (Aboo-Is-hák, T.) But you may not say, OayRaAna faEalota caAka as meaning When didst thou that? (T.)

IJ says that, were it syn. with mataI, it would be conditional; whereas it was not mentioned by his colleagues among the adverbs used conditionally, as mataI and Oayona &c.: but sometimes it has a conditional meaning, though that meaning be not explicit. (M.) A poet says,

L.foreign: OayRaAna nuWominoka taOomano gayoranaA wa UicaA
lamo tudoriki AlOamona minRaA lamo tazalo HaciraA

sense.s: [When we grant thee security, thou wilt be secure from others than us; and when thou obtainest not security from us, thou wilt not cease to be in a state of fear]. (I 'Ak p. 300.)
UiyRaAna: see OayRaAna, in two places.
MYinN part. n. of Mna in both its senses. MyinapN: see OawaAnN.

2. AyRh bihaA, (S, TA,) and, accord. to some, bihimo (TA,) and bihi, (K, * TA,) inf. n. taOoyiyhN, (S, K,) He cried out to, or shouted to, and called, (S, K, TA,) them, namely, camels, (S, TA,) and, accord. to some, horses, and men, (TA,) and him, (K, TA,) namely, a camel: (TA:) or AyRh bh signifies he said to him, namely, a man, and a horse, yaA wayohaAho [Ho! On!]: (A 'Obeyd:) and he said to him, namely, a man, yaA OayRuhaA AlrRajulu [O thou man]: (K:) or he called him, yA AyRhA Alrjl: (IAth:) and he cried out to him, or at him; or drove him away with crying or a cry; namely, an object of the chase. (TA.)
[Oayoha would seem to be a dial. var. of wayoha; for it is said that] Oayohaka is syn. with wayohaka. (K: [but see wayoha.])
OayohFA: see OayohaAta.
Uiyho, with the h quiescent, is a word used in chiding, or checking; meaning Hasobuka [Sufficient for thee is such a thing; &c.]. (ISd, K.)

UiyhFA signifies, (S, K,) as also Ayha, (K,) a command to be silent, (S, K,) and to abstain; (S, TA;) i. e. Be silent; and abstain, or desist: (TA:) both are used in chiding, or checking: and hiyha is used in the place of Uiyha. (Lth, TA.) You say [also,] UiyhFA EanRaA Be silent, and abstain from [troubling] us. (S, TA.) And UiyhaA EanRiI QloMna Abstain thou from [Troubling] me now. (AZ, TA.)
UiyhFA also occurs as meaning I hold that to be true, and approve it. (IAth, TA.)

Uiyhi, as also Uiyha and UiyhK, is a word denoting a desire, or demand, for one to add, or to give, or do, more; (Lth, K;) and a desire for one to speak: (K:) it (i. e. Uiyhi) is an imperative verbal noun, (S,) indecl., with kesr for its termination: (K:) you say to a man, when you desire, or demand, his telling or saying more of a [certain] story or subject of discourse, or his doing more of a [certain] deed, Uiyhi, with kesr. to the h; (S;) [i. e. Tell me, or say, more of this; say on; go on, or proceed, with this; or do more of this;] and QfoEalo Uiyhi [Go on, or proceed, with this; do it]; (AZ;) and for Uiyhi, you say, hiyhi: (Lth:) but when you make no interruption after it, you pronounce it with tenween, (ISk, S, K,) and say UiyhK, (ISk, S,) which means HadRivonaA [i. e. Tell us, or relate to us, something]; (Ks, Lh, (ISk, * S; *) and for this one says hiyhK, by substitution of one letter for another: (Ks, Lh:) or it means zido [i. e. tell, or say, or do, something more]; and haAti [i. e. give, or relate, something]; (Har p. 592;) and takalRama [i. e. speak]. (Idem p. 419.) In the following saying of Dhu-r-Rummeh,

L.foreign: waqafonaA wa qulonaA Uiyhi Eano OumRi saAlimK
wa maA baAlu takoliymi AldRiyaAri AlbalaAqiEi

sense.s: [We stopped, and we said, Tell us some tidings: inform us (OaxobiriynaA being app. understood) respecting Umm-Sálim: but what is the case (meaning what is the use) of speaking to the vacant dwellings?], he has used the word without tenween, though making no interruption after it, because he intended a pause. (ISk, S.) Ibn-Es-Seree says, When you say, Uiyhi yaA rajulu, you only command him to tell you more of the subject of discourse known to you and him, as though you said, haAti AlHadiyva [Give, or relate, the story, or narrative, O man]: but if you say, UiyhK, with tenween, it is as though you said, haAti HadiyvFA mRaA [Give, or relate, some story or narrative], because the tenween renders indeterminate: and Dhu-rRummeh meant the tenween, but omitted it through necessity. (S.) As says that Dhu-rRummeh has committed a mistake; the expression of the Arabs being only UiyhK [in a case of this kind]: ISd says, the truth is, that it is without tenween when determinate, and with tenween when indeterminate; and that Dhu-r-Rummeh asks the ruins to tell him more of a known story, as though he said, Relate to us the story, or tell us the tidings: (TA:) Aboo-Bekr Ibn-Es-Sarráj says, citing this verse, that Ayh is not known in a case of this kind without tenween in any of the dialects; meaning that it is never conjoined with a following word unless it be with tenween. (IB, TA.)
OayohaA: see what next follows.

OayohaAta i. q. hayohaAta [Far, or far from being believed or from the truth, is such a thing: or remoteness, or remoteness from being believed or from the truth, is to be attributed to such a thing.]: as also OayohaAni↓, (S, K,) and OayohaAna↓, (K, TA, in the CK AayohaAnu,) [and several other dial. vars., for which see hayohaAta,] and OayohaA↓, (TA; and so in some copies of the S and K; in other copies of these, OayohFA↓; [but the former is app. the right;]) with the n [or the t] suppressed, (TA,) which is said in pronouncing [a thing] to be remote [whether in a proper or a tropical sense]: (S, TA:) Th explains OayohaAni↓ as meaning baEiydN celika AA explains it as meaning baEuda celika, making it a verbal noun; and this is the correct explanation: (TA:) or the meaning is AlbuEodu, [as I have indicated above,] (K in art. hyh,) but this is only when li is prefixed to what follows it, as Sb says. (TA. [See hayohaAta.])
OayohaAna and OayohaAni: see OayohaAta, in three places.
OayRihN Having a strong, or loud, voice; and vigilant, or wary. (Ham p. 675.)
OayRuhaA: see OaIRN; last portion of the paragraph.
